TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Yesterday, Senator O'Chee addressed a question to me about the televising of Question Time. Senator O'Chee referred specifically to the ending of television broadcasts before Question Time had finished. Orders of the Senate, agreed to on 31 May 1990, authorised the televising of Question Time by the ABC. It should be noted that the ABC is not compelled to televise the proceedings of the Senate. The television broadcasts of Question Time in the Senate and the House of Representatives, and the duration of those broadcasts, are a matter for the ABC. —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: ANU and CSIRO: Fellowships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1.Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Practices Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned request that Sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act be repealed without delay.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAX LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FRINGE BENEFITS TAX MEASURES) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two Bills, the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill 1992. The first of those two Bills, the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill, proposes to give legislative effect to the Government's personal income tax cuts announced in the 26 February economic statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the so-called One Nation statement, which in effect has disappeared without trace since that time. There are some relics of that statement still around, and this Bill reflects one of them.

PARA.TAB: The second Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill, will increase the taxable value of fringe benefits by the value of tax payable, plus allowing a deduction for any fringe benefits tax payable. My comments today will be directed mainly towards the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill. I am sure my colleagues will have more to say, not only on that but also on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill.

The Tax Legislation Amendment Bill provides new personal income tax scales for 1994-95, 1995-96, 1996-97 and subsequent years as proposed by the Government in its One Nation statement in February, and subsequently reaffirmed in the Budget and now in this Bill. The one thing to say at the very outset about these proposals of the Government is that in essence they are irrelevant, for two reasons. Firstly, there is no way that the Government will be able to deliver the tax cuts proposed in this Bill in the unlikely event that it is re-elected to govern again. The proposals are arguably the most irresponsible set of proposals for taxation reductions, totally unfunded, that we have seen in the history of this nation. The other reason the Bill is essentially irrelevant is that this Government will not be in power after the next election; therefore, the legislation will not come into effect. The coalition Government, the Hewson Liberal-National Party Government, has a clearly announced agenda for taxation reform and it is that agenda that the incoming Government will implement.

Before I go any further in relation to the detail of these Bills, I point out to the Senate that this is the first series of debates today on a package of Bills which the Government claims it wants to achieve by the end of the day. There are no fewer than 30 Bills on today's Notice Paper for consideration by the Senate. I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that is an absolute disgrace. I doubt that we have ever seen a more incompetent management of government business in the history of this Senate.

In my seven years in this place, I have never seen the absolute shambles that the Government's legislative program has fallen into. I see the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) smiling benignly at me across the chamber. He ought to be hanging his head in shame at the disgraceful way in which the Government has mismanaged its legislative program.

TALK.START.PARA: —He criticised the Kennett Government for rushing through 20 Bills.

—As my colleague Senator Knowles said, the Kennett Government in Victoria recently attracted a lot of criticism for rushing through 20 Bills in three weeks. What this Government is doing today is rushing through 30 Bills in one day. In the last two or three weeks of the Senate's sitting, we have had to deal with over 80 Bills. If that is the best that this Government can do with its legislative program, it is just as well that it is on the way out and in its dying days.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill. The tax cuts that are proposed in the Bill are targeted towards an attempt to buy the votes of swinging voters for the next election. The Senate will recall that these tax cut proposals were rushed through in February. They were contained in the panic statement by the Government, One Nation, in a futile attempt to counter the very exciting proposals for necessary change in the Australian economic scene in the coalition's Fightback proposals. The Government was struck dumb by those. It cobbled together a statement called `One Nation', of which these tax cut proposals were one part. As I said before, we have now seen that One Nation statement sink virtually without trace.

The great fault of the One Nation statement, so far as this type of legislation and these types of proposals are concerned, is that there was no attempt by the Government to explain how it would finance the huge additional spending proposals that it put forward or the tax cuts that were proposed. There is no way that a Labor government could deliver these tax cuts. As I said, it cares only about the next election—so who cares whether these tax cuts are not delivered in three or four years time? The first of the tax cuts does not come into effect until the 1994-95 financial year. At the time these tax cuts were reconfirmed in statements by the Government in September, Terry McCrann wrote in the Herald-Sun in Melbourne:

SPEECH.PARA: The provenance of these promised tax cuts bears emphasising. They were spawned in One Nation last February and fiscally justified by what can only be described as fraudulent economic projections that could easily have passed for a Bond Corporation balance sheet in the glory days.

That has been reconfirmed by everything that has happened since. The One Nation economic forecasts for growth for the period ahead had quite unrealistic growth forecasts of 4 per cent plus, going out each year until the middle years of this decade. Those forecasts have been pared back progressively since they were announced in the One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: Today we have the quite extraordinary situation—and it was debated, at least in part, during Question Time yesterday—where the Prime Minister, on the one hand, says that 4 per cent is still achievable growth and that if we cannot achieve 4 per cent, we ought to pack it in and give up as a government. He has been saying that for several months. His chief acolyte and promoter, who is one of the people who catapulted him into the prime ministership when he politically assassinated Prime Minister Hawke this time last year, Senator Graham Richardson, says that anyone who believes that 4 per cent growth is achievable in the immediate future `would I think be joking'. That is another example of the enormous inconsistency and division that wracks this Government in terms of some of the fundamental elements of government and of the economy, which is the centrepiece of the whole task of reducing the horrendous unemployment problem that Australia faces.

The other great crime—which is not too strong a word to use—in relation to the particular proposals that are contained in these Bills for tax cuts is that not one cent of tax relief is provided for any low income earners or part time workers earning under $20,700 a year. The tax scales provide no tax relief at all for lower income earners. That is in stark contrast to the proposals that have been put on the table for more than a year now by the coalition in its Fightback tax cut proposals, in which there is very significant relief for income earners at the lower end of the scale. So much for the care, concern and compassion that this Government professes to have for the lower income earners and the more disadvantaged in our community. Colleagues will elaborate on some of my opening remarks.
I move the following amendment in respect of the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a)attempting to prejudge the decisions of a future government by legislating for unfunded tax reductions so far in advance of their proposed date of application and regardless of their funding; and
(b)its failure to:
(i)provide in the proposed tax reductions any reduction in the burden of taxation on lower income earners, and
(ii)take account of the implications for the economy of the unfunded nature of the proposed tax reductions".

These tax cut proposals are not only totally uncaring so far as their regard for lower income earners is concerned; they are also totally irresponsible in that they have not been funded in any way. Therefore, the implications for the economy are very serious indeed, as we move to the middle years of the decade. They will simply further compound the enormous budgetary problems that this Government has introduced over recent years. We have seen a massive deterioration in the Commonwealth's financial position in the last few years—a deterioration which over the last three years has already amounted to about $30,000m. These proposals will just compound that problem in the years ahead.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I reiterate that the great fault of this Bill is that it attempts to tie the hands of future governments by proposing tax cuts so far in advance of their date of application. In December 1992 we are dealing with tax cuts which will not even start until 1994-95 and which extend out for four or more years beyond that.

That is an absolutely and totally irresponsible way to go about the management of economic policy and government in this country. That is yet another reason why this Government ought to be calling an immediate election so that the people of Australia, who have suffered so much under this Government, who have seen their living standards slide, who have seen their nation and themselves go so far into massive debt compared to the rest of the world, can have the opportunity at the first possible date to throw this Government out, to vent their anger on this Government and to elect a government that has economic responsibility, the creation of jobs and the caring for and the well-being of the people as it first priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Taxation Legislation Amendment Bill and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill. The Taxation Legislation Amendment Bill is unprecedented in the sense that it legislatively provides for tax cuts that are far into the future and are unfunded. Therefore, what this Government is doing in this legislation is putting a millstone around the neck of any future government in terms of its options, given the unfunded nature of this legislation. The Bill is also bad in the sense that it fails to deliver tax cuts to the lower income earners. That is a tragedy at this time when it is essentially these people who are suffering the stigma of low incomes, part time work and so on.

PARA.TAB: This chamber will recall that in the Budget statement the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) intimated that new taxes would be necessary if the Government could not bring a future Labor Budget into surplus as projected in the One Nation statement. After weeks of coercion by the coalition as to what these new taxes would be, a major policy statement was delivered on 16 September of this year. These Bills were introduced in the other place the following day.

The Bills were designed to calm the justified fears that Labor would not be able to deliver on its promised One Nation tax scales. It is interesting to note that the provisions in these Bills, even though they have been introduced and debated now in 1992, would not come into force until 1996-97. This is in stark contrast to all the other Bills that have been debated in this chamber this year, when the legislation quite often lagged behind the introduction date.

According to the second reading speeches by both the Treasurer and Senator Button, these Bills `are to give effect to the Government's commitment to deliver on these tax reductions without resort to the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax'. To deliver these tax cuts will do nothing but create a millstone, as I said, around the neck of a Labor government should what I regard as the impossible occur and the Labor Party be returned at the next election. The coalition is the party with a well-thought-out plan to deliver genuine and much needed taxation reform.

A returned Labor government would have difficulty financing the proposed tax cuts. The Government's decision to legislate now for tax cuts in 1994 and beyond shows a desperate attempt to give a facade of legitimacy to its decision that I believe it will be unable to implement. The One Nation growth estimates have been so wrong. Only a few days ago, the economic news out of Europe and Japan was so gloomy that the International Monetary Fund had to downgrade its forecasts with regard to these two countries. In the paper today we read of commodity prices being severely down in a number of areas. What happens on the world stage will impact on Australia and on this Government's ability to deliver those tax cuts.

The Tax Legislation Amendment Bill proposes to reduce the tax rates in two stages. I have been interested to note that the figures given by various government documents, as to how these cuts are to be financed, do not add up. The numbers in the explanatory memorandum to the legislation conflict with the Treasurer's statement in relation to both Bills. In fact, the explanatory memorandum says that the Government will raise $1,525m from this measure in 1994-95 and $840m in 1995-96. Meanwhile, the summary table explaining the tax changes on page 13 of the tax policy statement says that the fringe benefits measures will raise $1,640m in 1994-95 and $840m in 1995-96.

The Government has already announced significant changes in terms of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill which will reduce the amount of revenue. On equity grounds, the Opposition agrees to that particular amendment because these organisations, basically the non-profit organisations, would have been discriminated against quite unfairly in the sense that they would pay a grossed-up fringe benefit and would get no deduction in respect of the expenses incurred. For that reason, as we indicated earlier, we will be supporting that amendment.

The tax cuts proposed in the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill before us are inequitable. Forty-seven per cent of all taxpayers—that is, those on the lowest scales—will receive no tax cuts at all. The Keating tax cuts do not reduce the lowest marginal rate from 20 per cent, as the Opposition's do, to 16.2 per cent, nor do they increase the tax-free threshold of $5,400. You might recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the coalition's Fightback package lifts that threshold to $7,000. Therefore, no taxpayer on an income under $20,700 will obtain a tax cut under this Government, but they will under a Liberal-National Party government.

The planned personal tax cuts in this Bill will create a hole in this year's Budget. One must not forget that there is also a cumulative deficit of nearly $50 billion from 1991-92 to 1995-96. The question arises: how will this all be paid for? The Government, of course, has relied on its hastily put together tax statement of 16 September that it proposes to raise $2.5 billion over the two years to reform the FBT system. In his statement, the Treasurer says:

SPEECH.PARA: A significant share of the revenue yield of the changes will come from tax exempt government sector employers who have benefited from lower taxes on fringe benefits until now.

The question arises: how are the various local, State and Territory governments going to pay for all this? It will mean cuts in State services in education, health, and law and order. Their funding is a matter that this Government has not yet decided upon.

PARA.TAB: It is significant to note that the Government does not provide for the increase in grants to the States, Territories and local government which would be necessary to provide some compensation to the tax exempt employers for the cost of the additional fringe benefits tax payments. Again, not only does this Federal Government have a problem created by this legislation but the States and Territories have one too.

The Government has also stated that it will achieve part of the increased revenue from improved compliance of business on the everyday taxpayer. However, the legislation is not before us today as it will not be introduced until 1993-94, although I intend to devote some of my comments to this proposal today, as it is a vital part of the revenue changes.

The question arises that if compliance is such a large problem, as the Government claims, why has the Government not dealt with this previously and why forestall the introduction of this part of the statement until 1994? The Tax Office is to receive an extra $114m over three years to implement these extra compliance measures. The Tax Office is critically short of staff at the top end. The money will mainly be spent on hiring extra staff.

The Tax Office has conceded that voluntary compliance will increase as the Tax Office increases its own audit activities. The details of expected revenue gains show that business will be the provider of most of the increased collections. The Tax Office is planning to allocate 100 additional staff to the audits of the top 100 companies. As each auditor now returns $1m a year, the Tax Office has confidently predicted that it would obtain additional revenue of $100m from this source alone.

As a result of the recent Papas Carter independent report on the Taxation Office's audit of the top 100 companies, one can only wonder whether this gain will come from the uncertainties and the grey areas in the law rather than poor compliance practices of these companies. One wonders, after these companies have been audited for up to two, three or possibly four years, how much extra money the Tax Office will continue to obtain from this so-called higher compliance from these sorts of big businesses.

But small businesses will also be affected by this increased compliance as they have been marked for extra attention under the compliance statement. The businesses will certainly be affected and will have to pay most of the costs associated with the strengthening of the PAYE legislation and information reporting requirements. Overall, it has been estimated that the new compliance measures will cost businesses an extra $700m over two years. Many small businesses and companies will be pushed into bankruptcy or insolvency, especially when we realise that this will be the third impost on small business in as many months.

Let me remind honourable senators that business firstly had the superannuation levy, followed by the increase in the training guarantee levy, which is the original training guarantee levy, and now the new car parking legislation. This Government is about taxing businesses. On the other hand, the Opposition, under the coalition's Fightback proposal, aims to take these sorts of taxes off business and thereby create extra employment.

I refer to a comment made by Mr Michael McKenna, the Director of the Australian Society of CPAs. He doubts that the premises of the compliance strategy are sound. This is from a top accountant in Australia. He says that it appears that they are based on an inference that the accounting rules encouraged tax avoidance on the part of some small businesses. Further, he questions whether the small businesses being targeted in this strategy would really contribute substantially to the tax harvest.
Similar views were echoed by the Australian Financial Review on 29 September, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the depressed level of business activity, the straight line projections for revenue growth predicted by the Tax Office in what . . . are conservative estimates must be seriously doubted. If ever there was a climate in which the so-called law of diminishing returns could operate, the present level of business activity is it. Corpses never line up to donate blood at the Red Cross Blood Bank.

These sorts of comments and others highlight just how unsound the Government's estimates of revenue to be raised are and cast doubts on the possibility of the eventual implementation of proposed tax cuts in the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill. But what is certain is that the burden is very much falling on business—the employers of this community who are having such difficulty at present managing just to exist, to pay their bills and to keep their heads above water.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to make some pertinent comments with regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill. I applaud the amendment that the Government is putting forward to exempt the grossing-up effect on, basically, the non-profit sector of Australia, which includes religious institutions, scientific bodies, hospitals and various non-profit organisations. This measure must have been one of the unintended consequences when the legislation was first framed.

There is no denying that the changes in this Bill are a significant fundraising measure. The changes are to commence on 1 April 1994. In effect, the value of fringe benefits is to be grossed up to an amount paid equal to the cash salary that would need to be paid by an employer to produce the same after tax benefit to an employee. Basically, fringe benefits, by way of emoluments, will disappear from the pay packages around Australia because they simply will not be worth while. The net result of this Bill is that an employer's fringe benefits payments will almost double. At the same time, an employer's income tax will be reduced—that is, if the employer pays any income tax at all—by an amount less than the increased fringe benefits payable.

According to Butterworths weekly tax bulletin No. 46, there are a number of problems that will arise if this new method is implemented. Firstly, it assumes that all employers started saving tax by reducing employees' cash salaries generally and providing fringe benefits of an amount which left employees in the same after tax position. That is not necessarily true. Secondly, it assumes that all employees who receive fringe benefits tax are in the highest tax bracket—that is, $50,000-plus. That is not true. In most cases the reality is probably quite different. The main type of benefit traditionally provided by an employer, for example, a company car, has always been provided as a fringe benefit. Furthermore, a company car would normally not be able to be cashed out by the employee.

It appears that the measures may have been derived from a practice of some employers to allow high income employees to use salary packaging to obtain an `arbitrage' benefit on the difference between the company tax rate of 39 per cent and the higher fringe benefits tax and personal tax rate. We believe there is an opportunity for some tax minimisation schemes in that there is too big a difference between the corporate tax rate and the top income tax rate. In salary packaging planning, however, the benefit normally was given to the employee and did not represent a saving to the employer.

The effect of the gross-up goes far beyond preventing the use of salary package planning, given that many benefits will not be able to be cashed out. Instead, it amounts to an additional tax on employers and could be considered harsh for those employers not paying income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I note the position of the non-profit organisations. Very few of those, effectively, are involved in salary sacrifice packaging arrangements. A further effect of the amendments is that franking credits will be decreased as employers will be paying more fringe benefits tax and less income tax.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the coalition is concerned about the imposition that these new arrangements will place on local government authorities and businesses because of their unfunded nature. This is a bad package of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill 1992. As Senator Watson has already pointed out, it is nothing but a fundraising exercise because of the shortfall that the Taxation Commissioner has had in the last 12 months of raising funds for the tax cuts that this Government has promised—unfunded, of course—out of the One Nation package. It is introducing the grossing-up factor, and the grossing-up factor is to attack the employers or companies that are cashing out FBT.

PARA.TAB: It was quite legal, of course, to pay FBT at the tax rate of 39c in the dollar, and that will be taken up to the top tax rate of 49c plus the Medicare levy. The situation is that most small businesses were paying far less than that and were using the cash out system rather than paying the FBT. In my opinion, in most cases they were doing that to get away from paperwork more than anything else. It was better for a small employer with one or two employees to pay the cash benefit so employees were taxed themselves rather than having to go through the paperwork.

It is unfairest of all on local governments, which are not taxpayers. This Bill allows FBT paid to be totally tax deductible, but if people are not paying tax there is no relief. Today's Australian Financial Review reported:
In another FBT change, Mr Dawkins has offered a partial FBT rebate to non-government, non-profit organisations from April 1994, when a new FBT regime is due to begin.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in that statement he was talking about exactly what he said: that is, non-government and non-profit organisations in relation to the car parking fringe benefits tax. He, or whoever is the Treasurer at the time, should be looking at this to make sure that local government is not unduly penalised. In Western Australia alone, local government is up for an extra $1.75m for this grossing-up situation. Local government does not have an endless supply of money, and in this case it can only be recouped from extra rates.

PARA.TAB: Though there is a limited time to talk on these Bills. I have a copy of a letter from the Local Government Association of Western Australia. I have shown it to the Minister. That letter explains it all. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN MUNICIPAL ASSOCIATION
4 November 1992
Hon J S Dawkins MP
Federal Treasurer
Treasurer's Office
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 1600
Dear Mr Dawkins
NEW FBT LEGISLATION
The WAMA Committee resolved at a meeting held on October 7, 1992:

"That WAMA object most strongly to the Federal Treasurer at the additional tax burden to be imposed on Local Government by this proposed legislation (grossing up the value to include FBT) and call for a complete re-appraisal of remote area fringe benefits tax valuations.

The estimated cost of this legislation to Local Government in Western Australia is $1.75m, the bulk of which comprises additional FBT on private motor vehicle use, which includes travel to and from home for garaging purposes. This sum of $1.75m will now have to be found by Councils, through increased Government grants or property rates, or by the employees of Local Government.

The legislation increases the tax burden on Local Government from 48.25% to 93.2% of the valuation, whereas the effective tax rate payable by a tax-paying company, after deductions from taxable income, will be 17.85%. And Local Government is supposed to be the tax exempt body!

In seeking to eliminate a tax "perk", the Government is, in consequence, aggravating inequities within the existing system. These inequities essentially arise by virtue of the regressive nature of the regime in that all fringe benefits are taxed at the top marginal income tax rate, irrespective of the marginal tax rate payable by the recipient. Thus, lower-paid recipients of fringe benefits effectively subsidise the higher-paid. In particular, the increase in the gross tax burden on benefits for the higher-paid, and a widening gap in the tax-inefficiency of remunerating employees on less than the top tax rate in fringe benefits, not cash, will have an especially severe impact on both companies and Government employees in remote regions.

I mentioned earlier that the bulk of FBT payable by Councils relates to car usage. This particularly applies to the metropolitan area. However, in remote areas, and particularly the Pilbara, a range of fringe benefits are virtually forced on Councils if they are to compete for labour. Subsidised housing is the principal "fringe benefit" in this context.

Companies in remote Australia have historically had to provide their own infrastructure and basic living conditions for their employees. They are now taxed for doing so, and have no ability to "cash out" the so-called benefits for their employees, because they are written into individual awards and, in he case of the Pilbara, are enforced through State Agreement Acts. They are often provided for employees towards the lower end of the wage structure, and can more realistically be viewed as necessities.
Local Governments which exist in this environment must, of course, follow suit, and it is only exacerbating the situation when they have to pay 93.2% tax on the value of these benefits.

A report commissioned by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and co-ordinated by Professor Harris of James Cook University, entitled "Northern Australia Economic Development Strategy", identifies FBT and a number of other taxes that impact disproportionately on remote Northern Australia. These include income tax, payroll tax, FBT, transportation "taxes", wholesale taxes, alcohol, tobacco, private fuel.
The effect of these taxes is to impede economic and social development, including downstream processing.
The second recommendation of the report commissioned by the Prime Minister provides:

"The Commonwealth Government should review the structure of its taxation measures to identify ways in which indirect taxes (or taxes not levied on income or profits) may impede economic growth in Northern Australia by imposing additional costs on firms. In this respect a remote area criterion should be included in the evaluation of taxes, along with other criteria relating to efficiency, incidence, and revenue raising capacity.

Unless there is a re-appraisal of remote area fringe benefits tax valuations, this current legislative attempt to eliminate "perks" will fall disproportionately and inequitably on remote areas which have an imperative to provide benefits other than cash.

Given that one of the reasons for the introduction of this legislation is to raise additional revenue to offset intended income tax cuts, and given the statement in your Second Reading Speech that "a significant share of the revenue yield of the changes will come from tax exempt Government sector employees . . . ", the argument must be raised as to whether this piece of legislation does not create more anomalies than it removes.
From the Local Government perspective, this is unquestionably so.

Virtually all Local Governments in Australia are being asked to pick up a tax burden which is unjust to varying degrees to prevent the possibility that some few Local Governments may benefit by paying the private expenses of employees, which could quite simply be "cashed out" by substituting salary.
Yours sincerely
E L Chown
Deputy Executive Director
Western Australian Municipal Association

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I said in the beginning, it is only a fundraising exercise. This package of Bills relates mostly to unfunded promises and this one goes so far towards cutting down the unfunding. I believe they will have to be looked at again very closely when we are in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is the height of hypocrisy that the Government dares to bring in these Bills with two days of sittings before an election is called. When one considers the manner in which the Budget and the One Nation statement have failed in their projections, for the Government to pretend that it can introduce tax cuts which it will honour in 1994-95 and project that far into the future is a joke.

PARA.TAB: That well-known document the annual report of the Australian Taxation Office shows that not only did the Government get its projections wrong with a shortfall in revenue of $3.5 billion because the Tax Office did not even factor in the recession, but the only growth centre of any tax collection is FBT. Accordingly, fringe benefits tax grossing-up provisions are put in place, which are simply a grab to get more tax from businesses which are struggling to survive.

Job losses are continuing and unemployment is going up continually, and yet this Government does not have the decency to even examine the impact of this grossing-up provision, so that FBT tax will come out at around 43c in the dollar. There has not even been a consideration of how that is going to impact and add to unemployment. Furthermore, there is, as I said, the sheer cynicism of bringing in the Bill to legislate for alleged tax cuts into the never-never by a Government which will be in the never-never.

Let us take a look at the record of the Government and the Tax Office in being able to project anything beyond several months. In the Budget statement, what did Mr Dawkins say? He said, `We shall introduce our announced personal income tax cuts and the Budget deficit will fall as economic recovery strengthens'. What economic recovery strengthening? We have had projections of growth of 4.7 per cent in One Nation, 3 per cent in the Budget, and, in fact, we are running at 2.1 per cent. The Prime Minister has said, `If a government can't do 4 per cent, it doesn't deserve to be elected'—and it will not be.

So here we are, in these last two days, with a wad of Bills as long as your arm still to be dealt with, simply because the Government cannot manage its business properly. We sit through until 1 o'clock or 3 o'clock in the morning to debate legislation which is important to this nation, and we have these Bills foisted on the House to be rid of in a short space of time.

In looking at the work of the Tax Office and the little deals that went on between Mr Dawkins and Mr Boucher, we see the hole that was found in the Budget figures. It was shown by the Opposition that there was no money at all to pay for those tax cuts that we are now supposed to be putting into legislative form. So three weeks after the Budget, that infamous statement on tax policy is brought down—a document prepared by Mr Boucher and his Tax Office, accompanied by the confidential minute signed by Mr Boucher, allegedly finding $1.7 billion to fill up the hole in the Budget.

In asking questions of Mr Highfield and Mr Carmody at Estimates committees, we found that they were asked to work on that additional statement one week after the Budget, and yet the whole package was brought in on 16 September. In other words, all that alleged work was done in 2 1/2 weeks. Anyone who cares to read the Hansard report of the Estimates will find that as we went through the so-called additional amounts of revenue that would be found, of $350m here or $350m there, absolutely no work had been done to substantiate those figures at all. So it is all fairyland stuff.

In that hearing, we saw that the Commissioner had entered into competing agreements. He had entered into an agreement with the Department of Finance that in order to spend $1.2 billion of taxpayers' money buying information technology for the modernisation program, he in turn agreed that there would be a reduction of 3,000 staff, which is quite clear and quite explicit in the agreement. He then entered into a competing agreement with the Public Sector Union, which virtually outlawed any compulsory redundancies at all. The net result is that we have 1,000 staff on the payroll of the Tax Office for which there is no appropriated sum. There is not enough money.

What the Tax Office has done to try to remedy that is to convert administration moneys into salary moneys, which is allowable in terms of management but not in terms of abuse. Furthermore, it has forward borrowed $19m against next year's appropriation to try to make up the shortfall. At no stage in all the hearings with Mr Boucher and the officers of the Tax Office did they admit to the shortfall. Indeed, they tried to say everything was lovely, including getting the man that they call their chief bean counter to give a presentation to the Committee which, quite frankly, was wrong. It had two errors in it, and that meant that the Committee was misled by that information.

One error was that he presented a graph to the Committee which showed that the $19m forward borrowing had in fact been repaid in this financial year to the tune of $18m. It had not. On further questioning, what we ascertained was that, by cajoling, the Tax Office had got a commitment from the Government that in next year's Budget it would forgive the borrowing of up to the tune of $18m.

Following on that, we looked at the borrowings that would be available in subsequent years up to 1995-96. As and from this year the amount that can be borrowed against forward appropriations has gone from 3 per cent to 6 per cent, and the chief bean counter showed those figures. The only thing he had not done was read the Finance Regulations that accompany those changes. What those Finance Regulations say, very specifically, is that one may not borrow in consecutive years. In other words, it is what I said in the beginning about the Tax Office: that its mismanagement was so bad that had it been a private corporation it would have been put into receivership.

Subsequently, we got a copy of a speech given by Mr Boucher to all his staff. It is six months earlier than the hearings that took place, and he says, `Could everybody please save money'. The speech says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the effect of fewer people leaving, especially during the past couple of years is still with us. Our budget shortfall is around $20 million out of a total salary and administrative budget of some $825 million. If we did nothing, we would for 1992/93 effectively have 600 people over our salary budget.
That was the information that was denied in those committee hearings. A sad and sorry tale is the administration of Mr Boucher and his Tax Office.

PARA.TAB: The other point that remains a very serious question to be answered is what transpired between the Budget and the bringing down of that subsequent statement. In the Budget Papers there is a statement by Mr Dawkins which says:

SPEECH.PARA: If the fiscal position nearer to the time is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain the revenue structure. These changes—referred to in the Budget Statements—would allow for the 1995-96 deficit to be between 1/2 per cent and 1 per cent of gross domestic product.

Looking at those statements, one can see that they were talking about having a withholding tax on interest and other taxes. But paragraph 4 of the confidential minute signed by Mr Boucher that accompanies the statement says:

Earlier this year, when addressing the question of a domestic withholding tax on interest I made the general point that it is a tenet of income tax administration that the most efficient and effective means of gathering tax is to have it deducted at source.

One of the many questions I asked of Mr Boucher which he refused to answer was: when did he change his mind? Clearly, he had given that advice prior to the Budget. What pressures were brought to bear in order to change that? Mr Boucher is not just like a head of any other department. He is a statutory head. He can only be sacked on the motion of both Houses of Parliament. He is entrenched for a seven-year term, which he has chosen to leave after one year of the second term of appointment.

PARA.TAB: There are many questions indeed that need to be answered as to how that $1.7 billion was found in a 2 1/2-week period. When one investigates the figures, one finds that they cannot be substantiated, and yet that whole sorry mess is the basis for the alleged funding for these so-called tax cuts. What a sorry tale has been woven by this Government. There is a debt of $162 billion, one million people unemployed, and the Government has no policies to deal with it at all. What do we get? We get red herrings put on the trail. Yesterday we had Senator Tate, the man who originally told us in this chamber that the Government had no policies, come in and talk about changing the oath of allegiance.

What we need is solid policies to get rid of that $162 billion debt and to put a dent in the figure of one million unemployed. We need confidence, we need policies and we need strong leadership, but the Government is not giving them. Every time it makes a statement, one can believe that it will be proven wrong down the track. This is just another example. What a subterfuge. We are going to slug the very businesses that have any opportunity of providing employment, on the basis that we have to have a grab for tax so that we can pretend to promise tax cuts years out, when this Government will be out of office.

There are so many injustices in this package of Bills that they deserve to be thrown out lock, stock and barrel. It is indeed a sad and sorry day when we see debate on this mess curtailed and when we see the tactics of a government, unable to handle its business so as to get through it in an orderly way, panicking, trying to grab at straws and saying, `Umpteen years down the track we might give you a tax cut'. It is not good enough for the Government to pretend that it has the interests of the people at heart. It clearly has not. This package of Bills deserves to be condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first Bill I would like to discuss today is the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill 1992. This Bill is a direct result of the very weak recovery of the economy over the last 12 to 18 months. The One Nation statement proposed a number of measures to help stimulate the economy. It proposed, firstly, to return the Budget to surplus within four years and, secondly, to do this while promising what we consider to be ridiculous personal income tax cuts in both 1994 and 1996. The key assumption for all of this to be possible is a rapid and sustained increase in economic growth. Close to 5 per cent was predicted. This was greeted with scepticism, incredulity and hilarity by all commentators and all sides of politics. As we know, it was revised down in the Budget. The fact that it had to be revised down meant that the dual promise of returning the Budget to surplus and making these personal income tax cuts could not be kept without increasing taxation in other areas.

PARA.TAB: Today we have before us the related increased compliance regime previously announced by the Treasurer. Despite the fact that these measures for compliance are intrinsically fair, nobody really believes that they will fill the yawning deficit. Contrary to the views of previous speakers, the Australian Democrats believe that the fringe benefits tax is one of the better reforms of the Keating period in Treasury. There was a huge equity problem with the tax treatment of fringe benefits and there was justifiable anger in the community about the unfairness of differing tax burdens, depending upon how an employee's remuneration was structured. The structure of the fringe benefits tax was to impose tax, via the employer, on the net benefit enjoyed by the employee. The benefit is tax deductible to the employer but the fringe benefits tax itself is not. This was a reasonable structure while the company tax rate and the maximum marginal income tax rate were aligned. However, the cut in the company tax rate to 39 per cent introduced a clear advantage to employees in taking their remuneration in the form of fringe benefits. This Bill proposes to impose fringe benefits tax on the gross benefit obtained. The benefit is grossed up by adding the fringe benefits tax to the net benefit, and the fringe benefits tax itself becomes tax deductible to the employer. This will ensure that an employee will face the same effective tax burden whether the income is by way of cash or non-cash benefits. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard some worked examples of grossing up which demonstrate the effect of this legislation and the equity of the Government's proposals.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The fringe benefits tax (FBT) legislation, when first introduced, sought to levy FBT to a similar extent to the income tax that would have been payable had the benefit been payable in a monetary form. This was achieved through the close alignment between the FBT rate, the top marginal rate of income tax and the company income tax rate. However, the position was disturbed by the reduction of company rates on 1 July 1988.
Consider the following example under the current rules where a taxable employer provides a fringe benefit worth $1,000:
Cost to employer of benefit provided: 1,000
Value for FBT purposes: 1,000
Tax deduction for benefit provided: 390
Tax deduction for FBT paid: 0
Total cost to employer: 1,092 (1,000+482-390)
Employee's income tax at 48.25%: 0
Commonwealth Revenue: 92 (482-390)
If the employer were to provide the equivalent salary so that the employee had $1,000 to purchase his own benefit, the calculation would be as follows:
Cost to employer of salary provided: 1,932
Value for FBT purposes: 0
Tax deduction for salary provided: 753
Tax deduction for FBT paid: 0
Total cost to employer: 1,179 (1,932-753)
Employee's income tax at 48.25%: 932
Commonwealth Revenue: 179 (932-753)
The above example shows that the employer would save $87 (at the Commonwealth's expense) by providing a fringe benefit rather than salary.

Accordingly, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Act 1992 provides that as from 1 April 1994, FBT will be applied to the "grossed-up" value of any fringe benefit provided ie. the equivalent salary value of the fringe benefit, while allowing taxation deductions for FBT paid. Thus, example 1 will now become:
Cost to employer of benefit provided: 1,000
Value for FBT purposes: 1,932
Tax deduction for benefit provided: 390
Tax deduction for FBT paid: 363
Total cost to employer: 1,179(1,000+932-390-363)
Employee's income tax at 48.25%: 0
Commonwealth Revenue: 179 (932-390-363)
Thus, equivalence is restored between the total cost to the employer and the Commonwealth Revenue (compare examples 2 & 3) irrespective of the mode of remuneration.
Non-Taxable Employers

However, the situation is slightly different in respect of employers exempt from the income tax, such as local councils. In respect of non-taxable employers, the present FBT calculation (equivalent to example 1) is as follows:
Cost to employer of benefit provided: 1,000
Value for FBT purposes: 1,000
Tax deduction for benefit provided: 0
Tax deduction for FBT paid: 0
Total cost to employer: 1,482 (1,000+482)
Employee's income tax at 48.25%: 0
Commonwealth Revenue: 482
In respect of non-taxable employers, the present salary calculation (equivalent to example 2) is as follows:
Cost to employer of salary provided: 1,932
Value for FBT purposes: 0
Tax deduction for salary provided: 0
Tax deduction for FBT paid: 0
Total cost to employer: 1,932
Employee's income tax at 48.25%: 932
Commonwealth Revenue: 932
The above example shows that the employer would save $450 (at the Commonwealth's expense) by providing a fringe benefit rather than salary.
In respect of non-taxable employers, the new FBT calculation (equivalent to example 3) is as follows:
Cost to employer of benefit provided: 1,000
Value for FBT purposes: 1,932
Tax deduction for benefit provided: 0
Tax deduction for FBT paid: 0
Total cost to employer: 1,932 (1,000+932)
Employee's income tax at 48.25%: 0
Commonwealth Revenue: 932
Again, equivalence is restored between the total cost to the employer and the Commonwealth Revenue (compare examples 5 & 6) irrespective of the mode of remuneration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The impact of this Bill would have been fairly harsh on some non-taxpaying employers, and this effect was obviously anticipated by the Government. Consequently, the Government has allowed a rebate to some employers who are exempt from income tax, basically to neutralise the effect of this Bill. Some of the bodies affected by this are public benevolent institutions, sporting, educational and scientific bodies, community service organisations and trade unions.

PARA.TAB: We think the rebate move is fair and appropriate, and so is the caveat the Government has given. The rebate is to ensure that the legitimate activities of the various organisations are not unduly affected. However, this also makes the provision of fringe benefits very attractive to the employees of those bodies, and so there is a risk of abuse. The Australian Democrats support the Government's proposal for monitoring the level of fringe benefits in order to ensure that the rebate is not overly generous to some employees.

It is important to note that, although the fringe benefits tax is paid by the employer, the real incidence of the tax is on the employee. This principle does not change whether the employee works for a charity or a trade union. One interesting result of this legislation is that certain types of benefits will become more tax effective, and hence attractive, in salary packages.

Certain types of expenses do not qualify for tax deductions to the employer, for example, some entertainment and leisure expenses, so they are not subject to the fringe benefits tax.The increase in the fringe benefits tax rate effected by this Bill will mean that these non-deductible expenses will be more tax effective than they currently are, so we can be reasonably confident that these larger loopholes could be exploited in the future. I believe that the Government should also address this area to see whether a further restructuring could be achieved to ensure that these non-deductible benefits are treated in a tax neutral manner. Certainly, the Democrats would support any fair moves in this area.

This measure will commence on 1 April 1994 and will raise over $1.5 billion in 1994-95 and $840m in future years. It is quite extraordinary that this massive revenue measure does not seem to have raised a ripple of community angst. My office has not received any representations at all on this matter. Given the reaction to the superannuation guarantee levy, parking tax and other revenue proposals, I think that is quite unusual, because it is a massive revenue proposal.

The second Bill in this package is the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill. I am sorry I cannot talk positively about this Bill either. It is the Government's enactment of the One Nation personal income tax cuts and it vies for the award for one of the worst pieces of legislation the Labor Government has introduced over the last 10 years. It is part of the Government's strategy—the `have your cake and eat it too' approach—of promising to broadly match the Fightback income tax cuts but without the nasty GST. So the nation has been involved in what I have been calling an obscene tax auction: when in doubt appeal to the hip pocket. This continues the trend of the Keating Treasury of cutting marginal tax rates, as opposed to adjusting the thresholds at which various marginal rates commence.

The Government is continually saying that these rate measures must not be viewed in isolation, and this begs the question: why not? We hear at length from the Government that it has broadened the tax base. It has, and it has done that with the support of the Democrats. But many of the measures were long overdue and the coalition has supported many of them as well. The fact that the tax base is fairer is not a justification for making the personal income tax scale less fair. It is so counterproductive of the Government to seek to reverse the good work it has done in the area of base broadening by seeking to give back the additional tax raised by flattening the progressivity of personal income tax.

This legislation proposes to introduce income tax cuts from 1 July 1994 to 1 January 1996. They are very regressive tax cuts. In my view, there has been insufficient public scrutiny of them until recent weeks. What people have failed to grasp is that this legislation proposes to give absolutely no tax cuts to those people with earnings of less than $20,700 per year; all the low income earners will get no tax relief for at least the next five years.

This is at a time when we have a significant trend in the economy away from full time employment towards part time employment. Indeed, Access Economics has estimated that there are an additional one million people in Australia who are underemployed; that is, who cannot get the full time work they desire. These people in particular will get nothing from the kinder, more compassionate Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Government claims that reducing unemployment is the No. 1 priority. I agree. But I do not think it can achieve that and at the same time give a huge, unaffordable bribe to those lucky enough to be in full time work or those lucky enough to have significant income from investments.

Let me repeat: this legislation gives nothing to those earning under $20,700 per year, but it will deliver $47 a week to those earning $50,000 or more. That means people such as us. That means that people such as us in the Senate deserve a $50 a week tax cut, while Australia is racked by what seems like a permanent recession. It makes one wonder about the priorities of those with work. Why should we deserve more consideration while the unemployed become increasingly disillusioned?

These two Bills—but this Bill in particular about which I am speaking—were considered yesterday by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The Bills were condemned in terms of being unaffordable by almost every sector of the community represented there. Those representatives included the Catholic Bishops Committee for Justice, Development and Peace; the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research; Dr John Quiggin from the Australian National University; the Australian Council of Social Service; Mr Garry White from Corporate Investment Australia; and Mr Paddy McGuinness, a correspondent for the Australian.

I do not find myself agreeing with Paddy McGuinness very often, but I thought his presentation yesterday was particularly lucid when he said, in essence, that this particular Bill was a very bad Bill and that the decision to pursue tax cuts was a very bad decision. He said that it is bad economics, it is bad fiscal and tax practice, it is bad social policy, it is bad constitutional practice and it is bad ethics. On the issue of bad constitutional practice, we did question the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, on this yesterday. I am still unconvinced that it is appropriate for a government, close to an election, to tie the hands of or to bind a future government. It really does reduce the options of that future government. It does preclude the use of discretionary tax rates either to stimulate or to contract fiscal policy. It significantly ties the hands of a future government. I think it is wrong to do that.

Most of the witnesses at yesterday's hearing of the Committee agreed that, because we have not been able to live up to the growth expectations, because there is a question mark over inflation—in one case, one witness suggested—we cannot afford these tax cuts at this time. We cannot afford to set them in place now, even though they do not commence until 1994-96. It would be irresponsible.

Could I point out the position of the Opposition on this, because all the speakers here this morning have said what a terrible thing it is the Government is doing. I think it is important to point out that they are following their policy of criticising but not voting against Budget Bills. The Opposition members attached a reservation to yesterday's committee hearings. I draw people's attention to that. It does not go far enough, in my view, because they may then be in government, but they are accepting the right of this present Government to tie their hands. What will they do if they are in government? What will they do with a Senate which may be controlled by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats? I find their attitude disappointing.

If the Government insists on spending $8 billion, I would suggest to it that it could find much better ways to do that. It could start by looking at the tax thresholds. It could start by looking at the inequities in child-care relief. It could start by paying some attention to the plight of self-funded retirees. These are much fairer ways in which to spend $8 billion. The Democrats believe that these tax cuts are blatantly opportunistic, unaffordable, unfair and irresponsible, and this legislation should be opposed on those grounds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who shortened their contribution and those who I know had interest in the legislation but took themselves off the list to expedite the proceedings. Consistent with my practice on other such second readings, I will not abuse their cooperation by making a long response. But it is very important legislation and it would be inappropriate for it to go unresponded to, so I will try to strike a balance between those two pressures.

PARA.TAB: The two Bills before us are both important, although quite distinct. The fringe benefits tax legislation has had pretty well widespread support in this chamber. I understand that some senators have raised concerns about some particular sub-parts of it. I do not share their view but I will not traverse that, because broadly people accept the principle that there was, to use the shorthand term, arbitrage going on in the way people were using fringe benefits and getting particular advantage because of the structure of the tax system. That is a practice which will be finished by these changes. That probably explains why Senator Kernot, for example, has not had any expressions of concern about this legislation, because everybody who is caught up in it realises that it is a measure that was overdue. Many of the acknowledged experts had been calling on the Government to take action of this sort for some time.

The Government amendment to provide a rebate to non-government non-profit organisations so that the impact of this grossing-up is not as severe on them as it otherwise might have been has been well received, though it would not please the tax purists because those non-government non-profit organisations also have the capacity, which some unfortunately have exhibited, to abuse the tax system in the way that they go about providing remuneration packages to their employees. Nevertheless, they are providing a socially worthwhile function and, provided there is no flagrant abuse of this rebate mechanism, we think it is a fair compromise between tax purity and fairness and socially desirable outcomes. I thank honourable senators for their support for that legislation and that proposed amendment. I will not debate it any further.

The principal matter that has been debated is the One Nation tax cuts. We have to make it very clear right from the start that there is no apology from the Government for the fact that these tax cuts are focused on working Australians, Australians in that range just below and just above average weekly earnings. These are people who are out there working hard to make a living and who have been showing great wage restraint. They have not been the beneficiaries of the increasingly targeted welfare expenditures of the Government, where we have tightened the focus on things like family allowance supplement, so that people in the middle have felt squeezed. They have been showing significant restraint for the last decade. We do not apologise for the fact that we are targeting these tax cuts to those people. I think most Australians would recognise that from time to time, notwithstanding the increasingly tight targeting of expenditure, we have to recognise the pressures on the people in the middle, and this is an example of doing that.

It is nevertheless true, as was raised in the Committee yesterday and by Senator Kernot—I did not hear anyone else pick it up—that Australia does have to consider how long we can go on reducing the tax take. We do have to look at the fact that we are one of the two lowest taxing countries in the OECD. Australians have reasonable aspirations for a level of government service provision that is consistent with a modern Western democracy, and to fund that we need a reasonable level of tax.

We cannot go on cutting revenue and not looking at how we are going to provide the services to which Australians consider themselves entitled and which, I think, a reasonable society should provide. But I do not think we cross that bridge on this occasion because we are talking about fairly small tax cuts, if one looks at them over the time period in question. We are looking at substantial, targeted cuts, but we are not talking about any fundamental change in tax as a percentage of GDP.

I understand the concern that people raised yesterday in the Committee hearing and today in the second reading debate about the long term nature of this legislation, but I think we have to put that in perspective. In the lead up to an election, every party is going to set down what it thinks the tax situation should be over the next three years. The Government has the opportunity to make that intention clear by legislation. The Opposition does not have that opportunity, but it has made clear its view about what the tax levels for Australians should be over the next three years. It may be that it is about to change that view slightly. Nevertheless, whatever it says on Friday, there will then be set down what the Opposition thinks the tax regime should be for the next three years. I assume that at some stage in the course of the debate between now and the election the Australian Democrats will do the same. So we are telling Australians the terms on which we wish to seek re-election. This is one part of it, and we are legislating to make our intention clear.

It is true that it does not make sense to look at the social or economic impacts of these tax cuts in isolation. No Government initiative stands in isolation from the package of measures that preceded it and accompany it. When one looks at the overall structure of the tax system, with the broadening of the base, particularly the introduction of capital gains and fringe benefits, one will see a substantial enhancement of the equity of the tax system. We have seen a focusing of tax cuts. The biggest percentage drop in the marginal tax rate has been for people earning below $20,000 over the last 10 years, and that is where the tax cuts and the expenditure targeting has been focused. The nature of the tax burden is such that it is not the most effective mechanism to provide assistance to people on incomes below $20,000 a year; it is much more effectively done on the revenue side of the Budget, and the Government intends to continue to do that.

If we look at every tax cut as simply proposing what will flow to people on incomes below $20,000, we create illusions of equity. I dwelt on that in the Committee yesterday; it is in the Hansard and I will not speak about it any further. A number of Opposition senators spoke about the Opposition tax cuts. I think Senator Short described them as exciting, and they are certainly exciting some interest amongst Australians and they are expressing their view. That interest continues to be reflected in the opinion polls, and I welcome that. Opposition members spoke about the equity of the tax cuts they are proposing. In these difficult times, and even if they dropped the second stage of their tax cuts, they are proposing to drop the top marginal tax rate even further. That seems to me to be not a priority. It is certainly not a priority the Government shares at this time. This tax measure, which is focused on Australians who are on or about average weekly earnings, does not do that and I do not think it is appropriate. It is the mechanism by which the marginal tax rate for the overwhelming majority of Australian workers is reduced to 30c in the dollar without having to impose a GST on them to fund it.

I welcome the fact that, yesterday in the Committee stage and today in the second reading stage, there has been wide-ranging debate on the relative merits of these two measures. Although there has not been much consideration of the fringe benefits tax measures, to the extent that there has been, there has been support. Overall, it was a positive debate, and a contribution to economic debate in Australia. It is a great pity that Senator Bishop could not resist the temptation to come in and abuse the Tax Office again, even though it had nothing to do with this legislation. It is a pity that we could not, in this instance, get a constructive contribution from her. I thank all the other senators for their contribution, and recommend the two Bills to the Parliament.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: TAX LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate the Opposition's concern that the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill contains no tax relief for low income earners. Anyone earning less than $20,700 a year will have no tax relief under this Bill. If the Government is seriously concerned about the plight of low income earners and lower income earners in our community and the hardship imposed on them, as it professes to be and as it well should be, then there should be significant tax relief for people in those lower income brackets.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the funding of the tax cuts contained in the Bill, nowhere is there mentioned in the Bill or, more significantly, in the explanatory memorandum, the so-called enhanced compliance measures that were announced by the Government in September—some reference was made to this by Senator Bishop in the second reading debate—because the Bills are based on entirely unsubstantiated claims as to where the funding would come from, rather than identifiable provisions. The Government was forced to reveal pseudo additional revenue sources after it brought down its August Budget because it was unable to fund all its fanciful promises, like the tax cuts included in this Bill.

The Budget contained a secret taxes reference. When the onslaught got too hot and hard to handle, the Treasurer had to act. In response to the obvious huge hole in the Budget, the Treasurer announced a couple of new initiatives to part fill the gap. One of those was a change in the calculation of fringe benefits tax, included in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill 1992.

The other item was a so-called compliance windfall that the then Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, claimed that he had suddenly found on 15 September 1992, just a couple of days before the Government made its announcement. That money was estimated at $1.7 billion over two years. However, for an unexplained reason it does not become available until the first tax cut years, 1994-95 and 1995-96, just in time to fill the Government's Budget gap. Again, for an unexplained reason, that money was also not known at the time of the Budget, a mere month earlier.

The guesstimated figures of the Commissioner and the Treasurer that were released as part of this Bill and its foreshadowing announcement in September have no basis. How can they have any basis when they are currently not collected? Those figures that are ostensibly there to fund at least part of these tax cuts contained in this Bill have no credibility at all.

On behalf of the coalition, I repeat that this Bill and its specific provisions is a sham. It is nothing more than a cheap political fraud. I have no doubt at all it will be seen as such, but I come back to the point I made earlier in the second reading debate, that to a large degree this is, in fact, irrelevant because, when in government after the next election, the Hewson government will introduce the tax reform agenda that it has announced, and that will overtake this Bill. The Bill is a sham. It is an attempt to buy a few cheap political votes. It will be seen as nothing more than that. I have no doubt at all that this Bill and its provisions will catapult, in a quite counterproductive way, on the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Short to explain to those people of Australia who are listening, and those who may watch at some time when this debate is broadcast, given his criticism in his comments in the second reading debate, why he speaks one way and votes differently. I think that it is a distinction which is not clearly understood by the Australian people: why he criticises the Bill but votes for it.

—The people of Australia have to learn to live with this disastrous Government. The Government will stand or fall on the totality of its legislation, including this legislation which everyone knows is a fraud and a sham. The coalition wants this Government to be, as it will be, judged on this legislation, plus the other legislation and the disastrous incompetencies that have marked its term in office. This is part of a continuing, long term chain of incompetence and political shams that the Government has now become noted for and the people of Australia will judge accordingly at election time. I have nothing more to add on that.

—I would like to make a short statement regarding the Tax Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I found myself, mistakenly, on the wrong side of the chamber in that particular division. I was confused as to whether it was a second reading amendment or a vote against the Bill. I had not intended to vote against the Bill, and I would like the record to show that. I offer, as an ameliorating factor, the fact that we sat very late last night. I had about one hour's sleep last night; I think we are all in that position, but I was the one who found myself on the wrong side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments in response to what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) said in his summing up. He said that these tax cuts were targeted, but it is a fact that, in the targeting that the Government has chosen, 60 per cent of women are left out by virtue of the fact that they occupy a great many part time jobs, and 46 per cent of Australians will receive no tax cut at all. In times of high and projected continuing unemployment, it is time for a radical rethink about how we share the burden of unemployment in this country. Paying a jobs levy, as suggested by the Australian Democrats, is one way; paying more tax is another.

PARA.TAB: I would like to quote Dr Ian Manning, from the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research, who gave evidence to the public hearing of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration yesterday. He explained a comment by Brother Mark O'Connor from the Catholic Bishops Committee for Justice, Development and Peace. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Brother Mark used the strange Catholic words `structures of sin'.
I find that a really interesting concept—the structures of sin. He continued:

To try to translate that into economists' terms, there is at least a component in that of poor incentives, of rewards being given to people who do not particularly deserve them and failure to reward people who are contributing a great deal more to the common good. This, of course, means attention to micro-economics, and broad tax cuts which assist people whatever their micro-economic contribution are rather beside the point.
I would like to commend that to the Parliamentary Secretary for his consideration.

PARA.TAB: The second point made by the Parliamentary Secretary upon which I would like to comment is what he said about the Government's right to legislate into the future. Technically, the Government has that right, but it is most unusual. Governments usually confine themselves to making promises and letting Australians judge on the competing promises. It is most unusual and most inappropriate to attempt to bind the hands of a

SPEECH.PARA: future parliament in this way. I agree with Paddy McGuinness that, in seeking to legislate when knowing the composition of the future Senate, we could very well build a fiscal crisis into the future. I think that is most regrettable.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the Bill contains amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to allow certain flat dollar superannuation contributions which are linked to the earnings of a standard employee to be acceptable for superannuation guarantee purposes.
Those amendments are presently limited to employers making superannuation contributions in accordance with an industrial award or law in place prior to 21 August 1991.

The amendment now proposed will extend those standard earnings base measures to employers in the NSW coal industry who make superannuation contributions for employees in accordance with a new industrial agreement called the New South Wales Coal Mining Industry Statutory Superannuation Fund (Salary Sacrifice) Agreement.

The amendment will allow this new agreement to be accepted as an industrial award which was in place prior to 21 August 1991. This will have the effect of allowing the standard employee earnings base in the agreement to be acceptable for superannuation guarantee purposes.

Further minor amendments are also proposed. One is to extend the time for an employer to obtain a statement from a superannuation scheme so that benefit certificates in relation to it are deemed to relate to a complying superannuation scheme; the extended time will be 30 days after the Bill receives Royal Assent. The other is to clarify that, when Royal Assent is given to the Bill, retired persons will be able to transfer certain benefits into superannuation funds irrespective of whether they retired before or after the date of Royal Assent.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the Supplementary Explanatory Memorandum being circulated to Honourable Senators.
Mr President, I commend the amendments to the Senate.

—I do not think there is anything more to be said on those amendments. We support them and, therefore, they can be put.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one other matter, which relates to clause 7 of the Bill.
