In relation to the self-employed, particularly company directors, would the Parliamentary Secretary confirm whether there will be some classes of persons who will, as a result of being required to have SGC contributions made on their behalf, lose the ability to provide for their own superannuation on a tax deductible basis? If that is so, is that deliberate government intent? If so, why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to the normal qualification that if that income on which the superannuation guarantee being paid is less than 10 per cent of income, the separate category applies and the problem does not arise. Otherwise that is the situation.

—The intention is that, even though they might have currently existing quite generous arrangements, they will be effectively precluded from accessing them as a result of the compulsory regime being imposed upon them against their will?
—They will not be precluded from accessing them; they will be

SPEECH.PARA: precluded from getting a tax deduction on future contributions to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it also the case that someone working, for example, as a nanny for 25 hours a week will neither gain superannuation guarantee charge benefits nor be able to make tax deductible contributions if the employment represents more than 10 per cent of that person's total assessable income?
—I am advised that the answer to that question is no. If the levy is not payable on that person's behalf, he or she still has the eligibility for deductions under the existing provisions.
—It has been suggested that the definition of eligible employment should cover only those employees actually entitled to the benefit of the SGC. Is that the Government's intention?

—The situation should be as Senator Alston outlines. It is also the understanding, on which I based the previous advice, that that is the effect of it as drafted. Now that we have amended the Bill and it has to go back to the House, I will undertake to have an examination to make sure that is what the words properly say. I will either take action in the House or advise the Senate to do so.

PARA.TAB: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INVESTMENT) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has great difficulty with the package before us at present in terms of the foreign investment funds. Those concerns were outlined both in the second reading debate and in the extensive committee deliberations that took place with a number of outside people concerned about the impact of this legislation. We had earlier pressed the Government to delay the commencement date. That was partially successful in that the implementation date will no longer be 1 July 1992 but 1 January 1993. We requested that the Government extend the commencement date to 1 July 1993. This was not acceptable, and we could get no assurance that such an amendment would receive passage through this chamber.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will have a detrimental effect on many genuine businesses that are exporting Australian expertise where the overseas interest is not a controlling interest. This will be very damaging to the technology industries and those where Australia has built up an expertise. I give examples to indicate the sorts of businesses that we believe are going to be detrimentally affected: car parking and shopping centres. Australian businesses have built up an expertise in this area. They have sent that technology to Europe, particularly to France. Because of local requirements, corporations do not have a majority interest and their interest is below 50 per cent. Those corporations will be caught under the accrual methods even though they make an adequate distribution of income.

We believe this Bill is deficient in so many areas. It fails to recognise what comparable tax jurisdictions, for example, the UK jurisdiction, do in providing an adequate or sufficient distribution. Therefore, the Liberal-National Party coalition, when it gets into government, will have to review the operations of this Act. It was sold on the basis of being an anti-avoidance piece of legislation. The Government has gone far beyond that. In fact, the legislation will be detrimental to many migrants coming to Australia and expatriates returning to Australia bringing home their superannuation policies where those policies are in excess of $50,000.

The Bill has some bad features. It has gone far beyond the original intent, which was the third tier of the anti-avoidance measures in relation to overseas income. We regret the Government's lack of support for the suggestions that have been put forward by the Opposition at the committee and during the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to Senator Watson's concerns about this particular issue, I thank the Committee and honourable senators overall for their consideration and support of this Bill in general. Although the matters are important to the people affected, we are now talking about some minor parts of what is a broad concept and an important one. I thank honourable senators for that support. We have had this debate both in the committee and at the second reading stage. Our view is that the scope, both in breadth and depth with regard to this Bill, has been refined sufficiently to strike a fair balance. History will be the judge, but it has been reviewed both in a consultative process by independent experts and by Senate committees and I think we have as good a balance as we are going to strike. Therefore, the Government intends to persist with the legislation as it stands.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (CAR PARKING) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendment to this Bill and formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 3, after proposed section 39C insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Taxable value of car parking fringe benefits—"marked value" basis [Employer may choose market value basis]

PARA.TAB: "`39CA.(1) An employer may elect that this section apply in relation to any or all of the car parking fringe benefits in relation to the employer in relation to a particular year of tax.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Market value basis of working out taxable value]

PARA.TAB: `(2) Subject to this Part, if an election is made under subsection (1) in relation to a car parking fringe benefit provided on a day in a year of tax, the taxable value, in relation to the year of tax, of the fringe benefit is:

(a)the amount that the recipient could reasonably be expected to have been required to pay the provider in respect of the provision of the benefit if it were assumed that the provider and the recipient were dealing with each other at arm's length;

SPEECH.PARA: reduced by:

PARA.TAB: (b)the amount of the recipients contribution.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Valuer's report must be given to employer]

PARA.TAB: `(3) An election purporting to be made under subsection (1) in relation to one or more car parking fringe benefits is of no effect unless:
(a)a suitably qualified valuer gives to the employer, before the declaration date, a report, in a form approved by the Commissioner, about the valuation of the fringe benefits; and
(b)the valuer is at arm's length in relation to the valuation; and
(c)the return of the employer of the year of tax, in so far as it relates to the taxable values of the fringe benefits, is based on the report.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government amendment provides for an alternative in terms of the method of assessing the amount of fringe benefits tax that will be applied in terms of this particular legislation. In a limited sense, it will render an alternative which will provide a lesser payment of tax in certain limiting circumstances. To that extent, we agree with the amendment, but I give notice that we will have a further amendment of our own.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Liberal-National Party coalition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:
"2A. The provisions of this Act do not apply to scientific, religious, charitable or educational institutions.

The Liberal-National Party does not wish to be associated in any way with a tax of this nature on education. Further, we do not wish to be associated with a tax on religious institutions. I think that we are essentially a Christian country, but the tax will of course apply to other religions such as the muslim religion and so on.

PARA.TAB: There was a thought amongst certain people that perhaps charities could be included as religious, but to remove any doubt in certain quarters we have included the word `religious'. But it is certainly our intention to cover religious organisations.

So, in effect, the Opposition amendment will mean that the car parking tax will not apply to government schools, private schools or universities. We believe that to impose a tax that some would pay and others, depending on their location from a car park, would not pay would be just so discriminatory and could, certainly in the private sector, affect the viability of private schools. Generally, charitable organisations will not be affected in a major way from the point of view of revenue, but from the point of view of equity we have included them.

The Government, according to this legislation, expects to receive $90m in the first year. According to the Budget Papers, the figure is $120m. We believe that either of those figures can still be achieved because the Government has grossly underestimated the revenue to be derived from this measure. It will have a tremendous impact in terms of revenue raising across the business community and all those other organisations. So the actual amount will be far in excess of either of those amounts.

We have sought to exclude but a small part of the organisations that would otherwise be caught up in this heinous and dreadful car parking legislation. This is another tax on business. Business is most unhappy with this tax.

This legislation went through a committee process in which we had more witnesses than any other committee that I have been associated with in the taxation field. I believe that the submissions and the presentations, particularly from the education authorities, were such that we just could not stand by and allow these taxes to be imposed on religious organisations.

The Parliamentary Secretary said that the Government intended to provide certain regulations, which we have not seen, which in certain circumstances could exempt certain schools. That had a lot of worries for us. Again, because of the discriminatory nature of the tax, we believed it was unfair to place that sort of cloud over schools. We thought it was even unfair for a Minister to have to make those sorts of judgmental decisions as to who should be caught within that net and who should be excluded.

We believe that we have honoured our Budget commitment to the Government in that this coalition is not denying the revenue that the Government sought. We believe that the revenue is going to be very much greater than what has been outlined. Already, as a result of an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Fringe Benefits Tax Measures) Bill, the Government has diminished its own revenue take anyway because of the taking away, the grossing-up effect, by virtue of the previous amendment 65J.(1)(a) to (l).

The Government has recognised that. We seek to make a small change in relation to religious, charitable and educational institutions. We do not discriminate between the public and the private sectors, and we hope that we will get the support of the Independents, the Democrats and even fair-minded people on the Government side. I hope the Government will accept our amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the fair-minded people on the Government side, I indicate that we have two concerns with the Opposition's proposed amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill. One, which I think Senator Watson will accept, is a drafting matter—I will raise this as I go through—which is, I think, common to how he wishes to proceed and would allow him to achieve his purpose. The second concern deals with the way in which we would prefer to see this amendment proceed if it must proceed.

PARA.TAB: We have to be careful when we say that we do not agree, for example, with taxing education. Let us make it quite clear that the fringe benefits tax legislation at the moment applies to schools. In the Bill we just carried, we voted that it continue to apply to schools at the existing rate. It applies to private schools, public schools, universities and TAFE colleges. It applies to educational institutions; it always has and it always should. Let me make that clear.

The fringe benefits tax also applies to scientific, religious and charitable institutions. Those three terms—other than educational institutions, because I think that is fairly clear—are very difficult terms to define. In a different context I think there is some degree of precedent about the meaning of those three words in the tax law. But they are here in a different context and we will have significant argument about what they mean. But I want to come back to that in a moment.

I now want to focus on how we think the amendment should read. I draw Senator Kernot's attention to this proposal too. There are two ways in which we would change it. One I think Senator Watson will agree with, and one goes to substance. Our first problem—the drafting problem—is that saying, `The provisions of this Act do not apply to' is too broad. For example, this Act denies deductibility to employees of their car parking expenses and we do not wish to have that, I assume, not apply to people who work for these sorts of bodies. There is no reason why those employees should be placed in a different circumstance. So I assume that what Senator Watson wishes his amendment to read is, `The provisions of this Act do not apply to benefits provided to employees of'—and then he sets down the categories. I think that actually achieves the purpose which Senator Watson wishes.

We would like to do a second thing. I made this clear to Senator Watson. We prefer not to have this amendment at all. If I had an indication that that was a possible outcome, that would be the Government's preferred outcome. But, if we cannot have that, our second option, apart from that drafting point, is to limit the application to schools. I understand, and we heard at a committee hearing, that there is significant concern, particularly expressed by private schools, in an Australian sense of the word—the British would call them public schools, but let us keep it sensible in Australian language—which were represented at the hearing. We understand the Opposition's desire, if it is going in that direction, to apply the principle equally to government schools.

We would not have done either of those two things, but we could live with that, if we must have an amendment of some sort. We could even recognise some net benefit in that. We do not think it is an enhancement, because there are other ways in which the outcome for the schools and individuals in question could have been better handled. But if the Senate is of a mind to carry such an amendment, we would like it to read: `The provisions of this Act do not apply to benefits provided to employees of schools'.

Having made my point about the drafting, I now address our concerns about the breadth of the exemption that is being proposed, even when it has been properly drafted. The words `scientific, religious and charitable' do not have a definition in this or in any of the accompanying tax legislation to which people would look for interpretation. In the amendments to the previous fringe benefits tax legislation that is not a problem. The wording was exactly the same as the historic wording in the income tax legislation. It is in exactly the same context; it has the same application; and people are confident that they know what the interpretation of that would be. There is a body of precedent and interpretation.

We have taken these three words out of that context and put them here as an initiative with no limitation. With regard to scientific organisations, there is probably no organisation that employs more bachelors of science than does IBM. Is its research laboratory a scientific organisation? I do not know the answer, but we cannot suddenly say no. The court has every right to interpret it in accordance with the normal meaning of the word. Even by speeches in support of the amendment, we cannot require the court to interpret a word other than in its normal meaning. If the normal meaning is not clear, the court can then look to supplementary sources such as the speeches here to determine its interpretation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to do that on many occasions.

—I understand that. But my point is that, when the word has a normal meaning, the courts do not then look to the supplementary explanations; they ask what the word `scientific' means and, if its meaning is clear, the courts quite properly feel bound to deal with the words the Parliament has carried. One does not have to draw as long a bow as the IBM example to realise how broadly we are talking when we use the word `scientific'. There are all sorts of bodies out there, lobbying on behalf of the science community, which do not get the income tax exemption because they are lobbying organisations, but they probably could get in under this.

PARA.TAB: It may well be that the CSIRO is the only arm of government to which this does not apply; nor might it apply to the Institute of Marine Science and such bodies. We are going to have people next door to each other, who are working for the same employer—maybe even doing the same job—with one working for a government department and one working for the CSIRO but under different categorisations. In all those cooperative research centres which are being funded by the Government and which are fundamentality private bodies, half the people who come to work may come from BHP and the other half may come from the CSIRO. How is that going to be interpreted in terms of a scientific institution?

On the face of it, that problem does not arise with the concept of `religious institution' because we all think we know what that means. But Senator Watson would know—I am not sure the rest of the chamber would—that the income tax exemption that applies to religious institutions applies to the Sanitarium Health Food Co. because it is owned by a religious institution. We are not all that happy about that, but the attempt to disentangle that would be too difficult. I suspect that their competitors are even less happy with it, but that is not a matter we are debating today. The Government is not proposing to change that. Certainly this amendment means that that company's advantage is enhanced.

It is a very unpopular thing to do to stand up in any public forum and say any benefit should not apply to any charitable institutions, but we have to make it clear that it is already the case that public benevolent institutions are exempt from fringe benefits tax. So most of the bodies to which most of us would look for the definition of a charity do not get caught because they are public benevolent institutions.

So we are concerned about those three categories and we are concerned about the broad sweep of educational institutions. It would certainly cover private English language ELICOS institutions; it would certainly cover a broad sweep of educational institutions which we believe have got no right to this special provision that is really being sought on behalf of those suburban schools which might be caught up by coincidence. The example we had before the Committee was in the inner western suburbs of Sydney—it may have been Burwood or somewhere in that area. What was raised before the Committee was the concern of a particular school, it being an example of schools of that nature which may get caught by the coincidence of the definition of what constitutes a full day commercial car park, and that there may therefore be an anomalous situation cast upon some schools.

I am not sure that that is actually an unintended consequence of the legislation, but we accept the concern that was articulated by the National Council of Independent Schools of Australia, by the particular private school that came before the Committee and by a number of back bench members of both parties. It has been Government members who have expressed this concern to me, but I am sure others have expressed it to others, and some candidates have expressed it fairly forthrightly to me. The concern has been fundamentally about schools. We are not talking about much money here, because we are talking about a small number of individuals at a very small number of schools around Australia; those which happen by coincidence to be in the CBD, of which there are very few, or which by dint of circumstance get caught because of their relationship to what is interpreted under this legislation as a full day commercial car park.

I suspect that, if the Act went through unamended, the final outcome would be that there would actually be very few caught. But if the chamber is of a mind to say, `That is a consequence that is unacceptable to us', then I urge honourable senators not to cast such a broad net but to have the Bill say that the provisions of this Act do not apply to benefits provided to employees of schools. My concern is in two parts. One is merely drafting. I am sure Senator Watson accepts this part at least of what I am proposing, that, even if he wishes to persist with his broader sweep, it should be that the provisions of this Act do not apply to benefits provided to employees of the institutions which he has designated.

In addition to that drafting change, I urge the Committee to consider limiting this to schools. I think we will then have resolved the concerns that were expressed by such bodies before the Committee without broad revenue and competitive distortions, which I do not think any of us here would intend. I am not trying to imply that the Opposition intends those, and I am therefore urging honourable senators not to open up the possibility of those unintended consequences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer for his remarks. I must point out that it is not unusual in circumstances where people are opposing issues that they take extreme situations. For example, to suggest that, for the purpose of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Fringe Benefits Tax Act, IBM comes under the common parlance definition of scientific, religious or charitable is drawing the net a little too wide.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the generality of the exemptions we are seeking, we acknowledge that these organisations do not generally pay tax. The refinement Senator McMullan suggested—and I am quite happy to go along with that refinement—is not a significant one, but I agree that it does tidy up the provisions. I would like therefore to amend my amendment, if it is going to be a means of getting the Government to agree to it, to insert the words `benefits provided to employees' prior to the words `scientific, religious, charitable or educational institutions'. As we do not have an explanatory memorandum, for the purposes of determining the significance of the words, they have the meanings and connotations normally associated with them in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the fringe benefits tax legislation as it currently stands.

Again, it is very important for the community to know that taxes will not be paid on benefits provided to employees under these various headings: scientific, religious, charitable, or educational institutions. These are the institutions that cannot afford this sort of payment. I must point out that the representations made to the Committee from a number of schools, particularly in the Sydney area, indicated that where there is an enrolment of about 700 students the figures could be as high as $80,000 to over $100,000. It is true that fringe benefits tax applies to fringe benefits provided by the schools, but the payments under the other legislation do not have the financial impact of the sorts of figures I have just presented to the Senate. With respect to car parking, these benefits are provided to teachers who are probably parking on the edge of, or even on, the oval, where their cars might get hit with footballs or cricket balls or have kids climbing over them. They have to park behind washrooms and all over the place. They are not car parks in the sense of what would be provided by a major organisation in downtown Collins Street, Melbourne.

I put it to honourable senators that the amount of money that would be involved in car parking for these sorts of organisations would be horrendous. It has the potential to wipe them out. As I said before, we cannot stand by and see these sorts of monumental impositions applied to religious organisations, charitable organisations and scientific organisations in the normal parlance and in the sense to which the Fringe Benefits Tax Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act relate.

We note that the Parliamentary Secretary would wish it to be confined to schools. I have a particular problem with the discriminatory nature of that. A university such as Melbourne University could have a bill amounting to hundreds of thousands of dollars. It would be a lot of money to be paid by Melbourne University, and yet other universities which are over one kilometre away from a public car park would escape that imposition completely. Many members of the Liberal Party who are keen on the educational fairness area do not wish this horrendous tax to extend in such a discriminatory manner to universities. True, it raises a significant amount of revenue. I reiterate that the Government is confident, and we are confident, that this tax will not impede in any way the collection of revenue of between $90m and $120m in the first year, as outlined in the various documents. Whichever figure is taken, the amendment will not lessen that figure. It is true that it will reduce the overall take, but we believe that the Government has underestimated the tax take from this car parking levy. The impact will be so great that the Government will receive lots more money—of the dimensions it put forward, for example, when it first legislated for capital gains tax. It was a minimal amount the Government expected to take, but what happened when the returns started coming in? The same sorts of figures came up.

The definition of a commercial car park is far wider than people generally think. Some of the examples given to the Committee indicate that a lot more businesses are going to get caught and that there is a lot more bookkeeping. We would like to knock out this whole legislation because it will have such a severe impact on business; it is another cost on business. We do not like it, but particularly we cannot stand by these taxes on religion and education.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—Senator Watson, are you seeking leave to amend your amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 2, page 1, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "2A. The provisions of this Act do not apply to benefits provided to employees of scientific, religious, charitable or educational institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats think that the principle of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill is a great idea. However, as the weeks have elapsed it seems to us that a lot of problems in the administration of it have been highlighted. We like Senator Watson's amendment, but I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether there is not a public safety aspect to university campuses, for example. If the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has indicated his willingness to exclude night shift workers, is there not some argument to be put for afternoon shift workers, who start at 2 o'clock and finish about 11 p.m.? I understand the Government's concern with the broad sweep of educational institutions—I am not happy about ELICOS, for example, being included—but I think it is preferable to go with the way it is rather than seek to confine it simply to schools in the way that the honourable senator would wish us to do.

PARA.TAB: Also, this legislation presupposes good public transport systems, which we do not have. We are trying to encourage people to use these systems—I am talking about students, nurses, teachers, et cetera—but I do not think those systems are yet sufficiently in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to debate the examples given by Senator Kernot. I do not share the concern but I also can count, and I know that a lot of people have been cooperating very strenuously to assist the passage of the program. The Government does not accept, and will not accept, the amendment in the form in which it is being proposed. I thank Senator Watson for accepting the drafting change, but we will seek, I suspect, to change this in the House of Representatives. We will then discuss it with representatives of the Opposition and the Democrats on that basis rather than trying to do it on the run here and using up the time of the Committee when we could be dealing with other important matters. I simply say that we do not like that form of words, although we understand what honourable senators opposite are trying to do. If they do it in the more limited way we propose we could agree. If they are not prepared to do it in that more limited way, and if the majority in this place wish to do that, then let the Committee do that. We can then get on with our other business and we will have time during the remaining couple of days this week to try to resolve the matter before us.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

(a)published in the Gazette; and
(b)made available, without charge, to any interested person.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Matters to be taken into account in making guidelines]

PARA.TAB: `(3) In making commercial government bodies guidelines about a particular kind of eligible government body, the matters to which the Board is to have regard include, but are not limited to:
(a)the commercial environment in which the eligible government body operates; and
(b)whether there is a framework for the oversight of the operations, and the monitoring of the performance, of the eligible government body and, if so, the nature of that framework; and
(c)the extent to which the eligible government body is:

TAB.TAB: (i)bound by regulatory laws of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories; and
(ii)subject to taxation and charges under the laws of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories; and

PARA.TAB: (d)the extent of private sector equity investment (whether direct or indirect through one or more interposed companies, partnerships or trusts) in the eligible government body; and

(e)if the eligible government body is established by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory—the policies of the Commonwealth, the State or the Territory, as the case requires, regarding the issue of the extent to which the eligible government body should be treated as a fully commercial entity.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Tax-exempt bodies ineligible for entry on Register]

PARA.TAB: `(4) The commercial government bodies guidelines must set out a criterion to the effect that an eligible government body will not be entered on the Register of Commercial Government Bodies with effect on a particular day if, assuming that the body had derived income on that day, that income would have been exempt from income tax because of a relevant exempting provision (within the meaning of section 160K of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936).
`(5) An instrument formulating commercial government bodies guidelines is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Applications for entry on the Register of Commercial Government Bodies

PARA.TAB: `39HC.(1) An eligible government body may apply to the Board to be entered on the Register of Commercial Government Bodies.
`(2) The application must be:
(a)in writing; and
(b)in a form approved by the Board; and
(c)accompanied by such information as the Board requires.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Board's decision on application for entry on Register of Commercial Government Bodies

PARA.TAB: `39HD.(1) After considering an application under section 39HC, the Board must decide to:
(a)grant the application; or
(b)refuse the application.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Board deemed to have refused application if no decision made within 90 days]

PARA.TAB: `(2) If the Board has not made a decision under subsection (1) before whichever time ("eligible time") is the later of the following times:
(a)the end of the period ("original 90-day period") of 90 days after the day on which the application was received by the Board;

(b)if the Board, by written notice given to the applicant within the original 90-day period, requests the applicant to give further information about the application—the end of the period of 90 days after the Board receives the further information;

SPEECH.PARA: then, at the eligible time, the Board is taken to have made a decision under subsection (1) to refuse the application.

PARA.TAB: `(3) If the Board makes a decision under subsection (1) before the eligible time, the Board must give written notice of the decision to the applicant.
`(4) A notice under subsection (3) relating to a refusal must set out the reasons for the refusal.
`(5) If the Board decides to grant the application, the entry of the eligible government body takes effect on:
(a)the day on which the decision is made; or
(b)if the applicant requests—such earlier date as the Board specifies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Entry may take effect on a date earlier than commencement of this section]

PARA.TAB: `(6) The Board may specify a date under paragraph (5)(b) that is earlier than the commencement of this section.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [Back-dated entries—Register taken to have been in existence]

PARA.TAB: `(7) If the Board specifies such an earlier date, this Part and section 73CB of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 have effect as if the Register of Commercial Government Bodies had been in existence on that date.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of application for entry on Register of Commercial Government Bodies

PARA.TAB: `39HE. The Board must not grant an application under section 39HC unless the Board is satisfied that the applicant meets the criteria set out in the commercial government bodies guidelines.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Removal from Register of Commercial Government Bodies
[Removal of body which does not meet criteria set out in guidelines]

PARA.TAB: `39HF.(1) The Board must remove an eligible government body from the Register of Commercial Government Bodies if the Board is satisfied that the body does not meet the criteria set out in the commercial government bodies guidelines.
`(2) The Board must not remove an eligible government body from the Register of Commercial Government Bodies unless the Board has:
(a)given a written notice to the body:

TAB.TAB: (i)stating that the Board is considering removing the body from the Register of Commercial Government Bodies; and
(ii)giving the reasons for considering the removal of the body; and

PARA.TAB: (b)invited the body to make a written submission to the Board:

TAB.TAB: (i)within 60 days of receiving the notice; and
(ii)about the proposed removal; and

PARA.TAB: (c)if such a submission is made within that period—had regard to the matters raised in the submission.

`(3) If the Board decides to remove the body from the Register of Commercial Government Bodies, the removal takes effect on the day on which the notice mentioned in paragraph (2)(a) was given to the body.
`(4) If the Board decides to remove the body from the Register of Commercial Government Bodies, the Board must give written notice of the removal to the body.'.

SPEECH.PARA: I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum, a further supplementary explanatory memorandum and an additional further supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to this Bill. I seek leave to incorporate the explanatory remarks with regard to those amendments.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment will make it perfectly clear that where Australia has concluded a double tax agreement with another country, the rules set out in the agreement will apply to royalties derived by residents of that country who carry on business in Australia through a permanent establishment such as a branch. That is, the royalties will continue to be taxed at normal rates of tax with allowance for expenses incurred in deriving the royalty income.

The supplementary amendments to the research and development (R&D) changes in the Bill give effect to the Government's policy that government bodies and associates which operate on a fully commercial basis should not be treated any differently from private business enterprises.

Guidelines will be prepared by the Industry Research and Development Board in consultation with relevant interested parties. These guidelines will list the criteria that need to be satisfied for a government body or associate to qualify as a commercial government body.

A register will be prepared and administered by the Industry Research and Development Board listing the names of those government bodies or associates that have applied and satisfy the guidelines. R&D deductions will not be denied to investors in R&D syndicates or other financing arrangements involving listed government bodies or associates, even if guarantees are offered.

The further supplementary amendments to the R&D changes will provide transitional measures for companies whose R&D proposals were approved, or for which approval was sought, between 31 March 1992 and 10 June 1992.

Companies whose projects qualify for the transitional measure will not be denied deductions for expenditure on the R&D activities related to those projects where the expenditure is incurred to certain government bodies and the investor is not fully at risk.

Following upon changes made to the entry for home consumption provisions of the Customs Act, consequential amendments need to be made to the sales tax law. Where sales tax is payable at the time of importation of goods, it is payable at the same time as Customs duty, that is on the entry of the goods. With the introduction of electronic lodgment for Customs entries, the sales tax provisions are no longer in alignment with the Customs entry provisions. This Bill will amend the relevant sales tax provisions to bring them back into line with the Customs entry provisions.
None of the amendments will have any financial impact.
I commend the amendments to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1PAGE 7 CLAUSE 6

PARA.TAB: Insert new para (d)
", or a nominated candidate," after "party" in new clause 78 (1B)

SPEECH.PARA: 2PAGE 10 CLAUSE 9

PARA.TAB: Insert new Clause 9A

SPEECH.PARA: 9A. Subparagraph 23(g)(v) of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after "purposes" the following words "including an organisation which satisfies the criteria for listing under section 78AB(1)

These are tidying up amendments. The first one arises from the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill that we passed at the end of last year. I think it is convenient to tackle at this point in the legislative program something that I believe we overlooked in that Bill.

PARA.TAB: The No. 5 Bill proposes to move the provision dealing with tax deductibility of political donations from the deduction provisions in section 51 of the Assessment Act to the gift provisions in section 78. We support that, but in preparing for this it has come to our attention that the rule which allows a deduction of up to $100 for donations to political parties is unfair in that it discriminates against those candidates who are not members of a registered political party. I did not intend to overlook that when we debated this matter in December last year.

What it means is that an independent candidate is at a fundraising disadvantage relative to a candidate from a party contesting the same division. We think that donations to candidates contesting the same election should be treated equally by the tax law. Currently only donations to a registered political party qualify for deductibility. The amendment will remedy this by allowing deductibility for contributions to nominated candidates as well as to registered political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am having a bit of difficulty with the first of Senator Kernot's amendments because the advisers seem to think that there is still a drafting problem. But let me go to the substance and not fiddle around with that. We will come back to the drafting problem later. The Government's fundamental position is that we do not agree with the deduction in the first instance, so we are not of a view that it should be amended. We do not think it should be there at all. One of those quirky little things that happen to legislation when it passes the Senate is that we get add-ons. We do not like it. I have not got much more to say about that at this stage. I may come back to it.

PARA.TAB: I have got something to say about the second one. When I read it, the significance of it did not leap off the page immediately. What we are talking about now is that certain organisations have had extended to them a benefit—that people can make tax deductible donations to them—which is at some cost. The rest of Australia is saying that we will subsidise these organisations in the way that we subsidise a lot of other organisations because we consider them worth while. Not only do we want to encourage individuals to contribute but we want to subsidise them to do so. We are now also going to say that those organisations are exempt from income tax, without being able at this stage to say what all those organisations are.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is going to be a register.

—That is right. I do not think there is anybody in this Senate who knows who all those organisations are and what it is that makes them more suitable to be exempt from income tax than a lot of other organisations to which deductible contributions can be made.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the Committee should go down that path. There is a limited range of people who are eligible to receive tax deductible donations and within that group there is a broad range of organisations. I think that, if we were being rigorous about it, we would say that there is more there than should be there and some should be taken out. But let us put that to one side. There are many organisations which everybody would accept are the sorts of organisations which ought to be there if there are going to be tax deductible donations for anybody.

Suddenly we find one group has been taken out and people are saying that instead of this benefit, which has only recently been extended to some of those organisations, those organisations should get a second round of benefits, whereby their activity would be exempt from income tax. I have not thought this through yet, but some of them conduct commercial activities and run shops. Why on earth should they be able to be income tax exempt to run a shop when a lot of other people are struggling in competition with them? I have not had a lot of time to think about this but it does not seem to me to be an equitable measure. With apologies to an absent colleague, it is like something that seemed like a good idea at the time it was first suggested, but on second thoughts it seems that this is not a course of action that the Committee should take.

I may wish to come back and say more about amendment No. 1, because I am still trying to work out where it fits in the Bill. Apart from anything else, I think there is a drafting problem. I am vigorously opposed to amendment No. 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, there is a little confusion about which amendments are being moved. Perhaps it is only my confusion.
—I am moving the recirculated amendments Nos 1 and 2.
—The paper has `Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6)' at the top, does it?

—It should have `Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5)'. I would also like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that Senator Coulter has circulated an amendment to clause 9 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5).

PARA.TAB: I would like to make a couple of comments to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan). I understand his objection but, if it is taken to its conclusion, it means that where a group of Australians, for example, associate technically to try to protect an endangered animal or to rehabilitate some degraded land then they should not, we believe, be taxed for that community service. That community service should be recognised by the taxation system, and that is what this amendment will effect. We are not seeking to remove the current prohibition on those bodies which are engaged in political or lobbying purposes. We think that, now there is to be a register of environmental organisations which qualify for deductible status, it is time to grant community service status and hence exemption from income tax for those bodies also.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I do not respond to all the points Senator Kernot raised she may wish to reiterate them. I was trying to catch up with the two amendments that are before us at the moment. If I miss something, we will have to come back to it. I apologise for that. Having two ears is not always sufficient to follow all the conversations one is trying to keep up with at the same time.

PARA.TAB: I have two problems with amendment No. 1. It is a little like the last one; there are drafting problems we can fix easily, but there is a substantial problem. In two seconds I thought of a loophole that opens, even though I understand what Senator Kernot is trying to do, now I have got it in context. It is hard to argue against that until we think about the consequences. I think it needs to be done a little more tightly.

The section that should be amended is 78(1)(aaa). Section 78(1B) limits to $100 the amounts which can be contributed; section 78(1)(aaa) gives the eligibility. That is easy to do. If Senator Kernot wishes to persist, I am sure the Committee will give leave for that to be moved in that amended form. We do not need to amend section 78(1B) also; the $100 limit will apply to nominated candidates if the amendment to section 78(1)(aaa) proceeds.

On the face of it, without Senator Kernot having had a chance to think about it, the Labor Party and the Liberal Party will each have 170 candidates at the next election. That simply means that somebody can make a tax deductible donation of $17,000 to all of us because he may send all our candidates $100 each, or he may send the national secretary a cheque for $17,000, saying, `Please distribute this to each of your candidates equally'. That is a $17,000 tax deductible donation to each of the candidates. Maybe Senator Kernot already knew that that was what was involved and that is what she would like, but I do not. I am very unhappy about the $100; I am appalled by the $17,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you explain that again? A nominated candidate, separate from a registered party?
—I will be a nominated candidate at the next election—
—But you will be registered by your Party.

—Yes, but I am not my Party; I am a nominated candidate. It will be a separate designation in the Income Tax Act if Senator Kernot moves this amendment, and it is a separate category under the Electoral Act. This is not a considered legal opinion; it is an expression of serious concern. Not everybody in this place will be a candidate because we are not all up for re-election, but I certainly will be. All the major parties will have 170 candidates. If somebody can give a $100 tax deductible donation to each candidate, he can give a $17,000 tax deductible donation to each political party. The old Pandora's box, which we were trying to close and which Senator Kernot helped us close, would reopen, and we do not wish to see that happen.

PARA.TAB: It may be possible in some way, if we must go down this path at some future occasion, to draft an amendment that would not cause that problem, although I cannot on the face of it see how. It may be possible, but this amendment does not do it. I urge Senator Kernot not to proceed with amendment No. 1.

I want to come back to amendment No. 2. I do not know whether the Opposition has considered this amendment. I had to give it some consideration because I do not immediately know what all the provisions of subsections 23G(5) and 78AB(1) are. It is a terrible confession to make that I do not immediately have to mind the words of every subsection of the Tax Act. I am 20 years behind some people who have been accumulating that information in this chamber, so I make that confession readily.

I have now confirmed that all it means is that people on the environment register will be income tax exempt—that is, the Wilderness Society running its shops, and all those other people, but not, for example, people on the foreign aid register or those relating to the arts or charitable institutions. I think that we cannot go down that direction. It may be a necessary part of one's green credentials to move such an amendment, but I am sure that we do not need to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like to act in haste on amendment No. 1. If the Parliamentary Secretary will give me an undertaking that we can revisit this amendment, I am happy to withdraw it. I would need that undertaking.
—Revisit when?

—The Parliamentary Secretary knows when the election will be. I am just seeking an indication from him that we can revisit this amendment. It may not be possible, although it would be preferable, to have some more time spent on it this week, given the uncertainty of what is going to happen to this Parliament in February and March.

—I am happy to give that undertaking, for two reasons. One is that it may be that on more rigorous scrutiny, the problem is either not as great as I think, or maybe does not even exist. We all have to pore over it. The second reason—just to reiterate—is that the Government does not like the amendment in the first place, but if it does apply to parties and if we can make it apply to candidates not of parties without blowing open the whole thing, then there is some equity in that. We would rather have equity so that no-one got it, but if it is going to exist, I accept that there is some argument at least to say that it should be able to apply to independent candidates as well as to parties.

PARA.TAB: Yes, I am happy to give that assurance. The problem may not be as profound as I had thought. It just leaped off the page to me as a potential problem. I doubt that we will have a chance this session, because I do not think that this Bill will come back to us. If it does not, certainly that can be done at the first opportunity. There will be other tax Bills next session, whenever that may be, and we can have a look at it then.
Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendment No. 2 be agreed to.

—The coalition would wish to give this amendment deeper and further consideration. I think that it is the sort of issue that can be revisited on another occasion when similar legislation is presented before the Parliament. It is very difficult, when legislation is introduced with such haste and debates are brought on so quickly, to get the scheme of things right. I think that today's concerns by the coalition and by the Democrats and others are indicative of our intention to try to get the legislation right, to make sure that there is equity and justice and fairness, because a taxation system that does not meet those sorts of criteria is indeed a bad one.

PARA.TAB: I think that both the Democrats and ourselves are seeking to achieve those purposes in a very difficult time frame in the heat of the lead-up to an election and, while we have a great deal of sympathy for the Democrat amendments, I think that in relation to all of them, I would like to revisit them on another occasion.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 9, page 9, proposed subsection 78AB(6), after the subsection, insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(6A) Directions given under subsection (6) are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deals with the tax deductibility of donations to conservation bodies. The situation which has obtained until now is that a limited number of conservation bodies have had tax deductible status. The Australian Conservation Foundation, the organisation that I know best because I was on its council for 17 years, had a scheme by which donations made to that body could be accompanied by a letter indicating a preference for the direction in which that donation was to be spent. Through that mechanism, tax deductible status was extended, effectively, to other groups, but involving enormous hassles and administrative costs for the Australian Conservation Foundation and the other organisations.

PARA.TAB: What the Government is seeking to do here is to remove that system of tax deductibility and replace it with a list under which, as I understand it, a much more extensive group of conservation bodies will achieve tax deductible status directly and in their own right. I understand that the conservation bodies are very happy with that arrangement and certainly it will relieve the Australian Conservation Foundation and several of the other major national bodies of that administrative burden of passing donations on where donors indicated a preference.

I think the notion that there should be a tax deductible status for conservation bodies should be strongly defended, particularly in view of the attacks that have been made on that tax deductibility by some members of the Opposition over a considerable period. I point to the fact that those who would advertise in a promotional way do so to increase the sale of a particular good or service but do it in a way which seeks to change the perception of the person to whom the advertising is directed. Their interest is in changing the perception to include the consumption of the good or service. That sort of advertising attracts tax deductibility.

The conservation bodies, on the other hand, advertise not because it will provide any direct benefit for them but because they believe that in the public interest it is important to change the public perceptions to a different point of view, and all that the conservation bodies get out of it is their share of what they perceive as the common good. I think, on that philosophical ground, one could more strongly defend the right of conservation bodies to have tax deductibility, rather than promotional advertising by commercial interests. So I do not think the desirability of conservation bodies having tax deductibility can seriously be tackled on philosophical grounds.

This particular amendment relates to the process of de-listing, once a body has run the gamut of both the Treasurer and the environment Minister. I noticed that throughout a number of clauses dealing with this section both these Ministers have to be satisfied; there is the word `and' in every clause. It is the environment Minister and the Treasurer that have to do certain things.

These organisations have run that gauntlet. They have been assessed in terms of the eligibility criteria for registration in order to get onto the list. This amendment seeks quite simply to ensure that, in the process of de-listing, they come back before the Parliament because we are aware, and the conservation groups are very much aware, that there are very powerful vested interests in the community which are inimical to the interests of conservation groups and we would not like to see the process of de-listing carried on simply by the two Ministers putting their heads together, under strong pressure to take a particular organisation off the list. It is therefore appropriate that that decision be reviewed by the Parliament and that good reasons be brought forward as to why an organisation, having achieved tax deductible status, should have its name removed from that list.

While I am on my feet, and to save time, I would like an assurance from the Government on another aspect that is absolutely vital. Under this amending legislation, the existing organisations that have tax deductible status will lose that tax deductible status and this provision will come in in its place. The replacement, of course, is dependent upon the Treasurer and the Minister for the environment as quickly as possible constructing that registered list. I would like an assurance from the Government that when this legislation is passed, as it will be very shortly, the Government will make every effort to ensure that that list is constructed as quickly as possible so that those organisations that attain tax deductible status under this legislation will not be left in limbo and possibly fall through a hole because there is an election to be held before 1 July, when these provisions would come into effect. I would like to receive that assurance from the Government so that the conservation groups can be certain of the circumstances under which they will operate post-July, particularly in view of the fact that before July there must be an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coulter for his amendment. I do recognise, from a tax point of view, that it is very significant and represents the sort of direction in which we probably should be moving. The amendment is somewhat similar to matters the Opposition has been giving deep consideration to over many months now. Our drafting would be somewhat different but I think the intent would be similar.

PARA.TAB: The issue is certainly very important from the perspective of those who are in opposition, but for those who are in government, given the nature and composition of this Senate, it certainly would take away a degree of flexibility in the case of certain organisations becoming misdirected in the process of their activities. For that purpose, at this time I would have some difficulty with the amendment, because we are going through the pros and cons of the issue of disallowable instruments, and the impact they can have, particularly where organisations, as it were, go off the rails.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will first respond to Senator Coulter's particular request. I am advised that there will be no gap between the people having tax deductibility under one categorisation or one system and then the introduction of the other arrangement. I am assured that there will not be any such gap. If Senator Coulter wants a more detailed response, we might talk subsequently, but I am assured that that problem should not arise.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the substance of the proposal, I understand what Senator Coulter is concerned about. We do not wish to see an organisation easily discriminated against, but this register is a very significant enhancement of the situation, as Senator Coulter acknowledged, and I do not think we want to go down this particular route. We already have a register in operation for cultural organisations, which does not have this provision. I certainly do not think we should have a one-off for groups we like. I am not casting any aspersions on the Democrats' attitude to cultural organisations. That is a concern others might wish to enjoy raising; I do not intend to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like your attitude to trade unions or the Opposition's attitude to business?

—No. I am simply saying there are only two registers, the cultural register and the environmental register, and they should be treated the same. I do not have to administer the register of cultural organisations, but it seems to be working very well. That comment may not be greeted with much enthusiasm by those closer to the firing line, but from a distance it seems to be working well. I am advised that there is quite a turnover: quite frequently a lot of small organisations go out of existence and go off the register. We do not want to be proliferating disallowable instruments in that way with regard to the management of this register.

PARA.TAB: At the moment there has to be some recognition in this Parliament and in this community that one sanction is the sanction of public opinion. That is the democratic sanction. If a future government were to discriminate wilfully against an organisation because it did not like its politics, it would have to take the consequences of having made that decision and be subject to the normal democratic constraints that we all face when we make decisions which people oppose.

So we should not have one rule for people on the environment register and one rule for others. If people want the protection of requiring parliamentary approval to take off, they do not go down the register route; they go down the specific legislative route, and that is cumbersome. I much prefer the register route which we are going down at the moment. Notwithstanding that I accept that the attempt is to protect people against unfair or discriminatory action, I am not persuaded that this is the appropriate way to go about it at this stage. I do not support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not seek to divide on this matter. However, I seek some more assurances from Senator McMullan in relation to the creation of the register. What I heard him say went only to the extent of ensuring that the peak organisations—of which there are few—which now have tax deductible status will certainly be on the register before 1 July.

PARA.TAB: But take, for instance, an organisation like the Conservation Council of South Australia, which has been receiving donations through the Australian Conservation Foundation and therefore attracting indirectly a tax deductible status. Those organisations also want assurances that they will not drop through the net. It is therefore necessary that this register be constructed very quickly—suppose there is an election in February and this register is not constructed?

Clearly, Senator McMullan is anticipating a much larger group because he is talking about smaller groups coming and going, dropping off the list and so on. I do not know how many groups the ACF has acted as a tax deductible umbrella for, but it would be at least tens of groups. I should like some assurance with respect to those groups that the register will be constructed quickly so that those groups can go forward into next year with the assurance that post-July they will have that tax deductible status.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give one assurance and one promise. The assurance is that we will move, and are moving, as quickly as we can with regard to this, and action is already under way. The promise is that I will write to Senator Coulter outlining the process to date and the timetable as I see it, because I do not have all that information and it is not primarily the responsibility of the Taxation Office, it is primarily that of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. SPEECH.PARA: INCOME TAX (DIVIDENDS AND INTEREST WITHHOLDING TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.
Progress reported.
Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Mutual Recognition Bill in some ways is one of the most important pieces of legislation to come before us this year. It provides a mechanism to enhance the free movement of goods and service providers across State and Territory boundaries with the objective of making this country one national market. Under the framework set up by the Bill, the various States and Territories will recognise each other's regulatory standards with respect to both goods and occupations.

PARA.TAB: Agreement was reached at the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference to work towards implementing a scheme of mutual recognition throughout Australia. On 11 May 1992 an agreement was signed by the States and the Commonwealth under which the States requested the Commonwealth to enact legislation to give effect to certain principles of mutual recognition relating to the interstate sale of goods and the carrying on of occupations.

The agreement notes that the heads of government have agreed to establish a scheme for implementation of mutual recognition principles for goods and occupations for the purpose of promoting the goal of the freedom of movement of goods and service providers in a national market in Australia. It requests and empowers the Commonwealth to pass a single Act which will override any State or Territory Acts that are inconsistent with the mutual recognition principles. The Commonwealth has the power to make this legislation through section 51(xxxvii) of the Constitution which provides that the parliament has the power to make laws about matters referred to it by the parliament of any State or States.

This Bill is the Commonwealth's part of a scheme involving the enactment of complementary legislation by the States and the Commonwealth. The Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister (Mr Free) advised the House of Representatives during the second reading of this Bill that New South Wales had already passed the necessary complementary legislation. It has recently been introduced into the parliaments of Victoria, Queensland, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. This scheme has clear support from governments of all political persuasions, which shows that everyone involved recognises the importance of mutual recognition to the Australian economy.

There are clearly many advantages in removing the artificial barriers which restrict the movement of goods and labour between States. There will be cost savings for producers of goods who will no longer need to modify their products in order to meet different standards in different States; there will be benefits from the enhanced mobility of the labour force; and, ultimately, the advantages for producers and suppliers of goods and services will obviously result in benefits for the consumers of those goods and services in terms of increased choice and lower cost.

As my colleague the shadow Attorney-General said in the debate on this Bill in the other place, mutual recognition is an outstanding example of what can be achieved when all governments in Australia work together in the national interest. The coalition, therefore, welcomes this Bill as a start. We commend it and trust that mutual recognition will eventually be extended beyond goods and occupations to other parts of the Australian economy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Mutual Recognition Bill 1992. It introduces a concept adopted by all State and Territory governments of Australia. It promotes the uniformity of standards for goods and occupations across all States and Territories of Australia. The Bill introduces two principles. First, as it applies to goods, it means that goods that can be sold lawfully in one State or Territory may be sold freely in any other State or Territory, even though they may not comply with all the details of regulatory standards in the second State or Territory. As an extension of this principle, it also means that goods manufactured or produced overseas which comply with the standards in the importing State are able to be sold in all other States or Territories.

PARA.TAB: The same principle applies to the recognition of like occupational standards. States and Territories have agreed to empower the Commonwealth to pass a single Act which will override any State or Territory Act or regulation that is inconsistent with the mutual recognition principle.

This is a very important piece of legislation and it marks a major change to our present system. The benefits are that uniform standards across Australia become possible. The adoption of mutual recognition forms part of the new federalism and is directed at removing present inefficiencies that arise from different State regulations on goods and occupations.

Adoption of the principle arose from meetings between the Premiers and the former Prime Minister over the last two years. The heads of agreement between the Commonwealth and the States was signed on 11 May this year and a legislative program was proposed for the State legislation to be enacted by 31 October this year and the Commonwealth legislation by January 1993.

By passing this Bill, the Commonwealth is meeting its deadline, but as yet all States have not passed the necessary legislation. Mutual recognition has not received a lot of public exposure or discussion. It does mean that a lot of State areas of responsibility are transferred. Many State representatives have concerns about how it will eventually affect some of their State activities.

To this end, it must be remembered that Australia is a big country and many State standards are geared towards special State conditions. Sometimes regulations cannot be applied uniformly across a State due to the great diversity of working and living conditions found in Australia. It is hoped that mutual recognition will never lead to ridiculously high and costly standards being imposed on businesses and operations where, for example, they may be required in densely populated areas of Australia but not in the remote areas.

As part of the cooperative federalism and because the States have agreed to this major step on behalf of State organisations and individuals, all State governments have an obligation to ensure that the purpose of mutual recognition is achieved. States must ensure that standards are not lowered to the detriment of industries and, ultimately, Australia. Our high quality and standard of produce in agriculture and manufacturing are the reasons for our great success on export markets. There is a fear that the standard of the lowest common denominator State may become the standard for goods or occupations. Such an outcome must be guarded against and acted upon by the States.

The introduction of a uniform standard by means of applying the principle of mutual recognition will have an effect on the functioning of many State organisations. This will need addressing so that damage is not done to our high quality industries. There is a need to ensure that the Australian standard which is eventually adopted and which sets a uniform national standard is the most advantageous standard for Australian industry and its consumers.

Unless a proper national standard is set at the States' insistence in practical terms, it means that the national standard could become the standard of the State or Territory that has the lowest standard. A real danger lies here with imported goods. Under mutual recognition, any imported good that meets the standard of the first State it is imported into is able to be sold everywhere else in Australia.

However, in some industries where some goods, particularly agricultural goods, are not produced, some States do not have relevant standards. This is where the States must ensure that a national standard is adopted that maintains the high standards of the existing Australian industry. For example, Australia has a dried fruit industry of the highest standard, which in turn guarantees its high international standard on world markets. But because this industry only exists in some States, only those States have strict industry regulations. This is a case where a national standard must be reached between the States. I believe steps have been taken by some States to have a national standard applied. As it now stands, the non-producing States allow a window of opportunity for the importation of substandard produce under mutual recognition.

As well as a relevant national standard being necessary, the Imported Food Control Bill 1992, which is currently on the Senate Notice Paper, will provide a further means of ensuring that substantial imports are not allowed to enter Australia and wreak havoc on the production and quality of our world standard industries. It is in the detailed effects of mutual recognition on individual State industries that the States must monitor and assist if problems arise.

For example, in relation to the Queensland egg industry, which has traditionally organised itself on the basis of a State industry, time will be needed to restructure to gain the most for the industry from changes. The States must make sure that, in the rush to achieve uniform standards, such industries are not irreparably damaged.

I also mention that concerns for the effects of individual industries must be taken into account if mutual recognition is ever extended to New Zealand, under CER, where there are further differences in vital areas such as quarantine. Mutual recognition for goods and occupations comes in with the support of all State and Territory governments. However, in supporting this Bill, I urge all State and Territory governments to meet the State responsibility in endorsing this principle and ensure that their industries and people grow and prosper from the move and that no unintended damage or consequence follows.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support of this legislation. Senator Hill, in his speech, identified the main objectives and value of this legislation. Senator Boswell has supplemented that with a slight Queensland gloss, but otherwise with his usual perspicacity. It is a good example of cooperative federalism at work in the national interest. Honourable senators have said that the aim of mutual recognition is to remove artificial barriers to interstate trade in goods and services and to remove the artificial barriers to the mobility of labour caused by regulatory differences amongst the States. We have had many decades of experience in trying to work with regulatory barriers of that kind, and this legislation will go a long way to improving that situation immensely.

PARA.TAB: If the legislation does that, it will enhance the competitiveness of the Australian economy. It is a major step forward in the achievement of micro-economic reform and will lead to the establishment of a truly national market. I do not think it is necessary for me to say any more than to thank honourable senators for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 will amend the Superannuation Act 1922, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988. The purposes of the amendments include compliance with the superannuation guarantee requirements; compliance with the occupational superannuation standards; streamlining of some of the Commonwealth superannuation schemes; and clarification of some areas of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties note that the proposed amendments will only have a minimal financial impact. The coalition recognises that the Bill is an uncontentious one, it being a matter of technical amendments and clarifying amendments. The coalition does not oppose the passage of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Parer, both for his support and his brevity.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Pipeline Authority Amendment Bill 1992. The primary reason for the Bill is to set up a subsidiary of the Pipeline Authority to operate the Authority's commercial sectors. During the committee stage in the House of Representatives, the Opposition moved an amendment that received the agreement of the Government. I understand that it is incorporated in the legislation we are debating today. The amendment ensures that the Government will privatise the Pipeline Authority—or that nothing will be done to prevent the sale or disposal of a pipeline.

PARA.TAB: Growth in the natural gas industry over the last 20 years has led to its present position as the third source of primary energy after coal and petroleum in Australia. Australia has abundant proven gas reserves. The 1991-92 annual report of the Authority noted that the projected demand requirements show that the current ratio of proven reserves to annual consumption exceeds 80 years. However, exploring for and proving up gas reserves is still very much a demand driven activity. The main feature of the reform package of this legislation is to provide for the creation of a subsidiary of the Pipeline Authority to undertake those operations that are based on a commercial rate of return.

The Commonwealth's only direct hands-on role in natural gas operations is through the TPA, an independent statutory authority. Existing contracts with the Australian Gas Light Company restrict the Pipeline Authority to a cost recovery non-commercial basis of operating the gas line from Moomba in South Australia to Wilton on the outskirts of Sydney. This gas pipeline system passed about 70 per cent of the total energy consumed by New South Wales.

Lateral pipelines also supply gas from Young to Cootamundra and Wagga Wagga and from Dalton to Canberra. An extension of the pipeline to the Riverina towns of Leeton, Narrandera and Griffith is under consideration. The 1992 Budget announced that the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline system has been reinstated to the program of major asset sales.

Every time an amendment to the Pipeline Authority Act comes up, I cannot help but recall its origins. This was part of what could only be termed a very loony plan by the mentor of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the late R.F.X. Connor, Minister for Minerals and Energy in the Whitlam Government. Topically, it also had links to some degree with the ill-fated Khemlani loans scandal. The plan by Mr Connor, as honourable senators might recall, was to criss-cross Australia with government operated pipelines and use Arab oil money to buy out the rotten multinationals involved in the mining industry. It was typical Labor pie in the sky stuff, and now we see the Labor Government positioning itself to sell the flag bearer of that previous Labor Government.
