It is also interesting to note the comments at the time by the now Prime Minister, Mr Keating. It was the grand plan, as I said, to criss-cross Australia with pipelines. I think it is worth referring to a few of Mr Keating's remarks. He pointed out in the House of Representatives that the first stage was to be laid from Gidgealpa to Sydney, 780 miles, and that, taking into account all the laterals, eventually there would be 5,500 miles of natural gas pipelines. He equated it to the great Snowy Mountains Authority and so on. He then went on to say, and I think this is a comment worth repeating:

SPEECH.PARA: We intend to see that our natural resources are not plundered and raped by private enterprise in this country and are not exploited for their own purposes.

The grand plan, as I mentioned, was to criss-cross Australia and there was also talk at the time about a further pipeline from Palm Valley to Kalgoorlie and an additional spur line from Sydney to Brisbane. It is interesting to see the reason given for the spur line to Kalgoorlie. The remark was made by the then Minister that the reason for that was that Western Australia was short of natural resources, particularly gas. In the light of recent discoveries and what is happening on the North West Shelf, it just shows you how foolish people in this field can be to make those sorts of predictions and be found out in subsequent years to be so wrong.

PARA.TAB: To achieve this grand plan there was to be nationalisation of the plan by the East Australian Pipeline Corporation to acquire what it had already planned in building the pipeline from Gidgealpa. Eastern Australian Pipeline was a subsidiary of AGL. I think it is ironic that the great supporter of the grand plan was the current Prime Minister, who is now presiding over the sale of the pipeline.

The Opposition supports the Bill, which was successfully amended in the other place, as I have indicated earlier. A sale of the pipeline is unlikely to occur before 1993-94 but it is essential that the Authority operate in the most efficient manner leading up to the sale. The proposed legislative reforms would see the Pipeline Authority set up a subsidiary and operate in accordance with the government business enterprise accountability guidelines. In the past the Pipeline Authority has been constrained by its Act and its contracts with AGL in the types of activities that it can undertake and the profitability of those activities, particularly in the haulage of gas on the main Moomba to Sydney pipeline. The new subsidiary would have wider functions than the Pipeline Authority, including the provision of consultancy and transmission support services relating to pipeline construction, design and operation in Australia and overseas.

The coalition regrets that the Government did not take advantage of the opportunity it could have availed itself of a couple of years ago in order to proceed to the privatisation of the pipeline. It is coalition policy to privatise the Pipeline Authority in the first year of achieving government. The Government tried to set aside some commercial contracts that we regarded as having been entered into on an arm's length basis, and sought to change those commercial contracts in midstream. The situation has now been rectified and it would appear, based on decisions that have been handed down in the courts, that the Australian Gas Light Co. may well have had a first right of refusal on the sale of the Pipeline Authority and its assets.

The coalition is of the view that, historically, individuals and companies run enterprises better than governments. Further, if the privatisation process is to achieve the objectives we set out, it is important that employees of any organisation or enterprise that is to be privatised as a part of that process are part of workplace agreements that might arise; also, that they are part of the future ownership of any enterprise that is privatised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Parer for his interesting history lesson and his support for the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL COUNCILS AND ASSOCIATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act was passed in 1976 and came into operation in 1978. It was originally intended to provide a simple and cheap method of incorporation for Aboriginal organisations at a time when State legislation varied widely between the States. This method of incorporation has proved popular, with over 1,600 organisations being incorporated under this legislation. Once incorporated, many organisations seek funding through ATSIC. They are then subject to regulation by the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations. In recent times it has become apparent that the powers of the Registrar to ensure minimal accountability of the organisations are limited.

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal Councils and Associations Amendment Bill proposes 13 amendments to improve procedures of organisations, increase accountability and make organisations' financial affairs open and transparent. First, the amendments specify how general meetings of the association, including annual general meetings, are to be called, and the procedures of the conduct of those meetings, including provisions for proxy votes. Second, they disqualify persons who have been found guilty of fraud or dishonesty from being a member of the governing committee. Third, they set a time limit for the preparation and lodgment of financial returns to make them available to members and to ensure that the auditor is independent of the association. Fourth, the amendments set time limits for holding annual general meetings. Fifth, they ensure that there is compliance with the rules of the association. Sixth, they ensure that members of the governing committee act honestly and disclose any conflicts of interest. Seventh, they allow the Registrar to arbitrate in disputes. Eighth, they empower the Registrar to direct persons to produce any books or records. Ninth, the amendments give the Registrar power to convene meetings where requested or where the committee has resigned. Tenth, they empower the Registrar to appoint an administrator in certain circumstances. Eleventh, they clarify the role and functions of auditors. Twelfth, they introduce simple, straightforward procedures and remedies in relation to inspections and investigations. Thirteenth and lastly, the amendments increase the minimum number of people for registration of an organisation from five to 25.

All these amendments are wholly consistent with the direction the coalition proposes to take in its ATSIC Green Paper; they are not controversial in nature at all. For example, we strongly support No. 13, which increases from five to 25 the number of people for registration. As we understand it, a lot of the existing organisations incorporated under the Act are in fact non-functioning. A recent audit by the registrar of all the organisations that have been incorporated since 1978 has found that something like 400 so far are completely non-functioning, and that inspection is continuing. Although they are non-functioning, they are still registered.

It seems that there could be some merit in looking to move organisations across from this system into the jurisdiction of the Australian Securities Commission. ATSIC has considered this recently but opinion was divided. On balance, ATSIC members have felt at this stage that they wanted to have organisations incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act, which is fine; but in the longer term there would seem to be some merit if we could adequately grandfather existing organisations so that they would be able to transfer across with minimal inconvenience. It would probably be a much better thing to have Aboriginal organisations incorporated under the ASC so that appropriate measures could be taken in those situations where the interests of members needed to be protected from people who perhaps were using them to their own advantage.

In support of that preference for organisations to be incorporated under the ASC, the coalition in government would initiate discussions with ATSIC as to the most appropriate mechanism and timing of such a move, if in fact the coalition was capable of getting agreement with ATSIC on this matter. The coalition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Baume told us, the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act was originally introduced in 1976 in an attempt to provide greater simplicity and flexibility for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and groups, and today we are looking at it with respect to incorporation. We believe simplicity is important in order to ensure that the administrative and financial burden is not too great, and flexibility is vital to ensure that the needs of a wide variety of community organisations are met. It is important that those twin aims are maintained and, if possible, enhanced. The Democrats are satisfied that this legislation does that and, accordingly, we will be supporting this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Since the legislation was first enacted it has become apparent that some aspects of it are less than adequate in enabling the effective functioning of associations. Consequently, we acknowledge the need for amendments clarifying and strengthening the rights of members of associations and ensuring open and adequate accountability to the communities they operate within and on behalf of. Democrats recognise the need to ensure that the opportunity for reform which is presented by this Bill is taken. There are more changes yet which we believe will need to occur, but the amendments contained in this Bill will at least get things moving in the right direction.

In relation to this point, I have been given undertakings by the office of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, that there will be a further review of the principal Act in 1993. On that basis I believe it will be appropriate to consider further fine tuning at that time, rather than in the atmosphere that prevails at this time of the year. So while I have a couple of minor concerns with a couple of the amendments, I think it is important that the improvements and the clarifications contained in this legislation are introduced as soon as possible.

A particular concern I have—I have written to the Minister about this and I hope it will be considered as part of a further examination of the operating of this Act—is about the powers of delegation which have been conferred on the registrar. As was noted by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the registrars are to be given the power to delegate their responsibilities to any person. This power may be too broad. Perhaps consideration should be given to narrowing it, but I acknowledge the difficulty that may occur in this regard because the registrar deals with associations from a range of areas, including geographically remote areas, and it may be difficult to define a specific category of person who should be entitled to receive this delegated authority because of this reality.

Certainly, the change is preferable to the current situation where the registrar can delegate his powers only to the deputy registrar. At this stage, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, on the matters of delegation of power and reversal of the onus of proof.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator B Cooney
Chairman
Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney

I refer to the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No 16 of 1992 (11 November 1992) and to the letter from the Secretary of your Committee dated 12 November 1992 concerning the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Amendment Bill 1992 ("the Bill").
I wish to offer the following comments upon the comments made in that letter.
Delegation of power to `a person'

I agree that as a general proposition there should be appropriate limits placed on powers of delegation of statutory powers. I note the Committee's comment about remoteness being a consideration when the delegation provision was first made. However the remoteness of the locations in which the powers need to be exercised is, in the context of the Bill, now a more compelling consideration than was the case when the original delegation was passed. This is because the Registrar's powers in relation to organisations, many of which are in remote locations, have been considerably enhanced. These enhanced powers include investigation, inspection and arbitration.

The Committee is correct in assuming that I have some idea of the persons to whom the power is likely to be delegated. I would expect that, where possible, government employees, employees of statutory bodies (for example Land Councils) and professional people would be delegates. Again, however, because of the remoteness of many organisations I do not think it is practicable to identify all of the classes of persons who may be delegates. For example, a delegation might be given to a respected Aboriginal community leader who possessed greater intimacy with local issues than a Canberra based Registrar. Any delegation would be a single purpose delegation, limited in scope and for a specific duration.
Reversal of the onus of proof

At the outset I should explain that the policy objective of clause 5 of the bill is to make it more likely that the financial reporting provisions are complied with so that the executives of the organisations are more accountable for the manner in which they handle finances.

In light of the need of that policy objective to make each member of the Council or the Governing Committee responsible for the accounts, records and financial statements of the Council or Committee respectively, it was necessary to provide a defence for the member who was not involved in the business of the body at the relevant time, for instance through absence from the country or illness in hospital.

Further, the provisions relate to financial obligations of the bodies concerned and the liability imposed is likened to the responsibility of partners for the debts and financial obligations of the partnership. In this case this kind of obligation is imposed by statute and it is therefore necessary to provide a statutory defence for the `innocent' member in order to rebut the presumption created. The matters which would go to proof of the defence, on the balance of probabilities, are matters which will be peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant as well as being difficult and costly for the prosecution to negative beyond reasonable doubt. The reversed onus is in my view therefore justified in this case. I understand that this approach is consistent with the principles normally applied by the Senate Committee.

There are a number of precedents for this kind of defence in other areas where financial obligations are imposed. I refer the Committee to sections 165 and 166 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 and subsections 11A(5) and 11B(6) of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990.

Finally I draw the Committee's attention to the relatively low level of penalty attaching to these offences, the regulatory nature of the obligations created and the fact that the defences provide an excuse for what might otherwise be a situation of strict liability made necessary by the policy objective I have referred to above.
Abrogation of the privilege against self-incrimination
I note the Committee's comments on clauses 5, 16 and 21 and the Committee's further comments that these clauses are in a form which the Committee has previously been prepared to accept.

In my view these clauses achieve an appropriate balance between, on the one hand, increased levels of accountability on the part of Aboriginal organisations and the need to protect personal rights and liberties on the other.
Amendment
It is noted that clause 21 of the Bill contains an error and the matter will be taken up with the drafter.
I trust the above information will meet the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
Robert Tickner

Whilst more high profile measures such as the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation are important, so too are measures such as those that this legislation is trying to achieve. The number of associations incorporated under this Act has grown substantially. The review of the Act is overdue. Fortunately, it has become more widely accepted and acknowledged that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must be allowed and enabled to determine the way in which they want their cultural, lifestyle and other community needs addressed in the way which they feel is most appropriate. It is recognised that in any field where agencies and associations exist that are controlled by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, such agencies should receive preference in allocation of the funds which are intended for the benefit of indigenous communities.

PARA.TAB: The provision of funding naturally brings with it responsibilities on the part of the recipients adequately to account for the appropriate expenditure of those funds. It is one of those myths that has a lot of currency in Australian society, and one that the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is seeking to turn around, that somehow or other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders have mountains of money thrown at them which they can spend in any way they wish. The reality is radically different. In fact, indigenous organisations have to provide greater accountability for their funding than any other recipients of government funding in this country. The amount of funding provided is clearly insufficient to deal with many of the very real manifestations of disadvantage with which we are all too familiar.

This Bill will increase the requirements of Aboriginal councils and associations to account for public funds which are provided to them, and it will increase the ability of the registrars of such councils and associations to ensure that this occurs. Changes have been made to the principal Act to introduce simple procedures for inspecting and investigating organisations and to clarify the registrars' powers. These changes will also make it easier for members of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander communities to address any problems that may arise in any association, whether the problems arise from accidents, other unforeseen difficulties, or malpractice. The Australian Democrats believe that these changes should increase the confidence of the broader community and, more importantly, should increase the confidence of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities that their local associations are more able to meet their needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Senator Kernot's incorporation of the letter from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) into Hansard has removed the need for me to deliver most of what I was going to say, which, in fact, was fundamentally encapsulated in the assurances which the Minister has given in that letter and his explanations as to the queries of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I can certainly confirm Senator Kernot's idea that currently the Government, in consultation with ATSIC, is pursuing a further range of amendments to the legislation in the new year.

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal Councils and Associations Amendment Bill is a major contribution towards achieving greater accountability for the funds spent through Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations. The Bill is particularly important at this time when new funding provided by the Government of $400m over five years, in response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, is being distributed in large part through Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations. The amendments are necessary to help ensure the effective expenditure of these funds. In that context, I believe they will be welcomed by the majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations. I thank the members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for their support of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and relates to the just announced decision of the Australian Government to send troops to Somalia. As the Minister is aware, the coalition has indicated its support, in principle, for an Australian Defence Force contribution to the Somali tragedy. Bearing in mind that the decision to deploy forces overseas is presumably always taken with great care, would the Minister advise the Senate what exactly will be the task of the Australian force? In his press conference mention was made that it may have a responsibility for disarming the armed factions. If that is to be the case, when is that decision to be made and who will be making it? Whilst risk is always acknowledged as part of the job of the armed forces, nevertheless I wish to ask the Minister: what is the risk assessment in relation to the contribution of Australia to this mission?

—I acknowledge Senator Hill's point that the coalition has supported in principle the commitment of Australian troops to Somalia. That will involve a battalion from the operational deployment force in Townsville. The approximate proposed date of deployment for arrival in Somalia is 10 January.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill has asked what I think is the crucial question in Operation Restore Hope that has not been finally resolved; that is, will that coalition involve itself in the active disarming of the factions? That is a matter that is being discussed in the United Nations at the moment. There have been discussions with the principal participant in this exercise—the United States—and it is a matter that has exercised the minds of the Prime Minister, Senator Evans, myself and no doubt many other people in this Parliament. That is a matter I would expect to be resolved in the next two weeks.

Our general attitude is that if UNOSOMSOM, the group that follows Operation Restore Hope, is to be successful, some attempt must be made to disarm the warring factions. That does not necessarily imply that people will be rounded up and arms ripped out of their hands. Quite clearly, the warring factions in Somalia are tending to go and hide and bury their weapons. Much of the effort may be put into discovering where those weapons are buried and the destruction thereof. That is an issue that is not finally resolved. I express the view of the Australian Government that to make UNOSOM, the group that follows Operation Restore Hope, work it must be an issue that is given the highest priority for consideration. Australia, being a participant now, will be actively involved in that consideration.

Senator Hill also raised the very valid question of threat. Our advice is that if the role of Operation Restore Hope is to fall short of disarming, the risk assessment would be medium to high. If, however, Operation Restore Hope goes to the active disarming of the factions, the risk factor would be high to very high. It is one of the reasons why the Australian Government has given thought to committing a battalion rather than a company. It is far more self-supporting and far more capable of defence than a single company would be in these circumstances. It is our evaluation that a battalion is the minimum contribution we can make if we are going to be active in these circumstances in a peace enforcement exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If I may press the Minister a little further, bearing in mind that Operation Restore Hope is not a UN force but nevertheless a force acting under the sanction of a UN Security Council resolution, presumably a decision to disarm—even if it is the advice of the Security Council to do so—would be taken by the operational commander, who will be an American. Does that mean that the Australian force would automatically assume that task if the decision is therefore made by the American operational commander?

—I do not think that it is necessarily automatic, but I think that it is highly likely. The command arrangement in this exercise is that the Australian battalion will be under Australian national command, but under coalition operational control. I repeat: I think that these matters should be resolved at the United Nations and I am sure that those involved in the coalition will have discussions and are having discussions with those in the United Nations to resolve this crucial issue. I would expect it to be resolved at that level, rather than simply by an operational commander making a decision and asking the rest of the coalition to fall in line.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that under the so-called reforms to workers compensation introduced by the Kennett Government, some workers could end up receiving benefits of only $3 per week? Is the Minister also aware that the Victorian Government plans to reduce its unfunded liability by passing on workers compensation costs to the Commonwealth's social security and health budgets? Is the Minister considering adopting similar proposals and, if not, can he explain why he is satisfied with the Commonwealth's own workers compensation legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Kennett Government changed the WorkCover Act in Victoria, with the new changes to take effect from 1 December this year. It broke judicial precedence and, in effect, dismissed the judges of the workers compensation bench. As well, it reduced the entitlement to Victorian workers, and it did that retrospectively. That is to say, under this legislation people who were enjoying an entitlement at law had that entitlement removed retrospectively.

PARA.TAB: There were a number of other things, too, that occurred. The definition of `entitlement' was altered so that workers who had previously been entitled now are no longer entitled, despite the nature of their injury and its work-related cause. In addition, a new concept of so-called notional earnings has been introduced to reduce the benefits that would be applicable to workers under workers compensation.

Let me deal with the tightening of the definition of `compensable injury'. Previously, a worker had to show that the employment had contributed in some way to the injury. Now, the legislation requires that the employment had to be a `significant' factor. The legal difference between `some way' contributed and that the work now is a `significant' factor in contributing means that a whole group of workers who would have been entitled to workers compensation because they suffered accidents while travelling to and from work, because of disease arising at their place of employment, or because of stress imposed on them, are no longer entitled to workers compensation. In addition to that, the notional earnings concept means that an employee will be deemed to have been at a certain stage of recovery and is able notionally to earn some sort of income. That notional amount will be deducted from the employee's workers compensation payment, whether the employee is earning that income or not, thus reducing workers with injuries to penury.

Importantly, this legislation will push people on to the Australian social security framework. If they are off workers compensation, are unable to claim benefits under workers compensation, and have no income, they become beneficiaries under the social security scheme of the Commonwealth. So, Victoria is subsidising itself by pushing workers out of compensation entitlement and making the taxpayers of Australia pay for a scheme that Victorian employers should fund for workers compensation.

The question asked of me was: what is the Commonwealth's situation? We have reduced the cost of workers compensation to Commonwealth employees quite considerably. The reduction has been 25 per cent over three years, reduced to 1.7c in the wage dollar from 2.6c.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to answer the final point that he could not conclude.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —What I was saying—and I am grateful for the opportunity to enlighten the chamber—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I invite you to rule that question out of order. In no shape or form is it a supplementary question. It is not even a poor attempt at seeking an extension, which is not allowed under the rules that regulate Question Time. I suggest to you it is a pure and utter abuse of process and ought not to be allowed.
—Can I speak to the point of order?

—Order! I am going to rule on it immediately. There are numerous points of order here every day when somebody says, `Now answer the part of the question that you did not answer when I asked you the first time'; and perhaps Senator Childs should have read it out, but I will allow it in those circumstances.

—The Commonwealth workers compensation scheme has been able to reduce costs to the Australian taxpayer without reducing benefits to workers employed by the Commonwealth. It has done so by increasing the safety protection in the workplace, ensuring a higher safety level, and by providing case work monitoring by Comcare Australia in order to get workers back to work in a way harmonious with their recovery from injury. Thus, as I have said, it has reduced costs to the taxpayer by 25 per cent, but without reducing the level of benefits.

PARA.TAB: What is true, and what may be the reason for the anxiety on the Opposition benches, is that the consumption tax package of the Opposition, the so-called Fightback package, proposed to abolish the national compensation scheme and go down the Victorian route.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that the Government's chief economic forecasting advisory body, the joint economic forecasting group, is in the process of submitting a set of pessimistic revised projections showing that the Australian economy has stalled and that One Nation was a waste of good paper, and given that the Treasurer has cancelled tomorrow's scheduled National Press Club speech, in which he was intending to release these key joint economic forecasting group revisions, I ask: when will the Treasurer now announce the downward revision of his inaccurate 3 per cent Budget forecast which itself replaced the Prime Minister's wildly inaccurate and always unrealistically optimistic 4 per cent forecast in the Government's illusory One Nation statement?
—As I said, Question Time in the Senate should be called `Rhetoric Time', and I will deal with the rhetoric in the question first.
—Do you find it impossible to answer questions?

—Mr President, all these interjections! The Liberal Party this week is supposed to be the listening party. Dr Hewson and Mr Reith are rushing around the country listening to everybody—hearing tongues, hearing voices, hearing footsteps; that is what has caused all the listening. There has been a lot of listening going on and honourable senators opposite should listen in Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Every country in the OECD has had forecasts revised downwards. All economists in this country have revised forecasts downwards, so honourable senators opposite should not get too excited about the Government doing that. Senator Short referred to the `ridiculous' 4 per cent forecast in the One Nation statement. At that time both the OECD and most commentators had that sort of forecast for Australia, and they have revised them downwards. So Senator Short should not make it a particular sin of this Government that it has done that.

As far as the first part of Senator Short's question is concerned, when the joint economic forecasting group reports to the Treasurer, as I believe it will shortly, it will not say anything, I am sure, about One Nation and the forecast in One Nation. It will not say anything about revised forecasts. It will not even say anything about Fightback, because it will be a responsible forecasting document, a best effort by a forecasting group. When the Treasurer gets revised forecasts he will announce them at the appropriate time, and I am not sure when that will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Yet again, that was another total non-answer from this Minister. As the Government's failed policies have created the need for another significant downward revision in the economic growth forecast to a level way below that required, on the Government's own admission, to prevent a further massive rise in the number of jobless, what is the Government's positive agenda to solve this unemployment crisis and the accompanying foreign debt crisis which has left every man, woman and child in Australia with a foreign debt equivalent to $11,000?

—Under the guise of asking a supplementary question, Senator Short wants to turn this place into a propaganda machine for the Liberal Party which, at this time, has no policies at all. There is total disagreement amongst those on the other side about what their policies are on every major issue. If they want to turn this into propaganda time, they should follow the example of their Leader and Mr Reith: they should start listening. I answered Senator Short's question. I told him what the forecasting group would do. I told him all those things. So he should not use supplementary questions as an excuse for his silly propaganda.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. As a former shipbuilding industry worker, I ask the Minister whether he can advise the Senate on the current health of the Australian shipbuilding industry. What are the industry's export prospects, and has the shipbuilding bounty made a positive contribution?
—The shipbuilding industry disappeared under you.

—I heard Senator Newman interject, `The shipbuilding industry disappeared under you'. I tell Senator Newman that the shipbuilding industry which we used to have disappeared when those opposite were in government. When this Government came to power, total exports for the shipbuilding industry amounted to $5m a year. This year, exports will amount to in the order of $450m. Senator McKiernan takes an intelligent interest in this matter. I am sure his question was provoked by his knowledge that I was in Western Australia at the weekend inspecting some of these ships.

PARA.TAB: When this Government came to power, there were serious doubts about the future of the shipbuilding industry. There was no reason for confidence. As I said, the figure for shipbuilding this year is around $450m, with exports accounting for more than 80 per cent of that. Today Australia has a sizeable share—about 10 per cent—of the world market in ferries and luxury yachts, with very good prospects in naval and police patrol craft and fishing vessels.

For example, in Fremantle at the weekend I saw two patrol boats for the Hong Kong police which left the yard on Saturday for Hong Kong. I saw other vessels that are beating tough competition in international markets. Success in these sorts of things is based on industry and governments working together. On the industry side, we have seen more and more dynamic marketing and management which have enabled us to exploit high skill based, world-class design and innovation with new materials.

As to the Government's role, the ship bounty has been of critical importance. So has support from the Export Finance Insurance Corporation and other Government programs. In June 1985 there were 91 shipyards in this country, all eligible for bounty. As a result of Government policy, in June 1992 there were 13 shipyards sharing that bounty money, and exporting nearly $450m worth of exports.

The Opposition has no policy on this industry. It has threatened to axe some of the supporting programs, such as NIES, but, more recently, we have seen a turnaround in other areas of support such as R&D concessions and funding for Austrade. There must be a degree of uncertainty in this very important and growing industry for Australia faced with uncertain policies by an alternative government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and follows the Prime Minister's scare campaign to convince Australians that Dr Hewson would not exempt food from the GST, no matter what he promises to do before the election. Given that Mr Keating has said Labor would vote for a GST because Dr Hewson would have a mandate to introduce it, but that yesterday Mr Keating promised to vote against the GST on food, I ask the Minister: firstly, does he accept that Mr Keating cannot have it both ways—if Labor votes with the Democrats against a GST on food, then Dr Hewson cannot break his promise even if he wants to? Alternatively, does Mr Keating intend to fulfil his long held ambition to vote for a GST on food, as an accomplice to Dr Hewson's crime?
—I cannot be in that sin-bin with Senator Coulter. What the Prime Minister has said on this issue—
—Today, yesterday or last week?

—It does not matter because the principle is exactly the same. The answer to Senator Coulter's question is that the Government's position is that if a coalition government were elected and had a strong mandate to introduce a GST in any particular configuration, the Government would support that in the Senate. If a coalition government did not have such a mandate, it would not.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is really a repeat of the first part of the question, which was not answered. If the GST does not include a GST on food, how can Mr Keating claim that Dr Hewson can do a back flip if the Government is saying it will not support a GST on food and the Opposition when in government does not have the numbers in the Senate to pass that through?

—This is very much in the realm of speculation because we do not know what the Opposition is going to do about anything. If the Opposition does not know what it is going to do about anything how can we or Senator Coulter have any clue as to what it will do? I have nothing to add to the first part of the question. We will have a look at what the Opposition proposes on Friday, if anything.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of the Criminal Justice Committee of the Parliament of Queensland, which is led by the member for Townsville, Mr Ken Davies. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome the members of the Committee to the Senate and trust this visit to Canberra will be informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate of the outcome of negotiations which took place at the EC summit in Edinburgh last weekend with regard to the recognition of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia? Also, is the Minister aware of reports of growing instability in that country? Can he advise the Senate of the current situation in relation to the stationing of UN peacekeeping forces and humanitarian aid to Macedonia?

—Unfortunately, the EC summit in Edinburgh did not resolve the question of recognition of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. The consensus reached at the Lisbon summit remains in place—namely, not to extend recognition to that republic while it continues to use the name Macedonia.

PARA.TAB: As I and the Prime Minister have stated before, Australia has taken a similar position to that of the European Community. We will not be able to move to recognition of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia until outstanding problems associated with the name under which the former republic will be known are resolved. Of course, we do all hope that this issue can be resolved expeditiously and that in the interim calm will prevail between the parties concerned.

One heartening aspect of the EC's consideration of this issue was the steps taken to ensure that in the interim the people of this republic are not further penalised by the diplomatic impasse. The Community, it was announced, will make available to the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia a substantial package of economic assistance. The EC also explicitly underlined the importance of providing access to funding from the international financial institutions and of the regular and properly monitored supply of oil.

Less hearteningly, I think we are all deeply concerned by recent reports that we have seen speculating on a possible expansion of conflict into the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. Certainly, the Australian Government welcomes the adoption on 11 December of UN Security Council resolution 795, which unanimously approved the Secretary-General's proposal for an 800-strong deployment of UNPROFOR personnel to be located on the territory of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia along its borders with Albania and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro).

This force will have an essentially preventive mandate of monitoring and reporting any developments in the border areas which could undermine confidence and stability in the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia or threaten its territory. That deployment will comprise a 700-member infantry battalion, 35 military observers, 26 civilian police monitors and a small civil affairs and administrative component. As the Secretary-General has said, this is the first example of preventive peacekeeping deployment as outlined in his `Agenda for Peace' recently published in the UN General Assembly.

I am pleased to see the UN taking action in this way to prevent possible conflict. This is an occasion of a number of precedents being set. The Somalian enforcement exercise is the first time chapter VII of the UN Charter has been used in that way in a humanitarian exercise. This is the first time we have seen a preventive deployment of UN personnel. Both, I believe, would be regarded by the international community generally. and certainly in this country, as entirely appropriate roles for the UN to be playing in the post-Cold War environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to a report in the Canberra Times of today which states that corrected company accounts by the Brown and Hatton Group, half owned by the Prime Minister, show that Brown and Hatton has a `contingent liability' to former Tourism Minister Mr John Brown totalling $4m. Why does he not regard the Prime Minister of Australia being a party to a contingent liability of $4m to a former Minister of the Crown in his Government, now lobbyist, as a massive conflict of interest?

—I see that Senator Baume is not in his seat, so Senator Archer has picked up the burden of this huge issue today. The allegation last week was that the Prime Minister was going to make a profit out of all this. Now it appears that he may have a contingent liability. The Opposition wants to argue both sides of the coin, I suppose, but that will not give it much benefit. As I have said before, unless there is anything which goes to my ministerial responsibility, I am not in the business of commenting on the private affairs of individuals, whether they be in relation to their business interests, their personal interests or any other interests.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister confirm reports that Mr Brown is to be appointed to the Pig Industry Policy Council?

—I know nothing about that. Senator Archer might arrange for one of his colleagues to address that question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy tomorrow. Of course, the Liberal Party is singularly reluctant to pursue this issue where it ought to pursue it—in the House of Representatives. Its Leader is not only rushing around the country hearing voices, hearing footsteps—listening all the time—but also he is still supposed to be Mr Clean. The Mr Dirties over there are doing his work.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of a report from the Victorian Council of Social Service, VCOSS Paper No. 10, entitled No room to move for Australia's unemployed published in August of this year? Is the Minister aware that the report recommends that the reduced employment prospects by moving rule be abolished because it is `having a devastating effect on the individuals and families subject to the 12-week cancellation or postponement of their Jobsearch or Newstart allowance'? Has the Government investigated or monitored the effects of this rule, which penalises applicants or recipients who are judged to have `significantly' reduced their employment prospects by moving to a new location, without `sufficient reason'? What are the Government's intentions with regard to this rule?

—I do have some information from the Minister for Social Security on this matter. The Minister is aware of the report and the recommendations in that report that the rule be abolished. As the Senate might know, the rules were introduced in November 1989 in response to public concern and other evidence that some unemployed persons were deliberately moving from one location to another and, in doing so, diminishing their chances of work.

PARA.TAB: It should also be recognised—I think Senator Powell appreciates this—that under the legislation, under the rule, moves for health or family reunion reasons are allowable. The Minister has taken into account that the labour market has deteriorated since the rule was introduced, and that the number of clients affected has reduced significantly—from some 2,000 to some 500 a year.

We also recognise that movement of unemployed persons to areas with few job chances is not really a long term answer to both the problems of unemployment and their standard of living, even in the short term. Nevertheless, taking into account the report and these changes of recent months, the Minister is of the view that it is important that the provisions operate fairly. Consequently, the two departments involved in the administration of the policy, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, will examine these provisions and will report to the Government on them—I think the due date for report is early April next year—with a view to seeing whether, in view of the changes in the market and in the numbers of those affected, the rule may be reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate assure the Senate that the Prime Minister was not present at any Cabinet, Ministry or committee discussion of Government decisions on Foreign Investment Review Board requirements for investment in agriculture; the dumping of Canadian pork imports or the pig industry legislation recently before the Parliament?
—This has all been asked before.

—Yes, of course it was asked before. It was never answered; that is the problem. As I asked the Minister last week—and I have not yet received an answer—will the Minister table Mr Keating's declarations of interest as recorded by Cabinet officers and as required by Cabinet conflict of interest rules?
—Senator Boswell did ask me a question about this issue a week or so ago. I must say I overlooked it because I thought it was a fairly trivial question, but I apologise.

PARA.TAB: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows: the amendments to the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which is what Senator Boswell asked me about, are all matters of minor policy. There was no consideration of these matters by Cabinet. The legislation committee of Cabinet met on 10 November 1992 to consider legislation to be introduced that week and gave approval to the introduction of the Bill in question with amendments. In accordance with usual practice, the Prime Minister did not attend that meeting and has not had any involvement with this legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. My question arises from last month's CSIRO report to Mrs Kelly entitled Towards healthy rivers which states, in part:

QUESTION.PARA: One criterion for river quality is that it should at least be suitable for safe drinking.
I ask the Minister why Mrs Kelly approved a discussion paper which throws out the commonsense suggestion that our rivers should be fit to drink and replaced it with the following recommendation:
Australia's rivers should one day be fit to drink most of the time.

In other words, that would allow a serious decline in water quality in many rivers. Is this the sort of substandard water policy we can expect in next Monday's environment statement by the Prime Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Like so much that is pursued by the Democrats, that ideal is simply unachievable. I know from personal experience that it is often unachievable for reasons that have nothing whatever to do with human involvement. The Minister has provided me with the following answer to the question. The approach proposed by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency in its discussion paper is perfectly reasonable and is not a recommendation which would allow a serious decline in water quality. The recommendation is merely recognising a simple truth: water in some of our rivers, even under natural conditions, is not always drinkable.

PARA.TAB: It would be pointless to have a goal which is unachievable in natural circumstances—which, of course, never stops the Democrats. During flood conditions, water quality will be temporarily reduced because of high turbidity and high levels of nutrients from run-off from farmlands and urban settlements. In periods of low flow, some of our rivers will have increased levels of salinity, even when their catchments have not been disturbed.

It is also worth noting scientific evidence that suggests that blue-green algal blooms, which occur in our rivers under certain circumstances, occurred prior to European settlement. During such blooms, river water is undrinkable. It is, however, a reasonable expectation that in periods of average or above average flow these rivers would not contain contaminants that make them unfit for drinking. The Government is working hard, through the development of the national water quality management strategy, to put in place measures which are deliverable and which will ensure an improvement in water quality. As to the second part of the question, there will be nothing substandard about the environmental statement, as will be clear on Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Does the Government's privacy legislation apply to the Department of Veterans' Affairs? If so, can the Minister explain how it is that a widow, after applying for a war widow's pension, was sent a rejection statement based not on the death of her husband, but on the death of another veteran, which included that veteran's name, file number and intimate details of his health diagnosis? What confidence can anyone dealing with the Department of Veterans' Affairs have that confidential information will remain confidential? Has the Privacy Commissioner been informed of this serious breach? What action, if any, has the Government taken to see that this never happens again?

—If the unfortunate incident to which Senator Newman refers did occur in the way that she has described, then quite clearly there has been a breakdown in some form of clerical manipulation of information which was essential to enable the Department to deal properly with the war widow—if that is who she was—concerned. Assuming that those facts were correct, then I hazard the claim that this would be a rare and abnormal event and an aberration in the usual working of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which, I imagine, deals with tens of thousands of claims in any short period and hundreds of thousands of claims over the course of a year. So to single out and highlight this particular incident and somehow to infer that that is an indication of an overall lack of privacy concerns within the Department of Veterans' Affairs would not, in my view, be correct. In so far as this incident has occurred—and I will accept that for the moment—it would be a matter of grave concern to the Department.

PARA.TAB: To answer the last part of Senator Newman's question, I believe that management would take steps to rectify the situation to ensure that whatever technological problem occurred with the computer print-outs or whatever does not recur at a future date. If the Privacy Commissioner could add anything to the investigation by management within the Department of Veterans' Affairs of the incident, I am sure his assistance would be thought to be useful. But I would imagine that management itself would have sufficient concern to move very rapidly to remedy any defect in the processing of such claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate of the significance of the signing yesterday of the Australian Shipping Charter of Practice and its implications for the future of the Australian shipping industry?

—Yesterday I attended the signing of the Australian Shipping Charter of Practice by the Australian National Maritime Association and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Australia leads the way in maritime safety.
—That was a good question from you, Burnsie.

—It is not a trivial matter at all; it is an extremely serious one. The current condition of world shipping has become an international scandal that has caused not only the loss of thousands of tonnes of shipping and cargoes but, more importantly, the loss of hundreds of human lives.

PARA.TAB: Australia is leading the way in maritime safety and ships standards and is taking a strong role in the United Nations International Maritime Organisation to encourage better world standards. The Australian shipping industry, in adopting this charter, is stating to the world that it offers a high quality, safe and reliable service. Senator Alston might be interested to know that in the past two years alone seven bulk carriers carrying Australian cargoes have been lost at sea, some of them with the loss of all hands.

This charter is another initiative of an industry that leads the way in micro-economic reform, and it seeks to continue the reform process without sacrificing its high standard of safety and decent labour practices. It is an industry that refutes the purist view that Australian industries can only become more efficient and productive through unrestricted exposure to the rigours of foreign competition.

Only last week an article in a leading business magazine on our flag carrier, the Australian National Line, commented that the Government had to `bite the bullet' on shipping reform by opening the coastal trade to foreign ships. The implication is clear. Despite the substantial performance gains from almost a decade of unprecedented restructuring and industrial peace, real change will never occur, according to this article, until Australian ships are forced to compete with all comers in the international shipping market. This is false.

High quality Australian flagshipping or the flagshipping of any other advanced maritime nation cannot compete on cost grounds with flag of convenience vessels operating out of tax havens and with Third World crews working in oppressive conditions. However, our political opponents are committed to ending Australia's long established cabotage policy and throwing open the coast to cheap foreign shipping.

Under the Government's reform program and investment initiatives—Senator Button has been commenting on them earlier today in Question Time—almost $2 billion has been committed to modernising a third of the Australian merchant fleet, which currently stands as one of the youngest shipping fleets in the world. It is about half the average age of the international fleet. The instability created by the abolition of cabotage, together with the conflict created by the Opposition's industrial relations policies, is guaranteed to kill, stone dead, the industry's long-standing cooperative reforms and the massive investment program in the future of Australian shipping—an industry which employs directly about 4,500 Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of former distinguished President of the Senate Sir Harold Young. On behalf of all honourable senators, I wish him well on his visit to Canberra.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is it correct that employees of the Federal Government are not permitted to engage in union activities during work hours without incurring penalties? What restrictions apply to Federal Government offices in terms of election material or political activities of staff employed in Federal departmental offices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It mystifies me why this question is asked under the Employment, Education and Training portfolio when my primary portfolio is Industrial Relations. The question seems more appropriate to be directed to me under that portfolio.
—That is a telling point.

—I am just mystified by it. Be that as it may, let me turn to the question. In broad terms, the provision of time off for union activity in the Australian Public Service is applicable where safety matters are concerned, to deal with questions of occupational health and safety, and where, broadly, a grievance can be presented, dealt with and dispatched. If the question is about that sort of time off, as I understand the regulations, that is a tolerable exercise of the proper interface between management and unions in managing the Public Service.

PARA.TAB: If it is time off for electoral campaigning in union elections, I would have a different view on that. Without being able to cite the particular regulation, I do not think it is allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister therefore explain why officers employed in the Moree office of the Commonwealth Employment Service appeared on television during a work day taking part in a Public Sector Union protest against coalition policies? Further, can the Minister explain why how-to-vote cards supporting the Labor Party were freely available on the counter of the CES office in Moree and how an officer of the CES, and identified as such, can be permitted to appear on a television news broadcast blatantly promoting Labor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of that supplementary question—I point out that I have only one minute to answer and there are four questions—if officers of the CES were taking time off to protest against coalition policy, I could understand that, as long as they were not being paid by the CES. I do not imagine that they would have been paid if they were participating in the national day of protest, because that is not our policy. I can understand why they would want to protest against coalition policy—because of the cuts to the CES, the cuts to their own jobs and the draconian changes to unemployment benefits, including kicking people off the unemployment benefit after nine months, as the Opposition proposes.

PARA.TAB: I will take the rest of the questions on notice because they involve questions of fact—whether these things did, in fact, occur. I will check those and supply the answers in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of the distribution of a pamphlet advertising a hairdressing salon known as Rafters, located in Bellerive on Hobart's eastern shore? Is the postage code on the envelope which was used to distribute the pamphlet the same as that allocated at government expense to the honourable member for Franklin, Mr Bruce Goodluck? Mr Paul Rafter is the husband of Mr Goodluck's daughter Catherine. Is she employed in Mr Goodluck's electoral office? Will the Minister investigate this abuse of government postage?

—I am not aware of the hairdressing salon Rafters. I am not aware of the postage code. However, I suggest that Senator Sherry provide me with the information and any documents that he might have. As I do in these sorts of circumstances where the use of government resources may be applied improperly, I will order an investigation into the matter. I will not pre-judge the case, but in circumstances where there are allegations of improper use of taxpayers' money, obviously I will order an investigation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the Public Service Commissioner's policy restricting the right of redundant Australian Defence Force personnel to join the Australian Public Service or a Commonwealth agency and to the legal opinion of Mr Michael Finnane, QC—described by the Minister in this chamber as very impressive—that the Commissioner has acted outside his authority in applying this policy to the ADF. Is the Minister aware that the Commissioner has now advised each department and agency in writing that enforcement of this policy is at their own discretion and that the Commissioner has no power to enforce it? Will the Minister now explain why the Department, being in receipt of this advice and Mr Finnane's opinion, is continuing to advise redundant ADF personnel that they are unable to apply for positions within the Department? Will the Minister instruct his Department to exercise its discretion immediately and lift the restriction, which is not enforceable and may well be illegal?

—I have instructed officials in my Department to take this matter up with Senator Cook's Department as a matter of urgency. If it cannot resolve it at an officials level, I will be taking it up with Senator Cook himself, with a view to taking a Cabinet submission forward to resolve this particular matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's answer, I again ask whether the Minister will immediately instruct his Department that ADF personnel who have won positions on merit with the Department of Defence and allied agencies since the Commissioner's policy became known and have then been denied their right to fill those positions because of that policy, might be immediately considered for employment in the same or similar positions or receive just compensation if they have been found to have been disadvantaged?

—Those are the sorts of issues that I intend to resolve in the discussions between the Department of Defence and the Department of Industrial Relations. We do have a legal opinion that suggests a certain course of action. That does not have absolute infallibility, but as I described it—and as Senator Ferguson correctly summarises—it is an impressive legal opinion. On the basis of that and on the basis of the Commissioner's ruling and writing back to us, we are taking that matter forward.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the latest information from the island of Flores following the recent earthquake? When will Australian assistance arrive in Indonesia and what is the current position in relation to Australians who may have been in the area on Saturday?

—Indonesian authorities now put the death toll following the earthquake in Flores at 1,540 people, with most of these deaths occurring in the Maumere area on Flores. About 80 per cent of the buildings in Maumere and the surrounding fishing villages close to the epicentre of the quake have been damaged or destroyed. Babi Island to the north of Maumere was particularly badly hit, with most of its inhabitants perishing in the subsequent tidal wave.

PARA.TAB: Following consultations, including discussions with our Defence attache, who travelled to Flores yesterday, Indonesian authorities have now welcomed assistance from Australia. A RAAF Hercules aircraft will be departing from Darwin tonight with a view to arriving in Maumere early tomorrow morning, 16 December. These initial emergency supplies, valued at approximately $200,000, will include tents, tarpaulins, plastic sheeting, large plastic water containers, generators, antibiotics and other medications for the treatment of wounds, and water purification tablets.

The Government is coordinating with the Northern Territory Administration and Commonwealth assistance will be supplemented with some relief supplies from the Northern Territory, including milk powder. I emphasise that the Government remains ready to respond to requests for additional assistance, both to ameliorate the immediate situation and to contribute to longer term rehabilitation and reconstruction of the area.

As to Australians in the area, there are still no reports of any Australian casualties in the earthquake and its aftermath. So far Indonesian officials have not referred to any expatriates as being among the casualties. By comparison with yesterday, we now have reports of some 26 Australians possibly being in the region. Embassy officers have accounted for the safety of 10 of these. Our embassy is continuing to follow up on the other 16, including through the visit of a further embassy officer to Flores today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has there been a massive cost blow-out in the computer based booking and tracking system purchased for Comcar? Can the Minister indicate the total cost Australia-wide of the system? Can the Minister also indicate what problems have plagued the system in Canberra and also give an indication of the total time the system has been unavailable in the ACT since the targeted operational date of September? Does the IBM RISK 6000 system purchased by Comcar to operate with an Ingress database possess two basic set and test functions? If not, is this why the system has had a disastrous response time? Finally, does the Minister recognise that his Department may have wasted millions of taxpayers' dollars on a lemon?
—It is a bit hard on IBM.

—It is a bit hard on IBM, Senator Collins. IBM was chosen because of its competitive price, its local assembly and performance. A problem did exist with that machine operating the selected database management system. It was discovered in a private business during the implementation stage and was subsequently rectified in early 1991. The machine is now in production and recurrence of that problem has not been evident.

PARA.TAB: Implementation of the system as an integrated solution commenced on 21 September 1992 as a pilot program in Adelaide. Other States are being brought into line progressively, as was planned. There were some minor teething problems in respect of Adelaide. I am advised that the system is now working well, both in Adelaide and in Canberra. The Secretary of my Department—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Comcar drivers.

—Senator Campbell can talk to Comcar divers all he likes. They are not necessarily experts. In Senator Campbell's case—no, I will not go on. The Secretary of my Department obviously read the same article that Senator Calvert read. He asked the staff to explain. He assures me that the article is off the mark.

PARA.TAB: Let me say one thing in respect of Comcar—and I will keep on making this point. The Opposition has a policy in respect of Comcar which is basically the gutting of the organisation. As a consequence of that, it anticipates saving some $10m. If those opposite look at the steps that this Government has taken in respect of Comcar, if they want to look at the changes, they will find that by the end of this financial year we will have achieved some $11.5m in savings. The organisation is intact and will remain intact. Management consultants have been brought into it and have restructured it. Workers have had restructured arrangements, restructured awards. As a consequence, the organisation has reduced its deficit, as opposed to increasing it.

It is an organisation from which the Government has recouped more in the last 18 months, to the end of this financial year, than those opposite with their Fightback way ahead policy will ever achieve. It is about time they acknowledged some of those achievements, rather than picking up some scuttlebutt that they read on the back page of a Canberra newspaper or that they hear in the back seat of a car.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the Minister's dissertation on Fightback and all the other things. He was obviously well briefed about the question, but I ask him: what has been the cost blow-out of the system?

—In answering Senator Calvert's question I told him that, although there were minor teething problems, the system was working well and has been put in place without major hiccups. I have not been advised of any extra cost because of these delays. I do not expect that there will be. There might be some sort of fantasy in Senator Calvert's mind that would suggest that, because of the delay, there might be some extra costs involved in purchasing the system. I do not think there are, but I will let Senator Calvert know if there are.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. The Minister will be aware that in May this year the Australian Government signed the World Health Organisation Code for the Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes, in an attempt to protect children in developing countries from commercial exploitation. Can the Minister tell the Senate what action the Government has taken since May to implement the code in Australia? What steps is Australia taking to monitor the implementation of the code in developing countries?

—The question of the marketing of breast milk substitutes is important even in the Australian community, let alone in developing countries, which seemed to be the burden of Senator Crowley's question. Certainly within Australia the message that is put out by most mothercraft and other nurses is to the effect that breast feeding is the best feeding—
—Breast is best.

—`Breast is best', I think was the expression used by Senators Herron and West by way of interjection. I believe that the provision of adequate information relating to breast milk substitutes is very important, as is appropriate marketing, so that women are not put under undue pressure to substitute milk formulas for the natural process. There will, of course, be occasions when that is indicated and is the proper and right thing to do, and in that situation it is important that the importers and suppliers of infant milk formulas do their marketing in a way which conveys correct information and does not turn into a high pressure exercise.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, Australian manufacturers and importers of infant formulas signed an agreement at Melbourne's Royal Children's Hospital in May of last year, which was the eleventh anniversary of the adoption of the World Health Organisation code in relation to this matter. I recall being there with Mr Brian Howe, the Federal Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, and representatives of various community groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why were you there?

—I was there because I was Minister for Consumer Affairs at the time. Australia has seized the opportunity to show the world that ethical marketing of infant formula is possible, to the benefit of families everywhere, whether breast fed or bottle fed. I believe a most important aspect of the new agreement has been the setting up of a panel to monitor and advise the Government on its operation and the general marketing of infant formulas. The panel is chaired by Professor Kerin O'Dea, Chair of Human Nutrition at Deakin University. The suppliers are represented by Mr Michael Sharpe, the Managing Director of Sharpe Laboratories. I do not know whether Senator Coates is here, but I note that, importantly, the community representative is Ms Ros Escott, who is a counsellor with the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia and has been very prominent in this particular field.

PARA.TAB: I believe that what Australia is doing has significance worldwide. It is being looked at worldwide. It is also important, as Senator Crowley indicated, that we take steps to ensure that particularly Pacific island states, which have less well developed consumer protection mechanisms, have the benefit of a similar approach and a cooperative arrangement with the manufacturers and suppliers of breast milk substitutes to ensure that those people, in their own cultures, do not have their ordinary breast feeding practices subverted by high pressure publicity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to the continuing disastrous unemployment figure in Australia, with one in just over eight Australians now unable to find a job. What is the Government forecast for unemployment when the school leavers seek to join the work force at the end of January next?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer that question to the Minister and reply in due course.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's non-answer. As he is referring my question to the Minister, could he also ask the Minister what the Government's policies are to correct Labor's tragic unemployment level? Could the Minister indicate to the Senate whether he is prepared to be honest with the Australian people in his response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of that question is offensive, but we are used to offensive questions from Senator Parer. I will tell him what Government policy will not be: we will not be kicking people off the dole after nine months, like the lot opposite are proposing to do. Since we have turned in four successive quarters of positive GDP growth, we will continue to do that. I also tell Senator Parer that because company pre-tax profits rose by 26 per cent in the October quarter—67 per cent above the recession low—we will continue to get that type of growth in the economy and that type of money for investment.

PARA.TAB: Retail sales went up by 2 per cent at the end of October and we will continue growth in the economy in that way. We will continue to see the ongoing rise in advertisements for job vacancies. We will not talk down the economy. We will talk realistically about the economy.
