TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 December, Senator Harradine asked me a question about participation of parents in the work force. I have obtained an answer which I think takes Senator Harradine part of the way on this issue, if not the whole way. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable Senator's question:

The size and structure of the workforce in Australia has changed significantly during the past decade. Between 1982-83 and 1989-90 the workforce increased in size by 20.5 per cent. A feature of this growth was the increase in female employment opportunities; in June 1990, females accounted for 41.3 per cent of total employment compared with 37.4 per cent in June 1983. The Government, of course, closely monitors developments in employment composition, and the Australian Bureau of Statistics regularly undertakes detailed surveys of the labour force.

The trend towards greatly expanded female employment opportunities reflects a variety of economic and social factors. These include, for example, changing social attitudes to married women joining the workplace, increased female participation in further education (enhancing employment prospects), more opportunities for part-time employment and the increased availability of child care services.

The honourable Senator has suggested that financial compensation be provided to persons who desire to leave the workforce for socially constructive alternatives. The Government believes that financial assistance to families and individuals should continue to be directed on the basis of economic need and not as an inducement to individuals to leave the workforce. The Government has in place a range of policies that directly assist families, including Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement and assistance for child care. Families also benefit from more general policies, such as health and housing.
It should also be emphasised that the Government would not introduce incentives that discriminated between employees or parents on the basis of gender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 December Senator Coulter asked a series of questions regarding the Australian Heritage Commission. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has provided answers to Senator Coulter's questions. Given the length of the answers, I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Question to the Minister for Transport & Communications representing the Minister for the Environment

PARA.TAB: 1. Why has the Australian Heritage Commission imposed a de facto moratorium on nominations by community groups to the Register of the National Estate, and why are Commission staff being discouraged from actively protecting the National Estate areas.

2. Given that the Commission's collaboration with State forestry agencies on regional assessments in Western Australia and Tasmania has resulted in its increasing co-option by those agencies, will the Minister terminate such collaboration, and instead establish more open and independent regional assessments under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

3. Will the Minister review the operation of the Commission and its Act to restore its independence, its co-operation with public interest groups, and its obligation to protect this country's heritage.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Heritage Commission has not imposed any sort of moratorium on nominations to the Register of the National Estate by community groups. In fact, the Commission is actively pursuing discussions with community groups to encourage them to prepare applications for National Estate grants program funds to conduct studies of regions or types of places. A major outcome of these studies would be the preparation of batches of National Estate nominations.

In relation to the protection of the National Estate areas, and consistent with Part V of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, Commission staff continue to provide advice to Commonwealth decision-makers on actions which may affect National Estate places. The Commission also provides advice about matters related to the protection of the National Estate to State governments, industry groups, community groups and any other interested parties.

The Australian Heritage Commission has carried out a regional assessment of the National Estate values in the southern forests of Western Australia. This regional assessment was an independent assessment undertaken by the Australian Heritage Commission, in cooperation with the Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM), using all available data, including that held by CALM. The assessment was subject to a six month public review period, the results of which did not substantially alter the technical assessment.
The Australian Heritage Commission has no agreement for such work in Tasmania.

The Minister does not consider that the Australian Heritage Commission has been co-opted by State forestry agencies and is pleased that for the first time State agencies (including conservation agencies) are making their data available to the Australian Heritage Commission, and is satisfied that this has resulted in a rigorous, independent and more complete assessment than was previously possible.
Any such regional assessment would become part of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act in the event of it being triggered by a major project.
The Commission has also developed a fuller community participation model for all future regional assessments.

The Minister is fully satisfied that the Commission is operating independently, that it is carrying out its duties in a manner consistent with its statutory responsibilities and that it is cooperating with its stakeholders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Childs this day relating to workers compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: This answer dealt with workers compensation. Senator Cook referred specifically to what he described as the terms of the workers compensation scheme in the State of Victoria. Mr President, there were—and you may have heard them—a number of comments made during Senator Cook's answer urging him to look also at the workers compensation arrangements in South Australia. I draw the Senate's attention and the attention of the Minister to an article which recently appeared in the Herald-Sun in Victoria which compared—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very unreliable newspaper.
—Senator Cook has just called that a lie.
—Order! He did not.
—I did not. I said it is unreliable.

—The article goes very clearly through the two schemes and compares the nature of them—one which was put in place by the coalition Government in Victoria, and the other which was put into place by a Labor Government in South Australia. The article, written by Geoff Easdown, says this:

PARA.TAB: South Australia has cracked down on the folly of what was regarded as the most generous workplace insurance scheme in the country.
Its government-run WorkCover system was reformed, with SA's Parliament making changes which in some areas—

SPEECH.PARA: and I stress `some areas'—
are far tougher than those the Kennett Government instituted when it laid to rest our hopelessly indebted system of WorkCare.

I think that even Senator Cook would not stand up in this Parliament and defend the system which operated in Victoria as a result of the Cain-Kirner-Halfpenny changes to WorkCare which occurred in that State over the last 10 years.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that, unlike their Victorian counterparts, injured South Australian workers are now denied even the most basic right to sue the employer for negligence. According to this article, South Australian workers have lost the centuries old common law right to seek redress through the courts. Their claims will be limited to a maximum settlement of $155,000. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . while Victorian workers can still resort to common law and seek awards for loss of earning capacity, up to a maximum of over $671,960.

PARA.TAB: Under the new plan, once an injured worker has been on weekly payments for two years the SA WorkCover Corporation can at its discretion shift that person on to a lump sum payment rather than weekly income maintenance support.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of Senator Cook, who may reply, I suspect that would mean that the workers would be liable for Commonwealth benefits and, presumably, they would meet the normal tests. I would be interested to hear Senator Cook's remarks on that, since he was rather concerned that such an occurrence may happen under the Victorian scheme. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Yet despite their protests Victorian workers still have the right to sue and the only legislative bar which has been invoked here under the Kennett changes is against minor and trivial claims.

SPEECH.PARA: The South Australian Government had to deal with a similar problem which emerged in Victoria as a result of a poorly designed workers compensation scheme. Senator Cook will be interested to note that under the South Australian changes the concept of being compensated for pain and suffering has been abolished, but not in Victoria where the maximum claim allowed under the maims table is $50,000.

PARA.TAB: Two States—one Labor, one Liberal—are seeking to reform the workers compensation scheme, dealing with a very difficult problem which emerged as a result of Labor Government policies during the 1980s. One State has moved in a particular direction, and it appears—at least according to Geoff Easdown; I would be interested to hear the Minister's comments—that South Australia, in many respects, has brought down a scheme which could be described, in the language that Senator Cook would like to use, as being even tougher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that Senator Kemp should rise on this matter. First of all, I say categorically that I do not regard the Herald-Sun as a newspaper that is reliable in its reporting. Nonetheless, I will compare what the Herald-Sun says with the actual facts and deal with that later at my convenience.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, while it is true—and we are proud of it—that the South Australian Government is a Labor Government, it may have escaped Senator Kemp's notice that there has been an ongoing industrial campaign in South Australia over changes to the workers compensation Act because the upper House in South Australia, the Legislative Council, was taking a view about changes that it wanted to impose on the South Australian Government to modify the provisions within the South Australian workers compensation Act.

What came out as legislation was an unhappy compromise between the blocking powers of the upper chamber over the lower chamber where the South Australian Government is formed and where the legislation was first promoted. So it is not fair then to say that this is a comparison with the policies of a Labor government when the government is in office as a government but not in power in both Houses of the Parliament. It is the outcome of the use of the review powers of the South Australian Legislative Council, which is a different thing.

If we take a logical view of this matter—I know that is not the long suit of Senator Kemp—nothing that has been said here answers the primary position that I put in answer to my question. It is not logical to say that I am wrong because someone else did it. We have not done it. The Commonwealth has reduced the cost of workers compensation by 25 per cent to Australian taxpayers for Commonwealth employees, without reducing the benefits to the employees, by running an intelligent approach to workers compensation. The debate about workers compensation always misses this fundamental point: the first concern is accident prevention and safety to lower the accident rate.

The second concern is proper and swift medical attention to repair the accident or damage caused to, or the disease that has been afflicting, the individual. The third responsibility is to ensure proper compensation without loss of wages. The fourth responsibility is to provide a rapid road to rehabilitation for an injured worker. Our scheme concentrates on all of those criteria, not simply on the amount of compensation.

The fault of many of the State workers compensation schemes is that they are a gift to the legal community and to the insurance companies. Whenever the cost to employers of compensation premiums rises, the benefits are reduced to keep the costs under control. But no rein is put on the huge legal fees taken out of the system by lawyers or on the rapacious profits of insurance companies taken out of the system. I can sympathise with many employers having to pay the premiums they do, and not seeing them in the pockets of their workers when there is an accident, because the snouts in the trough are those of the legal profession and the insurance companies.

Under our scheme we have avoided that. That is why we have lowered the costs, improved the benefits and guaranteed the safety of our employees. We have the model arrangement. What the Opposition is anxious about is that it intends to abolish that under Fightback. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very serious issue, that is, the proper compensation that should be paid to workers injured on the job. It does not matter whether workers in South Australia, Victoria or elsewhere are the ones in question; if they are denied proper compensation, that is a great tragedy. The difficulty in this area is that somebody has to bear the loss. If somebody is injured, as a result of that injury loses work and, as a result of that, loses income and incurs hospital expense, someone has to pay, whether that be the worker, the employer or some insurance scheme.

PARA.TAB: In Victoria the system has been changed. It is conceded that there ought to have been some change. Senator Kemp reads from the Herald-Sun that it is only minor or trivial claims that do not attract common law and that the more serious claims do. That is true. But the Herald-Sun—it certainly would not be Senator Kemp—has taken a cavalier approach to this in saying that minor or trivial injuries are the only ones that are denied compensation.

Injuries that involve less than 30 per cent of the whole person miss out. A person who fits that category is somebody who loses his leg beneath the knee, who loses a non-dominant hand or who has a serious back injury through no fault of his own and perhaps through the negligence of his employer. Those persons are denied compensation. So the issue must be looked at squarely. It is a tragedy where a person who has had injuries of the sort I have described is denied proper compensation for those injuries.

It is said that industry cannot stand the cost. Whether industry can or cannot, certainly the worker cannot stand the cost that is involved in losing money or in having serious operations. If the employer is not going to pay, someone else should. It is a community responsibility. The worker should be compensated, and compensated properly.

I wish to say something about the lawyers in this matter. Clearly, in Victoria very heavy legal costs have been involved. Most of those costs have been as a result of the Accident Compensation Commission going out to get legal advice. Those solicitors who have looked after workers have done so responsibly and reasonably. Too often the lawyers in this area are criticised, and criticised unjustly.

I simply say that one of the great tragedies in Victoria is the abolition of the Accident Compensation Tribunal. That tribunal was set up to look after the workers' rights. It is an important issue to be faced by this Parliament, and by every parliament, that people holding the equivalent of judicial office can be sacked without proper attention being paid to their future. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Archer this day relating to corrected company accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer asked Senator Button a question about the conflict of interest that has emerged from the revelation in the corrected annual accounts of the Brown and Hatton Group—that is the piggery group half-owned by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—which show that there is a contingent liability totalling $4m to the company of Mr John Brown, the former Minister for Tourism. Perhaps we should have a quick look at this peripatetic debt as it does seem to wander around a bit and it creates a problem.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating has an equity of $4.2m in this piggery group which has the debt to Mr John Brown. In the 1990 unaudited accounts of Mr Keating's piggery group, the debt was shown as an asset of goodwill of $4.5m, which was offset by the debt of $4.5m due to Mr Brown's company. But in the so-called corrected group accounts filed on 26 November 1992, this debt was converted into shareholders' funds instead of liabilities. It boosted shareholders' funds in Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd to $7.5m and provided, along with an incredible $4m revaluation of buildings, the great bulk of the $8.4m of equity shown in the holding company, Euphron, in which Mr Keating actually holds a half-interest through his family company.

The group's goodwill in these corrected accounts was shown to be $4.76m. However, in last weekend's parent company accounts for Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, goodwill had disappeared altogether and $4m of the debt to Mr Brown was converted into yet another new form—making three forms in the last few months—this time as a contingent liability.

I do not know whether the present corporations law permits this kind of paper shuffling that significantly alters the apparent financial position of a company. I would hope that if the law allows this to happen, the Government will take some action to ensure that people doing business with companies like this receive a true and fair view of their financial strength. This contingent liability now owed to Mr Brown is to be paid, according to the company, `If the company makes sufficient profits and has sufficient funds available to pay it'.

The clear implications are that there is great pressure on the Prime Minister to bring about the deal with Danpork, which is the only way Mr Brown can get his loot. Clearly, we have a situation where the success of Mr Keating's multimillion dollar pig joint venture with the Danish company, Danpork, will have a massive impact on his company's capacity to pay the $4m to Mr Brown.

What concerns anyone, I suppose, who has any understanding of the potential for conflict of interest is that there are many government approvals, some of which it is claimed have already been received, that the Danpork venture requires in order to succeed. There are many governmental departments and agencies involved one way or another with the joint venture, and there are many unanswered questions, as Senator O'Chee, for example, has put forward. Clearly, the potential for conflict of interest is a serious one. It seems unfortunate that in his answer to Senator Archer, Senator Button totally ignored that potential for conflict of interest and, as with all matters, simply poured personal abuse on the Opposition for asking the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take over where Senator Baume left off: the conflict of interest problem which appears to have arisen as a result of the revelations of the accounts of this company. More particularly, as Senator Baume said, to be a success this project needs numerous government approvals. Certainly, at the time at which it was originally proposed, the project needed numerous government approvals. We all know that the original, and perhaps still existing, secret proposal is to import genetic material from Denmark. This is something which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) claimed was never proposed. From the information available as a result of recent hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, we now find that that was the intention way back in 1990.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me is that AQIS claims that it has never had an application to import genetic material and live pigs from Denmark into Australia. Yet we also have available, as a result of hearings, evidence that shows that the head of quarantine in AQIS, Mr John Landos, was present at discussions in Copenhagen in September 1990, when our Ambassador, Mr Jeff Benson, and our Austrade official disclosed to him numerous details about this proposed joint venture—details that did not become publicly known for something like 18 months afterwards.

On top of that, we have a fax from our Austrade official in Copenhagen dated 22 November 1990 in which he says that he has had a discussion with Mr Hansen of the Federation of Danish Industries, who has just come back from Australia. Mr Hansen told him that all of the outstanding technical matters, principally quarantine ones, had been resolved. Yet AQIS says that this matter was never raised with it. That is the seriousness of the case. The introduction and the acceptance of genetic material from Denmark, where Aujesky's disease and mystery swine disease are rampant, would pose a very serious health threat to the Australian pig herd.

We really need to know on what basis that application was made and on what basis Mr Hansen could say that the issue had been resolved. There is only one official channel through which this issue could have been resolved: AQIS. AQIS said that it had never had an application and that the matter was not discussed with it at all during that time. So either AQIS was misleading the Senate Committee or somebody else was. Maybe Mr Hansen had the impression that he could get permission from somebody other than AQIS.

As Senator Baume said, the enormous financial pressure on the Prime Minister to get this deal through raises the possibility for all sorts of concerns about conflict of interest. While Senator Evans is in the chamber—I welcome him, as we all welcome him—I ask him to indicate to the Senate whether he is now prepared to table the material which is held on the Government files in relation to the knowledge that both our Ambassador in Copenhagen and our Austrade representatives had of this joint venture, as well as other people employed by the Department, what part they had in the discussions, and exactly how much contact they had. As a result of the documents that I have produced, there seems to be substantial evidence to show that they knew about it well before the details were publicly known in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson this day relating to Defence Force personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise today to raise this issue purely because of the human aspect involved with regard to Defence Force personnel who have either taken a redundancy package in the past six months or may be contemplating one in the near future. It is well known that most of those people, at the time of making their decision to take a package, were unaware that upon taking it they would not be able to apply for positions in the Australian Public Service which could be won on merit in competition with anybody else in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In my question today, I referred to the fact that a legal opinion was obtained from Mr Michael Finnane, QC, which the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) described as very impressive, that the Public Service Commissioner acted outside his authority in applying this policy to members of the Australian Defence Force in restricting them access to jobs in the Australian Public Service. I raise this purely because the commissioner has now advised each department in writing that the enforcement of this policy is in fact at its own discretion and that the commissioner has no power to enforce it.

The major point I raise is that, if the Public Service Commissioner has confirmed that the enforcement of those guidelines is at the discretion of the Department of Defence, the Department can, without consultation with the Department of Industrial Relations, use that discretion and decide today, if it wants to, to take on redundant Australian Defence Force personnel. I do not believe that the matter needs to go to Cabinet, as the Minister said, and it does not need to be referred to the Department of Industrial Relations because the Public Service Commissioner quite publicly stated that it is at each department's own discretion to enforce the guidelines.

I raise this particular issue because there are personnel in the defence forces who are considering redundancy packages. That decision is a very difficult decision to make in some cases and the decisions may depend entirely on the financial considerations that those personnel know they might have to face in the future or the opportunity that they might have to gain employment in the Australian Public Service.

A lot of people in the defence forces have been considering these options for a long time and they need to know one way or the other exactly what their situation will be so they can make those decisions with some sort of confidence, rather than waiting for a decision to be made, at some time in the future, by the Department of Defence, Cabinet or in consultation with the Department of Industrial Relations.

Again, in light of the opinion of Mr Finnane, QC, I would call on the Minister, in consultation with his Department, to instruct the Public Service that it could accept applications from redundant ADF personnel as a result of the current Army and Air Force redundancy programs; and that ADF personnel, who have won positions on merit with the Department of Defence and allied agencies since the commissioner's decision has become known, immediately be considered for employment in the same position or similar positions. Those people are going through unjust hardships at present, wondering just what their future situation will be. I believe that unfair financial duress has been placed on those people because they made their decisions without any knowledge of the restrictions that were to be placed on them then or might be placed on them in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the review of the office of Commonwealth Ombudsman and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: On 10 December 1990, the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, suggested that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration review the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. On 12 December 1990, the Committee resolved to review the jurisdiction, performance, resources and legislation of the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

The Committee received 74 submissions from individuals, organisations and Commonwealth Departments and authorities. It took oral evidence from 61 witnesses over 6 hearing days in May, June, August and September 1991. The Committee presented its Report to the President of the Senate on 20 January 1992 and the Report was tabled in the Senate on 25 February 1992.

Before dealing with the Committee's recommendations, the Government would like to express its thanks to the Committee for its efforts in producing this very useful report. The Government endorses the Committee's view that, over more than 15 years of operation, the Ombudsman has made a positive contribution to Australian public administration. The Committee's recommendations, directed to maintaining and strengthening that contribution, underscore its conclusion that in resolving individual complaints, the office of Ombudsman is performing an important function in its own right.

Over its period of operation, the office of Ombudsman has become a central element in administrative review and in public administration generally. It has compelled administrators to take a second look at the way their actions can impact on the members of the public with whom they come into contact. The Committee's recommendations are directed at producing a stronger and more focused Office, which will continue to deal promptly and effectively with large numbers of complaints from the public. The Government notes particularly the valuable contribution by the Ombudsman at a more general level that has arisen out of the investigation of individual complaints when administrative practices or legislation which may have operated unfairly or capriciously have been changed to the benefit of the public at large.

At the time of tabling this Report, the Government was aware that the position of Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman was about to become vacant, due to the appointment of the present Ombudsman, Mr Alan Cameron, as Chairperson of the Australian Securities Commission from 1 January 1993. The Government takes this opportunity to thank Mr Cameron for his contribution to public administration, especially in relation to the management of the Office. The response refers to initiatives that Mr Cameron proposed to implement in the Office. While it may be expected that these initiatives could be the subject of review by the new Ombudsman, the Government would see no reason why implementation of them should not proceed.

Recommendation 1 was that on the next occasion the office of Ombudsman is vacant, the Government seek candidates of merit from fields other than law as well as lawyers. There is no question that legal skills are relevant to the Office of the Ombudsman and, in fact, all Commonwealth Ombudsmen have had legal qualifications. That said, other skills are also relevant, and it is most important that any person appointed as Ombudsman be able to carry out the high level administrative and managerial functions of the position. As noted above, the position of Ombudsman is soon to become vacant. The advertisement calling for applications for appointment seeks "a person of integrity and standing in the community. He or she should be currently engaged in management or administration at a high level, in either the government or non-government sector". This approach does not discriminate against non-lawyers. On this occasion and in future, the Government will make it clear, when applications are sought, that responses from both lawyers and non-lawyers with appropriate management or administration experience will be welcomed.

Recommendation 2 was that the Ombudsman Act 1976 be amended to require the Government to respond to reports made to Parliament under section 17 of the Act within 3 months of tabling. The Government accepts that a response should be made within 3 months but does not consider legislation would be required. In circumstances where a section 17 report is referred to a Parliamentary Committee for consideration, the Government considers it would be appropriate to await any report from the Committee before responding. In such a case, the 3 month limit could apply from the making of the Committee report.

An important power of the Ombudsman is the power to recommend a remedy for the consequences of defective administration, including financial recompense. Where the responsible agency has no legal liability to make such recompense, it may be made by way of an act of grace payment under section 34A of the Audit Act 1901. In early 1989, the Minister for Finance authorised Secretaries of Departments to approve act of grace payments where the Ombudsman had recommended payment and the Department of Finance had been consulted. A trial of this devolved arrangement was carried out in 1989 and 1990, although devolution continued after the trial was completed. The trial was being evaluated at the time of the Committee's inquiry and the Committee recommended (recommendation 3) that, should devolution continue, it should be made subject to a limit of $5,000 (or $1,000 per year for continuing payments) and to a reporting requirement. The proposed amounts are one-tenth of the maximum amount which the Audit Act permits to be paid as an act of grace payment without reference to a statutory committee.

The Government notes that the Committee was of the view that unless the final evaluation of the trial can point to a real risk of undesirable precedents or significant inequity, it would have to conclude that the devolution should continue.

The Government accepts the thrust of the Committee's views: authority for remedying the consequences of defective administration should, in principle, reside with the heads of agencies and departments responsible for the defect. Similarly, heads of agencies should expect to be called to account not only for the matter giving rise to the proposal for a remedy but also for the remedy itself. The Government questions, however, whether devolution of the Minister for Finance's unique, statutory, act of grace power is the most appropriate way to achieve this: the power may be devolved to agency heads over whom the Minister has no legal authority, yet it is the Minister who remains ultimately accountable for its exercise.

Accordingly, the Government is considering an alternative solution to establish a non-statutory scheme under which agencies could determine the payment of compensation to persons who have suffered financial detriment as a result of maladministration at the agencies' hands, with provision to make payments for that purpose being included, as required, in the agency's or department's annual appropriations. Devolution of the act of grace power will continue until any new system is implemented.

Recommendation 4 was that the Ombudsman should have jurisdiction to deal with complaints from persons and organisations claiming to have been misrepresented on ABC programs. The Government is of the view that the Ombudsman's jurisdiction in relation to administrative matters already includes jurisdiction to deal with complaints about misrepresentation. The Government has, however, noted the longstanding dispute between the ABC and the Ombudsman about the extent of the latter's jurisdiction with respect to programming matters and agrees that the problem needs to be resolved.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 contains a mechanism by which the ABC and SBS will be able to be held to account by the Australian Broadcasting Authority for breaches of Codes of Practice established under their respective Acts. The Government considers that this should provide an adequate forum for persons who consider that they have been misrepresented by either broadcaster. The Ombudsman will retain jurisdiction over activities relating to matters of administration including those arising in the preparation and broadcast of ABC and SBS programs, except where the subject matter of the complaint comes within the jurisdiction of the ABA. The Government will also amend the Ombudsman Act to facilitate the transfer of complaints between the Ombudsman and the Authority.

If these arrangements do not prove satisfactory, and there continues to be dispute as to the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman or the ABA, the Government will consider legislative options, including giving the Ombudsman explicit jurisdiction over all aspects of misrepresentation on ABC and SBS services.

Recommendation 5 was that government companies and other bodies be placed within jurisdiction of the Ombudsman unless specifically excluded. The current position is that a government body is within jurisdiction if it is established under an Act. However, a government company is not included unless specifically referred to in a schedule to the Regulations made under the Ombudsman Act. A body which is within jurisdiction can cease to be so simply by becoming a government company unless included in the schedule. The Committee was apparently concerned that the structure of many Commonwealth bodies has changed over the years without explicit consideration being given to whether the actions of the restructured body should remain subject to the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman. The Committee focused particularly on Government Business Enterprises.

The Government agrees that it is necessary for the Act to contain a mechanism which would facilitate the making and execution of decisions about whether particular bodies should be within or outside the Ombudsman's jurisdiction. In deciding to introduce amendments to achieve this, the Government does not intend that bodies presently excluded from the Ombudsman's jurisdiction will be included or that bodies presently included will be excluded. Nor does the Government depart from its general view that Government Business Enterprises operating in a competitive environment should not be subject to constraints not applying to their private sector competitors. The Government notes that the Administrative Review Council (ARC) is to report in the near future on the application of administrative law to Government Business Enterprises.

Recommendation 6 arose from the fact that the Ombudsman Regulations were out of date and, for example, did not refer to bodies by their current titles and included some bodies which no longer existed. The recommendation was that the schedules to the Regulations specifying bodies included and excluded from jurisdiction should be reviewed. The Government amended the Ombudsman Regulations in December 1991 to take account of the changes that had occurred up to that time. It will make further amendments as required to give effect to this recommendation and to ensure that the Regulations remain current.

Recommendation 7 was that the Ombudsman Act 1976 be amended to enable classes of administrative action, specifically commercial actions, to be taken out of the Ombudsman's jurisdiction. While recognising and accepting (as did the Committee) that some commercial activities should not be subject to Ombudsman review, the Government believes that adoption of this recommendation could increase the prospect of disputes about jurisdiction between the Ombudsman and Government bodies, a result which could threaten the Ombudsman's overall effectiveness. As noted in relation to recommendation 5, the ARC is to report soon on the application of administrative law to Government Business Enterprises. The Ombudsman has exercised his discretion and decided not to investigate complaints about commercial policy decisions in the past and there is no suggestion he would commence doing so in the future. The Government has decided, however, to introduce legislation to make explicit the Ombudsman's discretion not to investigate complaints about activities of this kind.

Recommendation 8 was that the jurisdiction currently with the Merit Protection and Review Agency to investigate employment-related grievances be transferred to the Ombudsman. partly as a means of extending the coverage of the grievance mechanism to Commonwealth employees who do not have access to the MPRA under the present arrangements. The Government does not consider that it is appropriate to make the change proposed by the Committee. Removal of an important function from the Agency would reduce its size and field of operations to a point where its continued status as an important element in public sector management and industrial relations could be jeopardised. Instead, recognising the lack of a distinct border between the Ombudsman's jurisdiction and that of the Agency, the Government will introduce legislation to facilitate the transfer of casework between the two bodies.

On the issue of the coverage of Commonwealth employees, the extent to which the MPRA grievance mechanism is, pursuant to the provisions of the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984, available to employees not employed under the Public Service Act 1922 is determined by arrangements in place with particular Commonwealth authorities at the option of those agencies. This legislative scheme provides flexibility in relation to Commonwealth employment outside the Public Service Act.

Recommendation 9 was that the Ombudsman be given jurisdiction over the Parliamentary Departments, other than in relation to actions that are proceedings of the Parliament. The Government accepts this recommendation and will introduce legislation to include the Parliamentary Departments among the bodies about which complaints may be investigated. The legislation will ensure that the Ombudsman is excluded from investigating proceedings of the Parliament. Should the Ombudsman be dissatisfied with the response of a Parliamentary Department to a report under section 15 of the Ombudsman Act, he will be able, in recognition of the special position of the Parliamentary Departments, to report directly to the relevant House or Houses of Parliament rather than to the Prime Minister, and then to Parliament.

Recommendation 10 was that, consistently with recommendation 9, the Ombudsman should be unable to investigate those activities of the Parliamentary statutory committees that are proceedings of the Parliament as defined in subsection 16(2) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. The Government accepts the recommendation and will introduce legislation to remove those activities of the Committees from the Ombudsman's jurisdiction.

Recommendation 11 was that the administrative actions of the registries of the High Court, the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal be brought within the Ombudsman's jurisdiction. The Government will implement the recommendation and in doing so, notes that this will restore the jurisdiction that the Ombudsman had over the registries of Commonwealth Courts, other than the High Court, prior to the passage of the Courts and Tribunals Administration Act 1989. That Act gave the relevant Chief Justice or President formal responsibility for the administration of the Federal Court, Family Court or Administrative Appeals Tribunal and, in so doing, it had the unanticipated effect of removing the Court and Tribunal registries from the Ombudsman's jurisdiction. The Government also accepts the Committee's suggestions on the reporting arrangements.

Recommendation 12 was to bring the administrative actions of the courts, magistrates and coroners of Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands under the Ombudsman's jurisdiction. Noting the pending transfer of responsibility to Western Australia of responsibility for the courts of the Indian Ocean Territories and the unique position of Norfolk Island, the Government does not consider that there is any present need to accept the recommendation.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 gives the Ombudsman the function of inspecting records held by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the National Crime Authority relating to interceptions conducted by those agencies of telecommunications services for law enforcement purposes. The Ombudsman reports to the Attorney-General on that inspection.

Recommendation 13 was that this function be transferred from the Ombudsman to the Privacy Commissioner or the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. Noting the Ombudsman's history of successful performance of this role, the Government does not consider that this recommendation should be accepted.

Recommendation 14 was that the Government should consider assigning the role of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO) to the Commonwealth Ombudsman and that future decisions to establish specialist ombudsman institutions be made having regard to whether the Commonwealth Ombudsman could perform the particular function. It is the Government's intention that it not be directly involved in the selection of the TIO. The decision to extend ombudsman-type coverage into the operations of private sector companies was made in the light of the introduction of competition in telecommunications. The scheme accordingly, should reflect the commercial nature of the industry and cater for the commercial manner in which the participants (all the telecommunications carriers and other service providers which decide to participate on a voluntary basis) wish to deal with customer complaints.

In the circumstances, it would not be appropriate to extend the Commonwealth Ombudsman's jurisdiction to the private sector participants in the industry, particularly as the TIO scheme is being developed by the industry and will be paid for by the industry. The carriers propose that the TIO Council, which will be representative of scheme participants as well as consumers, will appoint the TIO as soon as a suitable candidate has been identified. While the Ombudsman has indicated that, subject to appropriate terms and conditions, he is willing to perform the role of the TIO, whether as a statutory function or otherwise, the decision as to who will be the TIO will be in the hands of the TIO Council.

Subject to a proposed review during 1993 of the application of Commonwealth law to the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation, the Commonwealth Ombudsman will retain jurisdiction over those complaints which will not be able to be dealt with by the TIO.

The appropriate structure and location for other specialist ombudsman institutions will be decided as and when those institutions are created. In making or contributing to those decisions, the Government will have regard to the degree of private sector involvement in the relevant field and the degree to which Commonwealth bodies in the field remain under any form of direction or obligation. The Government will however, introduce legislation to ensure that the Ombudsman is able to enter into arrangements to carry out non-statutory investigation functions such as those of the telecommunications industry ombudsman. The Government will also legislate to ensure that the Commonwealth Ombudsman is able to refer appropriate complaints and information to the TIO whenever he considers this necessary.

Recommendation 15 was that the Ombudsman increase the Office's activities in providing feedback to departments and authorities on complaint trends and in publicising its activities. The Government accepts the principle underlying the recommendation and has agreed to the provision of additional resources to enable the Ombudsman to publicise his Office's activities. The Ombudsman agrees with the Committee, as also does the Government, that the provision of feedback to agencies and publicising his Office's activities are valuable means of encouraging improved administration. As recommended, he is seeking to increase his Office's efforts in these areas. His intention is to develop the existing arrangements for senior level consultation between his Office and agencies, to emphasise the role of his senior managers in representing the Office in a variety of forums, to assist agencies and bodies reviewing agency operations to identify and correct administrative deficiencies and to foster media interest in his role and in significant matters which come before him. The Office's new information technology strategy is expected to assist in recording information on complaint trends and issues. In addition, the Ombudsman is considering whether the format of his annual reports might be changed to highlight complaint trends and systemic issues.

Recommendation 16 was that the Ombudsman's complaint recording system be improved to encourage changes needed in the administrative system. The Government has agreed to provide capital funding of $470,000 and ongoing funding of $53,000 to assist the Ombudsman to replace his Office's computer system and maintain the new system at a high level.

The Ombudsman shares the Committee's assessment that his Office's present computer system is near the end of its effective life. Its limitations cause substantial inefficiency and greatly curtail the Ombudsman's capacity to provide feedback to agencies. The Office will meet the cost, over the amount referred to above, of acquiring the new system from a resource agreement with the Department of Finance.

Recommendation 17 is that the Ombudsman establish a specialist unit to investigate major complaints. The Government has agreed to provide additional funding of $335,000 to enable the Ombudsman to establish such a unit, intending that it should deal with major investigations and all complaints about the AFP from or on behalf of Aboriginals which are associated with a death or which involve a serious injury resulting from custody. This latter function follows the Government's acceptance of recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.
The Ombudsman considers that the establishment of a special investigation unit will permit his Office to carry out its functions more effectively and efficiently.

Recommendation 18 was that unless adequate resources are made available for active investigation by the Ombudsman of a sufficient number of AFP internal investigations of complaints and for a reduction in delays in reviewing those investigations, the role of investigating complaints against the police be removed from the Ombudsman. As indicated in relation to recommendation 17, the Government has agreed to the provision of additional funding to the Ombudsman's office for the purpose of conducting major investigations, a proportion of which are likely to involve complaints against the police. It has also agreed to the provision of some modest additional funding in respect of general workload increases.

Recommendation 19 was that the Ombudsman recover funds from the Australian Capital Territory for the cost of investigating complaints relating to ACT policing. In fact, a cost recovery scheme is already in operation.

Recommendation 20 was that the Ombudsman promote his Office's services, targeted to low-income and disadvantaged groups. The Government has agreed to funding of $25,000 to enable the Ombudsman to conduct a survey of public awareness of his Office's services and $30,000 to carry out a modest promotional campaign, targeted to low income and disadvantaged people.

The Ombudsman has already taken some action to implement the recommendation. Several agencies with major service provision responsibilities have agreed to include reference to his Office in their publicity material and the Ombudsman is pursuing similar arrangements with other agencies. In co-operation with other interested agencies (which shared the costs), the Ombudsman has commissioned a survey of community awareness of his Office and administrative review generally. The Ombudsman will use survey findings as he continues to seek out low-cost promotional opportunities and to co-operate with other agencies, including review bodies in making his office known to the public.

Report No 34 of the Administrative Review Council, "Access to administrative review by members of Australia's ethnic communities", dealt with access to administrative review by members of ethnic communities and recommended an enhanced role for the Ombudsman as a central referral point for administrative review agencies. The Attorney-General will respond to the Report.
Recommendation 21 was that the Ombudsman encourage agencies subject to large volumes of complaints to establish internal complaint handling mechanisms.

The Ombudsman encourages and assists agencies to set up internal complaint handling mechanisms whenever there is an opportunity to do so. As an ex officio member of the Administrative Review Council, the Ombudsman participates in considering appropriate mechanisms for administrative review. While the Council is primarily concerned with external review of administrative decisions, it has recognised the value of internal complaint handling as a first step in resolving individual grievances.

Recommendation 22 was that the Ombudsman, in consultation with the Department of Finance, establish and report on a system of performance evaluation. The Ombudsman's Office already collects and reports on certain performance data and it has carried out a small scale evaluation of the Defence Force Ombudsman program.

The Office is looking for ways of identifying relevant and comprehensive qualitative and quantitative performance information. It has made some progress, but needs to do more work on establishing appropriate qualitative information. It will be necessary to complete this task and to have the new computer system record sufficient relevant information, before embarking on the formal evaluation program recommended by the Committee. The Ombudsman intends, once those steps are completed, to establish a formal performance evaluation system. The Government notes that the Ombudsman's Office is committed to evaluations of its complaint management system, promotional activities and the specialist investigation unit.

Recommendation 23 was that the Government propose and support an increase in the Ombudsman's funding to enable him to carry out the functions proposed by the Committee. As indicated in relation to recommendation 16, the Government has agreed to provide the Ombudsman with $470,000 for the purchase of a new information technology system, with a further $53,000 per annum for ongoing costs associated with the management of the system. The Government has also agreed (see response to recommendation 17) to an increase in annual funding of $335,000 to enable the establishment of a specialist investigation unit. This unit will have the additional role, anticipated in the Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, of investigating complaints by Aboriginals against the Australian Federal Police which relate to death or serious injury in custody. The Government has also agreed to funding to assist the Ombudsman in conducting a survey of public awareness of his office and a modest promotional campaign (see response to recommendation 20). These increases in the resources of the Ombudsman's Office are a practical demonstration of the Government's support for the Ombudsman institution.

Recommendation 24 was that the coordination comment on Cabinet submissions include an estimate of any likely significant impact of new initiatives on the Ombudsman's resource requirements. The Government considers the issue relates more to the preparation of Cabinet submissions than to coordination comments and will therefore take steps to amend the relevant part of the Cabinet Handbook so as to remind those preparing submissions for consideration by Cabinet of the need to consider possible impacts of proposed initiatives on the Ombudsman and to consult with the Ombudsman's Office in this regard.

Recommendation 25 was that the Ombudsman's resources be increased to deal with additional workload should the Taxation Relief Board be abolished and not replaced. The Government decided to abolish the Board in the 1990-91 Budget, but has not yet implemented that decision pending consideration of how the Board's functions might be carried out. Whatever mechanism replaces the Board, the Government agrees that if the Ombudsman could demonstrate a significant increase in his workload arising from that change, consideration would be given to additional funding.

Recommendation 26 was that, where the Ombudsman was given a specialist role, his performance of that role be funded through charges on the organisations subject to oversight. The Government accepts this recommendation in principle, although it will consider each case as and when it arises. As noted in relation to recommendation 14, the Government will introduce legislation to enable the Ombudsman to enter into arrangements to provide non-statutory complaint services.

Recommendation 27 was that the Ombudsman, in consultation with relevant executive agencies, should seek to establish a system of secondment of a limited number of public servants to investigation duties in the Ombudsman's office and that the Government consider the desirability of requiring the agencies subject to the largest number of complaints to fund those secondments. The Government supports this concept, noting that the bodies which attract most complaints are mostly large enough to forego a relatively small proportion of their resources.

The establishment of a system of secondments, and the nature of that system is, however, a matter for the Ombudsman. The Ombudsman sees considerable value in secondment and exchange arrangements with other agencies and, like his predecessors, has encouraged agencies to participate in such arrangements. Over recent months, several agencies have expressed a willingness to second staff to the Ombudsman's Office and a number of secondments and exchanges have taken place.

While the Ombudsman is optimistic that these arrangements will become a regular feature of his Office's staffing, he does not see them as substituting for permanent staffing. The Office has a limited capacity to absorb seconded staff while retaining the experienced officers necessary to maintain overall high levels of productivity.

Recommendation 28 proposed that the Ombudsman test the existing scope for employing staff under contract. The Government would be willing to consider whether the Ombudsman should be given a special employment power outside the Public Service Act 1922 if the Ombudsman finds the powers provided by that Act insufficient to meet his Office's needs.

Recommendation 29 was that the Ombudsman Act 1976 be amended to replace the requirement that there be three Deputy Ombudsmen with a more flexible requirement that there be no fewer than one and no more than three. The Government accepts the recommendation and will introduce legislation to give it effect.

Recommendation 30 was that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration meet regularly and jointly to consider a range of matters relating to the Ombudsman. The Government notes that consideration of special reports by the Ombudsman is already a standing reference of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Government considers that it is for Parliament to decide which Committee, or combination of Committees, should have the important new role proposed by the review but it indicates its support for a standing arrangement to monitor the relationship between the Ombudsman and the Parliament.

Recommendation 31 was that a panel, made up of the Chairs and Deputy Chairs of the Committee and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, advise on nominations for appointment as Ombudsman and on proposals to terminate appointments. The Government undertakes to consult with a panel representing Parliamentary Committees with an interest in the Ombudsman's activities in relation to future appointments after Mr Cameron's replacement is selected. The Government considers it is for Parliament to determine which Committees should be involved in this process. The Ombudsman Act already provides a scheme for removal of an Ombudsman which involves the Parliament.

The Committee should be well pleased with the Government's response to its recommendations. Of the 31 recommendations, 26 have been accepted in full or in principle. Of the 5 which have not been accepted, 1 (dealing with complaints against the ABC) has been overtaken by events, as has part of another (dealing with complaints about the Courts of the Indian Ocean Territories) and a third (relating to the Ombudsman's jurisdiction over government companies and other government bodies) has been accepted so far as it relates to government bodies currently within jurisdiction which change structure in the future. Only 3 recommendations (about the employment grievance jurisdiction, the administrative actions of the courts, magistrates and coroners of the island territories, and about the telecommunications interception records inspection function) were rejected.

The Government has welcomed the opportunity provided by the Committee's report to look afresh at the role and function of the Ombudsman. It has agreed to make some minor adjustments to the Ombudsman's jurisdiction and legislation and has approved a modest increase in his Office's resources. The fact that so few substantial changes to legislation have been needed after 15 years is an endorsement of the soundness of the policy underlying the creation of the Office. It emphasises the remarkable level of acceptance of the role of the Ombudsman by the community and by the bureaucracy. It is a reflection of the contribution of the present Ombudsman and his predecessors to fair and open decision-making in the Commonwealth sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take up a great deal of time at the moment in commenting on the Government response, but I think it is important that I make a few remarks at this stage to note the response and to say that I generally welcome the indications of support by the Government for recommendations from the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration about the Ombudsman.

PARA.TAB: The response is late as far as the timing promised by the Government for responses to committee reports is concerned, but it is in some ways a convenient time because the Committee has arranged to have a public hearing tomorrow with the Ombudsman in order to discuss his latest annual report. It will also provide an opportunity to discuss with him this Government response and to seek his views about the way in which the Government proposes to deal with some of those recommendations. It is very important that the valuable work of the Ombudsman be fully supported and continue in an acceptable way. As is known, Mr Alan Cameron, the current Ombudsman, is to vacate that position at the end of this year because he is taking up the chair of the Australian Securities Commission on 1 January. It is therefore important that we are having a discussion with him tomorrow and that this response has come down in time for us to look at it.

I welcome the Government's response on most matters. There are some recommendations that the Government has not accepted, and I express some disappointment about that. The response says that the Committee should be well pleased with the Government's response to its recommendations, given that 26 out of the 31 recommendations have been accepted in full or in principle. My reading of the report does not give me such a high proportion that I would declare as a success rate, but I still generally welcome the response.

One recommendation was that the Act be amended to require the Government to respond to reports made to parliament under section 17 of the Act within three months of tabling. The Committee thought it important that there be that obligation. The Government has accepted that a response should be made within three months, but it does not consider that legislation would be required to give it effect. I still think it would have been preferable to amend the Act to require that, but in any case the Government has indicated that it will respond within three months to any such report. Section 17 reports are relatively rare and, hopefully, it will continue to be a rare occurrence that there is a need for such a report.

It is interesting to note the response to recommendation 3 about the devolution of act of grace payments. The Government is considering a completely alternative solution to establish a non-statutory scheme under which agencies could determine the payment of compensation to persons who have suffered financial detriment as a result of maladministration at the agency's hands. The sting is that that would be effected within the department's annual appropriations, so that the agency or department would have to find the funds. That is an interesting alternative way of providing compensation payments that the act of grace system has provided until now.

As to the recommendation dealing with the ABC, I mention in passing that, because of other developments such as the introduction of the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the question of the Ombudsman and the ABC may not be as important a matter as it has been in the past.

The question of including or excluding certain government bodies, especially government companies, is a continuing problem area. I am not particularly clear about the impact of the Government's response to that and I am interested to seek clarification. There is proposed to be an amendment to facilitate the making and execution of decisions about whether particular bodies should be within or outside the Ombudsman's jurisdiction, but not intending that the bodies presently excluded would be included or that the bodies presently included would be excluded. I particularly disagree with the point that the Government does not depart from its general view that government business enterprises operating in a competitive environment should not be subject to constraints not applying to their private sector competitors. I still take the view that if a body is a government body it should be subject to the Ombudsman, as with other government requirements, even if it is competing in the market place.

I am certainly not proposing to comment on all these recommendations and the Government's response, but one recommendation I do welcome is that the Ombudsman is to be given jurisdiction over the parliamentary departments other than in relation to actions that are proceedings of the Parliament. It is important to ensure that, as well as the Executive departments in matters of straight administration, the parliamentary departments are also included in the Ombudsman's area of responsibility. The response indicates that, in recognition of the special position of the parliamentary departments, the report would be directly to the relevant House or Houses rather than to the Prime Minister.

I am puzzled about the question of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Recommendedation 13 was that this function be transferred from the Ombudsman to the Privacy Commissioner or the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. The response states:

SPEECH.PARA: Noting the Ombudsman's history of successful performance of this role, the Government does not consider that this recommendation should be accepted.

My recollection of the evidence to us was that there was not a particularly successful performance of this role and the Ombudsman wanted to divest himself of it, so that response is somewhat surprising.

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing to see that the Government has responded to the recommendation from the Committee that there be a modest increase in the funding of the Ombudsman's office, that there be substantial funding for the replacement of the antiquated computer system, and that there be a reasonable amount of funding to assist the Ombudsman to have a special unit to investigate major complaints. The problem was that the Ombudsman was so busy dealing with individual complaints that substantial areas had to be overlooked. It is important that major complaints that would require a great amount of resources should be able to be dealt with by the Ombudsman.

Recommendation 30 was that there be a regular meeting between the Ombudsman and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and its House of Representatives equivalent to ensure an ongoing relationship between the Ombudsman and the Parliament. The Government supports that in general, but suggests that it is up to the Parliament to decide which committee or combination of committees should have this role. I urge the Opposition to support the proposal that it be dealt with by the committees of both Houses together. I know that they have some reservations about such procedures, but I think it is important that the Ombudsman be seen to have a relationship with both Houses, not just with the Senate. I would like to see joint meetings of the two committees with the Ombudsman once or twice a year to review the administration of that area of government.
I welcome the Government response to the report and look forward to discussing it and the Ombudsman's annual report with the Ombudsman tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the review of the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I take the opportunity to congratulate Mr Alan Cameron on a job well done as Ombudsman and to wish him well in the very important work he takes up in the new year as head of the Australian Securities Commission. Mr Cameron always sought to work very closely with the Parliament. We appreciate the work he did, both with the Parliament and in executing his important role with people who had grievances with the system.

PARA.TAB: I wish particularly to comment on one of the points made in the Government response. I refer in particular to the comments on recommendation 25 of the Committee's report.

This recommendation states that should the Taxation Relief Board be abolished and not replaced, then the Ombudsman's resources should be increased to deal with the additional workload that would result. I am pleased to note that in relation to the Government its recommendation is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . agrees that whatever mechanism replaces the Board, should the Ombudsman be able to demonstrate a significant increase in his workload arising from the change, then consideration would be given to additional funding.

I welcome the Government's agreement to this recommendation. However, on a sadder note, I would like to point out that it is now December 1992. In the Budget of 1990-91, the Government decided to repeal section 265 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The cancellation of that section, had it taken place, would have removed the ability of taxpayers to seek relief for small claims in times of hardship and to place their problems before the Taxation Relief Board. It is very important that we have a mechanism that will provide a facility for taxpayers who are in financial distress for a number of reasons to get relief in genuine circumstances.

PARA.TAB: However, since that time, the Government has not been able to come up with an alternative as to how it should replace the Taxation Hardship Board. I believe it is time that the Government admitted that it made a mistake in the 1990-91 Budget with its decision to repeal section 265 and, consequently, the Hardship Relief Board mechanism. It has worked well and it has helped hundreds of taxpayers. It is interesting to note that as soon as this Budget decision was announced in 1990, a media release from the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The tax office is continuing to process relief applications from taxpayers who, due to serious hardship, have trouble paying their tax.
The media release continued:

Contrary to the concerns being reported in the media, the Government has not denied those in serious hardship avenues to seek relief from taxation liability. The current relief board system . . . will be replaced with more flexible administrative arrangements.

This chamber is still awaiting the announcement of the new flexible arrangements. In fact, nothing has been heard from the Government about these new arrangements—and fortunately so. But it is of interest to note that in May of this year, during questions in Senate Estimates Committee A, officials from the Australian Taxation Office reaffirmed the use of the Taxation Relief Board should a taxpayer find himself or herself in extreme financial hardship. In fact, it has been business as usual since the Parliamentary Secretary released his media release soon after the Budget.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Relief Board should continue and should not be replaced. I agree that the Ombudsman could provide the same sort of service so long as there is additional resources with specialist facilities locked into that operation, but why change a system that is meeting a need? This board helps the everyday little Australian. Since 1936 thousands of Australian taxpayers in circumstances of great need have benefited through the board, which gives them an independent avenue of appeal.

The board, with membership comprising the Commissioner of Taxation, the Secretary to the Department of Finance and the Comptroller-General of Customs—or their nominees—was able to assist people who often, through no fault of their own, had not been able to pay tax in certain situations. A good example, of course, is the death of a spouse. In such a case, a tax liability could be waived or eased. The average assistance, taking into account the amount paid and the number of taxpayers asking for assistance, is usually less than $2,000 per person.

Further, this board has objectivity and independence which it may not have under any new yet to be announced administrative arrangements. When one considers the economic problems of the 1990s, the decision to repeal section 265 of the Act was drastic. This situation has not changed; indeed it has worsened. There is now an even greater need for this board. This is evidenced by the fact that the Government has not yet found a replacement. In 1990 the only reason that the Government could give for the abolition of the Taxation Hardship Board—or the Taxation Relief Board, as it is otherwise known—was that the board was up to 18 months behind in its assessment of hardship cases. I believe that a better plan of action could be to streamline the board, rather than to try something new.

Therefore, although I welcome the Government's response to the need to increase the Ombudsman's sources, should he need to provide the hardship services, I believe that the best course of action is to continue and increase the services of the Taxation Hardship Board. The Government needs to admit that it was mistaken in announcing the repeal of section 265 two years ago. I believe that this board provides a useful service. I hope that it will continue to provide such relief in genuine necessitating circumstances. I thank the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:
