SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting elements of this Treasury statement on tax expenditures is that it reveals the collapse of private sector contribution to film production under this Government as a result of a combination of the recession we had to have and the Government's changed tax laws. Only in 1987-88, the Government was, in fact, providing tax relief totalling $131m as an incentive for the private sector to contribute to the production of films. This year, 1991-92, this document reveals that that relief has fallen to only $43m—less than a third.

PARA.TAB: This fall reflects, I believe, one of the major problems that the film industry is facing. It is facing a dramatic collapse in private sector contributions. As a result, it depends more and more heavily on Government grants, leading to the potential for bureaucratic decision making about what should be made. I am glad to say that Strictly Ballroom—perhaps the greatest success we have had in recent times in the film industry—was prompted, I think, by private sector support totalling about $1m.

On the other hand, I cannot say that bureaucratic intervention has been massively to anyone's disadvantage, at least not to the industry's disadvantage, to the extent that I think that Romper Stomper required support from governmental film people—including the Victorians. It required bureaucratic support and of course is getting strong reviews, if some occasional critical comments about the violent nature of the film.

But the essential point is this: because of the tax benefit involved, $43m of tax relief generates something like $108m worth of funds to the industry. I understand that, in 1992-93, that figure will be much less than it has been in recent years. As I said, last year the benefit fell by two-thirds from the level in 1987-88, when the Government changed its policy.

It is clear that we should do what we can to increase incentives to the private sector to invest in the Australian film industry. It is a marvellous industry with magnificent potential. What we are doing by going about it the way the Government is presently going about it is to reduce private sector investment. Here we have a brilliant opportunity, with Strictly Ballroom, for example, having excited an interest in Australian films to, if you like, provide a situation where ordinary investors, mums and dads who have some savings could, if there were a reasonable instrument and if there were reasonable tax incentives, participate in this industry with a small investment.

Unfortunately, under this Government, there is basically no such opportunity. There is no capacity for the ordinary Australian families to invest, say, $1,000 in a movie that they would like to support, a movie of their choice, largely because of the incredible bureaucracy, particularly in relation to prospectuses, which has developed.

We have a disastrous situation where the Government will continue to reduce the grants to the film industry while at the same time the amount going in incentives for the private sector to invest is also being slashed. The Film Finance Corporation has revealed that, after $68m in government grants last year, the amount will fall to $61.9m this year, $57m the year after, $54m the year after and $50m the year after that.

The coalition will provide clear, specific and supportive tax and bureaucratic structures to enable the ordinary Australian to participate in support for the Australian film industry. That is the dramatic difference between the Government's policy—of which one might say that the Australian film industry is doing well in spite of it—and the sort of policy that the coalition has, which will encourage private sector participation in order to maximise the benefit that government funds will get by encouraging private sector funds. For every $100 of government tax benefit, $250 will go to the industry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this very important document published by the Treasury for 1992. It is an annual summary, published every year, to provide to the Parliament the annual cost to revenue of various concessions given within the taxation system in Australia. It actually indicates in monetary terms the annual cost to the taxpayer and the community of giving various tax concessions, deductions and rebates—a range of tax breaks, if you like—to various groups in the community. I believe it is very important that there should be transparency in the tax system; that taxpayers should be able to see readily the total, based on certain assumptions, of what it actually costs each year to give tax rebates and concessions to particular groups in the community.

PARA.TAB: One of the differences between this Government and the previous Liberal Government is that the Liberal Government had a policy of proliferating tax concessions and tax breaks to specific interest groups in the community. It did not tend to look at the tax system as a whole. Rather it tended to address problems in the community by giving concessions for this, that and the other. The net effect of that was to erode the Australian tax base and to weaken the capacity of the system to generate revenue. Of course, taxes are a vitally important ingredient in developed industrialised societies. It is taxes that in fact pay for the very valuable services provided in the modern community, and the level of taxation is very much an indicator of how wealthy a society is.

It is interesting that in recent years these tax expenditures have totalled, from memory, $3,000m per annum. In other words, the figure in recent years has been $3 billion per annum. It is a very large sum. That is the kind of revenue that has been forgone in recent years as a result of a range of concessions given within the tax system.

A very large item that has contributed to that large total figure, certainly during the 1980s, was the non-taxation of the surpluses of the superannuation funds, which are very large institutions in Australia. The non-taxation of the surpluses of those institutions compared with the surpluses of other financial organisations has meant that there has been a large tax subsidy to that particular industry in Australia.

Other rebates and concessions also contribute to the annual total of tax expenditures. They include such things as the dependent spouse rebate where one spouse is working and the other is not. There are other rebates on the Australian tax form which provide assistance for specific groups, and they add to the total revenue loss documented by this type of report.

It is a very significant document. It is vital in a democracy such as Australia that the real or effective tax rates—the tax rates as they impact on people and on businesses in the community—coincide fairly closely with the published or stated tax rates. After all, when we go to vote in elections most of us can only really make judgments about the tax system based on the published rates, the rates that are seen in the tax schedules. But, of course, the more rebates, concessions, tax breaks and tax lurks there are in the system the more those published tax rates are not the effective rates; the effective rates are in fact somewhat lower. So it is important that this annual document is published to indicate the scale of the loss of revenue to the nation through giving a range of tax rebates and tax concessions in the system.

The size of that annual figure gives some idea of the difference between effective rates and the actual published rates on tax forms facing businesses and individuals. Over the years, the Labor Government has taken the view that it is more important to get down the general rates of taxation in the community—getting the schedule rates down rather than giving specific tax concessions in the form of rebates and deductions to particular interest groups, which I think has characterised previous Liberal governments, which have tended to focus on problems in the community by throwing tax lurks at them and providing tax concessions. We take the view that it is more important to benefit all taxpayers by lowering general tax rates on the tax forms.

The runs are on the board. When we came into office the lowest marginal tax rate on the income tax form was 30c in the dollar. It is now around 20c in the dollar. At the top end of the income scale, in 1983 the marginal tax rate was 60c in the dollar; it is now of the order of 47c. They are very real tax reductions. It is more important to lower general tax rates than to give a range of concessions and rebates. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority is charged with a duty to supervise and manage the transformation of the industry as it becomes necessary to install technical and administrative changes to the barrier controls that affect the TCF industries. The report gives a picture of the import and export balance, which is anything but encouraging. Consumer demand for textile, clothing and footwear products improved during 1992 by almost 4 per cent. However, when we look at the disparity between imports and exports, the picture is not good. In 1991-92 imports increased by nearly 12 per cent to $3.5 billion. Exports rose from a low base by over 14 per cent to reach a mere $418m for the year.

PARA.TAB: When considering that report it is relevant to look at some of the evidence that was provided by manufacturers representing the industry before the Committee on Industry, Science and Technology when it was considering the Customs tariffs package. I refer in particular to Mr Trumble's evidence. Mr Trumble is the president of the TCF Council. On the first page of the Hansard for that Committee dated 13 November 1992, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: My organisation represents an industry that did employ 120,000 people. The latest figure that we can verify—in March of 1992—is that it had dropped to 76,000. It is our prediction that, after the disaster that will occur in March of 1993, that will probably fall to 55,000 or lower . . .
He also offers some comments on what he has found in China. It is an example I have cited before but it bears repeating. He said:
In China . . . the rate of pay for a 48-hour, six-day week, with no benefits of the type that we require in this country, is under $A20 per week. . .
. . . in March 1992 the volume of imports from developing countries, principally China, went up by 23 per cent for a value increase of 31 per cent.

That in part is the answer to the comments of Senator Button, the responsible Minister, when he says that he cannot see that tariff reductions have actually resulted in loss of jobs. How else does he explain the loss of jobs? How else does he explain the increase in imports? Mr Trumble says further:

The majority of our industry holds no forward orders for the winter of 1993. Therefore, I suggest that our projection of 55,000 people left employed in the industry after March of 1993 is probably highly optimistic.

That is less than half the number of people who were employed in the industry only a few years ago. I have looked in vain in the report to find a comment by the Authority on this trend; on this reduction in output by the Australian TCF industry and the resulting loss of jobs coinciding with the current recession. I suggest that the Authority should address itself to this question and should recommend to the Minister that there be, at this stage of the current recession, a pause in tariff cuts to enable the industry to have a breather, to regroup, and to concentrate on those parts of the industry which are able to increase export activities, so that we retain at least part of the TCF industry which forms a substantial part of our manufacturing industry in Australia. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very timely report as a committee of this Senate, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, has been inquiring into the cost of justice. Clearly, legal aid has a very important function to fulfil in providing access to people who otherwise would not have been able to access the legal system.

PARA.TAB: I note that the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee has consulted with a number of legal organisations, such as the Victorian Bar Council, lawyers' organisations in New South Wales, Queensland and others, looking at various aspects of the matters concerning legal aid. It has discussed legal aid funding difficulties in Victoria. I wonder whether it also discussed on that occasion the interest on solicitors' trust accounts which is one of the major sources of legal aid funds in Victoria.

I wish to put on the record once again my view that the interest on solicitors' trust accounts should be devoted almost entirely to the provision of legal aid funds, that lawyers should fund their activities—such as education, conferences, overseas travel, publication of their journals—from other sources, and should not take funds which rightly belong to the public. After all, the interest on trust funds is not theirs; it results from the funds that people have placed in their trust accounts.

I note that the report addresses legal expenses insurance and if that becomes a major practice in Australia it should free up funds for legal aid. The report also looks at contingency legal aid funding schemes. Once again, we should be grateful if that is increased under some sort of control. I would favour court approval before contingency fees are permitted.

I also note that there is a substantial section in the report on the use of paralegals in legal aid activities and also, generally, in the legal profession. Apart from the other barriers that have been noted in this report, we need to make sure that the legal profession opens up its ranks a little and does not place barriers in the way of people who are not fully qualified but who can obviously provide worthwhile legal services.

There is an interesting statement in the report that the use of interpreters in legal aid service delivery is likely to be affected adversely since the budget of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has not provided for increases in demand. Clearly, this will be the case.

One other matter to which the report refers is the provision of legal advice to asylum seekers. We are all aware of the people, mainly from Cambodia, who are currently in detention in WA. I believe the authors of the report are to be congratulated for their request to the Government that we should provide legal advice to these people and that we should not accept the Department's view that a differential standard should be applied. People who are not Australian citizens, but who nevertheless appear before Australian courts, should receive proper legal advice so that their interests can be protected. The view is also contrary to the international conventions that we have signed and ratified on behalf of the Government. It is a very important international legal rights area. I conclude by referring to the fact that the Committee has had contact with the Fitzroy Legal Service. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a few comments on the 1991-92 annual report of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. The AWRC took over the $2.7 billion debt, a 4.6 million bale stockpile, the warehouses and other properties held by the former Australian Wool Corporation. The debt has now been reduced by about $412m and the stockpile has been reduced by about 530,000 bales. Of course, that is still hanging over the top of the market all the time and until those stocks are got rid of it will be a matter of concern to the woolgrowers. This will require improved economic conditions and a lot of promotion on the part of the Commission to make sure the wool is dispersed in the community. In the last little while, the economic prospects have deteriorated and that is of grave concern to woolgrowers.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in the debate about the rural adjustment scheme we heard about the problems of the people in the wool growing industry. It is well worth letting people in this chamber know that the objectives of the Wool Realisation Commission are to manage and sell the stockpile, to manage the sales to the extent possible to avoid unduly depressing wool prices, and to create conditions conducive to developing efficient private marketing and selling systems. That is what the Commission has primarily addressed itself to in its first year.

The Australian wool industry will not again be viable to the extent that it used to be until we get rid of the wool stocks held in Australia at the moment. I trust that the Australian Wool Realisation Commission will do that in an efficient manner as quickly as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the special event that was held in this Parliament last year: the first National Wool Day to stimulate community interest in wool in the national economy. That event gave the Australian Wool Corporation a chance to generate public support. It also helped disseminate information, which was widely reported in the rural press, although it was basically not taken up by the metropolitan media. That was a sad thing because the wool industry is very important to Australia and it is very important that all Australians promote it.

PARA.TAB: I said nearly two years ago outside the front of Parliament House that, unless we get out and promote our wool and sell it to the people who want to buy it, we will be in a lot of bother. We cannot just look after just this end of the industry, we have to make sure that we have people who want to buy it and that we can supply the article they want.

It is interesting to note that of the International Wool Secretariat funding by the partners, Australia funded 78 per cent, New Zealand 13 per cent, South Africa 8 per cent and Uruguay only one per cent. Australia foots the main bill for the International Wool Secretariat. In the last year or so woolgrowers have had problems in meeting their payments because the wool industry has fallen and not as much revenue has been collected.

Wool is an important industry to Australia. I would have liked to spend longer speaking on this matter, but I know that other members want to speak on other documents. I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This document has been presented by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and addresses the very serious problem of research infrastructure in Australia's universities. The poor attitude of this Government towards research in Australia has been well documented and addressed in this place.

PARA.TAB: Over the last few weeks I have brought to the attention of the Senate some of the problems facing research in this country. There has been the bungled funding arrangements of the National Health and Medical Research Council where it was assumed that it would get a $3m rise in funding—it actually got a $1m cut. This occurred because the superannuation guarantee levy, which was supported by the Australian Democrats, has taken $1m out of the research budget of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

This funding problem for the NHMRC has meant that many promising young researchers will be left without local funding and 100 jobs will be lost. The lack of funding by this Government is also evidenced by the fact that 19 per cent of applicants for the Australian Research Council grants were the only ones that were successful. This fact led to the Executive Director of the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies commenting that government support for research in this country was so low that to talk of a clever country was a joke.

This research funding crisis is evidenced in my own region where the highly acclaimed medical faculty of the University of Newcastle has only been able to receive grants for nine out of the 34 projects that it submitted this year. These projects covered vital areas of medical research, such as breast cancer, leukemia, heart and lung disease.

An article in today's Sydney Morning Herald notes that other important medical research has been abandoned because of a funding crisis that has led to a collapse of morale, security and stability in this area. The article notes that grants from the NHMRC have hit a record low with only 20 per cent of applicants across Australia receiving approval. As a result, projects of excellence are being put on hold or scrapped.

Up to 150 researchers will be forced to look for new jobs, perhaps overseas, with some of them leaving projects which they have worked on for many years. An example of this type of research is that being undertaken into benign prostate disease which costs Australia up to $100m each year to treat. It has been put on indefinite hold because another highly commended grant missed out due to of lack of funding.

The head of the National Health and Medical Research Council has warned that the crisis cannot be underestimated and the long term health care system will suffer because there will be no research base to underpin professional education and practice.

Excellence in education, including research, has never been a priority for this Government and the report presented by NBEET today is yet further evidence of this. NBEET notes in the report the tremendous strain placed upon research infrastructure in this country and recommends that another $70m be spent in this area. I commend this report to the Senate because that is very much needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties have concerns about the changes in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1992 to certain of the existing royalty arrangements. Those concerns are shared by the Australian Democrats. A number of other senators would be concerned about the potential loss of jobs as a result of these provisions. The new provisions apply unfairly to existing equipment leases with non-residents. The tax will result in severe financial distress to some taxpayers and will place the employment of many personnel at risk. Australian residents will often carry the tax under the proposal because it is common for royalty agreements to pass the burden for such taxes to the Australian taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: The effective rate of tax is up to 43 per cent under current Australian Taxation Office grossing out rules. The amendments incorrectly assume that all large profits are derived on equipment leases which currently escape Australian tax. The impact of the amendments on business unemployment has been ignored. It will be catastrophic in respect of a number of enterprises. Despite claims to the contrary, the amendments are inconsistent with overseas practice on equipment leasing. The amendments are also inconsistent with the move to self-assessment.

The amendments are effectively retrospective, as they apply to leases entered into or substantially negotiated at the time of the amendments. This is our major cause of complaint. There was no consultation with the equipment leasing industry. I propose that some reasonable transitional or grandfathering provisions be introduced. It is common practice that, when such significant changes to taxation are made—and remember, this is much more than a simple change of rates—transitional provisions should reasonably apply. I deplore the complete absence of transitional provisions in this legislation and the potential effect that their absence could have on employment, the loss of some high tech industry within Australia and possibly the loss of oil rigs operating off the Australian coast.

Therefore, I intend to place an amendment before the Committee proposing that the traditional transitional provisions apply to contracts entered into up to 5 November 1992, being the date the Bill was passed by the House of Representatives. I recommend this date to the Committee because of a general lack of knowledge in the industry about the amendments. They were not mentioned as such in the Budget Speech. There were no press releases or the like. Because of the significant lead-up time involved in negotiating agreements—many, if not all, of which I believe would have commenced pre-Budget—the lack of consultation and the severe impact that the changes will have on some businesses affected by these changes, I think it is unreasonable, given the general terms of the words used in the Budget announcement, to expect those people affected by such leases to have seen the wider ramifications of this legislation as it affects equipment leases. Therefore, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 81, page 53, lines 37 to 40, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "81.The amendments made, and repeals effected, by this Division apply in relation to amounts derived by a taxpayer during the 1993-94 year of income of the taxpayer or during a later year of income of the taxpayer, but do not apply in relation to royalties derived by a taxpayer under a contract concluded on or before 5 November 1992 for the use of any industrial, commercial or scientific equipment.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendment represents a considered intervention to protect a wholly Australian owned company employing 175 Australians caught up in the new definition of `equivalent leases'. If the Opposition had not moved this amendment, the Australian Democrats would have done so. I think it is necessary. It is a go-between—between asking the Government to provide transitional arrangements and cutting off these people in their prime, so to speak. This is a wholly Australian owned South Australian company that is expanding and contributing significantly to Australia's economy. Senator Watson's amendment on behalf of the Opposition, moving the date to 5 November 1992, is also worthy of support by the Government.

—I make it very clear that we will not be supporting this amendment or we would be saying, `We are going to grandfather tax avoidance'. That is something the Government will never agree to. You cannot tell me that anybody in the world leases their aeroplanes through Jersey as a matter of normal business practice. The company has been consciously, deliberately, as a matter of strategy, putting its business through tax havens to avoid tax and the other party has said to it, quite consciously, `You have to take the tax risk of our trying to pull this little stunt'. Now it finds that, having taken the risk, it has been caught.
—You haven't given them time to change.

—Haven't given them time? No tax avoider has ever been given a more generous deal than this, and no-one has ever been given a deal anything like as generous as the Opposition is offering, and none has ever deserved it. There is no question that if we said to any company in Australia, `You do not have to pay tax on your operations' they could be more successful. I understand the concern for this company. No-one wants to see any company not succeed. If we are going to say to any company we are concerned about,`Okay, we can fix your problem; you can run your business without paying tax', they will all succeed. The Opposition is saying here, firstly, `Here is a little tip for your tax avoidance trick. We think it was smart so we are going to let you keep doing it'. Secondly, it is saying, `We are not only going to let you get away with it, but we are going to let you get away with it with regard to contracts which you entered into after we announced that we were going to close the loophole'. That has never happened before. The company concerned is saying, `We are a less competent company than any other company that has ever had tax avoidance measures closed in the past'.
—They had bad advice.

—They had bad advice or they chose to ignore good advice. None of us know which. From the point of view of proper public policy, it does not matter which. In this amendment the Opposition is going for one of the besetting weaknesses of this chamber, which is that, every time we offer someone a soft option, they grab it. The Opposition is saying, `Here is a way to stop anybody from complaining, and we will let the rest of the taxpayers who do not know about it carry the can'. The Opposition is saying, `We will subsidise these people. All the rest of Australia will do without the tax revenue to help these people'.
—You'd have the long term benefit of continuing employment.

—Every company will do better if it does not have to pay tax. There is nothing in that argument. It is self-evidently true and equally irrelevant. They seem to me to be the two fundamental questions at issue. I cannot see how either of them are arguable. In a moment I will come to a third thing that has been drawn to my attention about the terms of the amendment. There are two issues in question. I have had many debates with Senator Watson and Senator Kernot in the past—we have not always agreed—and I cannot understand how those two informed and concerned citizens can argue that we do not have two facts clear in this case. The first is that this is clear and unequivocal tax avoidance. There is no commercial reason to route these things through Jersey. I am not saying that they were breaking the law or that they should be clapped in irons. They just used a tax loophole and we are closing it. I do not think that is arguable. I do not even think they would argue it. They might, but privately they would not.
—Your action is brutal and instant and doesn't give them an opportunity to change over.

—My point is that it is tax avoidance. The second thing that is not arguable is that some of these contracts—this is blatant tax avoidance—were entered into after the Government had announced that the loophole was going to be closed.

PARA.TAB: At the Committee hearing I listened with interest to some of the concerns that a company raised. I wanted to see whether in some way account might be able to be taken of contracts with a continuing effect that were entered into before the Budget or contracts in respect of which an offer had been made and a response was awaited before the Budget was presented. There were at least arguable grounds for contending that these people were disadvantaged peculiarly by the circumstances in which they found themselves.

I do not find that a very attractive argument. I have not been dealing with tax legislation all that long, but I cannot recall a previous instance where this sympathetic hearing was extended to people when a loophole which they had been exploiting was closed off. I will not be unequivocal and say that there has never been such an occasion. I have never heard of such an occasion; there has not been one in the last three years. Those are the two key elements. Notwithstanding our concern about individuals and individual companies, we have to run the tax system with a bit of rigour and guts.

Before I pursue any further the last concern which has been drawn to my attention, I would want the opportunity to look at it more closely. The concern was expressed that the amendment leaves open the possibility of the further extension of the contracts we are grandfathering; that it does not have an end point—that is clear and unequivocal; and that if people extend the contracts which we grandfather, the loophole may continue to be available for those continuing contracts. Honourable senators might gather the impression that the Government is pretty firmly opposed to this amendment. If so, they are right.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard an extraordinary speech from the normally very reasonable Senator McMullan. Obviously, he has a passion for something. We are referring to arrangements that were perfectly good taxation law. We are referring to contracts that were approved by the Taxation Office, some of which were granted an exemption from withholding tax provisions.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Kernot referred to one particular South Australian company. I wish to put before the Committee that these sorts of equipment lease arrangements will affect not one but many companies in this area. What this Government has suddenly done in respect of existing contracts is retrospectively change the tax base. It might be one thing to put up the rate of tax, but there are not many businesses which can carry the costs resulting from a completely changed tax base and the introduction of a withholding provision with a gross up of 43 per cent.

If those opposite want to be strident about this matter, I must say that, in the event of these businesses closing down, the loss of jobs will certainly be on their heads. Let the South Australian Premier be very clear about that. I am not so certain about some of the other contracts. But certainly, the one Senator Kernot referred to would be in a very marginal position. The company concerned has been operating for something like three years. It is introducing high technology—the sorts of things we should be doing—and operates on the basis of complying with existing law and having contracts examined and approved by the Tax Office.

In some cases an exemption is granted, depending on the nature of the business concerned. Therefore, what we are really doing is retrospectively changing the law. I acknowledge that there would be a tax advantage, a tax minimisation arrangement. We do not mind its being closed. But we believe that contracts that are in place have to be honoured under the old law. I seek the Committee's support in respect of those contracts.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief comments regarding Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1992. I want to put on the record that, despite what Senator McMullan just said, the Australian Democrats do support anti-avoidance measures. In Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6), one of the issues we did not have time to canvass properly was the issue of limited partnership and the concern about the possible impact of this legislation on the rapidly developing private infrastructure sector.

PARA.TAB: Limited partnerships are important vehicles used increasingly by the private sector, providing infrastructure hitherto provided by the public sector. This issue was discussed at length at Friday's Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearing. A related matter concerning the effect that this matter would have on the risk capital market was also raised. The special example used by a witness, Dr Dwyer, was the detrimental effect that the proposal to tax limited partnerships would have on the commercialisation of Australian research and technology. I think this is regrettable. We all know how hard it is for genuine entrepreneurs to raise risk capital in Australia. To the extent that this measure will impact on that vital economic activity, we think we should do all we can to avoid that.

The Opposition has indicated that it is not opposing these measures, nor moving amendments. It has proven to be extremely difficult to draft amendments in terms that would impact only on infrastructure capital and the infrastructure sector. I just want to put on the record that we believe special categories of partnerships, specifically those engaged in infrastructure and commercialisation of research, should possibly have been exempted from being taxed as companies.

(2)Clause 3, page 2, proposed paragraph 106J(2)(b), line 14, after "protecting", insert "certain".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a number of concerns about the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill. Our major concern relates to proposed new section 106N. The Government's intransigence in relation to this section defies belief. Originally, this section sought to empower the Minister to authorise disclosure of information about any conduct that may be a serious offence punishable by imprisonment for a period of more than one year. The section allowed the Minister to authorise disclosure of information for the purposes of law enforcement, a royal commission or other purposes described by regulation.

PARA.TAB: In the past two months, the Government has been told, literally by all and sundry, that this ministerial discretion has the potential to undermine the objects of this legislation. My colleague Senator Herron put most ably, from the point of view of not only a senator but also a practitioner in the field as a surgeon, what he saw were the problems that this legislation would bring to the area of quality assurance. On 31 October, the Federal Council of the Australian Medical Association reiterated its commitment to the principles of quality assurance, but emphasised that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . quality assurance programs can only be successful if all the information furnished to quality assurance committees is assured of absolute privilege.

Consequently, the Federal Council of the AMA moved to reject section 106N, which allows the Minister to withdraw retrospectively such privilege. On 29 November, the Council of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners resolved that section 106N may impair the purpose of the Act. In explanation, the President of the RACGP stated:

. . . Council is of the opinion that total immunity of information granted under the Act is essential for the purpose of the Act. Quality assurance mechanisms are designed to allow the most comprehensive enquiry to improve the performance of health professionals. Practitioners need to be able to explore issues thoroughly. They need to speculate and to express opinions and suspicions. When this involves people (identifiable practitioners or cases), this exploratory examination can be seriously impeded if there is a possibility of use of the material in litigation.

The National Director of the Australian Hospital Association has written to me, stating that he believes that the presence or application of section 106N would seriously undermine quality assurance activities. He states:

Quality assurance largely relies on the voluntary disclosure of clinical information by doctors. There can only be frank disclosure and discussion where both the committee members and the attending practitioner are assured of the confidentiality of the proceedings.

In a letter to the Chair of the Professional Indemnity Review Committee of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, the Executive Officer of the Quality Assurance Network, Dr Moss Cass, also expresses doubt at the wisdom of including ministerial discretion in the Bill. Dr Cass states that, if section 106N is not removed, he will be interested to see how the discretionary power can be used without destroying the process. He states that he does not believe that this discretion can be retained, be effective and not lead to the quality assurance process being defective. He asks:

Who will ever want to participate in the quality assurance process when a possible outcome is that, as a participant, one could be dealt with in a punitive fashion, and might have to have to undertake legal proceedings at great cost—financial and in time—to seek to defend oneself; or could be required to appear in court by someone else seeking to defend themselves and clear their name under the appeal mechanism?

Dr Cass also provided a copy of a letter from the Department of Anaesthesia at the Christchurch School of Medicine in New Zealand, which shows how the Anaesthetic Mortality Assessment Committee—and this is a national peer review process—had, according to it, become virtually inoperable as a result of information obtained by the committee being provided for a police investigation. Here we have a perfect example of the very concern we are expressing. Interestingly, in a letter to Mr Howe, expressing concern about the maintenance of section 106N, the President of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians states:

The College and its Fellows would in no way condone the concealment of offences against the law by an individual. Even the more hazy inclusion of "written and unwritten" would not be reason for exculpation. However there are many avenues available for the redress of medical negligence, culpability and misadventure. They are in no way vitiated by the restraint which should surround the voluntary, peer-reviewed and innocently proffered information coming from the Quality Assurance process. I earnestly and urgently request that you exert influence to ensure complete and inviolable confidentiality surrounding that process.

This is not coming from one section; it is coming from a broad range of areas. Because of my concern about the retrospectivity aspect of the Bill, I referred that part of the Bill to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Despite the fact that it had already considered this Bill, its members very graciously said that they would look at it again. I appreciate the attention that they have given to it. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said:

While the Committee accepts Senator Patterson's point about the retrospective aspect of the proposed new section's operation, the Committee notes that the `serious offences' referred to would have had to have been serious offences at the time that they were committed and that, in that respect, the provision could not be considered to be retrospectively making unlawful—
and they have underlined the `un'—

something which was previously lawful. The Committee also notes that it may be considered inappropriate that serious offences that come to light as a result of a quality assurance activity should not—
and they have underlined `not'—

be able to be prosecuted because of the confidentiality provisions contained in the Bill. However, in making this comment, the Committee seeks the Minister's advice as to whether there is currently (ie apart from the provisions of this Bill) any statutory or other legal prohibition against such information being divulged and used in the way contemplated by proposed new section 160N—
but I presume they mean 106N—
of the Bill.

I do not blame the staff of any of the committees in Parliament at the moment for making a small typographical error, given that they are working inordinately long hours. That was what the Committee said. The AMA responded to that when it had access to the Scrutiny of Bills report. It said:

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has made fundamental flaws in reasoning in relation to the proposed Section 106N. The Committee makes the unjustified logical jump from the test in the Bill of information about conduct which "may"—
and it has underscored that and that is the very word used in the Bill—

have been a serious criminal offence, to looking at the "worst" case—in which they seem to envisage that the quality assurance material will be the only proof that the health professional has committed—
and again it has underscored that—
a serious criminal offence.
It also said that Senator Lees, in discussing this Bill, uses the words `intentional criminal activities by health professionals'. It says:
In effect, they are—
the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and Senator Lees—
assuming that the health professional is guilty to justify releasing the information which may or may not suggest guilt.

I think, with all due respect to the Minister, I have to come down on the side of the AMA rather than, in this case, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's interpretation of it. The Bill says they `may have' committed an offence not that there is overwhelming evidence that the person has committed an offence. I am really quite concerned that evidence could be extracted on that basis.

PARA.TAB: The Government, in an effort to stifle the pressure being placed on it but, at the same time, maintaining this ministerial discretion, has been gradually watering down section 106N and the consequential sections of this Bill. We have now got to the stage where the Minister cannot authorise the disclosure of information of a non-factual nature, such as the statements of opinion, unless the information consists only of matter contained in a report prepared by a person engaged in the quality assurance activity.

However, this narrowing of the ministerial discretion still misses the central point. The fact is that total immunity and confidentiality are a necessary pre-requisite of an effective quality assurance process. The ability of medical professionals to be able to provide information to their peers without fear or favour is absolutely essential to the objects of this Bill. Again, I reiterate the comments that Senator Herron made about the importance of being able to be as frank as possible without fear or favour in that quality assurance process. As Dr Cass has stated, it is likely that this ministerial discretion will leave us in the very position that we are in now in which practitioners are hesitant to provide information due to the legal ramification that may result; this is the very position that necessitated this Bill.

The amendments of the Australian Democrats attempt to narrow the ministerial discretion even further by prohibiting a ministerial authorised disclosure in cases where non-factual information, such as statements of opinion, are contained in a report prepared by a person who is engaged in the quality assurance activity. While the coalition agrees that it is totally inappropriate for non-factual information to be disclosed by the Minister, we believe that the Democrats, like the Government, have totally missed the point. For any quality assurance activity to be effective, the providers of the information must be 100 per cent confident that they can be open and forthright without facing the likelihood of exposing themselves to expensive, time consuming and personally damaging legal repercussions.

The Democrats will undoubtedly say—and I think it is unhygienic to put words in their mouths, but I will have a go—`We only want to make sure that those who engage in real criminal or negligent activities are caught'. I think they might go on to say, `We have also narrowed the ministerial discretion by preventing the Minister from authorising disclosure for purposes other than law enforcement or to a royal commission'.

The coalition agrees that it is entirely appropriate for the Government to allow the Minister to authorise disclosure for prescribed purposes other than law enforcement. Again, however, the Democrats have missed the point. Quality assurance committees are not the equivalent of policemen. The workings of a quality assurance committee do not, in any way, prevent a hospital from investigating what it believes may be a negligent or criminal activity. All the information is still available for such investigations. Quality assurance committees do not take any previously available information and lock it away in a safe preventing either internal or external investigators from accessing it. Quality assurance committees should not be forced into a role of de facto medical investigators nor should the results of the information provided on a confidential basis during the peer review process be used retrospectively by other investigating bodies.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the coalition remains steadfastly opposed to the proposed new section 106N. We contend that it has the potential to undermine the entire quality assurance process, particularly in a society such as ours where there is an ever growing tendency towards seeking redress through the legal system. I seek leave to move amendments Nos 1 to 5 standing in my name on behalf of the Opposition.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, proposed subsection 106K(1), definition of "authority", lines 28 to 20, omit the definition.
2.Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 106K(1), definition of "serious offence", lines 13 and 14, omit the definition.

3.Clause 3, page 4, proposed subsection 106M(1), lines 14 to 16, omit ", as a result of a disclosure under section 106M or in any other way, must not, except for the purposes of that activity or in accordance with an authority given by the Minister", substitute "or in any other way, must not, except for the purposes of that activity".
4.Clause 3, page 4, proposed subsection 106M(6), lines 38 to 40, omit the subsection.
5.Clause 3, page 5, proposed section 106N, lines 6 to 16, omit the section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government does not accept Senator Patterson's amendments. It is very clear that in trying to establish protection for quality assurance activities being undertaken within the medical profession, it is important that we provide an environment of confidentiality and certainty that that confidentiality will not be breached, as being the normal way in which the activities of health professionals can be put under scrutiny by peer groups or the quality assurance groups in a particular institution.

PARA.TAB: The question of whether that should be an absolute quarantine situation or whether there can be some modification of it has been a matter which has properly exercised the minds of those who engage in these activities and want them to succeed. Of course the Government wants them to succeed and that is why it is bringing in this measure.

I think it needs to be emphasised that in relation to section 106N, we are talking about a very circumscribed set of activities or situation. We are talking about circumstances where it appears to the Minister that information became known after the commencement of the part, solely as a result of the declared quality assurance activity relating to conduct—whether that conduct took place before or after that commencement—which may have been a serious offence against a law. That is still the main thrust of this measure.

Senator Patterson raised the question: why use the phrase `which may have been'? Quite clearly, it would be improper for a Minister to substitute him or herself for a jury or a criminal trial. Therefore, there has to be a supposition on the part of the Minister concerning the possibility of the alleged activity having occurred and then characterising it as serious in accordance with the definition offered in the interpretation section: `being an offence punishable by imprisonment for a period of more than one year'.

Perhaps it has not been sufficiently emphasised that there is no duty on the Committee to disclose such an offence to the Minister. I think it is very important to understand that. There is no duty on the Committee to disclose its awareness of the possibility of such an offence to the Minister. So this whole matter is very largely in the hands of the Committee. If it considers that a matter ought to be brought to the attention of the Minister, then no doubt it will be, and then the Minister of course has to make a decision in relation to section 106N.

The other matter which has been mentioned by honourable senators is that the Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges was concerned about the original terminology in which section 106N was cast. In fact, amendments were made, which have now been incorporated in the Bill, which indicate very clearly that it is matters of fact and not matters of opinion that may be disclosed pursuant to this particular provision, unless the information consists only of matter contained in a report prepared by a person who engaged in the quality assurance activity. Basically, we are now saying that the subsection does not permit the Minister to authorise the disclosure of information of a non-factual nature such as statements of opinion.

That was very earnestly sought by many of those who made representations to the Government. By making those particular amendments, Mr Peter Carter, the secretary of the Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges, was able to write to the Department in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge receipt of your fax of proposed amendments to the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Bill.

The Chairman of the Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges has considered the proposed amendments. In the time available, he was unable to consult the Executive of the CPMC but nevertheless is of the view that whilst the proposed amendments do not meet absolutely all the concerns expressed by the CPMC, they are broadly acceptable and can be supported.

I think that is an important letter. It is an indication of the fundamental good faith that has been brought to this exercise by all parties who are trying to create a situation where quality assurance activities can be undertaken. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges
December 8, 1992
Ms Fiona Tito
Chairperson
Professional Indemnity Review
Department of Health, Housing and Community Services
GPO Box 9848
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Ms Tito,
HEALTH INSURANCE
(QUALITY ASSURANCE CONFIDENTIALITY)
AMENDMENT BILL 1992
I acknowledge receipt of your fax of proposed amendments to the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Bill.

The Chairman of the Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges has considered the proposed amendments. In the time available, he was unable to consult the Executive of the CPMC but nevertheless is of the view that whilst the proposed amendments do not meet absolutely all the concerns expressed by the CPMC, they are broadly acceptable and can be supported.
Yours sincerely,
Peter Carter
Secretary
COMMITTEE OF PRESIDENTS OF MEDICAL COLLEGES.
CC: Chairman and Executive CPMC

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not trying to weigh them up; I am just saying that we have tried to act in good faith and respond to concerns. That is the one that we think deserves to be given great weight in this Committee.
—You need to support your argument.

—It supports the argument. I think the argument can stand by itself that in situations where a committee has disclosed to a Minister most serious allegations concerning a doctor—that he may have engaged in serious criminal conduct—it is not unreasonable for society to say that there should be a mechanism whereby the Minister can bring that matter to the attention of law enforcement authorities or a royal commission. In so far as the Bill allows that to be done, I think it would be seen by most in the community as setting a proper balance in relation to these contentious matters. The Government will not be supporting this amendment moved by the Opposition, and believes that the amended form of 106N ought to be able to stand.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just pick up with some comments that Senator Patterson made about providers. We are not looking here just at the concerns of the medical profession; we have also to consider the concerns of the consumers. There certainly are very compelling arguments, but these arguments are on both sides. I do not have any doubts about the legal and moral merits of the Government's case. It seems to me that we have a problem of perception as to whether or not the doctors will feel and believe that the quality assurance process is one that they should and could get involved in without a lot of concerns about any ramifications of that.

PARA.TAB: If we get bogged down in worrying about those perceptions, I think we will end up with a quality assurance process that really does not work. I pick up something Senator Tate was saying about balance. What the Government has tried to do, and has almost succeeded in doing—the Australian Democrats have two amendments, because it has not quite made it—is balance those competing interests and make the decisions based on the concerns of both the providers and the consumers, those being treated.

This is certainly a long way from being an easy or a straightforward issue. I stress that the Democrats have devoted considerable time and debate. We have had a large number of briefings, we have had representations from a wide range of people from those representing the AMA to those representing consumer organisations. It is not just a matter of saying, `Oh, look, we will come down on the side of one group or the other'; we have to be very careful. We owe it to consumers as well as to the doctors to make sure that we end up with a process that really works.

We have eventually opted to leave two of these exemptions in the Bill. I will speak more on what we are actually doing with these when I get to our amendments. We are not going to support the blanket that the Opposition now wants to put on all discussions in those quality assurance committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not support the Opposition amendments. This is in the context of my disagreement in principle with this legislation. I am not alone in the community in supporting any endeavour by the medical profession to ensure the highest possible competence and quality assurance of medical services. Many today feel it healthy that the conspiracy of silence by the medical profession is breaking down into a more accountable, open responsibility for its activities.

PARA.TAB: The principle of quality assurance and the peer review process which underpins it need to be based on positive and ethical motivation, not on fear and protective regulation. Many highly respected medical practitioners have been voluntarily engaged in peer review activities for many years. They would be scandalised and ashamed at any suggestion that they would remain silent unless protected by this legislation instead of being motivated by ethical principles and the effort to gain the best possible outcomes for their patients and the wider community.

The Bill, and the Opposition amendment that we have before us, is based not only on the premise that doctors are unwilling to participate wholeheartedly and enthusiastically in a program designed to benefit both individual clients and society by honing their competence and service to the finest degree, but also on the archaic notion that they will participate only if they have a legislative protection against the divulging of information which may be gained through that process. I do not support the Opposition's amendments, on the basis that they remove an attempt to mitigate what I consider the undesirable and archaic notion of legislative protection for an already highly privileged group.

All professionals should bear the highest responsibility and accountability for their practices. No other profession has the luxury of protection beforehand. All the rest of the community must resort to retrospective damage actions in the case of unfair or specious revelations. Why should doctors be given this? Sadly, the example provided by Chelmsford Hospital presents outstanding testimony that people, no matter what their standing or profession, must speak out as a matter of conscience when highly suspect and dangerous practices may be occurring. I agree with the position of the Chelmsford Victims Action Group and their spokesperson, Barry Hart, who state:

SPEECH.PARA: Please find attached information re our submission to the Chelmsford Royal Commission regarding "peer review" and how it did not work with the Chelmsford case. This submission was prepared by the Group's barrister at the Royal Commission, Mr. Ken Crispin, Q.C., who is now the Director of Public Prosecutions in the ACT.
There were plenty of "Peers" reviewing the "treatment" or the consequence of the treatment but not one person acted.
Our submission also refers to the failure of the system to act on complaints and breaches of Acts and regulations. I have only included some of this material as there is so much of it.
The medical profession has no credibility in regard to its failure to act on the Chelmsford matter—there are no excuses.
To allow under these circumstances secret "Peer Review" Committees with gaol terms for disclosure is absolutely outrageous.
If these Peer Review Committees are to maintain standards of medical practice, how will anyone ever know if they are effective or not if the hearings of the Committees are secret?

This legislation actively discourages any communication under threat of a two-year imprisonment term. The Opposition amendment removes the only slight concession to public accountability via the Minister's discretion to permit disclosure if it may involve an offence which could gain more than one year's prison sentence.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators support this legislation, I urge them to rethink their position. If this Bill had been in force it would possibly have prevented the revelations of malpractice at Chelmsford Hospital and of a similar scandal at the Davis University of California Teaching Hospital in 1981 regarding the quality of cardiac surgery and kidney transplant programs. Both those scandals were exposed by the media. This legislation would penalise the media with a threat of two-year imprisonment.

This Bill takes the medical profession back to the dark ages of paranoid conspiracy and privilege instead of openness to scrutiny and accountability. It is an insult to all the highly professional, competent and dedicated medical practitioners who are known to me. I will be voting against the Bill. I have not opposed any Government amendments which may ameliorate its deficiencies; however, I do oppose the Opposition's amendments, which in my view make it even worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions that I would like to ask the Minister. For the sake of speeding up the process, I will try to put them all together. Could the Minister explain to me what is meant by `any other prescribed purpose', which appears on page 5 at line 16? I would also like to know whether anybody other than a member of the Committee can bring to the Minister's attention the fact that a serious offence against a law in force in any State or Territory may have been committed. If that is not the case, would the Minister direct me to where somebody is not permitted to do that?

PARA.TAB: Finally, I want to respond to some of Senator Chamarette's comments—and I am sure that some of the doctors will be interested to read what she said—and to some of Senator Lees's comments about a letter from the AMA, the same letter to which I referred when I was talking about the comments of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The AMA has said:

SPEECH.PARA: First, in any and every case of a surgical death, for example, it would be possible to say that a serious criminal offence may have been committed. Rarely will one actually have been committed. Secondly, preventing use of material generated for the purposes of the peer review will not prevent the Courts and criminal investigators having access to other materials which would enable them to investigate and prosecute effectively in appropriate cases. For example, clinical and surgical records would still be available. It would still be open for investigators to interview each of the health professionals involved in the relevant surgical procedure, and for all of those persons to give evidence to the Court—if necessary to be compelled by subpoena. Giving absolute privilege to materials brought into existence solely for the purposes of the quality assurance activity does not in any way prejudice those other mechanisms.

The Opposition will be saying that there would appear to be sufficient constraint and also sufficient power to get the information that would be required to determine whether a serious offence against a law had been engaged in.

TALK.START.PARA: —After carefully weighing all the arguments on this Bill, I have decided to support the Opposition amendments. Having listened carefully, in particular to Senator Chamarette, I feel constrained to very briefly put on record that, with respect, I believe that in her arguments she has confused two different issues. One is the issue of having information such as patients' records, the records of hospitals and the records of operations available for prosecution of any offences or for the careful examination of what has happened.

PARA.TAB: That is one issue. I do not think it should be confused with the issue of maintaining, as far as possible, the effectiveness of the quality assurance process, which I am persuaded would be severely damaged if, whether rightly or wrongly, those practitioners who participate in it would have to expect, in their perception, that if they disclose information within that circle, then that information could be used even in that strictly limited situation that the Bill now provides for the Minister, and from there for possible prosecution. I am making this decision on a very fine balance, but on the basis of first-hand information provided to me from people active in the field. I believe it is the correct one.

I simply wish to put on record that this in no way compromises the desire to have full and free information available to patients or to prosecute strongly any offenders and to remedy any malpractice in the medical field.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already spoken on this matter of quality assurance, but I had to rise on hearing the speeches of Senator Lees and Senator Chamarette. They said that they were concerned about the consumers and that there is a conspiracy of medical silence. All of us are concerned about the consumers. The whole of the medical profession is concerned about quality outcome and the delivery of quality service. Senator Chamarette said quite rightly that that is the aim of all the royal colleges, the Australian Medical Association and everybody that we can name.

PARA.TAB: The Minister seems to have read too many of Peter Cook's books, such as Coma and Fever, in which malpractice occurs through psychopathic intervention in hospitals whereby people are murdered for spare parts and things like that. When similar legislation to this was enacted in New Zealand as a result of a death following an anaesthetic, people stopped coming forward to give evidence at quality assurance committees. That was the point of what I was saying the other day.

We all agree with the objectives, as do all those bodies that I have mentioned—the quality assurance network, the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Association of Surgeons and the Medical Protection Society. All are in favour of the general thrust of the Bill. Nobody would disagree with it. But, with proposed new section 106N, we seem to have a sledge-hammer to crack a nut.

I note that in yesterday's Hansard—I think the analogy is relevant—a question on notice was asked of the Minister, `How many general practitioners were referred to a medical services committee of inquiry?'. In 1991, of about 22,800 general practitioners, 14 were referred to medical services committees of inquiry. I will put on notice later how many actually proceeded to prosecution for any offence and how many were actually convicted. In 1991-92, of what would be a greater number, 12 actually went to medical services committees of inquiry out of 25,000 or so. In my 34 years of being attached to a teaching hospital, I do not recall anyone, as a result of a quality assurance program, ever being charged, convicted or in any way committed to a court of law.

The introduction of new section 106N will have the effect, as in New Zealand, of stopping people coming forward. As I said previously, why would someone come forward to assist in an inquiry if they thought that retrospectively a Minister at his or her discretion could send them for prosecution? `Trust me, I am a politician' is what will go out from this to quality assurance programs if it is in the hands of the Minister retrospectively.

We have to approach reality here. If the Minister goes ahead with this, he will kill the quality assurance programs. Senator Chamarette referred to such things as the Chelmsford committee of inquiry. That was not a teaching hospital. I am not on firm ground here because I am not totally familiar with the matter, but peer review should not be confused with quality assurance programs. Peer review is within the profession with a formal mechanism to determine whether that treatment was in accordance with the current treatment of the day. In the case of Chelmsford it was. There was a legitimate argument that deep coma therapy was a form of treatment for psychiatric illness. I suppose, putting it another way, facts are at best current hypotheses; and it was the fact in those days that that was an effective form of treatment. Retrospectively, why did the nursing profession not speak out; why did everybody else not speak out at that time? It is all very well to look into these things retrospectively.

In a similar sort of fashion, if facts are at best current hypotheses, what is to stop something that we now believe to be a correct form of treatment being regarded in five years' time as indictable in the light of then knowledge? Once this legislation goes forward—and I thank Senator Spindler for his support in this regard—it is a matter that requires a fair amount of understanding to appreciate the significance of what is being proposed in this particular clause. Time will tell whether what I am saying is correct, but on the best evidence that I have from the people who have spoken to me about it and my own experience—

TALK.START.PARA: —And New Zealand.

—And New Zealand's, I thank my colleague—I believe that will be the effect. It is unfortunate that the Minister has not accepted the representations that have been made to him on this matter. I do not believe that it is something that is of light moment and that can be glossed over fairly superficially, as it appears to be. We will know within a short period whether it has the desired effect.

PARA.TAB: Already within the medical literature there has been commentary on this matter, as the Minister will know because of the lobbying that has occurred from the medical organisations. If this proposal goes ahead, it will be paid lip-service; the quality assurance programs will go ahead but the Government will never ever know whether it has achieved the objective of helping the consumers and promoting the quality of health care that should be a result, but will not be because of the failure to exclude proposed new section 106N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several honourable senators made a contribution to this committee stage and I want to reply to some matters that have been raised. Senator Chamarette raised issues of a more general character as the foundation for her approach to whether this Bill should be supported at all. As the chamber has supported the Bill in principle by giving the Bill a second reading, I do not believe that it would be fruitful to open up that matter as a whole.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette also raised the question of the Chelmsford incident. All that can be said about that is that if there had been a declared quality assurance program in place at Chelmsford with a declared committee et cetera, it is not fanciful to imagine that a member of the committee could have come forward at an early stage and made the Minister aware of what could have been regarded as serious criminal conduct in relation to the treatment of the patients concerned. I believe that there may have been an opportunity there, paradoxically, in terms of this Bill for an earlier disclosure of these matters than appeared to occur.

It is also important to emphasise, as Senator Spindler did in response to part of Senator Chamarette's remarks, that the only material or information we are talking about is information which is brought into existence solely for the purposes of the quality assurance program of activity within that committee. The other files, records and knowledge of matters which would be held within the hospital or known to personnel within the hospital could be available for a criminal trial, should one be undertaken. Those matters ought to be kept clearly in mind. We are talking about a fairly restricted body of information generated solely for the purposes of the quality assurance activities.

Senator Patterson asked for clarification on a couple of matters. Firstly, she asked what the Government had in mind as to what might count as prescribed purposes. It may be that this matter can be better dealt with when the Democrats move their amendments. In relation to that matter, because the activity that we are talking about of a criminal nature is primarily a matter for the States and the Territories, the Government wished to be in a position where, if a State or Territory said that it considered that this sort of information might, for example, be usefully disclosed at a coronial inquest, that might be a matter which after discussion with the States ought to be set down as a prescribed purpose. That was the type of further extension we had in mind when that was put forward. It has to be emphasised once again that all that would be disclosed would be matters of a factual nature, which could be useful to an inquest that was being undertaken.

Senator Patterson also asked whether a party outside the Committee could disclose matters to a Minister so that proposed section 106N would be triggered. I suppose, theoretically, that would be possible. How a person outside the committee would come to be aware of the information would be a matter of concern, because under proposed section 106M the disclosure of such matters to a third party by a member of the committee would itself be a serious offence in terms of the Bill.

The first hurdle that would have to be jumped is that one would have to assume a lack of confidentiality by committee members themselves, who are not under a duty to disclose information. Do not forget that they cannot be compelled to disclose matters; they are under no legal obligation to do so. In feeling that a matter ought to be kept confidential, they may not disclose it to a Minister but nevertheless disclose it to a third party, who could then disclose it to the Minister. That would have to be the way that it would work, but that would be a very rare instance indeed.

Senator Herron indicated that, in his view, the imposition of proposed section 106N on top of the great immunities that are given to this process by the Bill will undo the good intent that may lie behind the more general structure of the Bill. Though I defer to his experience—as he recounted it to the Senate, he said that he had spent several decades working in the medical profession and in association with a teaching hospital and so on—even his experience indicates that in like circumstances he has never been in a situation where what was revealed led, or could lead, to a charge of the doctor concerned.

In other words, generally speaking, in 99 per cent of cases—and doctors know this when they enter quality assurance programs—one is not dealing with material that could form information which a Minister considers ought to be disclosed to a law enforcement or royal commission process because one is fearful that a serious criminal offence has occurred. So doctors, understanding that that sort of situation will be extremely rare, will find within the structure of this Bill very real protections for the confidentiality of the process to which they submit themselves and an immunity from civil suits for those who undertake the work on these quality assurance committees. It will allow them to continue to discharge their very useful function of providing health care within Australia without being killed off in the way that Senator Herron fears. I have dealt with most of the matters that were raised in the Committee. I commend the Bill as it has been amended by us.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 5, proposed section 106N, lines 15 and 16, omit all words after "law enforcement", substitute "or a Royal Commission".

The wording of the Government's amendment, as it stands, is far too broad. I pick up what Senator Tate was saying earlier about some of the possible other prescribed purposes, such as coronial inquiries. If it were so specified and actually set out as a specific reason, then we would not have the problems that we do have. But trucks could be driven through it the way it is drafted at the moment. At some time in the future it could be defined to mean almost any `prescribed purpose', because all it says is for `other prescribed purpose'. Basically, the Democrat amendment takes out those words and lets the rest of the proposed section stand. In other words, we have no great difficulty with disclosure for the purposes of law enforcement or for royal commissions. It is one thing to say that people participating in quality assurance run the risk of having the protection waived if those sorts of problems arise, but we believe that it should not then be stretched out to also include `other prescribed purpose'. I believe it is unduly vague and may well undermine the whole process.

PARA.TAB: To pick up on a few of the points that Senator Heron made earlier, we do want this to work. It is about perceptions, as I said earlier. I think health professionals would be entitled to feel rather edgy about the potential size of the hole that could be blown through the whole immunity process. By removing these words, the health professions will have more confidence in the quality assurance process. That is obviously crucial to the success of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have said all I have to say. If there is any discretion at all, this legislation jeopardises the whole quality assurance process—I do not think I need reiterate that—either on the Government's amendments or the Democrats' amendments.

—I reiterate what I said in relation to this matter a little earlier, namely, that `prescribed purpose' is really put in to cover the situation that enforcement of criminal laws is a matter for the States or Territories. It may be that, after discussion and consultation with the States or Territories, they would wish the same sort of disclosure of this restricted body of information, created solely for the purpose of the quality assurance committee process, to be possible. They would like to see the disclosure, for example, to a coronial inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I also need to emphasise that the prescription of such a purpose would be contained in an instrument, which would be disallowable. Therefore, if it were brought before the Senate and any senator had misgivings about the way in which the further extension had occurred, then it could be disallowed. I imagine that, given the sort of debate that we have had this afternoon, it would be a very vigilant Senate which would look at any such prescription.
