The disallowable instrument would have a very hard time and would probably be disallowed unless, as I said, it were most carefully justified. For those reasons, the Government will not support the amendment moved by Senator Lees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that this will eventually turn up in regulation at some stage. Our problem is that we do not have that before us now. We are only able to deal with what we have precisely before us, and the regulations are not there. Therefore, I stress again—and I hope the Opposition will support us—that we need to make sure that this is as tight as possible to ensure that the confidence is there so that people will feel free to take part in the quality assurance process.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have absolutely no idea what the Opposition is doing. I would have thought that we would have at least had the Opposition's support, as it was closer to what it originally said it wanted, on that last amendment, if not the Government's support. I thought the Government was keen to get this legislation through. However, I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Government amendment No. 5, proposed subsection 106N(2), omit all words after "(such as statements of opinion)".

This final amendment relates to Government amendment No. 5. All we are doing is taking out the last few words. To go back to something Senator Tate said earlier about not wanting opinion disclosed, there may be opinion in that particular report. Again, our concern is that the confidence of the medical profession will be undermined because of holes in this legislation. I hope the Opposition will consider this amendment carefully, because it goes some way towards achieving what it said earlier it was interested in achieving.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I made it clear when I was speaking about our amendments that we will not compromise. It was either our amendments or the Government can live with its decision. We and a range of organisations and people involved have told the Government that the consequences of the legislation it is putting forward, even in the modified form the Australian Democrats are putting forward, will be to undermine the quality assurance process. Let the Government live with its decision. The people elected the Government to make these arrangements. Let it live with the legislation. The amendments of the Democrats will do very little, if anything, to move the legislation in the direction we wanted it to move. We wanted our amendments to stand as they were. Let the people live with the Government's decision.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette has expressed her concern about consumers. I am concerned about consumers too. People will not feel free, without fear or favour, to put forward their concerns or thoughts about what may or may not have been the case if they had time to think again in a particular emergency situation or if they had time to reassess whether somebody had some other factor involved in their condition and whether they may have done something different. They will not say those sorts of things. The Democrats will in fact reduce quality care of the people that we in the coalition are concerned about and whom the Government says it is concerned about. They are the people the legislation will affect. Let the Government and the Democrats live with the consequences. We put up what we thought were the best amendments. The Democrats and the Government did not agree with them. Let the public and the medical system live with what the Government says is best, despite all the advice it was given.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped that what we were about here today was trying to get the best possible quality assurance process. Instead, we seem to be playing some political games. The Opposition has now decided, `To hell with the whole thing'. All it is worried about is being able to go out to the electorate and say, `Look, aren't we tremendous, this has failed'. I think it is most unfortunate that the Opposition has taken this attitude.

PARA.TAB: I stress again that the important aspect of this amendment—it is perhaps even more important than the previous amendment—is that the way the proposed section reads at the moment the Government can have non-factual material disclosed to the Minister. As long as it is written down in that report, anything goes. We believe that that is not satisfactory and that it will undermine the quality assurance process. We want to see this process work. There is a very fine balance in making sure that all the various competing interests and concerns are accommodated and, indeed, dealt with as best as possible. All I can do is recommend that we leave aside the politics and try to get the best possible system that we can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by the Australian Democrats is resisted by the Government. Basically, the Government has proposed in an amendment to section 106N:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the following. . .

. . . Subsection (1) does not permit the Minister to authorise the disclosure of information of a non-factual nature (such as statements of opinion) unless the information consists only of matter contained in a report prepared by a person who engaged in the quality assurance activity.".
That amendment has, of course, been framed very carefully and takes account of the fact that many reports of QA activities will contain mixed fact and opinion.

PARA.TAB: This provision would allow the release of such reports for the purposes of law enforcement at royal commissions because of the likely difficulty of releasing the factual information completely void of any opinion. But it is important to recognise that whilst it will be available for law enforcement investigation, expert opinion will not be admissible in any subsequent criminal proceedings unless the court determines that those who expressed the opinions were expert witnesses for the purposes of the criminal proceedings, and such members would then be cross-examinable on any such opinions expressed. So it really will have a narrow effect in the unlikely event that any of this leads to a criminal trial.

It is to be emphasised again that the Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges has indicated that, whilst the chairman was unable to consult the executive, nevertheless he was of the view that `whilst the proposed amendments do not meet absolutely all the concerns expressed by the CPMC, they are broadly acceptable and can be supported'. On that basis I believe the chamber ought to support the original amendment moved by the Government. It should stand and not be further modified by the Democrat's amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Question put:
That the Bill, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: MEDICARE AGREEMENTS BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 2, page 1, subclause (1), lines 8 and 9, omit "the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent", substitute "14 June 1993".

The coalition's first amendment to the Medicare Agreements Bill seeks to extend the date on which the Bill receives royal assent. This extension of the date will not prevent the negotiation and signing of Medicare agreements with the States. It must be remembered that both sets of Medicare agreements to date have not required legislation such as this Bill. We have had two rounds of Medicare agreements which have not required legislation. It seems to me that the negotiations can go on and the agreements can be signed without this legislation actually being in place. There is no practical reason why the legislation has to be passed prior to the signing of the agreements, except that it will lock the States and Commonwealth into the Government's brand of public health care until June 1998.

PARA.TAB: The Government does not have a mandate to do this. The election is close at hand. We know that there are great differences in our approaches to health and health care delivery. This would tie up a lot of the flexibility that would be available if this legislation was not to be passed until after the election. It seems to be an obvious attempt by the Government to put its policies in place prior to the election. The Government does have a mandate to negotiate agreements in readiness for the expiry of the current agreements. I have no objection to that. It is quite appropriate that the States and the Commonwealth should be negotiating those agreements in readiness for the start-up date of 1 July 1993, but there is no earthly reason why the legislation needs to be passed for that process to actually go on and almost reach its culmination.

The Government does not have a mandate to force its health care policy onto the State public hospital system for another five years, regardless of the result of the next election. I call on the Australian Democrats and the Independents to support this amendment. The States and the Government can work towards those agreements, and the government of the day, that of the Liberal-National coalition, can work towards revamping those agreements, if it so requires—and obviously it would—and the people will be able to make the decision. We will have the mandate to do that.

The Government is ramming this legislation through. All I can say is that it is ramming this legislation through. Last Friday, the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs was absolutely atrocious. Senator Lees was present, but I was interested to find senators from the States most affected—the Independent senator from Victoria, Senator Powell, and the Democrat senators from New South Wales and Victoria—not there. It was a very important time. Two State Ministers came to present to the Committee their concerns about the effect of this legislation on their States. I would have expected those senators to have been present at that hearing to hear what those Ministers had to say.

As I said, it was appalling. One Minister told us that, at 1 o'clock in the morning, a journalist rang her and said, `Have you seen the alteration to the agreement?'. The Minister said that she had not seen it. Senator Tate, in a very rushed way, then tabled a letter. I do not blame Senator Tate for this; he is just the messenger who has to deliver all this nonsense when the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) does not negotiate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The errand boy.
—He is the errand boy or the lackey who has to do this work for the Minister, who never negotiates. It is always the same with either Mr Staples or Mr Howe; they do not consult.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate came in with the letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Premiers outlining the changes to the agreement. The two Ministers sat there—one was giving evidence and the other was sitting behind—astounded that this letter was being circulated. They were supposed to be presenting information. Yet a change to the agreement had obviously been leaked to the press—it was in the newspapers. The Minister from New South Wales said that he woke up to read it in the newspaper or hear it on the radio. That is not the way to develop agreements on the outline of a five-year plan for health.

I call on those senators from the two States most affected—New South Wales and Victoria—to support this amendment to enable the people to decide what form of health care service they require, through the use of the Medicare money, after the next election. This amendment will allow them to do that. I will be very interested to see, as will the people of both Victoria and New South Wales, where those senators sit when we vote on this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that I really should not worry about some of the nonsense that Senator Patterson carried on with. However, I will rise to the defence of my colleagues and say that all Australian Democrats senators were fully involved in discussions on the Medicare Agreements Bill 1992. Indeed, two of my colleagues sought full submissions from their respective States and were directly in contact with their respective health Ministers.

PARA.TAB: So it is absolute nonsense to suggest that all honourable senators should somehow suddenly pack themselves into a committee hearing. I did not see any Liberal senators from my State of South Australia. So if I follow on with Senator Patterson's strange reasoning, presumably they also were uninterested. But I will not say that of them. I know that they are also quite capable of watching committee hearings and, if they are interested, of reading the proceedings which are readily available.
This is a game in which I will not get involved. This whole amendment is unnecessary. It puts uncertainty into the process of the Medicare negotiations and we will not be supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment. We believe it is important that the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia expresses its view as to the proper structure for the Medicare agreements mark III to be negotiated within this framework and understanding. We believe that the States will have confidence in the agreements that are finalised in, I hope, the near future only if they know that the Parliament has very definitely given its imprimatur to the law set out in this legislation which, when passed, will receive royal assent.

PARA.TAB: As I say, this will give a certainty not hitherto available to the States, the Territories and the Commonwealth in the negotiating process that is still to be undertaken. Many months of consultation and deliberation between the various parties has already occurred, despite Senator Patterson's dismissal of the consultations which she characterises as being either trivial or non-existent. In fact, they have been extensive. We believe that the passage of this Bill will give a certain structure to the framework and foundation of the Medicare agreements. The certainty that is thereby engendered will enable the States and Territories to assent more willingly to the agreements which are sought to be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely tragic that the Australian Democrats and the Government do not accept this amendment. We have reached a stage of sophistication and understanding of health care in this country today that has not been reached before.

PARA.TAB: I give credit to the Government and the Department for the establishment of a series of inquiries that have led to this degree of sophistication and understanding. I believe that my own Party has not understood totally, and it is representative of the body politic as a whole in its failure to understand the health care financing system of this country.

Now we have the opportunity to do something about it. I particularly appealed the other day to Senator Lees because I believe she has an understanding of it. We have the opportunity in this country of developing a health care system that could be the envy of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—It is not, with respect, because there is a blindness on the part of the Government and the Department in failing to understand that there is no magic pudding out there. We have three parameters. We have a public sector of finance through the Medicare levy, which raises 17 per cent of health care costs, the rest coming from revenue and taxation. We have the States putting in a segment and then people paying out of their pockets. There is no magic pudding. There are only three places where the money can be raised.

PARA.TAB: The Government is saying that it will try to crush the private sector because it will not encourage private insurance. What is happening? People are paying out of their pockets, but because that cannot be quantified it is ignored. The Government turns a blind eye to it and says it does not exist: it cannot be measured; therefore it does not occur. I can produce evidence that about 10 per cent of people in my own State are not insured but go to private hospitals and pay out of their pockets. But there is no way of measuring that.

This is blindness on the part of the Government in failing to recognise that the only way in which we can increase the funds going into the care of the people of this country is to encourage them to take out private insurance, because there are no other funds. If the Government is realistic and believes philosophically in increasing the Medicare levy, bringing it up to 8 or 10 per cent and getting people to pay for their health care, then we will have a totalitarian system.

What happened to the totalitarian systems of health care in the world? I refer to the United Kingdom experience. I worked in the United Kingdom. When I wanted to do a hernia operation I pulled out a Visidex and picked people who had been waiting for 10 years. In Edinburgh waiting lists are not kept for hernias. After 10 years it was decided to scrap them because it was not possible to trace the people who were on the waiting lists.

There is no alternative. If the Government keeps on rationing it—and that is what it is going to do—keeping the funds down, keeping it at 8 per cent of GDP, and ignores the fact that we have an ageing population and the marvellous technology that is occurring in the world, claiming that it is of great benefit because we have kept that percentage of GDP down, where will Australia end up? It will end up like Queensland. In Queensland there is an 18-month waiting list to get an appointment at the orthopaedic department of the Royal Brisbane Hospital. Once a person gets an appointment, there is then a two-year waiting list to get a time for an operation.

The Government is blind, because it is ignoring what is occurring out in the community. If the Government goes on with its Medicare agreement Australia will end up the same way as every other country in the world that has done the same. What cannot happen here is what has happened in Canada. Do Government members know what happens in Canada? People go to the US. They fly neonates out from Canada because they cannot be treated there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who goes to the US—the rich people?

—The Canadians. Not the rich people; they drive across. Under the Canadian system there are bureaucrats determining who will go on the waiting list for coronary bypass surgery. The bureaucrats determine it; not the medical practitioners. The Government is heading the same way in Australia because that is what cost containment means. It has not worked in any other country in the world, and that is the direction in which this Government is continuing to head.

PARA.TAB: The reason why I am so passionate about this is that we have the opportunity in this country now to do something about it. There is a level of understanding in the Department, and the Department influenced the Minister to try to bring in co-payment. We saw what happened to that.

The amendment is to allow more time. The legislation will not come in until July next year. There is to be an election and I believe we will be given the greatest mandate we have ever had. Amongst the factors that will come into the election is the health care of this nation, which is rapidly deteriorating—3 per cent of expenditure going on the capital developments of the hospital stock, which is disappearing rapidly. We get this promise of an increase in the Medicare levy, which provides another $300m to be put into capital stock of hospitals. Two States already recognise that that will not work. Even the Labor States said they would not sign the agreement if they were put at disadvantage—and we still have not heard whether they will be put at disadvantage.

So if we go ahead in the direction we are going, we will be going downhill. I could supply a whole litany of the problems associated with health care in this country. It will be on the heads of the Government when the people out there in the real world who are trying to access the system as patients cannot get in. I agree that waiting lists are not a very accurate estimate of the failure of the health care system and that other things need to be considered.

I suppose the Minister does not care about that lady I mentioned the other day who has been waiting 18 months to get an appointment for a hip replacement. By the time she gets to hospital she will be too ill. She will be told, `We can't cope with your cardiac problems and you're not fit for an anaesthetic'. She is just one example. The other day Senator Patterson gave us another example about a patient who rang her and asked how she could access the system. She went to see the newsagent. In recent times, I have toured Europe and watched what has gone on there. The totalitarian systems do not work. They have the facilities in many places; they do not have the funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will need to be in the US. Go and read some of the international papers in the library. They are rubbishing the system.

—Do not talk about the United States. With respect, there is no system in the United States. There is not a community rating principle; there is no universal insurance. We have to understand how it works there. The United States has produced the best high quality medical institutes in the world—the Mayo Clinic and the Lahey Clinic. Where do people from Canada go for cardiac surgery and heart transplants? They go to the Mayo Clinic and the Cleveland Clinic for their care because they cannot obtain it in their own country. As I mentioned before, where will Australians go? They cannot go anywhere; they cannot go to Singapore or Hong Kong. Fortunately, 40 per cent of the people in this country realise the necessity for private insurance. With the acceptance of this amendment, the opportunity arises for the Government to do something about this system. If the Minister does not, we will do so in government.

—I oppose this amendment and we will be happy to support the Minister and the Government in opposing it. Senator Patterson says, `Wait until June next year'. Is Senator Patterson asking us to believe that then those opposite will actually ratify this legislation? It is quite illogical to waste time worrying about changing clause 1 or the date of assent when we know full well that those opposite have no intention of implementing this legislation. Those opposite must take us for monkeys if they think that that is a persuasive argument.
—That's why you're ramming it through now.

—Is Senator Patterson saying she approves the intent of this legislation and would actually pass it if we put the assent day back until June? That is nonsense. What happened last Friday? It was the cheapest political stunt I have ever seen—Commonwealth-State negotiations conducted in a Senate committee. It was an absolute shambles and a complete dishonouring of proper process. We were there to discuss legislation, not trawl across facts and figures and myths and legends. It was a plain political stunt, and Senator Patterson knows it. She got the questions before she went. As for standing up here and saying that senators from other States were not there, that is a very mean and limited complaint. With this legislation we have the opportunity to get the Medicare agreement through—not by deferring it until June, not by moving a strange amendment to defer the date of assent, but by passing this legislation tonight.
—The question before the Chair is that amendment No. 1, as moved by Senator Patterson, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 4, page 2, proposed subsection 23E(1), definition of "public hospital service", lines 37 to 41, omit the definition, substitute the following definition:
"`public hospital service' means a hospital service for which funds have been provided for the provision of that service in that hospital for public patients;

PARA.TAB: Note 1: For the meaning of `hospital' see subsection (3)(1).".

SPEECH.PARA: Currently in the Bill a `public hospital service' is defined as a hospital service provided in a recognised hospital or a hospital in respect of which the Commonwealth or a State provides funding for the provision of hospital services to public patients. The coalition believes that this definition is too narrow, particularly as the Bill links the provision of `public hospital services' to funding. The coalition believes that funding should be service based rather than hospital based. This current definition may mean that certain services, which are obviously `public hospital services' may be excluded.

PARA.TAB: We have to think of the fact that this agreement will be in place for five years and that some considerable changes may occur. For example, with the emphasis on shortening hospital stays, there will be a greater emphasis on providing home services. It is doubtful whether such home services would fulfil the Government's current definition of a hospital service. Therefore, I move this amendment to rectify that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting this amendment. We believe that it restricts the definition of a public hospital service to mean a service for which funds are being provided for the provision of that service in that hospital for public patients. This is a more restrictive definition than the Government intention that a public hospital service should cover a hospital service provided in a recognised hospital or other hospital service funded by the Commonwealth or a State for the provision of hospital services to public patients.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Government definition is to define the hospital services that will be the subject of the agreement between the Commonwealth and a State; to define the hospital services to which the Medicare principles and commitments will apply; and to define the hospital services to which the conditions established by proposed section 26 (3) to (6) will apply. As stated clearly in section 26, the Medicare principles and commitments, and the conditions established to give effect to those principles and commitments, are intended to apply to all eligible persons in respect of the provision by the State of public hospital services. I could elaborate on this, but I believe that I have sufficiently indicated why the Government cannot accept this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We do not see the need for it. I realise that home services are an issue of some contention, but a lot of the debate and discussion will be going on with the States as to what services will be funded. We see no need for this amendment at this point.
—I ask the Minister whether the broader definition of `public hospital service' covers private hospitals that are giving care to public hospital patients under contract to the public hospital.
—Yes, I understand that that is the case, Senator.
—In that situation, the public hospital service has no connection with the public hospital at all in a direct way.

—I understand it would be up to the State government to decide whether it could enter into an arrangement with a private hospital to enable the treatment of those persons who otherwise perhaps would have sought treatment in a public hospital proper. So, yes, I think I am agreeing with Senator Walters's statement.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 6, pages 3 and 4, proposed section 25, line 32 (page 3) to line 11 (page 4), omit the section, substitute the following section:

PARA.TAB: "`25.(1) An Agreement which has been entered into by a State must provide for the method of calculating the amount of base hospital funding grant payable in respect of a financial year during the grant period.
`(2) Financial assistance is to be provided on the conditions set out in the Agreement and in section 26.".

SPEECH.PARA: Currently the Bill provides that financial assistance is not payable to a State after 1 July 1993 unless an agreement has been entered into by that State. New subsection 25(2) sets out the five components of financial assistance payable under an agreement. Subsection 25(3) states that the agreement must provide for the method of calculating the base hospital funding grant. Subsection 25(4) states that financial assistance will be payable as set out in the agreement while subsection 25(5) states that funding will be provided on the conditions set out in the Medicare principles and commitments section. The coalition's amendment does not make the signing of the agreement a prerequisite of ongoing funding. We do not believe that the country's public hospital system and the health of thousands of Australian should be held to ransom in this way.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the coalition's amendment removes the five components of funding which the Government seeks to impose on the States until June 1998. The coalition believes that in the context of a five-year agreement there should be greater flexibility available for other methods of funding. This section seeks to set the funding components in concrete when further down the track it is quite feasible that more efficient and effective methods of funding may be determined.

The fact that last Friday the Federal Government announced quite significant changes to the previous funding proposals only highlights the need for that flexibility. For example, in five years time it is likely to be more appropriate that funding for acute care for the aged be moved across to the aged care funding category. In addition, the Government's insistence on five bands of funding would mean a massive increase in reporting, accounting, bureaucracies and in detailing the information and administration of the agreements and of maintaining that system of financial bands. For those reasons we have moved the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be rejecting the amendment which deals with several portions of proposed section 25. The effect of the amendment would be to move the focus of the section from the specific terms and conditions of financial assistance payable by the Commonwealth to a State to the largely unspecified details and agreements that relate to financial assistance. The proposed amendment removes specific reference to the condition requiring that an agreement must be entered into before financial assistance is payable by the Commonwealth to a State—that is, subsection 25(1). That is omitted in Senator Patterson's amendment. Obviously, omitting subsection 25(1) would have the effect of not formally requiring a State to enter into an agreement before it is paid financial assistance by the Commonwealth; whereas retaining subsection 25(1) subjects the Commonwealth and the States to a discipline which would be absent if the requirement were not to be inserted into an agreement. Retention of this proposed subsection is a guarantee to the Australian public that both levels of government are committed to implementing the Budget reforms and building a better health system.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the other proposed subsections which are dealt with in a way which removes reference to four out of the five components of financial assistance payable by the Commonwealth to a State, being 25(2)(b)—the hospital bonus payment; 25(2)(c)—the hospital incentive package; 25(2)(d)—a mental health incentive package; and 25(2)(e)—other health services funding. This appears to have the effect of freeing up the Commonwealth from apportioning the financial assistance in the manner specified in the subsection and, as such, is clearly inconsistent with the categories of funding and specified formulas in the draft agreements.

Removal of proposed subsection 25(4) provides greater scope for the Commonwealth not to pay a State amounts provided for in an agreement if circumstances changed. Inclusion of this provision provides security of knowledge that the Commonwealth will pay to a State a particular amount of financial assistance. The proposed subsection reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Financial assistance is payable in the amounts provided for in the Agreement.

Scope and procedures for variation of such amounts are dealt with elsewhere in the Bill. The amendment means that the States would not be guaranteed payment of money determined in the Medicare agreement. That surely would not be satisfactory. I believe the amendment is such that it ought to be rejected by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, the sky will not fall in if the States do not—
—Sign the agreement.

—I am so tired that I cannot remember what the Minister said. I lost the plot totally. I thank Senator Walters. Being up until three o'clock in the morning is telling on me but not on her. It is not necessary for the States to sign the agreement. There have already been two agreements and the sky has not fallen in. The States have been able to negotiate with the Commonwealth and get on with the business of organising—not all that wonderfully, let me say, and the point was made that there was no legislation for the agreement—to enter into an agreement. Bringing in legislation is only a new thing and we all know why. It is absolutely transparent. Legislation is being introduced to put in place the Government's policy for the next five years. Earlier I said `1988' when I should have said `1998'. I presume Hansard has corrected it. That says something about the fact that we are jamming legislation through. We were up until three o'clock this morning and again we are sitting tonight. It is no wonder one makes such mistakes. The sky will not fall if the States do not have to sign an agreement. I do not believe it is necessary to have enshrined in legislation a requirement for the States to sign an agreement. We believe that our amendment provides us with a much better way of going about this.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that basically what Senator Patterson is doing is untying the strings and ending up with a situation where there are no real undertakings and almost no need for the agreement. It seems to me that as we are one nation we should have, as much as possible, a standardised, adequate health service across all States. I am particularly concerned about the removal of the need for a mental health incentives package, which is a quite reasonable proposal. We are dealing with some very large sums of money and I am sure that taxpayers in all States would want to see such services ensured. Therefore, we will not support the amendment.
—Before dinner Senator Crowley told us that a political stunt was conducted on Friday. For once in my life I agree with her. It was a stunt.
—It had to happen before you left the Parliament, Senator.

—I guess so. I doubt whether she and I are agreeing on more than the principle involved. She would be looking at the matter differently from the way I am looking at it. On Friday a committee was to look at the Medicare Agreements Bill, to which none of the States had agreed. Indeed, as they came before us we found that Victoria and New South Wales had very basic disagreements, starting with the principles of the Bill. Western Australia still had problems with it. Western Australia said the problems were not great enough that it would want the Bill delayed. Queensland said that it did not have any problems with it. However, not one of the States said it would sign. None of the States has had any financial positions agreed upon.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister appeared before the Committee he purely made a statement, which none of us had seen before—none of the States had seen it—and we were meant to read it, digest it and ask questions of the States as they came up. I might add that we were not allowed to ask the Minister basic questions at that time, which I think would have clarified a number of issues because the States put to us very succinctly their concerns about the fact that private health care was not included in the principles of the Bill, as they wished it to be.

The Minister, of course, had his own version of the acknowledgment of private health. Had I been able to ask him questions about that, and had he put his situation early in the piece when he made his statement, the States would have been able to express their concerns or otherwise. But we were not given the right to ask him a question. He told us that he would not answer questions then; that he would come back later with his bureaucrats and answer them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh dear!
—That is correct, is it not Minister?
—No, it is not.

—I do not believe that. The Minister said that he would not answer them then. Senator Zakharov agreed with him. We can look up the Hansard. I do not know why the Minister bothers to deny things that happen, because the Hansard tells the truth if nothing else. We can have a look at the Hansard and come back to that later.

PARA.TAB: It was a sham. As I say, the Minister put down his statement that no-one had seen, that the States had not been privy to. Then halfway through the hearings the Minister came in with another letter—a letter for the New South Wales Minister for health and the Victorian Minister for health. There was none for Queensland or Western Australia. When I asked the Western Australian representative whether they were concerned that they had not received a letter, he said, `Well, we don't even know what is going on'. The Queensland representative said much the same. They did not know what was going on. Certainly they had not received letters.

We note, of course, that the Premier of Western Australia objected very strongly to the fact that New South Wales and Victoria had received letters and that she had not received any assurance that she was going to benefit in the same way. So it was a sham; it was a political stunt. I do not understand why this agreement is being forced on us at this hour on the second last day of sitting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You might wish that, but I think there are two more days after today.
—The third last day of sitting; we have Wednesday and Thursday. The agreement does not expire until July. So I really cannot understand why we have to go through this charade now.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are agreeing with the Government. I suppose that is the reason we have to go through this situation. There is no doubt at all that the States are not happy. There is no agreement. None of the States has signed anything. Yet the Senate is being told that this all has to go into legislation so that the final agreements that are not going to be put in the Bill will be cemented in and that only under very exceptional circumstances will a review take place.

I support the amendment that Senator Patterson has moved on behalf of the Opposition. I again ask the Minister, `Why carry on the charade?' It is not necessary. We have plenty of time to reach a proper outcome with all the States through negotiations being carried out in the proper way. Do not let us misunderstand the position. Negotiations have not taken place. That was made very clear to us by Minister Tehan and Minister Phillips from Victoria and New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister expect the States to sign the agreement prior to the Federal election?

—When dealing with a constitutional opinion that had been put to me, I made it very clear to the Committee that because we are operating in the area of section 96, which deals with financial assistance to the States, this is a matter which has to be agreed to by the States. It cannot be compulsorily foisted on them and a mandatory timetable cannot be set. So no, there is no requirement within the terms of the legislation before us that the States sign before the election, whenever that may be.
—Could the Minister explain why the Government decided it was necessary to have legislation when there have been two previous Medicare agreements with no such legislation?

—I mentioned to the Committee last Friday—and in a sense it has been substantiated by Senator Herron's very passionate and considered contribution—that we are at a stage in Australia's history in the provision of health care where it is very appropriate that the Commonwealth Parliament enunciate the principles which it thinks ought to govern this particular very important part of expenditure of moneys. But that is only the machinery part of it.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the Parliament should state the principles that should underpin in particular the care of eligible persons who are entitled to the provision of public hospital services. However, there should be an acknowledgment of the right of people to choose to be treated in private hospitals. Underpinning that choice is private health insurance. It is thought to be important at this stage in the evolution of our social history to incorporate and give statutory strength to those principles and agreements. For that reason, the Government has brought this forward for the consideration of the Parliament.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 6, page 4, proposed subsection 26(1), lines 12 to 20, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "26.(1) Where a State provides public hospital services in that State, the State in providing those services will recognise and promote the Medicare Principles and Commitments listed below:
(a)in the manner required by subsections (3) to (6) and the Agreement; and
(b)within the timetable set out in the Agreement.".

SPEECH.PARA: 7.Clause 6, page 6, proposed subsection 26(3), line 1, omit "To give effect to the Medicare Principles and Commitments, a State must", substitute "To promote and recognise the Medicare Principles and Commitments, a State is to".
8.Clause 6, page 6, proposed subsection 26(7), line 31, omit "adopt", substitute "promote and recognise".
9.Clause 6, page 6, proposed subsection 26(8), line 32, omit "`adopt'", substitute "`promote and recognise'".

The coalition amendment seeks to remove the Government's intention to make it a condition of the grant of financial assistance to a State that the State gives effect to certain Medicare principles and commitments which are outlined in the legislation. This sensible amendment will require the States to recognise and promote the principles and commitments outlined in the section. However, it will mean that the States and Territories will not face the prospect of losing financial assistance if they do not give effect to the principles and commitments.

PARA.TAB: Our amendments do not mean that the requirements upon the States in sections 26(3) and section 26(8) will be removed. These requirements will remain. However, under our consequential amendments Nos 7, 8 and 9, the undertaking of these requirements will mean that a State has recognised and promoted the principles and commitments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments. We have a longstanding basic commitment to Medicare. We have no problems with these basic goals being written in.

PARA.TAB: I do have some problems with some comments that were made about the committee process last Friday. The hearing was a very worthwhile exercise for those who went along to look at the legislation. However, I wish to add to some of the concerns expressed by Senator Walters about the actual process and the way the States have been dealt with in negotiations. Before doing that, I must stress that we are not in the business of being involved in those negotiations. All we are doing is setting up a framework within which those negotiations can take place. It is then over to the States and the Federal Government to sort that out between themselves.

I do have some major concerns about the way in which the States have been handled, particularly in the period leading up to Friday's hearing when, indeed, it seemed that an agreement had been leaked to the press before the State Minister, and certainly before the Premier of that State, had seen it. Putting that aside, I believe the committee process on Friday was very worth while when we were actually looking at the legislation before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, the Government will adhere to the placing within the statutory framework and foundation for the Medicare agreements to be reached, as Senator Lees has quite well put it, between the various governments. In other words, the Cabinets of the various Australian jurisdictions elected by the people will finally determine whether the agreements should be entered into or not. We believe that these Medicare principles and the commitments, which are in a sense subsidiary but certainly attached to those principles, are of high importance. I think it is important for the purpose of the record of this debate to emphasise that these Medicare principles are preceded by a preambular paragraph which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth and the States are committed to the following principles in the provision of public hospital services.
The explanatory note reads:

The Principles focus on the provision of public hospital services to eligible persons, but operate in the environment where eligible persons have the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

Quite clearly, the major thrust of the Medicare agreements will be to enable a flow of funds to substantially improve the capacity of the public hospital system throughout Australia to provide hospital services to eligible persons. That is the major thrust of the provision of the extra funding of $1.6 billion over six years to the various jurisdictions.

PARA.TAB: It is worth emphasising that this is the first time an enactment of the Commonwealth Parliament, with full statutory force, is recognising the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance. I believe that needs to be given further emphasis than has been given hitherto.

In so far as Senator Patterson dilutes that particular preamble and the principles, of course it cannot be agreed to, and the consequential amendment which Senator Patterson has moved also does not find favour with the Commonwealth, particularly where there is a replacement of the requirement that the States adopt the principles and commitments in a particular form which I will come to. I think `promote and recognise' was the substitute terminology offered by the Opposition.
It is important in relation to the requirement to adopt to read proposed section 26(3) which says:

SPEECH.PARA: To give effect to the Medicare Principles and Commitments a State must—
I then go down to (b)—
either:

PARA.TAB: (i) adopt the Principles and Commitments; or
(ii) if the State cannot adopt the Principles and Commitments—make reasonable efforts to adopt the Principles and Commitments . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a fair and reasonable statement of the obligation. I believe that proposed section 26(3)(b) is not affected by Senator Patterson's amendment. Proposed section 26(8) needs to be looked at too. It says:

In this section, `adopt' means to enact legislation that establishes the Principles and Commitments as guidelines that will govern the delivery of public hospital services to eligible persons in a State, but neither the obligation to enact that legislation, nor the State legislation so enacted, operates to create in any person legal rights not in existence before the enactment of the State legislation, unless the State legislation expressly provides otherwise.

I think that is a fair and reasonable way to put the obligation which is meant to be imposed on a State: it will establish legislation as guidelines, but one cannot vest in a person a right to insist that particular treatment be provided in accordance with those guidelines. That allows for the fact that it is always difficult to provide these services and it may not be possible in any particular instance to ensure that the principles and commitments work in favour of a patient presenting for that service. I believe it is important, nevertheless, to maintain proposed section 26. The Commonwealth cannot accept the amendment, which would have the effect of undermining the principles and commitments set out in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Patterson said a little while ago that this is driven by ideology. It is nothing else at all but that. The whole thing revolves around the principle, with which we have so much of a problem, that eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients. Senator Patterson's amendment says that the State must promote and recognise the Medicare principles and commitments—not give effect to but promote. We do that because we know that over 78,000 people are on waiting lists in those States that do put forward their waiting lists. Queensland does not. Queensland did not know what its waiting list was. It has not even bothered to find out or to record its waiting list. Tonight Senator Herron gave us some fine examples. People in Queensland cannot even get an orthopaedic appointment in outpatients for something like 14 weeks, far less have an operation.
—It is like 18 months.

—Whatever the time was. People cannot get an appointment to be seen, yet the Queensland representatives told the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs that a waiting list is not kept. They were thinking of doing it and they were going to start it soon, but they did not know when the figures would be available. They said they had a jolly good public health system, but they do not even know how many people at any one time are waiting to use that health system.We have now this stupidity written into the principles that eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients. The only thing that is left out is when they must be given a choice—when they need it or when it suits the Government's financial situation to give it to them? The Minister says that that is all covered in proposed section 26(3)(b). Then he scuppers his own principles and commitments by saying that if the States cannot adopt the principles and commitments they must make reasonable efforts. What on earth does he think Senator Patterson's amendment is if it is not that? The Minister might answer me later on what he classes as `make reasonable efforts', because I do not know what that means. What sort of reasonable efforts should a State make to be able to carry out the principle that everyone who is eligible ought to be able to have access? Proposed section 26(8) says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . neither the obligation to enact that legislation, nor the State legislation so enacted, operates to create in any person legal rights . . .

The Bill contains all this lovely hyperbole and highfalutin stuff. It says that eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients. Then the Government covers itself by saying further down in the Bill, `But of course you have no legal rights. Don't get carried away enough to think we mean it, because if the States can't give it to you, then all we require them to do is to make some sort of reasonable effort'—whatever `reasonable' happens to be. Then it says, `If you still can't get it when they make the reasonable effort, don't get carried away and think we really mean it, because you've got no legal rights anyway. We don't give you a legal right to have access to the money you pay in your Medicare levy. We're not going to make the States give you eligible persons access. If they can't, we'll just say, "You make reasonable efforts and we'll pass that as being OK"'. The problem is that this Bill, along with the Government's whole health policy, is ideology-driven.

PARA.TAB: Can the Minister explain to me why in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, our own State of Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia and the two Territories someone on a very high income can go into hospital and take a bed that a pensioner who is desperately wanting to have a hip replacement should have access to? As the Minister knows, I have had a hip replacement. I was not prepared to join the waiting lists and, because I have never trusted the Government's health system, and because I can afford it, I chose not to bludge on the system but to bear my own responsibilities and pay for private health care so that I would not end up taking a bed from someone who is not as fortunate as I and who could not afford to go into a private hospital and have his or her hip replaced.

Why does the Minister not believe that is the correct action for any Australian to take? Why is it that he does not believe that those who can afford it should take out private hospital cover so that they can have their elective surgery done in a private hospital and give beds to those people whom we on this side are very concerned about and whom those on the Government side profess to be concerned about? I do not understand the Government's ideology at all—and I am not sure that Government members do.

We on this side of the chamber believe that people who cannot afford to privately insure ought to be able to have access to a bed when they need it. The only way the Government will be able to afford to do that is to encourage those who can afford to take out private hospital cover to do so. We need the beds in the public hospitals. There are 78,000 people, not including those in Queensland, trying to get into those hospitals who cannot do so.

The Minister has read in the Sydney Morning Herald about the cardiac surgeons who have said that 44 people have died waiting for bypass operations because they could not get in. Why will the Minister not encourage all those who are well off enough to be able to take out private health cover to do so and to go into private hospitals and have their cardiac surgery done there? Some of the very good private hospitals do cardiac surgery very regularly. That would leave beds in the public hospitals so that pensioners and the less well off could have their cardiac surgery done in time so that they would not die on the waiting lists because of the Government's ideology. I would be grateful if the Minister could explain that to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters has raised—genuinely, but in a way which itself was laced with ideology—some questions which need to be addressed, but I will deal firstly with the more objective matter of waiting lists. I agree with Senator Walters in regarding it as a disgrace that a State in Australia is not able to describe the waiting list situation in the jurisdiction for which it is responsible. I think the fact that Queensland does not have such a list is a matter which ought to attract adverse comment—and obviously has.

PARA.TAB: I think it will be extremely important, if we are to reduce the waiting lists—whether known with precision or just anecdotally—to an acceptable level, for that information to be made available so that proper programs of management can be put in place to reduce the waiting time. There is no doubt that the $70m over two years, which is not a huge amount, will help in that waiting list reduction program. But it ought to be seen in the context of the $1.6 billion over six years which will be put into the public hospital services of Australia under the Medicare agreements to be negotiated, which I believe will have a cumulative effect of reducing those waiting lists.

I think it is worth mentioning that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), at the heads of government meeting in Perth, cut the nexus which had been in place between in-principle agreement to the Medicare agreements and the provision of the waiting list moneys—the $70m over two years. He invited States such as New South Wales and Victoria immediately to enter into a subsidiary agreement, a completely separate arrangement, to allow those moneys to flow into their jurisdictions to help reduce the waiting lists in New South Wales and Victoria, even though in principle they may not be prepared at this moment to agree to the Medicare agreements.

I would go one step further and say that if those States do not make that move to accept the waiting list money in the near future, given the instances which Senator Walters brought to the attention of the chamber, perhaps the Commonwealth should look directly to funding the hospitals concerned, bypassing the States with waiting list moneys. The money is sitting there. It is a human tragedy, and a fatal situation for some, that that money is not being expended. I believe that all the States ought to take up those moneys.

As to the question of ideology, I think Senator Walters undervalues the contribution which she has made to the Australian health system simply by the payment of her taxes and the Medicare levy on the high income she has been earning over the last several years. That gives her an entitlement to go into the public hospital system to receive treatment for an illness or to undo the effects of an accident that she may have suffered.

Senator Walters is not correct to use the terminology she did when she said that she would be somewhat embarrassed or would feel that she would be bludging on the system if she were to go into a public hospital. She is entitled to go into a public hospital. She has paid high taxes, and a high proportion further by way of the Medicare levy over many years, to help provide those services. I believe that she is entitled to go to the Royal Hobart Hospital if she so desires.

Of course we cannot go into personal details, but Senator Walters chose to go to a private hospital, I take it, in order to have the treatment she required. That is a choice that the honourable senator made. She made it because she had chosen to take out private health insurance. Once again, I believe that is the correct ideological position. We favour choice. We favour the fact that one should choose, if one so wishes, private health insurance. I admit that I made an error in my rather flamboyant reply in the chamber the other day about the question of Fightback and private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not like you to be flamboyant.

—I was carried away. But I do think it is still true to point out that under the Fightback package a person with the income of Senator Walters would be penalised through the tax system if she did not take out private health insurance—and I think Senator Walters would agree that that is true.
—That is true.
—So there would be a tax penalty.
—Yes.

—Yes. We have not reached that stage. We believe that Senator Walters is certainly free to choose to take out private health insurance. It is the right of Senator Walters in a free society to do so and give herself that further possibility, therefore, of taking the treatment that she wishes in a private hospital for the sort of surgery that she requires. But we do not believe in a form of coercion by financial penalties which are involved in the Fightback system at the higher end of the tax scale.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I think it also has to be said, on behalf of some of our very well regarded public hospitals, that the reason a person might choose and want to be treated there rather than at a private hospital is simply because of the reputation of the public hospital. Perhaps it has a clinical school attached to it and is a teaching hospital. It may well be that a person would make a very positive choice to be treated in the public hospital rather than in the private hospital and to exercise their entitlements, as I say, which they have as a taxpayer and Medicare levy payer to be served there as a public patient.

That is the brief answer, and I think we could go on all night about the personal reasons which underlie our commitment to a particular form of the provision of hospital services and their financing.Senator Walters has given her personal anecdote; I might just give mine. In 1963, when at first year uni I had a massive car accident, my parents were on the top of the MBF table. Like most Australian families after the war, my father had paid in at the top rate to protect his family. I forget what it was, but I think it was after a hundred days, or maybe it was 10 weeks, the MBF payments ceased and we were thrown back on to the financial resources of a family of two parents and three young children all being educated. Quite frankly, those resources were stretched to the absolute limit to deal with a situation where one was in hospital for month after month after month, year after year after year. It caused financial trauma, on top of the need to be healed physically so far as the family was concerned.

I determined then that if I were ever in a position to ensure that regardless of apparent income a person would be entitled to hospital services of a high quality without having to be financially traumatised by having to face very high hospital bills or the need to take out very high premium payments in order to protect oneself against an eventuality, I should look for something better than my family and I were confronted with at that time. That is the reason I have always been a very strong supporter of Medicare; and I believe that these particular principles and commitments are deserving of the support of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister will know, in those days there were other alternatives than the one his parents chose for him. After the hundred days, he could have very readily moved into the public hospital system. There was no need for him to stay in the private hospital system.
—No, I was in a public hospital.
—Then if the Minister were in the public hospital system, after the hundred days there would have been no further charge.
—There was.

—No, in those days there would not have been, not at all. As to what the Minister said a few moments ago, yes, under Fightback there would be a tax penalty, but we would not raise the Medicare levy for the poor as those opposite have done. From 1 June or 1 July the levy goes up to 1.4 per cent. We would not have done that. We have said no, that we will retain the levy, and anyone who wants to stay with Medicare can stay. We would not have raised the levy. Only people with the higher income would have had an increase if they did not decide to privately insure. Those opposite have raised it for the poor and they have raised it for people on the higher income.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister not to misquote Fightback. We would have kept the levy for the poor the same; we would have allowed them to maintain Medicare if they chose. We would have said to the people who could afford it, `You will pay an additional levy'. It would not have been the poorer people but just the wealthier people who would have paid the additional levy—unless they had decided to take out private insurance, in which case for them the levy would not have been increased. We would have said to the poorer people, `If you want to privately insure, we will assist you and will pay some of that contribution for you'. So again I ask the Minister not to misquote Fightback. It does not do him justice if he seeks to make political points that are not correct and proper.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 6, page 5, proposed Medicare Principles, after Principle 3, add the following principle:

EMPHASIS.TAB: ``Principle 4: Eligible persons have the right to choose health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance''.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to include an additional principle in the Medicare principles; namely, that eligible persons have the right to choose health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: The 40 per cent of the population—in fact, the diminishing numbers of people, but currently the 40 per cent of the population—who choose to take out private health insurance will, in the run-up to the next Federal election, be interested to know that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), in a press release earlier this month, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government supports the right of Australians to take out private health insurance to provide those extra services not available to public patients.
This would appear to be a total backflip from the position of his predecessor, Dr Neil Blewett, who in 1985, stated:
I have always maintained that Medicare's continued success and high popularity is dependent on the maintenance of a strong, viable private health care sector.

This backflip has been taken purely for political reasons. In the run-up to the next election, the Government wishes to continue to perpetuate the myth that Medicare provides a universally accessible and viable free public hospital system. This is simply not the case.

PARA.TAB: I understand the Minister's concern, given his personal experiences, to ensure that people have access of the sort he has just described, but I am sorry to say that he has failed. I only have to give the example of the newsagent near my office who rang me to convey his concerns about the old lady who comes into his agency. That is one example of this Government's failure reflected in some 70,000 to 100,000 people on the waiting lists.

Those people probably feel just as strongly as the Minister does about equity and justice and access to hospital but they are not getting it. The Minister cannot kid me that they are. It is about time that the Government realised that privately insured Australians underwrite our public hospital system and save the Government $3 billion in expenditure every year.

The Minister has only to come with me to visit little hospitals in country Victoria—I suppose he could go to visit hospitals in country Tasmania—and they will say to him, `The thing that is killing us is the fact that we no longer have privately insured patients'. One hospital told me that it had gone from 75 per cent to 25 per cent. It said, `We cannot continue to exist'. The hospitals are saying it. The Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Public Hospitals Association have jointly put out a statement—it is unprecedented for those two organisations to get together—and put the same point of view, that we ought to support private health insurance and recognise that it is an integral part of our health care delivery service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply need to state that the Government will not be accepting this amendment. It is very close in terminology to the explanatory note in the preambular paragraph to the Medicare principles, which I have already focused on in this debate. It is important that there be proper recognition that the public health care system in Australia operates in tandem with private health care and insurance.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to restate that, despite the peculiar form in which it is placed—according to Parliamentary Counsel practice—this measure does have full statutory force. There is no need to go to the Acts Interpretation Act to understand it because it is a full part of the statute. In that way, I believe this is the first statement by the Parliament in recognition of the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment either. We will be moving an amendment shortly that directly links any further drop in the number of people who have private insurance with an automatic review of the agreements between the States. We acknowledge that there is a link between the number of people privately insured and the amount of funding that the hospitals are able to obtain. At this point we are looking to that amendment rather than supporting the one now before us.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 6, page 6, proposed Medicare Commitments, after proposed Commitment 2, add the following Commitment:

TAB.EMPHASIS: "Commitment 3: The Commonwealth and the States are committed to the establishment of a National Health Policy by the end of 1994

PARA.TAB: Explanatory Note 1: This includes a commitment to examine all aspects of the Australian health care system funded and managed by both levels of government.
Explanatory Note 2: This also includes delineation of the roles and responsibilities of both levels of Government in health care.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will add an additional commitment, namely, the establishment of a national health policy by the end of 1994. The States have been pushing for this for a number of years. They recognise the need to delineate the roles and responsibilities of State and Federal levels of government in health care and to examine all aspects of Australian health care, funded and managed by both levels of government.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, such rationalisation should include agreed national health goals and targets. The benefits of such rationalisation will be substantial in areas such as health services for the aged. A national health policy will prevent the unnecessary duplication of services and will result in a greater clarification of responsibilities. It will mean less bureaucracy, greater accountability of scant resources and, most importantly, a better standard of health care for the public.

It is worth noting that the Australian Democrats have foreshadowed a similar amendment, although their amendment is restricted to national health goals and targets. We believe that no national health policy is anywhere near complete if it does not assess current funding arrangements or the Federal-State relations and their various responsibilities in the area of health care and health care delivery.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the only Liberal Party amendment that we are in any way attracted to. However, for the very reason that Senator Patterson gave at the end of her speech for wanting us to support it, we will indeed oppose it.

PARA.TAB: Written into the whole idea of a national health policy is this ongoing argument about where the money is coming from. We would for once like to put that aside in this chamber. Recent health debates in here show that we always seem to end up on that same sticking point—whether health care will be public or private and where the money will come from. We want to get away from that and start looking at goals and setting some targets so that we know what we are aiming towards. We want to put aside that ideological debate—not to ignore it but to not include it in the basic principles that we should be determining.

There has been an endless amount of research. I will talk more about that when I move my amendment. We do not need to go into any more background papers; we have it all written out before us. We need to simply put it together and to discuss and debate it with the States. We believe that that can be done in 12 months. Therefore, we will not be supporting the Liberal Party amendment, but we will be seeking support for our amendment at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be rejecting this amendment. Quite clearly, the central issue in the Medicare Agreements Bill 1992 is to clearly state and enshrine the principles and commitments to the provision of public hospital services. I believe that the broader review of the roles and responsibilities of health care in Australia should be determined in a more appropriate context. Quite frankly, I do not think that this Bill is that appropriate context. For that reason, the Government will not be supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10.Clause 6, pages 7 and 8, proposed paragraph 28(1)(f), line 41 (page 7) to line 2 (page 8), omit the paragraph.

This amendment will delete proposed subparagraph 28(1)(f), which seeks to require that certain variations to Medicare agreements can take effect only if both Houses of Parliament approve the variations by resolution. This is another example of this Government valiantly attempting to hold on to its failed system of public health, regardless of whether it retains power at the next Federal election.

PARA.TAB: This clause begs the question, `When is an agreement not an agreement?'. The answer is: when both the Commonwealth and the States agree to variations of a Medicare agreement, they must still have these variations ratified by both Houses of the Federal Parliament. This clause would mean that, when a Federal government does not have the numbers in the Senate, the Opposition with the assistance of those who sit on the cross-benches can block variations in the funding arrangements relating to a Medicare agreement. This is a far cry from the two previous sets of Medicare agreements in 1984 and 1988 where there was no overriding legislation, let alone the ability of an upper House to veto variations in agreements.

One wonders whether Mr Keating knows about this nasty little clause that is in this Bill. I presume that he does. Maybe he does not pay all that much attention to what goes on in this sort of legislation, but he appears to be more than willing to use the power of the Senate when it may be to his own advantage.

This clause is an attempt by Labor to enshrine its form of Medicare for another five years. The coalition believes that it is totally inappropriate for the Federal Parliament to potentially have the ability to lock an agreement into place where a State and the Commonwealth have agreed to variations to the agreement. At a time when there are major changes to our public hospital system, which the Australian Democrats have publicly acknowledged in their amendment, this will reduce the potential for flexibility in funding arrangements in areas such as aged care as well as in the development of a case mix approach.

I was interested to hear Senator Lees speak on my amendment No. 4. I cannot remember her exact words, but they were to the effect that she wanted to create a framework for the governments to come to an agreement and to then leave it up to the governments to get on with it. Senator Tate, in supporting Senator Lees, said that the Cabinets will decide whether the agreements will be entered into. They may decide that, but the Parliament may decide differently. The two of them can say both those things, but it is not really the case. The Cabinets cannot vary it; they are not in a position to do that. We are not leaving the Cabinets to decide whether they can vary these agreements. Senator Lees argued against her own point, and it was not very logical.

We believe that the agreement should not have to be approved by both Houses of Parliament. The States have been able to enter into agreements before. The framework that Senator Lees spoke of has been set up and we should let the States get on with it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking of consistency, last night Senator Patterson argued on the opposite side of the fence in this issue because she argued a case for parliamentary scrutiny, which is the same case that I am now arguing. At that time we did not agree with her. The only thing we can agree to agree on is that sometimes parliamentary scrutiny is appropriate. At other times—we argue very strongly that last night was one of those times—it is not appropriate. In this case, we will be supporting the clause because we believe that parliamentary scrutiny is appropriate.

—The Government rejects this amendment. We believe that once the agreements have been reached, with reliance upon the very firm foundations and the statutory framework established by this Medicare Agreements Act, as it will then be, it is important that there should be a certainty on the part of all the parties that the Commonwealth Parliament will play a role in any variation and act as guarantor to ensure that the matters that are of importance and listed in proposed section 28 can form a proper basis for variation only if, as I say, both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament approve by resolution the variation of the agreement.

PARA.TAB: I believe that that supervisory role is a proper one for the Federal Parliament at that stage of the life of the agreements. It is a precautionary and safeguard measure for the parties. I believe that is a proper role for the Parliament and therefore it ought to be supported in the form in which it appears in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say something about Senator Lees's comments. In fact, the situation last night was entirely different. They were not elected representatives; they were people appointed to a committee making a decision about guidelines with respect to human embryo experimentation.

PARA.TAB: It is quite a different situation from having elected representatives making a decision about an agreement; a Federal government and a State government agreeing to vary the agreement. It is quite a different situation and I do not think I am being inconsistent.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 6, page 4, after proposed subsection 25(4), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(4A) The Agreement must provide for the amount of hospital bonus payment payable to a State under the hospital bonus component to be reviewed each time the percentage of the national population who, at 30 June 1993, are covered by a supplementary hospital table falls by at least 2 percentage points or a multiple thereof

SPEECH.PARA: Note 1:If the percentage of the national population at 30 June 1993 who are covered by a supplementary hospital table is x%, then a review would be triggered under this section if the rate drops to (x-2)%.

Note 2:Subsequent review during the life of the Agreement would be triggered by additional drops of 2 percentage points over the base established at 30 June 1993.
