That is, if the percentage of the national population at 30 June 1993 who are covered by a supplementary hospital table subsequently drops to (x-4)%, this would trigger another review. Similarly, drops to (x-6)%, (x-8)% etc would trigger further reviews.".
2.Clause 6, page 4, add at the end of proposed section 25 the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(6) In calculating the percentage of the national population who are covered by a supplementary hospital table at any time, regard must be had to the data published by the Private Health Insurance Administration Council.".

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of these amendments is to establish a link between any further drop of 2 per cent or more in the number of Australians who are privately insured and funding for the public hospital system. It is acknowledged that there is by no means a direct link. However, there is some flow-over.

PARA.TAB: If honourable senators read through the first amendment, they will see that a review is triggered by a drop of 2 per cent on an ongoing basis. In other words, it would be triggered in 1994 and it could be triggered again in 1995, depending on the actual movement of people out of private insurance. The second amendment is consequential upon that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of comments I want to make. When we first saw this amendment it had not taken into account the issues that were in notes Nos 1 and 2. The amendment also refers to the supplementary hospital table. I think I am right in saying it ought to be the basic hospital table. I would ask the Minister to answer that question. If it should be the basic hospital table, then it really ought to be altered to read that way.

PARA.TAB: These amendments as a whole really treat the symptoms and not the cause. The Democrats are saying, `Throw some more money at this. If there is a problem, if the number of people who are taking up private health insurance decreases, we will just throw some more taxpayers' money to plug up the hole'. The fact that they voted with the Government just a moment ago in not enshrining in this legislation the role of private health insurance is consistent with what they are saying here: `We are not going to correct the problem of declining and decreasing private health insurance numbers. If the numbers go down, we understand that the States will need more money, so we will organise for them to have it'.

We ought to be looking at methods to provide incentives to encourage people to take out private health insurance. I have said tonight, and I will say again, that the Australian Hospitals Association and the Australian Private Hospitals Association together in an unprecedented venture put that case very strongly. Wherever we go throughout Australia, to either a public or a private hospital, the peak bodies and their members are saying exactly the same thing, that we need methods and incentives to encourage people to take out private health insurance. We should be doing that. In fact, our Fightback package provides tax credits for people on lower income levels who take out private health insurance rather than having taxpayers pay more money to fix up the inherent problem, which is what this amendment is doing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is my amendment, perhaps I should endeavour to explain it. Looking at the various tables, it seems that the supplementary hospital table is the one that people are moving out of most rapidly. Therefore, that was chosen instead of the base table. As for the ongoing debate—I suppose I cannot avoid getting back into public versus private again—somewhere we have to find the money. We do not believe that we should force Australians into private insurance, costing them many hundreds of dollars on top of whatever grant they may be given, depending on their income.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition package removes the restraints on the AMA by way of charging fees. While we may be able to trust our local GPs not to jack up their fees more than $4 or $5 a visit, I do not believe we can trust all and certainly not a lot of the specialists. So we will have an enormous blow-out in the costs of health. Rather than going down, as Senator Patterson suggested, the costs of health insurance could indeed rise further, particularly as the Opposition is also taking out bulkbilling and removing the gap. The gap is one of those price signals that lets people know that it will actually cost them something.

I wonder why, when we are trying to provide some sort of a mechanism by which there will be additional funds to try to prevent any further waiting lists, Senator Patterson now seems to have a problem with that, having complained so bitterly earlier about waiting lists. This is actually a way of solving the problem, to some extent at least, and of coming to terms with the fact that we have to put more money into the system to ensure that people in genuine need of treatment are able to get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to rise again, but I cannot let Senator Lees say that we will take out bulkbilling. That is wrong. Senator Lees should get it right.
—For all but the destitute.

—All but the destitute! We are not taking out bulkbilling for everyone. Pensioners and health card holders will be entitled to bulkbilling. Get it straight and get it right. The other thing Senator Lees said is that we will be forcing people into private health insurance. I know she listens to Senator Tate avidly when he gives answers in Question Time—and he got up and said that we were going to force all Australians to take out private health insurance. He began to admit this evening that he had made a mistake. He got a bit—
—Penitent.

—Senator Tate was about to be penitent, but he did not get there. He did not actually admit that he had made an error. He started to tell us. If we look at the Hansard, we will see that he stopped. I do not know whether Senator Tate saw the error of his ways, but he did not quite get to tell us that he had made the error. Now I have the opportunity to tell him. It is not right that we are forcing people into private health insurance. We are giving people a choice and we are saying to people that if they take out private health insurance they will get a tax credit—and it is not hundreds of dollars below the basic cover.
—Have you looked lately?

—I have looked. In fact, I did it just recently as an exercise to have some relatives of mine insured. So I know exactly what the basic rate is. Anyway, get those two points straight: we are not taking out bulkbilling for everyone and we are not forcing people into health insurance. If Senator Lees has to talk about our policy, at least get it right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I appeared before the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on Friday I indicated that the Federal Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) would be writing to his State counterparts indicating that he would agree to a provision for a review of the funding arrangements in the event of major changes in the health environment which resulted in significant and unavoidable increases in demand or cost. I went on to say that this would include significant decreases in private health insurance participation rates.

PARA.TAB: So it will not surprise the Committee to learn that the Government will support this amendment because it gives greater precision to that undertaking. I think Senator Lees has sufficiently explained why the supplementary hospital table was chosen. I understand that 88 per cent of those Australians who take out private health insurance do take out supplementary hospital insurance. As this is the table that gives access to private hospitals, if shifts occur onto public demand, they will be more significant obviously as a shift from private hospital to public hospital provision of care.

So this is an important specification, if you like, of an undertaking that I had signalled to the Committee that met on Friday. I believe that for that reason the Government can give its support to the amendment. The effect of the amendment is to precisely specify the point at which a review of the level of Commonwealth hospital bonus payments would be triggered, being two percentage points or greater drop below the June 1993 level of the proportion of the national population with supplementary private insurance. Further reviews could then be triggered by subsequent two percentage point drops.

Quite clearly, the States have a very real and genuine concern about their financial liability in the event of significant decreases in private insurance participation rates. We did argue on Friday that such decreases do not necessarily lead to corresponding increases in public hospital activity or costs. Indeed, attachment 4 to the New South Wales Minister's submission to the Senate Committee revealed that in the face of declining private insurance membership in New South Wales:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there has been an increase in private sector activity. This suggests that there have been no movement from the private to the public sector.

That is not good English, but that is what the attachment said. The amendment quite appropriately links potential reimbursement for significant decreases of people with private insurance following a review to demonstrable increases in public hospital activity through the bonus component of the agreement. For that reason, the amendment is accepted.

PARA.TAB: The consequent amendment provides that the data used to determine the national supplementary health insurance participation rate will be based upon that published by an independent authority, namely, the Private Health Insurance Administration Council. We think that is a useful guarantee and safeguard for the States and we are pleased to be able to support that amendment too.
Amendments agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate on Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1992 and Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 resumed from 12 November, and debate on Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 resumed from 3 November, on motions by Senator Robert Ray and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that this has been the craziest presentation of legislation that I have ever seen. I would not know how many times over the last two or three weeks Bills have been on and off and up and down. I think the arrangements have been changed five or six times today. I am absolutely staggered that the Government believes that it can run its business and the country in such a manner.

PARA.TAB: The Bills deal with issues of customs administration and implement a number of decisions on industry assistance, as well as dealing with a number of housekeeping matters, especially in the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). Key issues are, however, the amendments to anti-dumping administration and the further phasing down of assistance to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. This highlights the interaction of these two facets of industry policy.

The Opposition supports an orderly phase-down in tariffs, but it must be accompanied by effective protection against predatory dumping and subsidisation of goods exported to Australia. It must also be facilitated through the micro-economic reforms so necessary to enable Australian industry to compete both domestically and abroad. The Government has failed to measure up in both these areas.

While these amendments to the anti-dumping administration are welcomed by the Opposition, they are late in arriving and do not go far enough. Why has it taken so long for Australia to adopt the European and North American approach of a mandatory up-front interim duty? Was it because the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology took the initiative to look at the question of dumping?

Unlike the present situation where duty is not collected if the exporter raises the export price to the level of the normal value determined by Customs on price undertaking, firm action will now occur in each case where dumping or subsidisation is found to cause material injury. The onus remains on the applicant for dumping and subsidy action to make a case for material injury occurring. This is appropriate. The legislation now places the onus of proof on the exporter-importer when it comes to adjustments to the duty liability or a review of the liability, and this is how it should be.

Some press reports have stated that because dumping duty will now be payable for each and every shipment of an item for a six-month period, irrespective of any bona fide change in the export price of the goods, importers can have a problem. It is suggested that an importer can face enormous price disadvantages in the marketplace over this period. While this could be true in some cases, the local producer of the goods concerned would also have experienced price disadvantages in the market prior to the imposition of dumping duty.

Part of the solution for the importer is to have very close relations with the overseas supplier to ensure that the goods do not get involved in a dumping or subsidy situation in the first place. This may not always be easy, but under this legislation there is now a real incentive to avoid problems arising. Our anti-dumping mechanism should be swift and effective but in no way provide an alternative form of protection for industry in lieu of tariff protection. Neither should it be a de facto means of industry protection, but an effective measure to be used against those who cheat in international trade.

While this legislation improves the effectiveness of our anti-dumping administration, it is not as speedy as it should be. Following the Government's statement of 5 December 1991, it legislated to reduce the period for a preliminary finding to 125 days, or 145 days for the more complex cases. This is 25 days for determining a prima facie case and 100 days for the Customs investigation. This in the commercial world is still just too long.

The coalition proposes to reduce this to five days for the prima facie case and 60 days for the investigation. In these cases, time is of the essence. Companies can fail completely while their claim is being investigated. Also, the coalition will replace the present harsh material injury test with one that is less severe, again making sure that companies are not wiped out by the unfair trading practices of international competitors.

I turn now to the TCF industry. In maintaining its timetable for the phase-down of the TCF tariffs, the Government has put in place a program of measures to assist restructuring, boosting exports and enhancing the import credit scheme. Because we have reached the TCF area, I think it is appropriate that I make some mention of the report of the Industry Commission which came down last week. I draw particular attention to this on account of the fact that I am aware that there will be an amendment coming forward from another quarter concerning the actual quota figures. On page 5 of the IC annual report it states:

SPEECH.PARA: To give in to calls for a delay would send the wrong signals to industry. It would show that lobbying for government assistance can be more profitable in the short term than finding ways to improve long-term competitiveness. With that attitude, self-serving reasons for not resuming microeconomic reforms would multiply—the time would never be right.

In short, a pause in the reform process would not be effective in saving jobs overall, even in the short term. A pause now runs the risk that the reform process will lose momentum altogether. Deferring reforms which have the potential to confer wide-ranging benefits would be at the expense of taxpayers and consumers generally. The cost to the nation in terms of building opportunities for growth and sustainable jobs would be substantial.

While the proposals are good and proper, they are no substitute for meaningful micro-economic reforms, such as waterfront reform, which flows through to the importers and exporters; other transport reform, including rail; labour market reform; and reforms in energy supply. One has only to compare the situation of New Zealand industry with the Australian equivalent. New Zealand has lower labour on-costs, lower transport costs, quicker turnaround times and lower packaging material costs.

PARA.TAB: Australian industry must become more internationally competitive. A lowering of our protective walls is consistent with the objective, but so essentially is the reform of the economic infrastructure within such industry functions. The Industry Commission in its 1991-92 annual report strongly supports this view. On page 8 of that report, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Further progress in a broad program of microeconomic reform aimed at tackling underlying structural problems would improve Australia's international competitiveness, so that the economy would grow faster (and in a sustainable way).

That is what is important at this juncture. There has been lip-service given to this view, but the Government has done little in practice. The coalition has made a clear public policy to deliver on these reforms.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill. The movement of cargo automation is welcomed. Anything that can speed up the import process, reduce paperwork and reduce costs while maintaining control must be welcomed. But there are features of this program about which we are still not happy and which we will certainly be watching very closely. I am pleased to note that benefits will flow on to the port authorities and to AQIS as a result.

It is important that facilitation of imports does not occur at the expense of control. It is important that Customs puts maximum effort into its risk assessment, as reflected in its profiles used under the new system. The Opposition supports the measures to enforce greater waterfront security through identification requirements and new powers to stop and search vehicles. Again, I ask why it has taken so long after the need was identified in 1989 by the National Crime Authority.

Finally, there is the diesel fuel rebate amendment extending eligibility to fuel used in certain ships while travelling to and from Australian ports for repairs or refits. While the amendment is supported, it is yet another amendment to a thoroughly discredited administrative arrangement which, fortunately, will become redundant when excise is abolished under the coalition's economic policies for revitalising the country. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating this package of Customs Bills, I turn first to the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. This is an omnibus Bill proposing amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Administration Act 1985. There are three main proposals contained in this Bill. Firstly, it is designed to provide the legislative framework to establish a cargo automation system. Such a system will involve the electronic transmission to Customs of information relating to the reporting, screening and clearance of cargo. It will permit limited on-line computer access to such information by other specified agencies.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it proposes to improve waterfront security in accordance with recommendations by the joint review committee which examined the 1989 report of the National Crime Authority on port security and in particular to increase control over ships' crews and other individuals in waterfront areas. Thirdly, it seeks to extend the eligibility for the diesel fuel rebate scheme to vessels servicing oil and gas operations in the North West Shelf and Timor Gap exploration areas when those vessels travel to and from Australian ship repair yards for refits or repairs.
Vessels currently have a choice of repairs or refits being undertaken in either Australia or Singapore. However, as stated in the second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: Diesel fuel taken on by the ships in Singapore is at the international price, which does not include Australian excise. This has resulted in Australian ship repair yards being placed at a competitive disadvantage, especially those in Western Australia which are almost equidistant from the repair yards in Singapore.

This proposed amendment will effectively remove this competitive disadvantage. As well, there are some minor technical changes consequential on the introduction of the electronic lodgment reforms to the import entry regime in Act No. 34 of 1992. The Democrats will support this Bill without amendment.

PARA.TAB: I turn my attention to the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1992 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. I was very pleased to hear Senator Archer say that the Opposition will again move amendments to reduce the prima facie stage of anti-dumping applications to five days. I recall that the last time customs legislation was before the Senate the Australian Democrats and the Opposition moved a similar amendment. It went to the House of Representatives and was rejected there. When it came back to the Senate, the Opposition had gone to water and was not prepared to stick with the amendment. The Australian Democrats will support that particular amendment. We hope that this time the coalition parties will stick with their resolve and that the amendment will be passed. The Democrats will certainly seek to ensure that.

The two Bills that the Senate is discussing at the moment propose to amend the Customs Act 1901, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 to introduce a new regime for the imposition and collection of both interim and final dumping and countervailing duties. Under the present anti-dumping regime, dumping duty is not payable where the dumping margin is purportedly eliminated by an exporter raising the export price of the goods to the level of the normal value. These Bills propose to impose an up-front duty payable on all goods, the subject of a duty notice issued upon a positive preliminary finding. The importer can then have his or her actual duty liability assessed by the Minister at a later stage with a possibility of having any excess, up-front duty, repaid.

The details of the major initiatives proposed in these two Bills are as follows: to provide a mechanism whereby an interim duty will be imposed on each importation of goods subject to anti-dumping or countervailing measures; to introduce a requirement that unless information is provided in confidence a dumping duty notice or countervailing duty notice must show the normal value, export price and non-injurious price of the goods. In the case of countervailing duties, this will include any financial assistance by way of subsidy or bounty, and the non-injurious price of goods of that kind. Subsequent adjustments are calculated on each consignment of goods imported in the six-months period or, alternatively, the importer can ask for a review and substitution of another rate of duty 12 months after the last duty notice or ministerial review.

Clark Equipment Australia Pty Ltd, currently the sole producers of fork-lifts of 1.7 and five tonnes lifting capacity, has raised two concerns with us in this area. Firstly, it feels that interim duties must be assessed on each consignment and not on a random basis. Apparently this has been happening quite frequently in recent times. I will be seeking an assurance from the responsible Minister that this practice will cease and that each consignment will be properly assessed.

Secondly, Clark Equipment has advised that the current sections 269 TAB(1)(b) and 269 TAA(4) do not prohibit sales dumping by interlocking companies which have franchise or distributor agreements, and that such arrangements, in its view, should be brought within the definition of associates, which is the term used in the legislation. We thoroughly agree with that statement. Once again I ask the responsible Minister to address this question in the committee stage and to advise whether he is prepared to examine the best way to bring such franchise or distributor agreements within the definition of business associates.

I now turn to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The Bill proposes to enact a range of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Many of the proposed amendments are non-contentious. It is proposed to remove import duties from aquarium aerators, transmission shafts and cranks for outboard motors, and master recording blanks; to reduce the customs duty on aviation gasoline; to increase the duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by $5 per kilogram; and to revoke the customs component of duty on imported beer so that imported beer will attract the same rate of excise as locally brewed beer. I do not know what the local beer brewing industry has to say about that proposed amendment, but at this stage we have not had any reaction to it.

There are some measures designed to increase the competitiveness of Australian industry, and they are certainly welcome. One of them is to assist local footwear manufacturers by removing quota restrictions from certain parts of footwear, reducing the tariff rate from 32 per cent to 10 per cent, and accelerating the phasing out of preference for goods from Hong Kong, the Republic of Korea, Singapore and Taiwan. Certainly it will be welcomed that the hard-pressed footwear industry in Australia will get this benefit of a reduced duty on parts that it has to import. The other measure also is long overdue. It is hardly sensible to give preference to highly mechanised manufacturing economies such as Hong Kong, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan.

Another measure is to provide new duty free concessions for goods used in the food packaging industry which have a demonstrable performance advantage over similar goods now available in Australia. The third measure is to give effect to the Government's overseas assembly provisions scheme by allowing designated manufacturers to export Australian made textile parts and to re-import the exported parts duty free in made up articles with tariff on the value added. This is a novel initiative. While at first glance it looks as though we are exporting jobs, it must be realised that the alternative in most of these cases probably would be for the manufacturer to go totally offshore with the manufacturing set-up.

In discussions with the TCF union, we have been advised that the union is prepared to go along with this proposal, provided that the Government continues to be prepared to involve the union in the development of the management plan and on the basis of an impact plan on Australian employment in all of these matters.

There is one aspect of the management plans on which I wish particularly to comment. The code of conduct—which the Government should accept but as yet has not—would take into account the wages and working conditions, the human rights situation, and what I call the exploitation index prevalent in countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines and China where some of these agreements are going to be implemented. Clearly we must make sure that we do not profit by the repression and exploitation of other human beings. I believe we should press for working conditions to be lifted to the standards we enforce in Australia rather than to use and exploit human beings in other countries.

The most contentious amendments in this Bill are contained in schedule 6. These amendments give effect to the Government's announcement made in March 1991 to abolish quota arrangements for TCF goods from 1 March 1993. Goods previously subject to quota will now be subject to ad valorem rates of duty. This is an initiative from the Government which the Democrats strongly oppose. It is crazy for us to be removing quota restrictions when just about every other country in the world with any TCF industry of note has such protection in place. The reason is easily found, and I will quote yet again, as I did earlier today, from the information we have on the wages paid in China where the wage for a six-day, 48-hour week in a textile factory is less than $20.

Clearly, we cannot hope to compete. Clearly, we cannot hope to introduce effective tariff barriers to ensure that what is left of our TCF industry remains as a base from which we can build up an internationally competitive industry. What we must do, in the Democrats's view, is retain some quantitative restrictions.

I initiated a hearing on the legislation by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. In evidence before that Committee, Mr Trumble, the President of the TCF Council and the man who brought back the figures about the wages in Chinese factories, stated again that if we take the projected figure for next year into account we are looking at an industry that has lost more than half of the people it employed only a couple of years ago. It did employ approximately 120,000 people. The latest figure we have, for March 1992, is 76,000. The prediction is that by March 1993, which is only about three months away, the figure will be 55,000 or lower. The latest drop is very much a direct result of the measures proposed in this Bill.

We can easily see what is happening. In March 1992 the value of imports from developing countries, principally China, went up by 23 per cent for a value increase of 31 per cent. Next March, when the tariff rates drop a further four points, the flood of imports coming into this country from China will have the potential, as they did in New Zealand, to wipe out the local industry for the ensuing 12 months. It is almost impossible now to book a container out of a port in South East Asia to arrive in Australia before 1 March. If that is not a flood of imports—which Senator Button, the responsible Minister, continues to deny—I do not know what is.

There are other areas to which we should turn our attention. One of the demands that we should make is the liberalisation of trade barriers imposed by other countries. The multifibre arrangements adopted by other OECD countries will not be dismantled by them in anything under 10 years. The United States is now suggesting 15 years, and that is at the completion of the current Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations.

A National Institute of Economic and Industry Research report estimates that between 1988-89 and 1990-91 TCF protection policy changes have been responsible for 9,600 direct job losses, or 44 per cent of the 22,000 direct TCF jobs lost in that period. That report is now somewhat dated but, as we have seen from the other figures, the trend has continued and accelerated.

The Democrats will be moving amendments to stop the removal of quota restrictions and tariff cuts. All of these matters have been put on record during hearings of the Senate inquiry into tariffs which I initiated. I wonder whether the measures that Dr Hewson has foreshadowed, and which will be announced this Friday, will include some of the measures that are clearly demanded by the community, by industry and by unemployed people to take account of the recession. It is all very well to say that we must have more efficient industries and that we will achieve that objective by cutting tariffs. When these plans were laid we did not count on the current recession lasting as long as it has, nor on it being as deep as it is.

The Democrat amendments aim to leave in place quota controls and remove the tariff reduction program for the period 1 March 1993 to 1 July 2000 on the textiles and clothing contained in schedule 6. These amendments affect only the textiles and clothing listed in schedule 6 of this Bill. Further amendments would be needed to cover all items of the textiles and clothing which fall under the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Those changes are not part of our amendments this time.

I wish to advert briefly to one additional amendment, and that is the Government amendment following an announcement by Senator Button on 11 November 1992 that the Government would provide concessional entry for imported baby marche shoes needed in their early years by children who suffer from spina bifida. The amendment goes further than this announcement, as it proposes to allow non-profit organisations and individuals with disabilities to import free of duty aids and appliances which assist with their disabilities. The Australian Democrats welcome these measures. They follow a successful Democrat amendment moved about 18 months ago to remove customs duty from wheelchairs and other aids. We believe that the reduction of tariffs in those cases is certainly more than justified.

I repeat that it is necessary to review Australia's protection policy. I trust that we can look forward to some loosening of the zero tariff policy enunciated by Dr Hewson in the first edition of Fightback. Who knows, this might force Mr Keating to follow suit. We might yet have some hope to save our industrial base and to regain some of the jobs which are now on the scrap heap.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Legislation Amendment Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No.2) and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No.2) introduce some of the reforms to our anti-dumping system announced last December. They are in response to inquiries into our anti-dumping and countervailing laws, including the Senate inquiry which reported last June and which I initiated after reports of huge amounts of imported food flooding our markets.

PARA.TAB: The Senate inquiry made many recommendations, which the Government has introduced into our laws over the last 18 months. They include a lessening of inquiry times from 55 to 25 days for establishing a prima facie case, 100 days for Customs to reach a preliminary finding when interim duties can be imposed, and a further 120 days for the Anti-Dumping Authority to review and reach a final finding.

The final decision on whether to impose final duties is made by the Minister. The period for the Minister to reach his decision is open-ended, sometimes amounting to months before final duties are imposed and proven damaged to the Australian industry is remedied. This is an area that the Government should look into, as damage can continue to be done to the Australian industry during this delay.

These Bills introduce the concept of interim duties based on the difference between the normal value and the determined export price. Any excess duty can be repaid after six months. Review of interim duties on future shipments can only be made 12 months or more after the interim duty has been imposed or last reviewed.

The Senate inquiry, and others by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, all indicated that Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing laws had to be tightened up. The coalition will introduce even tougher anti-dumping laws. A prima facie case will be determined within five days, a preliminary finding made within 60 days, and a final decision within 90 days and 150 days, compared with the present 245 days.

Most importantly, coalition policy does not require the same decimation of local industry to establish material injury. There are still many difficulties encountered in our anti-dumping system. Two weeks ago there was the extraordinary negative finding by the Australian Customs Service on pork imported from Canada. Feed accounts for 70 per cent of the cost of producing a pig. Canadian producers get a 49 per cent subsidy on barley and a 26 per cent subsidy on corn. Despite that, Customs refused to accept that anti-dumping or countervailing duties needed to be imposed. It found a 2 per cent market share gain by Canadian frozen pork, a dumping margin of 2c per kilo and a subsidy of a few cents per kilo.

Then, as Senator Spindler has mentioned, there is the extraordinary saga of the fork-lift dumping case that has been running for more than five years. Customs has overridden court decisions and its own legal advice; the importers have even been given the choice of the exchange rate to be used. All in all, the decision has reduced duties from $3,800 to $900 a unit.

The world recession has seen the increased entry to Australia of subsidised and dumped products. There are many instances of goods kept out of the massive US and EC markets by high retaliatory tariffs. These goods are often redirected to the available and waiting Australian markets. There are also situations where certain imports are targeted at Australian products with the intention of killing off the Australian competitor. There are still a great many problems in the anti-dumping and countervailing system. Legislative changes have not addressed the unfair trading practices—an environment that Australian industries have had to face against dumped and subsidised imports. These take many forms, and I shall mention some across a range of products.

There is the recent case which was brought against Canadian pork, whose producers benefited from high feed subsidies, as I have mentioned, and there were 20 other subsidies on that Canadian pork. Already there is a level of subsidisation that Australian producers do not receive and cannot compete against.

The recent pork case is instructive. The pork industry showed the usual independence and resourcefulness of an Australian rural producer and funded its own case from its own resources. The case for the Canadians was funded by the Canadian Federal and provincial governments. Against the might of Canadian treasuries was the farmer fighting alone and unfunded to save the industry. Canadian imports began in August 1990. By the first six months of this year, pig prices were down by 25 per cent and producers were losing $20 a pig. The industry was facing its worst crisis for 20 years. Productive capacity was being permanently lost to the industry from high numbers of producers being forced out.

The way dumped and subsidised imports hit Australian industry can be illustrated by the pork industry experience. By mid-year, processors normally start stockpiling products to prepare for Christmas demand. This puts a floor under the prices. But this year they did not start storing because they knew they could use cheap imports at any time to meet the demand. Also, as they did not know how low the imports would force the local price, they did not want to get caught with stock on hand. The availability of imports drove prices down and at the same time out of all proportion to the quantities that have come in.

Subsidised products have brought Australian industries and companies to crisis point. Large international companies and governments are able to employ all sorts of techniques to disguise their dumping practices. In the pork case, subsidies reduced the normal price so the difference between the normal and export price was less than it would have been in the absence of subsidisation. As with the fork-lifts, large international companies can manipulate transactions between their overseas manufacturing company and their local representatives. They can practise dumping where the full costs of the sale are not reflected in the selling price in Australia. Nissan, in the face of a dumping notice against a Japanese trading house, has reverted to exporting trucks direct rather than through the trading house specified in the dumping notice, thereby avoiding the dumping duties altogether. Customs apparently has been aware of this alteration for months but has done nothing about it.

The Minister in December 1989 instructed Customs to monitor the importation of fork-lift trucks within the various product lines to ensure that the intention of the controls was not circumvented by the importation of the particular model and its subsequent sale with another category rating. To date, despite much documented evidence, Customs has failed to make one wharf inspection or follow up the supplied information—and I hope Senator Cook, if he is going to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button is, I think.
—I hope that he is listening.
—I am sure he will be well advised.

—I thank the Minister. In the fork-lift and pork cases, Customs did not invite further submissions on its changed direction, which has had the effect of reducing duties further. It issued the decision before it received a reply from the industry. Australian industries have to ask what more they can do to continue operating against the onslaught from dumped and subsidised products and against the way our anti-dumping system is administered. They spend their own resources on expensive and lengthy anti-dumping and countervailing actions without any government financial assistance such as their opponents receive. They take matters to the Federal Court at great expense. They assist and cooperate with Customs. They look for concessional by-laws against dumped components not made in Australia and find that they do not exist. They want to keep going employing Australian workers, developing their Australian industries and supporting other Australian component industries. Australian customers want to keep buying from them, but they are being blown out of the water by world surpluses of dumped and subsidised manufactured products finding easy entry into this country.

PARA.TAB: All industries across the board are being affected. Many multi-million dollar operations are close to closing their Australian operations because of the damage being done by dumped imports. Vitally needed business investment is not taking place because of the uncertainty caused by dumped competition. Viable industries are on their knees after losing obvious anti-dumping cases. Even when a lengthy and extremely costly case is won, the industry is subject to overseas government-funded appeals in our court—and I hope Senator Button is listening to this. This can be aided and abetted by Australian retail chains with their dominant position in the marketplace. The same big grocery chains promoting themselves with `Buy Australian' campaigns are at the same time importing and bringing action against successful anti-dumping actions, as is occurring at present in the tomato industry.

It is hoped that the reforms in this Bill will address some of the current problems in the system. However, the operation of our anti-dumping and countervailing laws is at the heart of the current major difficulties for Australian industry. The Government must be getting the same feedback from industry that I am getting—that our anti-dumping system is not creating a fair result for Australian manufacturers when faced by the many dumping practices adopted for imported products. The Minister's response when approached by suffering industries has been to give assurances that the offending practices will be monitored by Customs.

I urge the Minister to ensure that these assurances are followed through. It is only when we start to go into all the industries which are being severely affected by dumped imports that the scope and extent of the damage being inflicted on Australian industry becomes obvious. I support these Bills but urge the Government to take very seriously the irreparable damage being done to otherwise viable Australian industries by Australia being a soft destination for dumped and subsidised imports.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council

That the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council be authorised to continue to sit during the sitting of the Senate until midnight this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly to the Bills before us tonight and to confine my comments to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, particularly to the amendments proposed by Senator Spindler relating to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. Senator Spindler moved two amendments to schedule 6 of the Bill. The first amendment would have removed the proposed tariff reduction program for TCF products for the period 1 July 1994 to 1 July 2000 inclusive so that the tariff levels proposed by the Bill to come into effect on 1 March 1993 would remain at that level until amended.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment would leave in place the out-of-quota controls on textiles, clothing and footwear which the Bill proposes to abolish. Neither of these amendments were supported by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on 13 November 1992. The meeting of that Committee, which I attended along with Senator Button, Senator Spindler and representatives from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia, was extremely interesting. I would like to share with honourable senators some of the major points that emerged from this meeting.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being put 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has already mentioned that Mr Alan Trumble, the President of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia, was present at that meeting. He also mentioned that Mr Trumble had said that in the 1980s the industry employed 120,000 people, and that as at March 1992 this had dropped to 76,000 people. Of course, what Senator Spindler did not tell us was that all of this drop in employment occurred while the quotas were in place and the tariffs were at their previously high levels.

PARA.TAB: The TCF Council said that, after March 1993 when the industry quotas cease to exist, employment in the industry will fall to 55,000. Mr Trumble stated that the reason for this dramatic drop is that the industry is trying to compete with Third World countries such as China, where the rate of pay for a 46-hour, six-day week is the equivalent of $A20. It is obvious that the TCF industry is labour intensive. The major reason why developing countries are so competitive is that they can supply labour at a much lower cost. Under our wage structure in Australia we can never compete with countries such as China. As Mr Trumble said, even if we get 5 per cent efficiency improvement per year, there is no hope for us to compete on that basis.

The TCF Council is calling for the immediate introduction of import controls to safeguard the current market share for the local industry until an economic recovery is well under way. That is, it wants bilateral voluntary restraints in the form of quotas negotiated with developing countries. The Council is after quotas, not tariffs because, rather than relying on tariff protection to raise the price of imported T-shirts, the Council would prefer to limit the number of imported T-shirts sold in Australia.

The question I asked at the Committee meeting was whether the TCF Council wanted us to make a special exemption for the TCF industry over and above all other industries in Australia. The answer I received was yes. Senator Button at that hearing did not support this request from the industry. In fact, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what you are suggesting here is that this industry should have a totally different treatment from every other industry in Australia by having quotas or high tariffs. I have to say that my answer to that is no; that cannot be so.

Senator Spindler supported the Council by saying that tariffs are useful in competing against other OECD countries, but against developing countries there is a need to have quotas. He then asked the TCF Council representatives whether the Australian TCF industry would be competitive with world standards, provided that there were no barriers in other countries and that they would not be asking for assistance if the Government were successful in getting other countries to remove their barriers. Mr Kreitals of the Council said yes, but he then said:

Perhaps that needs some qualification. It strikes me as being a little too broad. If we take the prime developing country, China, unless we have quantitative restraint against China—on which it may say, `We have nothing against you'—we will not survive against that sort of situation because of the wage differential.

This does not appear to make sense to me. It would appear from the evidence before the Committee that in our textiles, clothing and footwear industry we can compete against other developed nations, but that we will never be competitive against developing nations. Surely that is the point: why are we trying to compete against countries such as China, Korea and Taiwan? The only way to compete against developing countries is to place quotas on their exports to Australia. However, I think that is going down the wrong track.

PARA.TAB: Australia cannot single out countries such as China for quota restrictions. Either we have restrictions for everybody or we have them against nobody. The whole tenor of what the Council was saying was extremely pessimistic. As Senator Button said during that hearing, one would think there were no successful TCF businesses in Australia any more. But that simply is not the case. There are successful TCF businesses and they are the ones that produce high quality goods. However, there seemed to be some reluctance on behalf of the Council to admit that high quality was the way to go.

The Council stated that it was dependent on Australia's clothing industry. This is a very narrow view. We cannot have a prospering TCF industry based on 17 million people unless it is heavily protected. The obvious answer is to export high quality goods. Furthermore, when I asked Mr Trumble from the Council for his reaction to people who say that the future of the industry lies in producing and exporting these high quality, well-designed goods requiring highly skilled workers, he replied that most of those exports were going to developed countries, which would indicate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that we can have a competitive industry when needs be and that our cost structure is not obviously out of line in those areas.

What does he mean by `when needs be'? Does this mean that the TCF industry is competitive only when it feels it needs to be? If the industry can feel the need to be competitive some of the time, why can it not feel the need all of the time? I am sure that the majority of the Australian public would be concerned, if not horrified, by this statement. Why should the taxpayer prop up an uncompetitive TCF business?

PARA.TAB: Another argument put forward by the TCF Council against abolishing quotas was that it believes thousands of jobs would be lost. Surely it has not escaped the Council's attention that the major loss of employment in the TCF industry from 120,000 in the late 1980s to 76,000 in March 1992 occurred while the industry received substantial assistance through tariffs and quotas. This loss of employment also occurred against the background of an economic recession. Who is to say that there is not going to be a further drop in employment, even if protection were to remain as it was during the 1980s? In fact, Senator Button said at this hearing:

SPEECH.PARA: What I distrust most is the empty promise. I regard it as a totally empty promise that, if you had a stop in the tariff cuts and quotas for this industry, there would be no more closures . . .

Putting all this together, the bottom line appears to be that the TCF industry not only wants all international barriers to trade withdrawn but at the same time to reduce the amount of imports from developing countries. No other Australian industry has this form of protection, so why should the TCF industry have it?

PARA.TAB: Australia is good at producing many products, but we are unable to produce all our requirements. We should import those products that we are unable to produce or that we are not good at producing. If that means that our textiles, clothing and footwear industry switches to producing high quality goods which we can export to wealthier developed countries, that is what we should do. If it means that we import cheap T-shirts from developing countries, so be it. The Opposition supports the Government in abolishing quotas for the TCF industry under the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to this debate for their warm support of this Customs legislation. I just want to make a couple of comments. First, I refer Senator Spindler to appendix 1 in the annual report of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, which was tabled in the Senate yesterday, and in particular to the import penetration ratios of textiles, clothing and footwear into Australia contained in table 9 on page 25. In 1986-87, the import penetration ratio for textiles was 56.9 per cent. In 1991-92, it was 54.3 per cent. In respect of clothing and footwear together, the ratio was 20.4 per cent in 1986-87, 25 per cent in 1990-91 and 27.7 per cent in 1991-92. There were four significant changes to the protection regime.

PARA.TAB: The 1991-92 figures show that the import penetration ratio for clothing and footwear is 27.7 per cent. For all other manufacturing, it is 31.1 per cent. Senator Ferguson wondered why this industry is singled out for special attention when it has that relatively low import penetration ratio in clothing and footwear. The textile import ratio has always been quite high—about 50 per cent—because we do not produce certain textiles in Australia or textiles of certain qualities and so on. The whole argument really turns on that sort of information.

On page 27 of the same report, there is a table showing wage and salary earners in these industries. According to the ABS figures produced here, the 1991-92 figure of 80,000 has come down from a high in 1986-87 of 108,000. That is no different from other industries. The figure for total manufacturing in the same period has gone from 1.04 million to 908,000. So the fall in TCF as a percentage of manufacturing decline in employment is 8.8 per cent. I commend Senator Spindler to a reading of some of these figures. Policy has to be made on the basis of facts and not on allegations made by particular vested interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bankruptcies and closures of factories.
—Senator Spindler told me once—it is no secret because he told the Senate—that he had been to a couple of towns in rural Victoria.
—Six of them, not a couple.

—All right, six. He said that there had been some factory closures in those towns. That is true and that is difficult, but nothing he advocates will stop that problem. What worries me about Senator Spindler's views on these matters is that he is going around holding out false promises and false hopes to people as a populist thing, which will not get anybody anywhere. Senator Spindler will presumably move his amendments in the committee stage of this legislation and we will oppose them. Let us be clear about that. But I warn him now that he will have to do it with a better factual argument than he has put in this debate to date. It is sometimes said that there is a lot of theatre in politics. But one cannot resort to theatre of the absurd when policy making. That is what I am afraid is happening here.

PARA.TAB: Senator Archer, in his contribution to the debate, said that he wants a preliminary finding on dumping in five days. That is not possible. It does not happen anywhere in the world. It is contrary to GATT. I know that it is Opposition policy in Fightback, but it is quite clear amongst those in the Opposition who have thought about it—when we last dealt with this matter I had a discussion with Senator Short about it—that that is quite an impossible proposition. It is warm and comforting, but it is quite impossible.

Senator Archer realises that, if a dumping complaint is to be proved, one has to establish normal values in the country of origin. If he thinks that that sort of thing can be done in five days, I assure him that it is not practical. These sorts of things sound nice, but they have nothing to do with the realities of this legislation.

The legislation puts some additional disciplines into the anti-dumping legislation such as a number of other countries have. We have about the fastest anti-dumping legislation in the world. We have a number of disciplines introduced into it by this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many years?
—It is not about years. That is old stuff.
—Pork. That is old stuff?

—Senator Archer says pork. Ultimately, because of the failure to lodge anti-dumping complaints, we, through Customs, had to put enormous effort into helping the industry to make a complaint. That was done. Customs is prepared to do that on certain occasions. The proposed suggestion does not quite accord with the facts.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing more to be said until the committee stage when we will get to grips with the realities of some of these amendments. Senator Spindler has a machinery amendment on which I do not yet have a view. I do not know whether Customs will like it; I have not talked to Customs. The Democrats have other major amendments which we will look at during the committee stages of the Bills. But, as I said, we will not be supporting them. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the second reading debate. I wish the Bills a speedy passage from here on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:

That consideration of the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1992, Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Consideration resumed from 10 December 1992.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments and new clauses to be moved to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clauses:

PARA.TAB: "3A. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after paragraph (b) the following paragraph:
`(ba)to facilitate access to conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and prompt settlement of industrial disputes; and'.
"3B. Section 111 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a)by omitting from subparagraph (l)(g)(ii) `industrial authority' and substituting `arbitrator';
(b)by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsections:

`(1A) Subparagraph (l)(g)(iii) does not apply to proceedings so far as they may affect terms and conditions of employment of a particular kind that are applicable to a particular class of employees, if:

(a)at any time after 7 December 1992, terms and conditions of that kind and application have been regulated by an order, award, decision or determination of a State industrial authority (whether made before, on or after that date); and
(b)terms and conditions of that kind and application:

TAB.TAB: (i)cannot be dealt with by a State arbitrator by compulsory arbitration (but not merely because an order, award, decision or determination of a State arbitrator cannot be changed during a particular period); and
(ii)are not regulated by an employment agreement; and
(iii)are not regulated by an award under this Act.

PARA.TAB: In this subsection:
"employment agreement" means an agreement that:
(a)was entered into under a State law; and

(b)regulates terms and conditions of employment of a particular kind and application that, if the agreement had not been entered into, could have been regulated by a State arbitrator by compulsory arbitration; and
(c)prevails over any inconsistent order, award, decision or determination of a State industrial authority; and
(d)during a particular period, but only during that period, prevents terms and conditions of that kind and application from being regulated by a State arbitrator by compulsory arbitration.

SPEECH.PARA: `(lB) The Commission must not make an award (other than an interim or provisional award) under subsection (1) regulating terms and conditions of employment of a kind and application to which subsection (1A) applies unless at least one organisation of employees that is a party to the dispute to which the award would relate:

PARA.TAB: (a)has taken reasonable steps to consult employees who would be affected by the award on the question whether they wish the terms and conditions to be regulated by an award under this Act; and
(b)has informed the Commission of the outcome of such consultations.';
(c)by adding at the end the following subsection:
'(4) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "compulsory arbitration" means the power to regulate terms and conditions of employment by arbitration:

PARA.TAB: (a)without the agreement of some or all of the employers and employees who would be affected by the arbitration (or their representative bodies); and
(b)whether after exhausting alternative means of settlement or otherwise;

SPEECH.PARA: "State arbitrator" means a State industrial authority that has, or at the relevant time had, the power, or powers that include the power, to regulate terms and conditions of employment by compulsory arbitration.'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to be moved by the Government were considered by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs at a hearing on Monday. One reason for referring this matter to the Committee is that it was apparent that these amendments, if enacted, would enable union bosses to transfer from the State to the Federal jurisdiction where there is not a system of compulsory arbitration in the State. It was also apparent that this legislation was squarely aimed at Victoria. In fact, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) said so in either his second reading speech or the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: This legislation has been a shambles from beginning to end. It was cobbled together after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a statement in respect of the Victorian legislation. That is reflected in the fact that we were given amendments very indirectly earlier last week and given some 24 hours to look at them. Even subsequently since those amendments were put forward, another set of amendments has been tabled here in the Senate today. They were cobbled together in haste for no other reason but to appease union mates.

The original amendments would have had unintended consequences in New South Wales and would have caught enterprise agreements in New South Wales with up to a three-year lifespan. Those enterprise agreements are put together in New South Wales in such a way that they vary from some 18 months to three years. During that period the agreements remain intact and can be varied only with the agreement of both the employers and employees. The amendments as introduced last week by Senator Cook would have caught those New South Wales enterprise agreements. New South Wales itself has a system of arbitration and yet within that period the agreements cannot be altered.

As I understand it, the new amendments enable the enterprise agreements in New South Wales to run their course without the threat of Federal interference. I ask the Minister: is it not a fact that the sole purpose of these amendments is nothing more or less than a sop to the union movement for transparent Labor political purposes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer has made three distinct statements. All of them are wrong. The first statement was that this is to appease union bosses to transfer from Victorian to federal jurisdiction. That is not right. Anyone who reads the amendments can see that any party to a State award can apply under the Victorian system as it now exists, but which is soon to be changed.

PARA.TAB: It is possible to foresee a situation in which a union may well want to access the direct bargaining features of the Victorian legislation, or in any other State where similar legislation is enacted in a way that makes life for an employer uncomfortable. That employer might wish to apply to a State industrial relations commission but be vetoed by a union in getting access to that commission and thus be forced to deal with the union and its ability to apply its particular brand of pressure in the field.

The Commonwealth regards that set of circumstances, should it obtain, as not desirable and that employers should have the right to apply to the Federal Commission to transfer the award. Similarly, it is possible to contemplate that the boot could be on the other foot and a union may wish to apply. This legislation requires that, should either party wish to apply, there has to be some satisfaction by the Federal Commission that it is the employees' choice to make the application where it be a union and that they support that. That means that there is a clear choice.

This legislation confers a clear choice on any State that wishes to abolish its system of compulsory arbitration. If Victoria be an example, that choice is to choose the Victorian system as proposed by the Kennett Government, or the system of compulsory arbitration that has served this country well for over 80-odd years. That is the plain explanation.

This is a contentious issue. People will say political things to score political points. Whatever they say cannot change the fact that that is what the legislation does. Whatever point scoring is entered into, it will not change the fact that we are offering a right wherever a State removes the right to compulsory arbitration.

The second statement which has been made and which is wrong is that this is aimed squarely at Victoria. It is not. This is national or Federal legislation, whichever way one wishes to style it. It will apply anywhere in this country where compulsory arbitration has been removed.

The third statement that has been made is that it was cobbled together in haste. It is true that this was done quickly. There is a difference between deft quickness and undue haste. This legislation has been discussed at the National Labor Consultative Council with the industrial partners, the employers and the unions. Their views have been taken on board and some changes in the original draft have been made to reflect those views.

This legislation has been discussed at a Senate hearing; it has been referred to the States for comment and two of the States have made comments. In the case of the State of New South Wales, we have made some adjustments to the legislation to reflect a concern that that State raised—and which we regard as a fair enough concern—and that is now accommodated.

This could be styled as haste if one wishes to be unkind. I would style it as proper, responsible government, sensible consultation, a preparedness by the Government to make the necessary changes to reflect the proper concerns of the parties and a strengthening of the intent of the Government as proclaimed in the remarks that I have made on previous occasions.

What we have before the chamber now is the outcome—albeit within a short time—which has observed the necessary courtesies of consultation, exposure, accommodation, redrafting and presentation in a more final form to the Senate. The hallmark of this Government is to engage in that process. The process was not one that was engaged in—if one cites the State of Victoria—vis-a-vis people covered by Federal awards in the Federal jurisdiction when that State Government enacted State laws which in our contention affect the rights of those people under Federal laws. However, this is not a matter on which we simply wish to engage in a political debate to score points. They are the clear facts of the matter and I commend the legislation to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to say that I support the Bill and the amendments moved by the Government. While I appreciate that this is Federal legislation, it is true to say that many people in Victoria will benefit most immediately from the options which this provides. It provides real choices as opposed to the sorts of choices put forward by the Opposition as being the hallmark of its industrial relations policy—that is, no choice for people in powerless positions.

PARA.TAB: In my speech during the second reading debate I strongly made the point that, because of the nature of the industrial relations system in Victoria, women have been clustered in the State award system. This system was only recently established—the State having had wages boards until relatively recently by comparison with other States.

What we are seeing in Victoria, from the reports coming from the relevant unions, is an increase in interest in union membership by women following the Victorian Government legislation. This will mean that they will find their industrial arms strengthened and may well indeed wish to make the choice to move to Federal awards. All this legislation does is provide them with the opportunity to do so, and it is an opportunity which I welcome and support.

I do want to say that in my remarks during the second reading debate on this amendment I relied heavily in some parts of my speech on an article from the Age of 13 November this year by Jan Pearce. I neglected to acknowledge that at the time and I wish to do so now. I do not like to use other people's material without acknowledging it.

I simply reiterate the point I made on second reading that, for the women of Victoria in particular and for those who are still disadvantaged in the workplace, this legislation, and these amendments in particular, will provide real choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which had this legislation referred to it for discussion last Monday. I know it is becoming an ever popular recourse for the Senate to refer legislation to standing committees for report back. In my view, 90 per cent of the time of the Committee last Monday was a waste of time. Not one senator turned up with any view to a change of mind after hearing the comments put before the Committee by the people represented.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer turned up representing the shadow Minister for industrial relations. From the very beginning, he was putting one view before he had even heard all the evidence. I turned up with a view I was going to put as a member of the Government. Senator Kemp did the same. Senator Spindler did the same. He tabled the amendment on which he had reached agreement with the Government. That was the only business that seemed to be relevant. I do not know why we had to spend five hours debating that amendment when most of us spent all the time trying to make debating points against each other on wider philosophical and political issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very good amendment.

—I believe the amendment worked out between the Democrats and Senator Cook on behalf of the Government is quite a reasonable amendment and has a proper balance within the practicalities of the industrial scene in Australia. Who did we find were asked to come along and give evidence? All the usual suspects in the industrial relations scene.
—The ACTU.

—Yes. Representatives of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the ACTU, the Department of Industrial Relations, the New South Wales State Government, the Victorian State Government and Solicitors-General giving their opinions about the evils of State rights being affected by Commonwealth legislation. We also had representatives from a group I had not met before called the Brethren. I think they may have come to the wrong meeting. The views they expressed seemed to have more to do with their version of christianity. I respect their right to hold their view, but it seemed to have very little to do with the legislation before us. But they used that opportunity to put their view. At times, I thought some of their remarks were rather ill-considered when they described our Asian neighbours in the region as `dark pagan countries'. I really do not think that is a suitable remark to be made in the last decade of the twentieth century.

PARA.TAB: So we went through the charade of the hearing. No-one changed their view. I admit I did not change my view. Senator Kemp did not change his view. Senator Parer did not change his view. Senator Vanstone did not change her view. In my view, we wasted five hours of the Committee's time. As more and more legislation such as this is being referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I want to plead for a bit of relief for that Committee and for some of these Bills to be referred to other committees and not to ours. We seem to be copping a disproportionate amount of them. They affect the much more constructive work the Committee can do in its inquiries into specific terms of reference where we can often achieve bipartisan recommendations on broader issues because they are properly conducted inquiries away from the heat emanating from political debates on issues out of this chamber.

Above all else, it is the remarks made by Professor Greg Craven representing the Victorian Government that have prompted me to speak in this debate. I understand Professor Craven is a newly appointed consultant to the Kennett Government to advise on this sort of legislation and other changes in legislation in Victoria. I respect the right of any government to employ outside consultants. I certainly have no objection to the Victorian Government employing Professor Craven. He is clearly an ideological soul mate of the Kennett regime in Victoria. He has certainly written previously on a whole range of issues, particularly concerning State rights. His view on State rights is in about 1856 in support of the colonies. If he had been alive in 1891 or 1896 he would have been opposing the Federation as affecting State rights. That is his view. But the most astonishing remark he made is in the Hansard at page 95:

I think the great virtue of federalism is that it divides and balances power. Some people say that there are no human rights in the Australian Constitution; the great human right in the Australian Constitution is in fact the Federal system of government.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a most extraordinary statement. Over the last 20 years the States have dragged their feet to stop Federal governments—Labor and Liberal—from signing the international civil and political covenants and the various protocols. I do not excuse some State Labor governments for being just as tardy as State Liberal governments in delaying the signing of these protocols. Delaying the signing of those protocols has meant that Australia is not up to the mark in its human rights obligations. The reason Australia is not up to the mark is that State governments have used the State rights power that Professor Craven is so keen on to stop the accession of those accords and the ratification of those conventions.

PARA.TAB: Professor Craven has the temerity to say that the Federal system has guaranteed human rights. That is an absolute joke. For example, up until the last decade nothing in the Federal system guaranteed one vote one value as a right for people in Australia to vote. State rights were used consistently to put down the right that all people are equal and should have equal rights to vote in elections.

I never saw Professor Craven marching in the streets of Brisbane against the gerrymander under Joh Bjelke-Petersen. When Joh Bjelke-Petersen was rorting the appointments to the State Supreme Court some years ago, when the most disgraceful interference into the appointments in the State Supreme Court in Queensland was going on, what did Professor Craven—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: we are debating the amendments to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I know that in second reading speeches honourable senators do range fairly widely, but tonight Senator Schacht is talking about human rights and marching in the streets of Brisbane. What relevance that has to the amendments to the industrial relations Bill is beyond me.
—On the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Aulich)—You probably do not need to speak on the point of order because I cannot uphold it. Senator Parer will recall that part 3A(ba) of the Government's amendments does in fact talk about conciliation and arbitration procedures for the prevention and prompt settlement of industrial disputes. At the moment Senator Schacht is in order, and of course he would not want to stray too far at this stage, given that the legislation is in committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that guidance, Mr Temporary Chairman. These were the matters that were raised after the second reading had been debated in the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when we had these amendments before us. No-one ruled them out of order then.

PARA.TAB: I find it hypocritical of people such as Professor Craven to talk about human rights and claim that federalism is the greatest protection of human rights. In my view, over the last half century in this country State rights have done more to restrict human rights than any other single concept. I look forward to seeing Professor Craven supporting the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade, which said that in a number of cases we ought to accede to various conventions—including ILO conventions which are mentioned in the legislation. So I find it extraordinary that Professor Craven would make such remarks.

Professor Craven quoted Alfred Deakin as being the oracle of all his knowledge on federalism and where it is going.
