He failed to mention that Alfred Deakin was a strong supporter of the introduction of the first Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1904. He was also a great supporter of protection, something that I suspect Professor Craven, being one of the new `bovver boys' of the Right in Victoria, totally ideologically opposes. Yet he quoted Alfred Deakin as being the defender of his view of the way that the Constitution should work. Had he been listening to Professor Craven, Alfred Deakin would probably be turning in his grave.

Professor Craven has an extremely limited view about the notion of nationhood in Australia. That ideological, right wing view, characterised by zealotry, would impose a system of government on Australia which would divide Australians and create conflict and division. Rather than having a concept of inclusion in our community where people, whether they are employers or employees, whether they are in Federal, State or local governments, work together, he is driven—and he advises the Kennett Government accordingly—by a narrow States' rights issue which is to the detriment of the well-being of all Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to take issue with a number of comments made by Senator Cook and the view he put that somehow employers would welcome the choice that these amendments might give them. I am not aware of any employer organisation in Victoria which has welcomed these amendments. That was certainly not the view of Mr Noakes and his colleagues who appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook mentioned that he felt there had been sufficient consultation. It is interesting that in the submission that was given to the Committee, the Victorian Government indicated its view that this was the most intrusive exercise of Commonwealth power since World War II. According to the Victorian Government, there are no national emergency circumstances which support or justify this move. The only basis for it is to allow a privileged group, the trade union movement, to flee from a modern industrial relations jurisdiction—one which the democratic expression of a State parliament has set up and which the trade union movement does not like—to the one which preserves and now seeks to extend pre-existing privilege.

In my view, a fair reading of the transcript from the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitution Affairs will clearly show—and we have also heard it from Senator Cook's own mouth—that these amendments were stimulated as a result of the actions of the Kennett Government in relation to its industrial relations mandate. It further shows that there is no other State in this country which will be affected by these amendments. Senator Cook showed that, despite any protestations that he may now make. The transcript is writ large. Undoubtedly, when this Bill is challenged before the High Court, the words of Senator Cook will be very carefully read in this regard.

I was intrigued by some of the comments of Senator Schacht. Senator Schacht is regarded as one—and, Mr Acting Deputy Chairman, you will know this—who has a particular interest in human rights. I do not dispute that this is of particular interest to Senator Schacht. He regularly comes in here and reminds us of his views. All of us welcome a concern for human rights. One of the problems that I have with Senator Schacht is—and I have said this before—that when issues on human rights come into conflict with Labor Party interests, he always comes down on the side of Labor Party interests.

Complex issues are involved here. There is the issue of the Federal principle. I would not demean this country like Senator Schacht did when he came into the Senate and said that Australia was remiss in its human rights records. I do not pretend that we are perfect but, by the standards of human endeavour and by the standards of most countries, Australia has been astonishingly successful. It has an absolutely outstanding record over a very long period in its concern for human rights. It is a pity that a man who is concerned with human rights feels so free to demean his own country in this area.

I also differ from Senator Schacht in that I believe one of the mechanisms that many countries that are democracies have put into place in trying to protect human rights is a mechanism to enable the effective division of power. Along with Professor Craven, I believe that the Federal principle—the Federal Constitution—is one of our protections. It is one of those protections which helps divide power. That is one of the reasons why I strongly support the Federal principle. It is a pity that if people differ with Senator Schacht, who holds himself out to be such a strong advocate of human rights, they are liable to cop the proverbial Labor Party bucket. Many people in the area of human rights would see that the division of power is important. Professor Craven would have much support in thinking that the Federal principle and the division of powers is an important way of protecting human rights.

Another issue which I would have hoped our human rights expert in the chamber would have addressed his mind to is that of democracy. I have heard the views of Senator Cook regarding the Victorian Government's mandate. However, there is no question that the Liberal Party, led by Mr Kennett, went to an election with an industrial relations policy which was spelt out. It was a central feature of the electoral campaign in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they mention abolishing leave loadings in the policy speech?

—Senator Schacht has had his say: can I have mine? The Australian Labor Party ran innumerable advertisements. There was a great deal of shock horror stuff, as one can imagine in an election campaign, warning people about what may happen if a Kennett government were elected. A Kennett government was elected and was able to record the greatest electoral victory in Victoria, certainly since 1907, and arguably in 150 years of Victorian political history. For the thrust of its industrial relations policy the Kennett Government received an overwhelming mandate from the Victorian people.

PARA.TAB: When a government is elected and has a clear mandate, is it entitled to put those policies into effect? I would have thought that the man who talks about human rights in this chamber more than anyone else might have been able to reflect on that issue. I strongly hold the view that the Victorian Government had a very clear mandate to put its policies into effect. However, those policies do conflict with the interests of the trade union movement and, therefore, with the interests of its political arm—the Labor Party. As a consequence we have particular amendments before us.

Again on the human rights issue, one of the interesting features to come out of the hearing of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was that there is no comparative country in the world which insists on compulsory arbitration as one of the great inalienable rights of its industrial relations system. Apparently Australia is unique in this regard. So all those countries which Senator Button, Senator Schacht, Senator Cook and others like to quote to us do not have a system which insists that across the whole economy there be a system of compulsory arbitration, which apparently is so vital in this country that we have to override the Federal principle, which I—in contrast to Senator Schacht—happen to believe is extremely important.

Another matter I wish to raise—I do not agree with this, but I accept that there is an argument for it—is that I am always worried where a country such as ours, a democracy, should make its own laws and those laws should be interpreted in tribunals and courts which reflect the composition and values of the Australian people. I am far less comfortable than Senator Schacht in ceaselessly relying on ILO conventions and other mechanisms. Nonetheless I concede that there is an argument, although I am not comfortable about it. Again I go back to my basic principles that Australia has dealt with this better than most other countries.

I ask the Minister whether he can point to the ILO convention which the Victorian Act appears to transgress. It is an important point because those opposite constantly speak about ILO conventions. It will be interesting to see whether, in the Minister's mind, there is any particular ILO convention which the Victorian Act transgresses. If it does, because it does not see the inalienable right of compulsory arbitration, it would suggest that an awful lot of countries are also outside the ILO convention. Perhaps the Minister, in his future remarks, could turn his mind to and point out the particular conventions which he believes the Victorian Act transgresses. Perhaps he can also indicate whether, if there is not such an Act, it is correct that interpreting the ILO conventions is a matter with which the Commonwealth Government in particular should concern itself or whether, as was put in the submission by the Victorian Government, it is more a matter for the relevant ILO body.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this matter briefly, I repeat and confirm what the Australian Democrats' industrial relations spokesperson, my colleague Senator Bell, has already stated—that is, the Democrats will be supporting the Bill and will be moving an amendment which will provide for the Commission to determine whether there is a need for a secret membership ballot of unions to be conducted when employees seek the protection of a Federal award because in a State in which they happen to reside—at this stage we are dealing with a situation in Victoria—such protection has been withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: However, it is quite clear that the legislation will apply to other States if a State government in Australia chooses to force workers into a position where they have no choice but to accept an enterprise agreement or a one-to-one agreement with an employer without the protection of an award and without the possibility of going to a tribunal to have it adjudicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get your facts straight. It is not compulsory. How about being honest?

—I know that Senator Parer has a hang-up about the word `compulsory'. Actually I think it is a misnomer. If I feel that my rights have been infringed and I want to take the person who has infringed my rights to court, is that called a compulsory court case? No, it is not. I go to seek my rights and the other person has an opportunity to defend his or her position. It simply means that if there is a dispute between two parties, they must have it arbitrated. Senator Parer may call that compulsory, and he may have a hang-up over it.

PARA.TAB: I think it is perfectly reasonable that if there is a disagreement we do not resolve it by fighting in the streets, by industrial action, but that we do it in a civilised manner under the protection of arbitration legislation. When we say that a State government has the right to initiate whatever legislation it chooses, particularly if it claims to have had an electoral mandate—although I suspect that the voters of Victoria never suspected that they would be placed in the sort of position that the Victorian legislation is placing them in—we should not forget that a State is a part of Australia, indeed that Australia is a part of the world, and that there are certain common standards of human behaviour that apply to all.

I turn to the issue of whether other countries have similar legislation which at the behest of one party, employer or employee, enjoins the other party to appear before a tribunal to have a difference arbitrated—the so-called compulsory arbitration. I think we should also consider that most other countries that do not bother to have such legislation have actually a legislated right to strike, which Australia does not have. I think that is a factor that in most cases explains the absence of this particular legislation.

Basically, we have the choice between whether workers should be forced into enterprise or individual agreements without regard to arbitration or awards, and whether we should put up with the instability, the industrial jungle warfare that this will cause and the loss of profits, stability and predictability and, ultimately, the loss of jobs that this will create. Will that happen, or do we want a system that adjudicates the differences that employers and employees may have in a civilised manner and according to law? I would suggest that this is the central question that is at issue. The Australian Democrats come down firmly on the rule of law rather than the rule of the jungle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to comment on some of the remarks made by Senator Schacht. One of the questions he asked by way of interjection to Senator Kemp was whether the people of Victoria were told that they would have voluntary unionism. In the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Senator Cook tabled the document that was a blueprint for the coalition before the election. I think it is worth recounting some of the items in that document. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition will open up new employment opportunities for Victorians by enabling employers and employees to negotiate wages and working conditions that reflect the needs of their business.
I am picking these out. I could quote the whole lot, but in the interests of time I will not. Further on it states:
We will enact laws which deter `wild cat' strikes.

Anyone with any inkling or knowledge of what happens in Victoria—and, of all people, Senator Spindler should know—will know all about the militant union activity in Victoria which has made it the laughing stock not only of Australia but of many parts of the world—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Kennett provoked it.
—That is under the existing system. Senator Spindler is promoting those sorts of people. Further on the coalition statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Victoria will be able to boast again about its commitment to productivity, service to customers, and certainty of delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler might listen to this in case he goes waffling off on some funny tangent which is not in keeping with what the current Victorian Government promised before the last election. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: 1 the primary focus of Industrial Relations will be between the employer and the worker in each enterprise;
How much clearer can one get? It continues:
2 union membership should be voluntary, not compulsory;

That is what has got the back up of these militant union leaders who have run City Hall, if we want to call it that, for the past 10 years, who have helped Mrs Kirner and Mr Cain bring Victoria down from being the leader in manufacturing and financing in this country to a position where it is the basket case of Australia. This Government was elected to fix that. Part of that was the introduction of that policy, part of which I have quoted.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask the Minister a couple of questions. He talks about choice. In fact, he has made the remark in the past that he has met employers unnamed who would like to remain under the existing system. Is it not a fact that under the Victorian industrial relations legislation, if an employer and his or her employees wish to remain under that system with a form of arbitration, they are entitled to do so? I would also like to ask, following up on the question by my colleague Senator Kemp, is it not a fact that relevant ILO conventions are concerned to promote the practice of voluntary collective bargaining and actually to prevent the imposition of compulsory systems?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind honourable senators that the question before us is that the Government amendment be agreed to. I think that it would be well worth while for the Committee to concentrate on the question before the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill and the Government's amendments, I observe that the Bill offers an opportunity for employees to apply to the Federal Industrial Relations Commission to be covered by a national award. If a union makes that application, we believe it would be unfair if union leaders could simply take an executive decision to take their case Federal.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have long believed that union membership should not be about paying fees and then obeying the directions of the hierarchy. We believe that union membership should be about belonging to an organisation and then taking part in the decision making. We believe that very effective participation in democratic processes is offered by the conduct of secret ballots and that secret ballots offer relief from any prospect of intimidation or coercion which might arise from other methods of member consultation and decision making.

That is why we have proposed an amendment which we believe achieves the provision of secret ballots in decision making with regard to this matter. The Democrat amendment provides for the conduct of secret ballots. It provides that the Industrial Relations Commission should determine the appropriateness of conducting such a ballot. Our amendment, which I shall move shortly, will replace the provision about consultation with employees that is in the Government's amendments. The replacement provisions proposed by our amendments will require the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to consider whether in the particular circumstances there should be a secret ballot.

We will be seeking to insert a new subsection, 111 (1B). This new subsection imposes an obligation on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission when it is considering whether to make an award. That obligation has two aspects. The AIRC must have regard to any consultation between a relevant union and the relevant employees on whether those employees want a Federal award.

The AIRC must also consider whether there should be a secret ballot before it decides to make the award. The obligation applies if the award is about matters that are exempted from the AIRC's discretion to decide that further proceedings are not in the public interest. The obligation does not apply to the making of an interim or provisional award. The references to employees who would be affected are not confined to union members only. Of course, that gem escapes Senator Parer's ear. The question he asked has just been answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has escaped Don Chipp's ear, too.

—I will repeat for Senators Kemp and Parer: the references to employees who would be affected are not confined to union members only. The Commission will be free also to take account of the views of employees ascertained in any other manner. I therefore move:

TAB.TAB: Proposed clause 3B, paragraph (b), subsection (1B), omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "`(1B) In considering whether to make an award (other than an interim or provisional award) under subsection (1) regulating terms and conditions of employment of a kind and application to which subsection (1A) applies, the Commission:

(a)must have regard to the outcome of any consultation between an organisation of employees that is a party to the dispute and employees who would be affected by the award on the question whether the employees wish their terms and conditions of employment to be regulated by an award under this Act; and

(b)must consider whether, in the circumstances, the views of the employees, or of the employees in sections or classes of the employees, who would be so affected should be ascertained by a secret ballot, and, if so, must refrain from deciding whether to make the award until:

TAB.TAB: (i)the employees in question have had a reasonable opportunity to vote on the question in a secret ballot; and
(ii)the Commission has been informed of the result.

PARA.TAB: `(1C) Subsection (1B) does not prevent the Commission from taking account of the views of the employees ascertained in any other way.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would cause the implementation of a long standing item of Australian Democrat policy—that is, our belief in the effectiveness, in democratic terms, of the method of secret ballots.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't sold it to Don Chipp.

—Perhaps because he did not listen. Before I conclude, I wish to address a couple of general remarks which were made in the course of what were virtually emasculated second reading contributions. I do not want to delve into the nether regions of the Hansard report of the proceedings of the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, but it was interesting to me that Mr Bryan Noakes appeared before the Committee. I respect Mr Noakes's background and his knowledge of industrial relations. As an advocate for his group, I doubt that he could be surpassed. In his contribution to the Committee's inquiry, he is reported at page 59 of Hansard as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Historically, the interaction between the Federal and State systems has been based on consensus and cooperation. It has been a clearly understood convention that the Federal Government will not unilaterally intrude into State areas, but that legislative changes which have implications for State systems will be of a considered and consensus nature.

Further on, when talking about the whole matter, he said that times have moved on. In Victoria's case, time certainly has moved on because that State has abrogated itself out of—I apologise for my use of English but it is the only way that I can describe the ugly move it has taken—its own legitimate jurisdiction. Into that vacuum the Federal Government has rightly and responsibly provided to those people who have had that privilege taken away rights which are held by all other Australians.

PARA.TAB: This nonsense about a mandate and about the industrial relations policy repeated just recently for our benefit by Senator Parer—all 15 words of it—did not include any mention of the emasculation of the Victorian IRC; it did not include any mention of the poll tax; it did not include any mention of the leave loading. No wonder the Victorian people recoiled in shock. They are in a state of shock all right, and I dare say they are welcoming this opportunity to return to the conditions enjoyed by the rest of Australia. Therefore, we support these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make some remarks about the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and pick up a couple of points that have been mentioned here tonight. When examining this legislation, the first thing we have to do is to look at what the real intent is. The real intent of this legislation is to centralise power in Canberra. One cannot interpret it as being anything else. It certainly disappoints me when I hear Senator Powell, Senator Bell and Senator Spindler being part of that process.

PARA.TAB: The federal system—the role of the States and the role of the Commonwealth—has been very important in the history of Australia. When we examine what is behind this legislation we should look particularly at proposed new clause 3A(ba). There is no question or doubt in my mind that this clause, which says `to facilitate access to conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and prompt settlement of industrial disputes', will end up in the High Court of Australia. I make the same prediction that I made when the legislation dealing with the super- or mega-unions of more than 10,000 members came into this place that, in time, such legislation will be overridden by the High Court.

I firmly believe that we should be cognisant of and take into account the likely outcome of the legislation we are putting in place. I would put it to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), to Senator Powell, to Senator Bell and to Senator Spindler, that deep down they probably also expect that that will be the result of this legislation. They are adopting a position for short-term expediency because they think they can get some political capital from the mandate which was given to the Kennett Government in Victoria. That is what this legislation is all about. In particular, that is what this amendment is all about. It is a direct attack on the Australian Constitution because it quite clearly leaves out the additional words of section 51(xxxv) of the Constitution—the words `extending beyond the limits of any one State'.

I believe that this legislation will change only for a short period the face of industrial relations in this country. It is going to override areas in which traditionally the States have operated. As we all know in this chamber, in the 90 years of industrial relations in this country, there has been a joint State-Federal system. There have also been some moves, albeit slowly in recent times, for some decentralisation or deregulation in terms of that industrial system.

This legislation will turn back the clock in terms of the little that has been achieved so far. It will not turn it back for very long for two principal reasons: firstly, as I have already mentioned, it will not stand up to the test of the highest court in this land; and secondly, it will not be very long before this Government is out of power.
I also want to deal with some of the things that have been mentioned here tonight, particularly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane, I pointed out before you started to make your contribution that the matter before the Chair is that the Australian Democrats' amendment to the Government's amendment be agreed to. That is the question which we should be addressing. So far you have not addressed that question at all. I suggest that in your remaining remarks you address yourself to the question before the Chair.
—Mr Chairman, am I permitted to ask you a question?
—If you require elucidation, yes.

—Mr Chairman, I have listened to the comments of each of the speakers in this chamber tonight, including those of the Minister, and they have ranged across a number of aspects of this Bill. Are you now saying to me that I have to be restricted in my remarks when the other speakers, in particular the Minister, have not been restricted in their comments?

—There is a procedure which we should be following in speaking to the matter which is before the Chair. I must admit that I have not been in the chair all the time this evening. Originally the question was whether the amendment moved by the Government should be agreed to. We have now moved to a different question. Senator Crane, I understand the comment you are making. I will allow you to continue because other Committee members have had the opportunity to range widely and I do not think you have spoken before. In that case, please continue, but I suggest to other members of the Committee that we should be following the correct procedure from now on.

—Mr Chairman, I think confusion has arisen because before you came to the chair the amendment moved by the Government was being debated. I suggest that we consider the Democrat amendment and dispose of it and then go back to the Government amendment. That will enable Senator Crane to speak to it.

—That is a sound procedure. Senator Crane, would it suit you if we disposed of the Democrat amendment? Then we would be able to debate the Government amendment, as amended, which would be before the Chair.
—Mr Chairman, as long as it is understood that I wish to go back to that point, I am happy to proceed on your direction and on Senator Parer's.

—I think what caused a bit of confusion was that there were some questions asked of the Minister and not responded to. We can come back to those later. The Opposition will not support the Democrat amendment.
—Don't you support secret ballots?
—It is only for cowards anyhow.
—Here is one of the union thugs talking about cowards.
—That's right.
—`That's right', he says. The coalition will not support this amendment because, among other things, it is unworkable.
—Because you hate workers.
—Senator Burns does not know what it is like to be a worker.
—Another lie.
—Senator Burns will withdraw that remark.
—I suggest that Senator Parer withdraw his remark which reflects on me.
—First of all, withdraw your remark.
—I withdraw, Mr Chairman.
—If you have a point of order, you can raise it.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The point of order concerns Senator Parer's reflection that I was not a worker.
—It is probably uncalled for at this time of night, but it is probably a debating point.
—Mr Chairman, I thank you very much for your protection from the standover tactics occurring on the other side.
—Now, come on. I think you should withdraw that.

—I withdraw, Mr Chairman. The coalition opposes this amendment for a number of reasons. The major one is that it is totally unworkable. We must admit, as is perfectly obvious, that Senator Cook is an expert in the field of industrial relations from the union point of view. He has had years and years of experience and he knows what he is on about. The Democrats have no idea—not only on this issue but on just about every other issue debated in this place. Senator Cook knows it is unworkable. That is the reason why it has been agreed to. I will give the Committee the reasons for that. The Democrat amendment talks about the outcome of any consultation between an organisation of employees, as does the Government amendment, by the way in which it is couched in somewhat similar terms. It has no definition in it whatsoever as to what is meant by `consultation'.
—Bosses' thuggery; that is all you know.

—Senator Burns likes interjecting, but he is an expert on industrial relations from the left wing union point of view as well. I would not dispute that, because I know the damage he did in Queensland in his heyday.
—Tell us all about it.

—Tell us about the way they used to hang your bike up on the crane. The second part of the Democrats' amendment attempts to soften the blow by saying that the Commission must consider whether in the circumstances the views of the employees, or of the employees in sections or classes of the employees, who would be so affected would be ascertained by a secret ballot.
—`Should' be ascertained, not `would'.

—The amendment says `who would'. It says, `who would be so affected should be ascertained'. That is logistically impossible. If by that the Government means—and I am not sure whether it does—that it wants to cover every employee in the field, whether or not that employee be a member of the union which is trying to get itself into the Federal system—
—Rubbish! It happens now. Non-unionists are covered by awards.

—We are talking about a secret ballot of every employee who might be affected, whether he be a member of a union or not. It means having a secret ballot of those people who the union does not even know exists and who, incidentally, do not want to know the damn union. There is no recognition whatsoever in that amendment of the employers being consulted by the employees or the unions. There is no obligation for the union to consult the employees nor for the views of the employer to be made available to the Commission. I will not prolong the debate, except to say that they are the reasons why we oppose this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the logistical difficulties on which Senator Parer seems hidebound and hung up are surmounted regularly in the secret ballots which already take place. One of those secret ballots, of course, is the Federal election; people who do not wish to take part in that seem to be able to escape it.
—Or a State election.

—Yes, Australian elections. These logistical difficulties are not insurmountable; they will not apply to every particular circumstance. These circumstances will be considered by the IRC and where difficulties arise they will be dealt with—as they are with all sorts of other opinion-seeking consultation processes.

PARA.TAB: I must remind Senator Parer that Mr Noakes, who represented the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry most adequately, reminded the Committee of the evidence and the findings of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems in 1985. Part of those findings which were quoted by Mr Noakes read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: There is merit in the argument that the move from State to federal jurisdiction may often not be in harmony with the wishes of the employees involved. A more rigorous test is justified.
That is precisely the reason for this amendment. The Australian Democrats wish to determine what would be in harmony with the wishes of the employees involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the Australian Democrats' amendment. It is a practical amendment. The amendment points the Commission to the need to observe a test. The test is: what is the view of the employees concerned in the area that is covered by the relevant State award? The Commission is enjoined by our motion to take that into account. The amendment requires that the Commissioner must take it into account and must be satisfied that there has been an exercise of an appropriate expression of view.

PARA.TAB: In some circumstances the Commission may regard that the parties reporting to the bench following documented meetings would be sufficient. In other cases, particularly where doubt by a respondent has been cast upon the case for the applicant, it may be that the Commission wishes to remove that doubt by ordering a ballot and doing so for part or whole of the people concerned. It seems to me that that is a reasonable thing. The practicalities or the difficulties would obviously be something that the parties might address themselves to in order to encourage the Commissioner to form a view about logistical possibilities or the practicality of what is being sought. The Commission, as a practical body, no doubt will make a wise decision in each particular case and a decision relevant to each particular and peculiar set of circumstances. So I have no difficulty in accepting the amendment.

In conclusion, I would add that if the Opposition votes against this amendment, it will be a surprising departure from all its rhetoric. That rhetoric has concentrated on propagating the pretence that industrial relations decisions are not always democratic. It may well be that in some cases they are not democratic, and where that occurs that is to be condemned. But it is not the case that universally they are not democratic, and in my experience in most cases they are.

The propaganda of the Opposition has always been that somehow this is a manipulation by union bosses and the Opposition has been strong in proclaiming the need for secret ballots to test that situation in any particular set of circumstances. Here is an option where it can be tested—and it seems to me that the remarks of the Opposition are to shrink from that possibility for fear that perhaps the decision may not flatter its own case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Parer, but there are a number of matters that I would like to have clarified in relation to the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell said that there was nothing in the 15-word policy, as he described it, of the Victorian Kennett coalition as it went to the election which mentioned that it would abolish the Industrial Relations Commission. Could I ask Senator Bell whether he has actually read the industrial relations policy that was put out by the Kennett coalition before the election? If he has read it, why did he inform the Senate—and I think I heard him correctly—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did.
—that the Kennett coalition prior to becoming the Government had not signalled that the Industrial Relations Commission would be abolished?

—Senator Kemp has put a direct question to me and I will give him a direct answer. We were provided by Senator Parer with a translation of the Victorian coalition's election promise. I did not write down exactly what Senator Parer said, but he said it quite strictly and with a lot of emphasis on each word. I think he said—I wrote it down shortly after—that the primary focus of the industrial relations policy will be on the contract between worker and employer, or words to that effect.

PARA.TAB: There was no mention in what Senator Parer gave us as a summary of the Victorian coalition's policy of that which shocked the electorate after the election. There was no mention there of the IRC, the poll tax or the leave loading. Senator Kemp is fiddling about with things other than that which Senator Parer gave us as a summary of the Victorian coalition's promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a voter who is resident in Victoria, I would like to supplement some of the comments that Senator Bell made. I would ask Senator Kemp, through you, Mr Chairman: when was the Victorian coalition's State industrial policy published in relation to the election; in which daily newspapers was it printed; how many copies were distributed to the four million-odd residents of Victoria; and can he point to any public debate on that point so that we can say whether the community, when it voted, was properly informed as to what was in store for it?

—I will ask the Committee to come back to the amendment before the Chair; and I want to ask Senator Kemp to disregard the question which was asked, which was quite out of order. The question before the Chair is that the Australian Democrats' amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Government amendment, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall endeavour not to repeat what I have already said. I was dealing with the Government's amendment which inserts the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to facilitate access to conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and prompt settlement of industrial disputes . . .

I had made the point that the Government, in moving that amendment, had conveniently left off a portion which relates to our Constitution. During the debate in this chamber on the establishment of mega-unions with a minimum membership of 10,000, the Government was told by me and other speakers that that legislation would be challenged in court and that in time, and at great cost, it would be found to be unlawful. That, of course, is what has happened.

PARA.TAB: I particularly want to make the point that the Government, Senator Powell and the Australian Democrats know full well that this legislation will end up in the High Court. In due course, I believe that the High Court will rule that the legislation contradicts what is in our Constitution. The Government, Senator Powell and the Democrats are going down this particular course in the knowledge that that would be the most likely outcome and that such a challenge would impose an enormous cost on a whole host of people in this country. Therefore, they should be more responsible in terms of bringing legislation before this chamber when they know what course it will take and the cost that will be borne by individuals as a result of the High Court challenges which are made.

I particularly make this point because we have consistently heard not only from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in this place but also from Senator Tate, in his capacity as the Minister for Justice, and others that there must be easy and cheap access to the law. This is cheap political point scoring, because the Government believes that it can get some political advantage out of this move, despite the fact that the Kennett Government was given a very clear mandate for addressing the many problems in Victoria in a whole range of areas, particularly industrial relations. In Victoria, the worst of the excesses which occur are mainly perpetuated by two people—Mr Halfpenny and Mr Wally Curran, who has been involved in the meat industry.

The Government is being totally negligent in its responsibility to pass legislation which will stand up in the highest court of the land. I will develop that point a little further. If this amendment to the Act were so good and so important to decentralising and deregulating the labour system in this country, the Government would have moved on it on its own merits and not on the basis of how high it should jump in response to what has occurred in Victoria.

There is no doubt that Western Australia is one of the strongest, if not the strongest, defender of the rights of the States in determining certain things which come under their jurisdiction. I have previously made the point that this legislation will have an impact across all States. The whole basis of this amendment and what is being attempted to be done will wind back the clock for industrial relations in this country. It is not a movement away from the centralised wage fixing system that we have had in this nation; it will centralise it even more. As such, it will be detrimental to the economic performance and well-being of this nation and to the very people whom it is supposed to protect.

A number of comments have been made here tonight. I do not intend to canvass them all because—even though I was pulled into order—most of them were outside the terms of what is before us. No doubt we will deal with some of those points later in the debate.

I was particularly interested in Senator Schacht's comments about human rights. I believe it is very important that industrial relations reflect the broadest possible definition of human rights. Approximately 30 per cent of members of the Australian work force, probably less today, are members of unions. I challenge the Government to put this legislation to a referendum of employers and employees across this country. If it did, I doubt whether the Government would get close to having that 30 per cent support. The greatest portion of people in the work force in this country have made a decision not to be a member of a union, to stay out of the industrial relations system and to negotiate totally free from the industrial regimes that we have in this nation.

The impact of this amendment in terms of the fundamental rights of the federation of the States will come back to haunt this Government. It will create an enormous cost that should not exist. This legislation is put forward on the basis that a failing government thinks it can get some political capital out of it. But I do not believe that that is the case. In fact, in a very short time, we will see this legislation going down the drain because it is in direct contradiction of and conflict with the Constitution of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the intrusion of the Australian Democrats' amendment, a series of questions were put to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). It might be appropriate that he now respond to some of those questions, because further questions will be asked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I would be ill-advised to respond if there are to be further questions. Perhaps I would be better advised to wait for all the questions and then respond to the lot. But since I have been invited and I am not churlish, I will respond.

PARA.TAB: A number of questions have been put. For the sake of convenience, I will start with those put by Senator Kemp. He opined that I had said that many employers support our legislation but that not one employer organisation would come out in support of it. That is right as far as it goes. However, I believe that a large number of employers support our move.

TALK.START.PARA: —You believe or you know?

—A number of them expressed their view directly to me. The other factor I cite is the Department of Industrial Relations-Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry joint survey of small business. That survey, which was jointly run by my Department and the peak employer body in Australia, found that 55 per cent of small businessmen preferred awards for the simple reason that they knew and understood them. They could reach for an award, find out the base rate and offer a prospective employee five or 10 bucks over the odds, shake hands on the deal and then get on with their business. They did not have to sit down and negotiate a complex agreement; it was all laid out for them. It was convenient, they understood it and they cherished and supported it. I cite that as an example.

PARA.TAB: I reject all of Senator Kemp's comments about this legislation being aimed at just one State. It is not; it is national legislation, and we have been over that point several times. I believe that there has been sufficient consultation. Senator Kemp said that no other country in the world has the arbitration system that we have in Australia. To my knowledge, that is true.

To my knowledge, no other country in the world plays Aussie Rules football. The fact that Australians choose Aussie Rules football as a form of recreation does not make them worse by world standards. If they are entitled to do that, they are entitled to choose a method of regulating industrial relations that is unique to Australia. The argument that no-one else does it is not a reason why we should choose a tradition and culture that we have developed as uniquely our own. In fact, there are many reasons to be proud of the system that we have evolved ourselves. It may not work in other countries, but it works here, and that is the important element.

The other point I make is that, despite what has been said, we are not attempting in this legislation to supplant a State jurisdiction. We are seeking to open and enlarge a right to the Federal jurisdiction should people choose to do so. We are not overriding a State. We are offering a right. It is for the people in that State to choose to exercise it.

A number of questions were asked by Senator Kemp about what conventions the Victorian Act transgresses. It is not a relevant question to the amendments before the Chair. It is not a relevant issue at all. The important thing about the amendments is that they are not based on any other head of power bar what I as a layman choose to call the arbitration power of the Constitution. While I believe the Victorian legislation happens to transgress a number of ILO conventions, it is not relevant to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones?
—That is not relevant to this debate.
—You can't specify them.

—I could specify them, but I would be diverted from the point if I was suckered into doing so. I prefer to stick to the point. The other question about who interprets ILO conventions is also beside the point. People, governments and parties do. If one or the other party believes they have been wrongly interpreted, they can take it off to the ILO for an interpretation. That does not mean to say we should not interpret them, but that issue is beside the point.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer has asked a question relating to choice. He is right in the way he phrased it. If a Victorian employer and union choose to opt for arbitration under the Victorian Act, they can have it. I have no objection to that part of it. What I object to is if one or the other party chooses to veto the choice of one or the other party there is no access to arbitration at all.

In my initial remarks here this evening I cited the case of where it may well be that an employer is vetoed by a union in gaining access to arbitration for the purpose of settling a dispute. If employers are vetoed, I think they should have the right to arbitration to settle a dispute, and that unions or workers should also have that right if they are vetoed by an employer. The right should be equal. Where they both agree, we have harmony; ergo, no problem. Where they do not agree and one is using veto powers against the other, we have a problem and one which ought to be solved in a civilised way. In this country that is access to arbitration.

Senator Parer made some other remarks about the ILO. While one could have a very interesting debate about the ILO, we may have that debate very soon when the Government introduces its legislation based on external affairs powers. That is a debate for that time; it is not a debate for now. Senator Crane made a couple of remarks that perhaps deserve correction. One was that the 10,000 minimum membership rule was challenged in court. It was not and has not been challenged anywhere, to the best of my knowledge. It was challenged in the ILO and that is not a court.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was challenged before the judges of the ILO.
—No, it was not. It was challenged in the committee of the ILO, the Committee of Experts—not the judicial body of the ILO.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. It is quite clear and my answers have been correct all the way through. Perhaps we can have an interesting discussion outside this chamber about how the ILO works so that Senator Crane knows it was not the judicial body of the ILO. The judicial body of the ILO made a decision on the right to strike. It did not make a decision on the question of minimum size. An interpretive body, a committee of the ILO, made that decision.

PARA.TAB: None of these questions are germane to the amendment that is before this chamber. That amendment seeks to amend section 111(1)(g) of the existing Federal Act so that where compulsory arbitration is abolished in a State the parties who wish to apply to the Federal Commission can apply with a minimum of tests—a critical one being the will of the workers concerned—to have their award moved to the Federal jurisdiction so that they can continue access to the Federal award.

With the greatest of respect to all of my colleagues at this very late hour of the night, I do not think that anyone has actually debated that question. The questions have been beside that point. If they wish to debate it, even at this late hour, we will accommodate

SPEECH.PARA: them, but it may well be more sensible to simply put the question to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Parer, I would remind the Committee that the question before the Chair is that the Government amendment, as amended, be agreed to, and I would ask that any questions or comments relate to that.

—The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has vast experience in industrial relations, certainly from the union side, so he is well aware of the practicalities as opposed to the theories that abound. I think he would probably agree with me in private moments that the legalism that exists within the industrial relations system is a pain in the neck to all parties. I ask the Minister: does the legislation not mean that any union in Victoria can manufacture a phoney paper dispute? In the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Minister when referring to disputation said that he did not mean strike action, he meant in disagreement form; so any union can manufacture a phoney paper dispute with an ambit claim, with which most employees are familiar, simply to force the change from a State award to a Federal award. In other words, it is an engineered situation. In this economic climate, why is the Government prepared to continue to play silly games, or to allow the unions to continue those silly games, when what is desperately needed is reform of this antiquated and inflexible system?

PARA.TAB: I refer the Minister to the book by Paul Kelly, The End of Certainty. He said that the only reason the Government did not deregulate the labour market and reduce that inflexibility—they are my words—was because of vested ties with the trade unions. Is it not about time that the Minister and the Government came out honestly and admitted that they are beholden to the trade union movement and that this is what this is all about? Or are they ashamed to admit it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not rise to the bait of the somewhat offensive end to that question. I thank Senator Parer for styling me as an expert in industrial relations from the union side. An expert has been defined as a drip under pressure. I hope Senator Parer does not mean that. My industrial relations experience has certainly been accumulated from the union side, but also from the Government side; from time to time I have been an employer and director of companies, so it is from that side as well.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of how a dispute is created, I could not agree, and I do not think any judicial body in Australia would agree, that the finding of a dispute in the manner practised by the Federal Commission could be called phoney. I do not think that is a fair comment at all. It is in conformity with the Constitution, wherever it has been challenged it has always been upheld, and it is a method of getting the matter before the Commission in order that it be resolved. What the community is interested in is that disputes are resolved and that they are resolved peacefully, without disruption, and in a way in which industrial life can continue uninterrupted and preferably in a more harmonious way. The mechanisms provided by the Federal Commission allow that, and one should acknowledge it. They cannot be called phoney.

As for reform, I do not really care what Paul Kelly says he thinks in The End of Certainty. What he thinks is interesting, but he is not an authority on this, and I think he would even be prepared to admit that. All of Senator Parer's other questions are just political points, they are not relevant to the issue before the Chair, and at this hour I do not want to engage in a political debate. We are, after all, in the committee stage of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions to put to the Minister. I would like him to clarify an issue which I think we are having in relation to various teachers' unions in Victoria. Where the Federal award provides lesser conditions than the current State awards, and the unions seek coverage in the Federal system as a result of these amendments, is it possible that the Federal award under which they seek coverage could result in lower pay and conditions for the particular union? Secondly, is it the Minister's view that the decisions of the AIRC should be adhered to? If he does believe that, could he enlighten the Senate as to why in April 1991 he and the Government rejected the national wage case decision and assisted the ACTU in campaigning against it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question invites me to speculate on what the Commission will do in a set of defined circumstances contained within the question. I cannot, on that information, read the mind of the Commission. In my experience, it is a folly to try to read the mind of the Commission even when one is in possession of all the arguments. Therefore, I do not think that there is an answer. There may be an answer that Senator Kemp may think is convenient to his case but I do not think, in fairness to the Commission, that one can say what the Commission will do prior to its hearing the arguments of the parties and satisfying itself that it has the full facts upon which it can base a decision. One cannot speculate on what the outcome will be. I just do not know the answer.

PARA.TAB: On the question of whether decisions of the Commission should be adhered to, I have been constant on that point. Yes, they should be, and the Government has adhered to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the third part of the question?
—We disagree with some decisions but we adhere to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister with regard to the new paragraph to be inserted, paragraph (ba):

SPEECH.PARA: to facilitate access to conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and prompt settlement of industrial disputes;

The Minister said earlier that he had acted under the heads of industrial power, or words to that effect. What legal advice has the Minister taken which would lead him to believe that this will stand up to a High Court challenge? I would also ask whether he is prepared to table that legal advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Routinely on matters concerning the law the Attorney will comment on Cabinet submissions. Before a Minister puts forward a Cabinet submission which involves a change in law that may have other implications, it is prudent to seek the Attorney's guidance about the meaning of the law within the understanding of the Government. I have done that and the Attorney has provided comment. As I reported to the Committee, that is within the ambit of Cabinet consideration and it is not appropriate that Cabinet considerations and material relating to those considerations be tabled.

PARA.TAB: I point out that Mr Rose, QC, the Chief General Counsel in the Attorney-General's Department, provided advice to the Committee dated yesterday during the hearing of the Committee. He expressed his view that the legislation we have proposed is constitutional. I refer to the letter that has been incorporated in the Hansard proceedings of that Committee for the full and accurate text of what Mr Rose has said.

Based on that advice and on our general understandings, we have no doubt that this legislation falls within what I as a lay person call the arbitration powers in the Constitution. We believe that it is constitutional and that anyone who proposes to challenge it would do so, frankly, on a vexatious basis for whatever political reason or motivation they might have. But that is a matter for them. I remark as well that, if it is challenged, I would wonder at the wisdom of that because I cannot understand why it would be that anyone would challenge—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you not speculating on a possible High Court challenge now?
—No, I am not. I would wonder—
—You would not speculate on my case.

—No. I wonder at the wisdom of it. It seems to me that such a challenge would be designed to prevent Australians choosing which industrial relations system they want. Why would someone wish to prevent that choice? Why would someone wish to deny that choice?
—That is what the Victorian election was about.

—We could have an interesting discussion here about whether an election in a State resolves all questions or whether citizens of that State have a right to their constitutional rights, and can exercise them in an appropriate way. I think that at this hour that is an idle debate. It is not directly related to the amendments.

PARA.TAB: My final comment is in relation to a question Senator Crane put to me earlier. Among all the speakers here this evening, Senator Crane has probably spoken most about the alleged infringement of States rights in this debate. Senator Crane and I both come from Western Australia, a State that vigorously proclaims its own rights. I would contend that this legislation does not infringe States rights. I think Senator Crane should be aware of his own Party's policy. That policy clearly states that, if the States do not agree to the system of industrial relations the Opposition is proposing, all heads of constitutional power will be used to shift the State jurisdiction to the Commonwealth, save the external affairs power. If Senator Crane is a loyal adherent to his Party's policy, he is in favour of taking industrial relations as practised by the States from the States, using every head of power in the Constitution save the external affairs one. He has been constant and loud tonight and, indeed, indignant about the invasion of States rights. If there is ever a chance for the Opposition's policy to be tested, I trust he will be consistent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) will be aware that at the very pinnacle of the system he has constructed stands the IRC. It is a very unhappy body at the moment. It is a body that has felt threatened by the actions of this Government over the past 1 1/2 years. President Maddern, in his recent annual report tabled in the Parliament, drew our attention to his continuing concerns with the attitudes of the Government.

PARA.TAB: I conclude these remarks by drawing the Minister's attention to a magnificent speech given in this Parliament some 61 years ago by Joseph Lyons when he walked out on the Labor Party. In that speech he covered many aspects of the Party's policies at that time, including the Arbitration Court. The Minister may be interested in what Lyons said:

The big issue before the people at the last election was the maintenance of the Arbitration Court and all that that tribunal stands for. Have we maintained that court? On the contrary, we have done everything possible to thwart it. Every means by which it could be prevented from functioning has been adopted, even up to within the last few days, and at the table on Wednesday night, the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr. Blakeley) said, "We shall do it again." If we had to say to the people, "We shall maintain the Arbitration Court, and stand by it so long as its decisions suit us but will upset it if they do not," the people would have swept us out of existence on that occasion as they did the other party.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw that to the Senate's attention because of what the Minister and his Party have done. They have undermined that particular body. Those are not my words; they are the words of people who have been very closely associated with the Commission.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to reflect on the words of Joseph Lyons. He walked out on the Labor Party because of a number of aspects, but because of that aspect in particular. I suspect that history may be repeating itself when the Government undermines the people's trust in an institution, while at the same time pretending to build it up. The Government is leading this nation into a potential crisis, and seems to be walking in blindfold.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come back to the question I asked the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). I endorse the comments of Senator Kemp. A lot of what he said was involved in what I said previously. In answer to my previous question, the Minister said that he had had a comment from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). He made reference to a letter that was tabled at the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I think, last Monday. Apart from that comment and that letter—and I respect the fact that he is not going to table what was said at Cabinet—has he taken any independent legal advice about whether or not this particular amendment would stand up to a challenge in the High Court and, if not, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legal advice we have taken is properly founded and compelling and we have no reason to take other advice.

—The two major areas of employment of those on State awards in Victoria are, allegedly, the clerical sector and the retail industry. Is it a fact that unionisation in those areas would not exceed 10 per cent? If so, is it not also a fact that to have employment agreements overridden by Federal awards, which can be sought by unions who represent a very small segment of those employees, would be clearly discriminatory?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot advise the Senate on the level of union membership in the retail and clerical sectors of Victorian industry. I just do not know. I would be surprised if it were as low as 10 per cent, but I am not in a position to confirm that figure. I do not understand the honourable senator's question about the situation being clearly discriminatory. The Industrial Relations Commission does not practice discrimination. The Commission enables both parties to put their case and judges against the criteria of justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case put. That is an exercise in fairness. So I do not see that the question of discrimination arises.
—Is it not a fact that the Industrial Relations Commission does not recognise individual workers, but only recognises registered unions or employer groups?

—It recognises the parties to the dispute. The shorthand is to recognise the registered unions acting for and on behalf of their members and the incorporated entity of the employer acting for and on behalf of itself, either as a respondent or as an applicant, as the case may be. That does not raise any questions of discrimination. The Commission would need, as a preliminary procedure, to satisfy itself that any application lodged before it by a union arose from a properly constituted meeting of the union and represented the views of that union—that union being defined, of course, as its members.

PARA.TAB: The big error in a lot of the logic the Opposition argues is that it sees the union as some sort of disembodied organisation, acting without reference to its own rank and file. I think we will find that the Commission is at pains to make sure that what is put in the way of claims is properly minuted and documented and reflects the views of the organisation. The fault the Opposition falls into is to shoot the messenger and ignore the message. If this legislation is adopted by the Senate and the House of Representatives and becomes law, it will be interesting to see how many people in Australia wish to vote with their feet to access this Commission. There will be no surer sign of their will than their taking those initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave the example of some 90 per cent of people in Victoria who work in those industries and who are not represented by a union being pushed along by the 10 per cent who are, and hence the remark about being discriminatory. The honourable senator, calling on his own experience in the trade union movement, will be well aware of the fact that, even though one talks about consultation and even about voting—not secret ballots but the ordinary voting—generally in the real world the union is able to prey on the apathy of people and a small minority calls the shots.
—How?

—Let us not go into it. To use Senator Cook's words, we can have that sort of debate on another day. I never cease to be amazed at people who come into this chamber and use language—recognising his background, I exclude from this Senator Cook, who must also be amused—that does not reflect the real world out there. The Government and the Minister wax eloquent about enterprise or workplace agreements, but is it not a fact that the workplace agreements to which they refer—and I have forgotten the figures quoted but increasing numbers of those, such as 600, have been mentioned—are acceptable only if they do not conflict with the union controlled award system?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that this is relevant to the matter before the Chair, but I have not been ruled out.
—It is with respect to compulsory arbitration.

—That is a political viewpoint; it is not a fact. There are many agreements that operate on the nod of a head or the shake of a hand. They are agreements that do not contract below the legal standards of an award and are often volunteered without any negotiation by an employer who wishes to pay above the award or to confer special conditions, either in an effort to attract a higher quality staff or to retain long-serving employees. That happens all the time. It is a feature of Australian life and it happens whether there is a union present or not.

PARA.TAB: In the debate about enterprise bargaining or individual work contracts, the tendency is to forget that the awards in the private sector prescribe a minimum rate, by and large; frequently and almost invariably, employers—maybe not so much in these more difficult times but in ordinary times—pay a little more in order to indicate their generosity and loyalty to their employees, which is quite legal. It happens all the time. It may contain an element of individual negotiation. So be it. No-one wants to regulate it. It is all lawful and has all the infinite flexibilities that anyone could want. The flexibility it does not have is to break the law, which is to say, not pay the minimum conditions and standards provided for in an award.

The other thing I should say is that if an employer in a particular case feels that the award standards are too high and too onerous and would run that particular company into financial difficulty, then all that employer needs to do is to apply to the Commission and the Commission can exempt that employer from an award or impose less onerous conditions. The fact that this avenue is rarely resorted to suggests that there is a lot of talk about inflexibility but not much real action on the subject when it is put to the test.

Furthermore, since the Commission would need to be satisfied that the allegations of the employer are true and would want to see the books of the employer to be sure that that is the case—very few employers are prepared to be open about their allegations and provide evidence of that character and to that level—the option is there and is exercised from time to time. It is one of the options that tends to be ignored in this debate but it is indicative of the flexibility of the system we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I again indicate that the amendment is before the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I do not want to get into that debate. I would enjoy it at some other time, if the Minister would like to talk about Metway, SPC, Power Brewing and all those other people as well. As a final comment, and I think this should bring forth some response from the Democrats, who have indicated that they are going to support this Bill, I refer the Democrats to the Sunday Telegraph of 13 December, where former Senator Don Chipp said:

PARA.TAB: Next Wednesday—

SPEECH.PARA: being today—
the Senate will vote on one of the most inequitable bills ever to come before it.

PARA.TAB: The bill will allow Victorian workers—

SPEECH.PARA: he means unions—
to escape from State legislation just passed by the Kennett Government to reduce labour costs—
meaning unit costs of production—
and improve productivity.

PARA.TAB: It will be an intrusion by a 10-year-old Federal Government—which has reduced the economy to chaos—into workplace reforms introduced by a nine-week-old Victorian Government democratically elected and desperate for relief from the inefficiency and profligacy imposed on the former Government by shameless, bullyboy union leaders.
It gave me some sadness to learn during the week that the bill will be supported by the Australian Democrats and therefore become law.
I can understand why the Labor Party has to protect the jobs and power of trade unions leaders, but I am at a loss to understand how or why they engage the support of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to describe the sort of industrial disputation that has occurred in Victoria—and Victoria has historically been by far the worst of all the States. He then says:
I cannot understand the Democrats supporting—
`illegitimates', I suppose I had better say, since the word he uses is unparliamentary—
like that. For my part, if bullyboys like some of those union leaders caught on fire, I would be reluctant to pour a nearby bucket of water over them.
Those are the remarks of former Senator Don Chipp, the founder of the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charming! Humane!

—Let me just respond to that interjection from Senator Chamarette, because there is a real world out there in Victoria, where the actions of certain people this Government now seeks to protect have brought a State that once was the jewel in the crown of Australia—from the point of view of manufacturing and financial centres—to the point where it is a basket case in this country. Efforts by the recently duly elected State Government to try to recover the debt, create jobs, make their industries more productive, and decrease the unit costs of production, are being thwarted by this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I had not meant to go into that sort of detail, but I was taunted by the interjection of Senator Chamarette, who apparently is prepared to say `tut tut!' to people such as John Halfpenny, and neglect the incredible damage done by people such as him to families, to single income families and to those families where there is no wage-earner. Such people have brought about the sort of tragedy we have seen. That fact cannot be avoided. The Democrats should respond to the comments by the person who founded them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with the amendment before us.

—At his provocative best, Senator Parer has managed to elicit a response from me. Of course, Senator Parer keeps talking about the real world and, in the real world, things change daily. We are not voting for the Bill, we are voting for the amended Bill. The amendment we proposed, which has changed the fundamental nature of the Bill as far as we are concerned, addresses the concerns Mr Chipp has expressed as an opinion. He is welcome to have his opinions.

PARA.TAB: I share one of the opinions expressed there that if we have any capacity to reduce the authority of so-called bully boys in this then we should take that opportunity. We should not be like the hypocritical coalition senators who sit there and say that they want to do something about it. When coalition senators have the opportunity to vote in support of the concept and practicality of secret ballots, they cringe on the other side saying, `We must not vote because somebody else thought of it', or, `We must not vote for something because we are afeard that it will not do the whole job'. Was I knocked over by the clamour of Opposition senators rushing to my door to try to help bring about the system of secret ballots which would work? No. We just see them comfortably sitting back, with their usual hypocritical manner, saying that it will not work. Unable to amend and perfect legislation, they are gleefully rubbing their hands at the prospect that it might not work. I think this will work. That is why we are voting for the amended Bill.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Cook's), as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
