SPEECH.PARA: Like the Government, faced with the changing face of industrial relations in this country and as a member of this Parliament, I asked myself whether there was anything I could do, particularly as a Victorian. Having a look at many aspects of industrial relations as they exist through legislation in this country, it did occur to me that one of the things that this Parliament should be doing is to shift the secondary boycotts provisions—sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act—out of that Act and into the ambit of the Industrial Relations Act. This is not, of course, an inspiration of mine; it is not something that I dreamed up myself. It is, in fact, something which many people over a considerable period of time have also believed should be done and indeed have attempted to do. While my amendments have been in circulation in this chamber for some five days, the particular measures that these amendments put in place have been around for eight years.

PARA.TAB: In 1984, the Hawke Government sought to do this very thing and failed to do so in this very chamber. The amendments that I am moving now are in exactly the same terms—apart from the fact that, because of subsequent or intervening changes to the Industrial Relations Act from the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the necessary changes have already been made—as those which were put before this Parliament eight years ago by the Hawke Government. I will not go through all the rationale that was put forward then, I will simply say, as the then Minister Button in this chamber said:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal objective of any regulation in this area—
of secondary boycotts—

must be the speedy, fair and effective resolution of the underlying dispute. This is not achieved by the legislative prohibition of secondary boycott activity. Indeed, provisions such as sections 45D and 45E may only serve to exacerbate a dispute and resort to them may result in a worsened industrial relations climate not only between the parties, but in the relevant industry as a whole.

That is just one of the points of rationale that the Government put forward through Senator Button in that case in 1984. But it is not just the Government in 1984 which has put forward objections to the way the secondary boycotts provisions are placed at the moment in Australian legislation. The view expressed in 1984 by the Government is widely shared. It will probably upset the Opposition, but I will quote ACTU policy, and it may upset Government members if these amendments are not passed. The policy says:
Sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act prohibit a wide range of legitimate industrial action by unions, members and officials. They should be repealed at the earliest possible opportunity.

The Trade Practices Act is a totally unacceptable vehicle through which to attempt to regulate the legitimate industrial activities of trade unions. The Act should be used only for promoting free competition and fair trading by business enterprises.

The Section 45D actions that have been taken against unions clearly demonstrate that the Trade Practices Act is not merely useless in settling industrial disputes but is positively harmful. The special characteristics of industrial disputes demand that they be dealt with under industrial legislation and not by recourse to the Trade Practices Act.

In 1991 in a direct request relating to convention No. 87 on freedom of association and protection of the right to organise, the ILO Committee of Experts also had a comment on Australia's secondary boycotts legislation. I will read from that request:

In its 1989 direct request the Committee noted that Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act 1974, rendered unlawful a wide range of boycott activity and most, if not all, sympathy action. The Committee considers that both of these forms of industrial action should be permissible in certain circumstances. For example, it should be possible to impose boycotts in relation to health and safety disputes on construction sites where there are several different employers.
The quote goes on to point out other areas where the Committee believes that such actions ought to be possible. It says:

These considerations led the Committee to ask the Government to provide information as to the practical application for Section 45D and its associated provisions, and to indicate whether it had any plans to amend the 1974 Act so as to bring it into conformity with the requirements of the Convention.

The Committee remains of the view that Section 45D and its associated provisions render unlawful certain forms of industrial action which ought to be permissible. Accordingly, it calls upon the Government again to take steps to bring this legislation into full conformity with the requirements of the Convention.
The Trade Practices Commission itself, in its fourth annual report, as far back as 1978, said:

The Commission would propose to limit court proceedings it might bring to cases affecting competition. . . because it is probably more appropriate that the right of private action or the Minister's right to bring proceedings should be exercised in cases not affecting competition. The Commission is a competition authority and it would seem desirable to avoid, where competition is not affected, getting involved in industrial disputes where the ultimate decisions as to the continuing or settling of cases may need to be taken by companies on commercial grounds or the government on political grounds.

When this Government was first requested by the ILO in 1989 to deal with the problem that it saw as posed by sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act, it responded by pointing out that its attempt to repeal the provisions in 1984 was defeated in the Senate, where the Government did not have control. It cited `strenuous opposition' by major employer groups and by the parliamentary Opposition. At this point, late in 1992, the Government faces an entirely different situation. Because of a change of policy by the Australian Democrats, the Government will now have no difficulty in gaining passage of repeal measures through this chamber. Obviously, it does not have any problem in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: Another change is the distinctly turbulent industrial relations scene at the moment with the advent of conservative State governments and the possible advent of a Federal coalition with intentions of bringing in a similar highly deregulated industrial relations policy. In this climate, surely nothing could be more vital than appropriate secondary boycotts provisions being in place. I say `appropriate secondary boycotts provisions'; I do not say `no secondary boycotts provisions'. My amendments are, in fact, relatively temperate as they are based on the eight-year-old amendments put forward by the Hawke Government.

I first put forward this initiative back in October. Recently—in fact, just last week—a very disturbing element has entered into the debate, and that is the Western Australian decision against the BLF. The ruling was given that the union had acted against section 45D in mounting a picket, in spite of that picket being entirely peaceful and the fact that union officials had given instructions not to stop anyone crossing the picket or to direct or request anyone not to cross. That is a very disturbing development and a very recent example of the difficulties this legislation poses. Surely, then, this situation effectively denies the right to peacefully picket and, indeed, quite possibly the right to demonstrate. Such a situation should not be tolerated in a country where freedom of assembly, freedom of expression and freedom of association are supposed to exist. When Senator Button concluded the debate on the 1984 amendments, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The place for dealing with the industrial disputes is not in the hands of the Trade Practices Commission.
I have already quoted from the Commission where it says that it agrees with that view. Indeed, it has agreed with it since the 1970s. Senator Button went on to say:

We have said that on numerous occasions and we will say it again in the course of dealing with this legislation. It is a matter which was in the Labor platform well before we came to government. It has been a consistent position.

PARA.TAB: That consistent position was not particularly evident earlier this year when the Government supported a Democrat move to investigate these issues yet again, for another seven months or so, to a time beyond the next election. I put these amendments forward as a contribution in the spirit of the legislation we have before us tonight and in the spirit of the amendments the Government has already moved to this legislation, to ensure that the Australian industrial relations law and provisions are appropriate and adequate, and give access to all parties in any disputes and are, therefore, available to all Australian people who may wish to express their views and exercise rights under industrial relations legislation.

As I said, there is a wide body of opinion that sections 45D and 45E put in place by the Fraser Government are inappropriate to deal with secondary boycotts. I believe my amendments are the most appropriate way that this form of action should be dealt with. They do not impede access to common law. In fact, they speed up the process of dealing with such problems with a 48-hour provision, with the Commission required very quickly to make a decision about whether or not it believes it can deal with any particular dispute and any particular boycott.

I commend these amendments to the Senate. The Australian Democrats have indicated previously that they will support these amendments. It really is up to the Government at this point to take this further step. It is not a new step; it is one this Government has attempted to take before to give maximum availability to people to exercise their rights and to have protections under industrial relations law in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few short comments in support of the amendments moved by Senator Powell to repeal the secondary boycott provisions known as sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974. As I said on 12 October, when these sections were being referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, participatory democracy is extremely important to the Greens, and we support ways of allowing people at a local community level to challenge decision making that has been taken out of their hands. Particularly in relation to environmental issues, sections 45D and 45E challenge the right of direct protest. The voluntary conservation movement needs all the help it can get if there is a coalition government after the next Federal election.

PARA.TAB: Community views on such issues as uranium mining, nuclear ship visits, nuclear technology experimentation, mining in national parks, forest destruction and hazardous waste disposal are often marginalised by government processes and vested interest lobbying. Protests against developments and discriminatory practices by companies come under threat also. On labour issues, sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive when compared with International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association and the right of free speech in the Australian Constitution. If anyone in this chamber needs an example of how restrictive these sections are, I refer them to a decision of a Federal Court judge, mentioned earlier by Senator Powell, on an action taken against the Australian Builders Labourers Federation, WA Branch, by the owners of J-Corp for forming a peaceful picket line outside the premises of a company. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In my opinion . . . the applicant has succeeded in establishing as against the BLF that by establishing and maintaining the picket line at the Riverdale site from 27 July 1992 it contravened s.45D of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

This came at the same time as accepting evidence that no union official stopped anyone from crossing the picket, neither had they directed or requested anyone not to cross. Their mere presence was held to be in contravention of section 45D. As K.N. Reynolds, branch secretary of the BLF, said in a letter to the Trades and Labour Council last week regarding this case:

The implications for the trade union movement and indeed for any community protest are staggering. The right to peacefully picket at all is so constrained by this judgment as to effectively deny that right. Any party, person or group engaged in the picket is by cause of this judgment open to an interpretation by their mere presence of having threatened the supply and delivery of goods.

Thus, I might add, being in contravention of these two sections of the Trade Practices Act. Community values have shifted to the right, as they tend to in times of recession, and the Labor Party has been dragged away from its roots by the pragmatic politics of government. At such a time, extending such interpretations of boycott brings us to a potentially oppressive situation.

PARA.TAB: I can think of no more graphic an example of how these sections could be used against the conservation movement than the protest outside the Eden woodchip mill on Sunday, at which I spoke. There, 150 peaceful protesters rallied to draw public attention to the continued destruction of Australia's native forest by the woodchip industry. Yet the manager of the Eden woodchip plant had told all log truck operators to stay home and not attempt to deliver logs to the mill until after the protest had finished. Under the judgment of the Federal Court, those 150 people are liable under sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

Another example is the longstanding and ongoing protest outside the old Swan Brewery in Perth, a protest which has the support of 78 per cent of the local community, who oppose that development. Even when it is clear that protesters are not attempting to stop workers entering the site, their mere presence is sufficient for them to come within the sanctioning powers of these sections. The court judgment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment and maintenance of the picket line involved an implied direction that it should not be crossed. Thus a boycott exists.

I do not expect that the coalition is willing to support the repeal of sections 45D and 45E. However, I would like to remind the Australian Democrats and the Labor Government that the repeal is part of their policy platforms. It is ironic that at a point approaching an election, where we still have the Labor Government—at least in name—it remains up to an independent senator to make the running on the repeal of sections 45D and 45E, with the support of a solitary Green, to be a voice for the Labor movement and its right to dissent, peaceful protest and freedom of assembly. I support Senator Powell's amendments and I urge the Democrats and the Government to do so also.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate, as has been indicated loud and clear several times before in several different forums, that the Democrats support these amendments. We have indicated loud and long with our written policy that we support this repeal.

—I am amused by the ignorance of the interjector, who seems incapable of being able to keep up with the fact that the Democrats' policy formulation process involves the full participation of the members, if necessary, day by day. It certainly does lead to the dynamic development of policy, and to scrabble around in ancient history and try to tag people with what happened 15 years ago is a mistake which Senator Kemp makes regularly in this place. It would be rather amusing to attempt to do the same thing with Fightback, I am sure—distinguishing which version we are talking about would deliver us with utmost hilarity daily. To remain consistent with the policy which has been well established and which we endorse, of course we support these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It was about a month ago, on 12 October, that the Senate agreed, on the motion of Senator Bell, to refer this matter for inquiry to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. That was an occasion on which the Senate divided, with all parties voting one way and the two Independent senators, Senator Powell and Senator Chamarette, voting another way. The matter has been referred to that Committee, terms of reference have been given to it, and the matter now arises in this manner outside the Committee and outside the process agreed by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I have to say on behalf of the Government that it is indeed a little surprising. It was the Democrats in 1984 who defeated the motion that is now being moved. It is a little surprising too that, having referred the matter to a committee for inquiry, the matter should be indicated in the way in which it is. The Government is in the position of saying that we do not support the continued operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act in industrial relations. That would be consistent with the finding of the ILO. This matter is in the process of the Parliament inquiring and reporting.

On the other finding of the ILO on the question of the minimum size of unions, although found by a committee and not by the judicial body of the ILO, I now foreshadow that I will seek the permission of the Senate to refer it tomorrow to the Employment, Education and Training Committee so that the Committee, on behalf of the Parliament, can inquire into both issues and report, and hopefully provide a logical basis for legislation. For those reasons, the Government will not be supporting this motion tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to debate at 1.30 in the morning the amendments moved by Senator Powell. Let me just say that, in view of the fact that this legislation was introduced by Mr Howard, I think, in 1978, the Opposition has consistently supported it. We have taken the view that it has been one of the great deterrents not to reasonable trade union people but to the more militant exponents of trade unionism in Australia. For that reason, we will not support the amendments.

—I want to make a few remarks about the amendments and endorse the comments the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) made just a short time ago. This matter has been the subject of debate within the Australian Labor Party for a considerable number of years. The Minister has indicated the efforts the Government has made in order to get a proper measure of legislation to govern the impacts of industrial disputes and secondary disputes. Those efforts were tried in 1984 and failed. The Minister went on to indicate that the matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training some two months ago. I am not exactly sure what that Committee has engaged in so far. It has had the reference for two months. I hope the Committee will expedite the inquiry and that when Labor is returned to the treasury bench following the next Federal election the Committee, after giving due consideration to the reference points in front of it, after listening to the evidence from employer groups, trade unions, workers, greens and independents, and the range of the community, will bring forward a recommendation. I hope the newly elected fifth term Labor Government will act immediately to implement moves to remove sections 45D and 45E from the industrial relations arena.

—The amendments proposed by Senator Powell are very much in accordance with what the party in government has tried to do for some years. I think it is a proper approach. Sections 45D and 45E in the Trade Practices Act fit very badly with the other legislation because that really is devoted to two things: competition amongst businesses and consumer protection. This really goes to another issue relating to the sorts of restraints that should be imposed upon people who want to impose secondary boycotts and, in certain circumstances, even primary boycotts.
—Well, vote for Janet's amendment then.

—I will take up the honourable senator's interjection because it is a very good interjection. He sees the logic of my argument so far is that we should vote for Senator Powell's amendment. That is probably right, and I think that Senator Sherry and Senator McKiernan would agree with that. On the other hand, as has been pointed out by the Minister, there are other issues that this Party has taken up, and in all the circumstances the Government—
—Including the forthcoming election in the next couple of months.

—Again, I take up that interjection because I think it is a very relevant interjection. Especially because of the forthcoming election, it is the judgment of the Government Party that at this stage this very proper amendment should not be supported. Given the fact that the elections are coming on and that there are other issues that must be looked at in a wider context, it is my intention to follow the Party's decision. For the overall good of the country, I will be going along with what my Party suggests is the appropriate thing to do.

—I have to say that one thing I would love to do in coming into the Senate would be to support the removal of sections 45D and 45E as they apply to industrial relations, because I do not believe that there is any place for the application of 45D and 45E, and common law, in industrial disputes. But, as the Minister for Industrial Relations has pointed out to this place, there was a resolution that referred this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which, incidentally, I am a member. Despite my beliefs on this issue, I will view the evidence given to the Employment, Education and Training Committee in a logical and consistent manner with my stated views on this matter, and I will certainly be recommending that we repeal the sections. Therefore, I will be supporting the Government.

PARA.TAB: I must say I am a little disappointed in the position of the Australian Democrats. I understand they are supporting this provision. That must be one of the most hypocritical flip-flops we have seen in this place for some time. It would be interesting to see what the Democrats would do if we were supporting this as well; I suspect they would have a sudden change of mind. It must be one of the more opportunistic positions the Democrats have taken for some time. I am supporting my Minister and I am supporting the Government in the vote on this issue. I think that that is what I am elected to do. I voice my views within the Party forums and then accept the democratically arrived at decision making process. I look forward to returning to this place after the election, with a re-elected Labor Government, which we are increasingly confident every day will occur. Should we be re-elected, of which I am confident, I will be doing my best, with the humble influence I have from the back bench, to make this a number one priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the support of the Australian Democrats for these amendments and, no doubt, they will vote with Senator Chamarette and myself when we call a division this time. I think they should be a bit shamefaced in doing so—Senator Sherry put it another way—because without the Minister's reference tonight to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) would have had a great deal more difficulty in ducking the issue and not adhering to his Party's policy. When he first got up to speak tonight, the Minister rose to a challenge from Senator Parer and made the comment that there is a great difference between deft quickness and undue haste. My grandmother used to say, `Act in haste and repent at leisure'.

PARA.TAB: The move on 12 October by the Democrats to establish a committee with a reporting date beyond the next Federal election was just such an act of haste. Senator Chamarette and I attempted to put an amendment which would have meant that if the Labor Party, which had had the policy for a long time, and the Democrats, who had had the policy for a shorter time, had needed more time, they could have taken until the end of November and we would have had a committee report now. But Senator Chamarette and I sat on our own that night, trying to tell the Democrats that they were making a wrong move. Now this Minister has been able to use the vehicle given to him by the Democrats to avoid the opportunity provided by these amendments to enact the policy of both of those parties.

There is no doubt that we will go into an election before that Committee reports—unless I am getting the good news from the Minister that we are not having an election until June or July, because that would suit me fine. However, I am sure that that is not the message. If there is a change of government, as I said when I spoke on that Committee reference, I can hear the bulldozers tearing into those forests now; I can see the sands being dug up; and I can see working people like those in Western Australia last week being up before the courts for peaceful protest.

That is what the failure to do this tonight might be bringing on the people of Australia, should they not have the wisdom—and it is an awful choice—to re-elect a less than effective Labor Government. As I say, this failure has been provided with some ease to the Government through the vehicle provided by the Democrats. No-one could regret that more than I do. It is a ducking of an issue; it is a ducking of party policy by both those parties in this chamber. These amendments will return to this chamber before we leave on Thursday by way of a private member's Bill, which will probably become a load on the back of both those parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to respond to something there. Senator Powell has interpreted what the Minister said as meaning that he would have a great deal of difficulty in refusing to support this without the existence of a reference to the Committee. I heard the Minister using that as one of the excuses but I also heard subsequent speeches from other members of the Party using other reasons for not supporting those amendments at this moment.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Labor Party, both in government and out of government, has had difficulty with these provisions. It has tried on several occasions to resolve the problem that sections 45D and 45E present, both to union members and to others who state the case for those provisions not being within the Trade Practices Act. It is true that in 1984 the Australian Democrats were one of the stumbling blocks to the Labor Party's attempts to be rid of those sections.

I catalogued the attempts that have been made in the speech I made in referring this matter to a committee. In noting the several and different failures, I thought it was important to achieve what was achievable. That is important in the context of what the Democrats have been accused of here tonight. We have been accused of creating a situation in which the acceptance of the amendments proposed by Senator Powell is not possible. Of course it is possible, and of course we have demonstrated that by supporting them ourselves.

In referring the matter to a committee, I anticipated that such an acceptance was not possible for the Government in the near future. Senator Cooney has referred to the election as being one of the pragmatic reasons that the Government used for justifying non-acceptance. In anticipating that, my aim was to get the matter widely discussed and to achieve what was achievable. I think we did that in a manner which was not anticipated by others in this chamber. We managed to get the reference to the Committee. Having done that, that does not stand in the way of our supporting our established policy. Therefore, disregarding the slights and slings, we still support Senator Powell's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last 10-minute section of the debate has been the most important section in the Committee this evening, at least since we discussed the early part of the Bill. The Australian Labor Party has flagged very clearly that, should it by some mischance win the next election, it will remove 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act.
—Would you like a bet in the chamber?

—We do not welcome the move, but we do welcome the honesty of the Labor Party in making that clear. As we go to the next election, it is important that people in small business and in the wider business community understand where the Labor Party stands on this issue. This debate has been very important in making clear just where the Labor Party stands. I shall certainly be making every effort to ensure that copies of the Hansard of this debate are sent to the relevant people. I think the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has clearly confirmed what the Labor Party policy is on sections 45D and 45E.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats, I think it is correct to say, until this evening had never come out and said that they would be in support of removing sections 45D and 45E. If the Democrats have said that, let me say that they have kept it exceedingly quiet. I look forward to refreshing my memory on a second reading of the speech Senator Bell made in referring sections 45D and 45E to a committee for examination. My recollection is that right from their foundation the Democrats have been one of the stronger supporters of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

This about-turn by the Democrats is important because again, as we go to the election, it is important to know where they stand. At least Senator Powell has been honest and frank with her views. I do not happen to agree with her views, but the honourable senator has put them in a frank and honest manner. Now we have to vote on it. The party that is in favour of removing 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act will be voting with us. The Australian Democrats, who until this moment have opposed the removal of 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act, will be voting with Senator Powell and Senator Chamarette. It is an important end to this debate, particularly as we are now going into the next election, that we know where we all stand on this issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp may well have made a very historic speech, though not historic from the point of view of his own self-interest. Senator Kemp has said that he will interpret the actions of the Government tonight as intending to do a certain thing in the next term of government, and he will campaign on that basis as if it has happened. If Senator Kemp does that, he removes from the Government any consideration about having to go through the due process of the Committee and look at the outcome of the inquiry. So in the end Senator Kemp may well be the person who pushes this to the conclusion that he does not want. I should indicate that if the Democrats do vote as they have foreshadowed tonight, I will raise the matter with the Cabinet tomorrow so that the Government can consider its position on this legislation. The Government will govern, and the Government will propose. We will not be pushed in terms of our agenda by anyone else.

—I think Senator Kemp needs reference to material that has been put on the public record by Senator Bell. During his speech referring the matter to the Committee, Senator Bell put on the record that the Democrats are very mindful of the position of small business, and that they see the abolition of sections 45D and 45E as going hand in hand with the establishment of either a labour court or increased powers for the Industrial Relations Commission to ensure that there is proper recourse to adjudication of such a matter and that it is handled according to law, as I have had occasion to say tonight, instead of the law of the jungle. Senator Kemp should stop misrepresenting the position of other people when he either knows, or should know, what the facts are.
—As a last ditch effort to a Minister who has quite clearly taken a very strong point that Senator Kemp has made, and before we vote—
—If we ever get there.

—Some things are important, Mr Chairman. I have stayed around here much later at night on matters much more frivolous and on debates without such substance. It is now quite clear that everybody is going into this election with their position on the secondary boycotts legislation very clear; Senator Kemp has made that clear. But there is some lack of clarity in one area that I would like particularly Senator Kemp and his cohorts to understand and acknowledge. When we talk in the shorthand of saying we should repeal sections 45D and 45E and take out the secondary boycotts provisions from the Trades Practices Act, we are not throwing the secondary boycotts provisions to the wind. They are to be inserted in a very reasonable, rational, responsible, efficient and effective way under the appropriate umbrella of the Industrial Relations Act. I think that is a thing that needs to be said, to be fair. That is the first point I want to make.

PARA.TAB: The second point may even encourage Senator Cook to save the time of members of Cabinet, because I doubt that they are going to disagree with the position they have taken for more than eight years—and, as Senator Button said, the position they took before they were even in government. The sort of noise and protest and campaigning—mostly, probably, a campaign of misinformation—against any such move as this, which the Labor Party has always been fearful of and which the Democrats have always been fearful of, is going to be just a drop in the bucket in the present industrial relations climate. Peter Boyle has got his work cut out telling us all that beggars cannot be choosers.

Because of the turbulent situation in industrial relations in this country at the moment it seems to me that there has never been a better time to take this small extra step. To my mind the Government is doing the right thing as evidenced by its own amendments. There has never been a better time to take this small extra step, particularly as we go to the next election, and speaking as a Victorian, I say that with some vehemence. I just wish to encourage the Minister, even in the little time he has left, as the Chairman very slowly puts the question, to take a decision which I am quite sure his Cabinet will endorse retrospectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure that the Chairman was trying to do it slowly.

That the Committee report progress and seek leave to sit again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have a motion that the Committee report progress. I have to put it without debate. The question is that the motion be agreed to.
—Mr Chairman, on a point of order, is it your ruling that that is a proper vote in circumstances where the last vote was defeated?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion in the name of Senator Button, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator McMullan moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion to recommit the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Teague

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: in the standing orders there is a requirement that if there is to be any vote put again in the Senate there needs to be seven days notice. Standing order 87 reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: An order, resolution or vote of the Senate may be rescinded, but not during the same session unless 7 days' notice is given and at least one-half of the whole number of Senators vote in favour of its rescission, except that to correct irregularities or mistakes one day's notice shall be sufficient.
I put it that it is not within the Standing Orders for a vote to be taken again—on a matter which has already been determined—unless there is the seven days notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on the point of order. This is not the first time that, through misadventure, a motion has been lost in the Senate.
—Misadventure!
—Order! The Minister has the call.

—Senator Hill was not so jolly when I was the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and we had a division in this chamber during which five Liberal Party members—and I can see a couple of them acknowledging this—were caught outside the door. When those five people came in, I had the motion recommitted because this chamber should reflect the proper view.
—What is the point of order?
—I am commenting on Senator Teague's point of order. I understand that those opposite like to shout me down.
—Order! I am going to take one point of order at a time.
—You are quite right.
—Thank you, Senator Crichton-Browne. We quite often agree.
—I was seeking to comment on Senator Teague's asking for a ruling on a point of order.
—What is your point of order? What is your point of order?
—Order! Senator Walters!

—I wanted to point to a precedent in which a variation of these circumstances occurred. The course of action I took then, as the Manager of Government Business, was to have a second division almost straight away to correct the unfortunate incident of five Liberal Party senators not making—

PARA.TAB: An Opposition senator—Because of your mismanagement.

TALK.START.PARA: —This time, yes, that is right—our mismanagement on this occasion. The previous occasion was because of the Opposition's mismanagement. It was resolved properly at the time, according to the wishes of the Senate.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. As I have said on this matter before, there would be no other group of people in Australia meeting at 23 minutes past 2 a.m. It is a demonstration of the insanity that occurs within this environment. I want that recorded in Hansard. We are entrusted with the governance of this country. Because of what has occurred tonight—

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The point of order before you is a question of whether standing order 87 can be overruled by way of a vote through the suspension of the Standing Orders. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator McMullan, has moved, on behalf of Senator Button, contingent on the Senate on any day concluding its consideration of any item of business and prior to the Senate proceeding to the consideration of another item of business, that so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent a Minister moving a motion to provide for the consideration of any matter. As somebody who is vaguely more than a casual observer in this matter, it is obviously my view that, a contingent notice of motion having been moved, once that motion is passed the Senate is then competent to move the appropriate motion, and it is simply a question of time and divisions before the question will be recommitted. It highlights the absolute nonsense of the Senate sitting at 2.30 in the morning on this day and the Government, in its bloody-minded determination—
—This is not a point of order.
—With respect, so far the Minister has been happy to hear what I have had to say. I wonder whether I might finish it.

—If there is a point of order against what I am saying, why does not Senator Gareth Evans interrupt me? The facts of the matter are that we are now sitting at 25 past two on a day determined by the Government as a result of its incompetence and that of its accomplices. It is a reflection on the Government, with its determination to make sure that we sit, that it cannot hold the numbers in the chamber. It is a very good reason, as Senator Robert Ray ought to know, for our not being here now. If the Government cannot hold its numbers, we ought not to be sitting. —Order! I have a motion before the Chair. You may speak to the motion, Senator Macdonald.

—In the same way as Senator Robert Ray spoke to this matter, I simply want to contribute by asking the Australian Democrats why they are supporting a government that is so incompetent in its management. I cannot ask them that because they are not here, but I address my remarks to Senator Powell and Senator Chamarette. I ask them why they are going to vote with the Government on this motion when the Government has shown its absolute incompetence in running this chamber. They know of the Government's incompetence in running the country. Why would they vote for it in this motion?

—We are not interested in history.

—History is important in this chamber because a lot of our behaviour is based on precedent. Is Senator Macdonald saying that, if at any time through some misadventure this did occur, a major amendment to a Bill would have been affected? We recommitted that motion without the Opposition having to go through the requirement of a contingent notice of motion or anything else. We offered to recommit it and then we lost that division.

Is Senator Macdonald saying that we were mugs two or three years ago to offer them that courtesy and that that will never be shown to this side? Ultimately what we want in this chamber, I think, is to reflect the views of the chamber and of the majority in the chamber, whichever way it goes. I think anyone would concede that the previous division did not do that. So I cannot see why we have to go through all the process at this time of night when a simple offer from the Opposition to recommit the motion could be made without any of this fuss, in the same way as it was made two or three years ago.

—I support the Government's motion. I also support the view that Senator Ray is putting. However, if the Opposition wants it to be done the hard way, I am quite prepared for that. I support the Government's motion for a reason of substance, not for a reason of political point-scoring of any kind. This is an important piece of legislation made all the more important by the amendments that have been passed. Indeed, I relish the possible opportunity of the recommittal of the amendments that were not passed. Nevertheless, this is, in its present form, or in the form it had reached in the Committee, a vitally important piece of legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several matters of concern to which I want to draw the Senate's attention, arising from the Loan Council inquiry that took place this evening. We received no satisfactory answer at all from Mr Cole, the Secretary of the Treasury, as to why, for 19 days between 17 June 1992 and 6 July 1992, he did not report to his Minister, the Treasurer, that he had found a $1.3 billion blow-out outside the global limits of the loan arrangements. As I said, there was no satisfactory answer given at all, despite persistent questioning.

PARA.TAB: There was another more alarming concern. Senator Coulter in the chair ruled in a very narrow way that the question of Mr Dawkins' failure to put into the Budget Paper No. 4 the fact that that blow-out of $1.3 billion, of which he, Mr Cole and the officers of the Treasury were all aware, was not within the terms of reference. It was a very technical and narrow decision, and I think it is one that has to be looked at thoroughly because, quite frankly, the Australian people want some answers.

There was a further move by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, to intimidate members of the Committee into the sorts of questions they would be allowed to ask at the inquiry. I wrote to Mr Dawkins in the following terms on 15 December 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: My Dear Treasurer,

I am in receipt of a copy of a letter dated 26 November 1992 from you to the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, Senator Coulter.
I take personal exception to your veiled attack on me contained in each of these letters.
This is the second letter the Committee has received from you of such nature.

The reply from our Chairman to your first letter set out the manner in which the Committee will conduct its proceedings. It was stated that the Committee will be bound by its terms of reference and Senate Standing Orders. Relevant resolutions of the Senate will apply.
Indeed, I find the tone of your letters generally unacceptable, particularly as you seem neither to have the sense of duty nor apparently the courage to appear before the Committee and give evidence.
Your attempt to fetter both the ability of public servants who will attend to give answers and intimidate committee members, including me, I regard as invidious.
Simple, straightforward answers to simple straightforward questions are what the Australian people require.
This is not facilitated when you hide behind the Prime Minister's skirts and plead executive privilege.
Be a man and attend.
Yours faithfully.

I have signed the letter and I have attached a copy of one of the letters that he wrote to the Committee which has indeed been published by that Committee. Most disappointing was the lack of information that officers were prepared to give today. When the Treasurer has a duty to be informed and the right to be informed, I think we have to take a very dim view of a Secretary who refuses to inform his Minister of a serious breach for 19 days with no good reason.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 November 1992:

(2) What avionics suite will be provided with these aircraft and, in particular, what model of bomb guidance system will be provided.
(3) What modifications will be necessary to the wings to ensure the newly acquired aircraft will be compatible with those already in service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: As I foreshadowed to the Senate on 15 October 1992, a Defence team has just visited the US to identify the costs and availability of ex-USAF aircraft and to assess the options for acquiring, storing and operating these aircraft in the RAAF. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, upon notice, on 12 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: Do Customs officers seize the boarding passes of passengers who have travelled on domestic flights of QANTAS in Australia; if so, why.
Can the Customs Service develop a procedure which does not require passengers to surrender their boarding passes, which are their property not the property of the Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: It is standard practice for Customs officers to retain the boarding passes of domestic passengers travelling on QANTAS.

This is for several reasons. Most importantly, by retaining domestic passes Customs is able to maintain its controls and prevent the passes from being reused or fraudulently altered. Allowing a passenger to retain a used boarding pass gives the passenger, or other members of the travelling public, the opportunity to reuse it later on an international flight in order to evade Customs attention. The pressures at the Customs barrier, where the passes are collected, are such that it is possible an officer would not notice that the date or flight on a boarding pass did not match the situation.

Breaches, both unintentional and deliberate, have been detected where arriving international passengers have evaded or attempted to evade normal control procedures by using domestic boarding passes. The implementation of the recent reforms has increased this risk represented to Customs by domestic passengers. The increase in the number of domestic travellers could result in an increase in the misuse of boarding passes.

Further, Customs uses the collection of domestic passes as a means of gathering statistics on the number of domestic passengers processed. Domestic passes are also used to record times and details of passengers subjected to further examination.

However, where passengers have requested their boarding passes for airline incentive schemes or souvenirs, they have been returned to the passenger with the "D" sticker removed, so that they are no longer domestic passes.
There is one option available which would allow domestic passengers to retain their boarding passes.

Customs could tear the "D" sticker from the boarding pass so that it was no longer identifiable as domestic. The passenger could then proceed with the remainder of the pass. The disadvantage of this system is the added time required to perform the task, which could impact on facilitation rates and the effectiveness of Customs controls.

It is not practical for Customs to develop alternate identity and security procedures, as a new "D" sticker has only recently been designed by the airlines in conjunction with Customs and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It is currently being introduced. The sticker will be attached to the front of the domestic boarding pass, and it will be an important identification and security document.

The main reason passengers request to retain the boarding pass is as a souvenir or to participate in airline incentive schemes. It would be unacceptable for the security of the Customs barrier to be jeopardised in order to facilitate airline incentive schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 17 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the provisions of part 9 of the Broadcasting Services Act covering codes of practice, specifically the requirement of 123.(2)(i) that programs be captioned for the hearing impaired:
(1) Will providers of satellite subscription broadcasting services be obliged to honour these codes.
(2) Will it be a requirement that any technology used for the transmission and reception of Pay Television be capable of carrying and decoding closed captions.
(3) How does the Government intend to ensure that deaf and hearing impaired Australians are given equal access to all visual broadcast media.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 includes a statement of the intention of Parliament that radio and television industry groups, including providers of subscription broadcasting services, develop, in consultation with the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) and taking account of any relevant research conducted by the ABA, codes of practice that are to be applicable to the broadcasting operations of each of those sections of the industry, including the captioning of programs for the hearing impaired.
If:

(i) the ABA is satisfied that a code of practice is not operating to provide adequate community safeguards for a particular section of the broadcasting industry and the ABA is satisfied that it should determine a standard in relation to the matter; or

(ii) no code of practice has been registered for a matter such as captioning/programming for the hearing impaired and the ABA is satisfied that it should determine a standard in relation to the matter;
the ABA may determine a program standard on the matter. Each subscription television broadcasting licence is subject inter alia to the condition that the licensee will comply with program standards.

(2) The Government has mandated that subscription television broadcasting services provided with a subscription television satellite (satellite subscription television services) shall be provided using a full digital transmission system. At the moment, digital transmission systems are still in the process of development and there is not yet an international standard for digital transmission systems.

If, after licences A and B are allocated, the two licensees agree on a standard the Minister, after consultation with Optus, is to declare that standard as the one to be used by all satellite subscription television broadcasting licensees. If the two licensees do not agree on a standard, the Minister must declare one, after consultation with licensees A and B and Optus, having regard to any relevant international standard.
The requirement to develop a code of practice on captioning should serve to focus the two licensees' attention on the means of providing the captioning service when they devise a standard.

(3) A significant start has already been made under current voluntary arrangements between the three commercial networks and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation with the Australian Caption Centre, which provide subtitling of approximately 7.5% of all television programs. The SBS provides open caption subtitles for programs in foreign languages which make them accessible to the hearing-impaired.
The Government has sought to facilitate captioning of programs for the deaf and hearing-impaired by providing funding to assist the operation of the Australian Caption Centre, and to assist specific

ANSWER.PARA: projects such as the captioning of the ABC's Late Edition News. The funding is provided as part of the Government's Disability Services Program administered by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, closed caption decoding devices are exempt from sales tax where they are for use by persons assessed to be profoundly deaf.
